review_text:
I am on my second reading of Trevor Noah's Born a Crime short memoir for two reasons: first, it's a very quick, enjoyable read with moments of humor, terror and disgust in it; second, because I want to understand how a person can come across so genuine but have moments that make you doubt their soul at a fundamental level. 
 Born a Crime is Noah's story of birth and survival under South African apartheid rule, the chaos after that rule fell and how his light skin (but not too light), dark skin (but not too dark), luck and nerve served and failed him. Each chapter, you read about how he engages in misfortune and adventure only to see one of his friends or family members be claimed by the oppressive governmental forces or the specter those forces cast, and just when you think it's going to be Noah himself, the finger of fate touches someone close to him. 
 The entire book is a loving tribute to his mother, who if even half the things were true, sounds like a model for all mothers and an outspoken work for reforming how we approach domestic abuse. He gives an unflinching eye on how far can you support someone who's willing to live in a bad relationship. 
 There's also enough visceral details on what poor and starving people use for food to last a reader a very long while. 
 What's definitely noticeable are the tales left behind in the margins: what happened to Teddy who went to jail for eating chocolates, how Trevor helped raise his two brothers after a harrowing event, and the challenges of becoming a comedian in South Africa and eventually the big question: how did he get out of South Africa? which is a recurring theme but unsatisfactorily never answered. The sad effect of these omissions is that it makes the book seem narcissistic at times which he readily cops to in the book, so that may be the truth. 
 Overall, while I feel enriched for his story and I'm happy he's made it out of that place, I like him a little less as a person.

This is a phenomenal memoir by Trevor Noah the late night comedian who took over for Jon Stewart. I had no idea that Noah was South African and that he grew up under the evils of apartheid. It was illegal for blacks and whites to have sex or relations and since he was a product of such a union, he was "Born a Crime. The work explores race, poverty, abuse, alcoholism, getting by with little, fierce maternal love, and the art of the hustle. I listened to the audiobook narrated by himself, which was a special treat. Loved It!!

Best book I've read so far this year and probably one of the best memoirs I've read.Period. In his own way, Noah gets you to understand the post-apartheid era in South Africa. A country, that like a modern day Picasso is full of complex emotions and social paradoxes and one that only a master story-teller can hope to describe. Noah does that brilliantly, keeping you swinging from laughter to tears and back, one sentence at a time. Can't recommend it highly enough.
I have enjoyed the Daily Show since Trevor Noah has taken the helm. This book gives you a background on Trevor and South Africa I have never read before. I really enjoyed it.
Wow. The audiobook is incredible. So fascinating and powerful. I wish I could have all my students read or listen to this book.

Absolutely outstanding. Captures the nuances of South African culture while always making you laugh. I loved doing the audio book on this one for all the Xhosa he speaks and nailing the tough pronunciations. Recommending to everyone.
Trevor Noah is basically the best person ever. So touching and motivating; and always funny.

This was a fascinating read. Trevor Noah maintained his level of humor while remaining honest and reflective of his childhood in South Africa. It is such a unique story and I am grateful he takes the time to tell it. My only critique is I was expecting a part of the book to discuss his career and how he grew into comedy and came to America. But on further reflection, I realize that is not what the purpose of the book was; the purpose was to tell stories of his childhood as a colored child in South Africa. And it was excellent.

This is *hands down* the best audio book I've ever listened to. Trevor Noah narrates the book himself, and it is as if you are hanging out with him in your living room, just listening to him telling stories. It doesn't seem as if he is reading a book AT ALL. His life, his stories, are so amazing. HIGHLY recommend!
Trevor Noah shares his experiences growing up in South Africa amidst the end of apartheid. He is an insightful storyteller and gives powerful examples of growing up in a racist world.
It's a story of hope ...

I enjoy Trevor Noah on TV and was interested to read his memoir--- because I don't know a lot about South Africa. I didn't expect much. 
 This is the story of his childhood/adolescence and growing up with his single mother-- a story of surviving life in South Africa and being treated as a second class citizen. We learn about his family and what he did in high school. This book does not go past the first couple of years out of high school--- nor does it touch on him becoming a comedian, but it is really well written and gives a good idea about life in South Africa for a "colored" child. 
 I hope he continues to write--- I would love how he went from a DJ in SA to a late night tv host in NYC.... 
 Read if you enjoy autobiographies or want to learn more about South Africa.

Seemed like a natural follow-up to The Daily Show's oral history -- but Noah doesn't really address his stand-up career or his takeover from Jon Stewart; instead, he focuses on growing up in apartheid-era South Africa and how it shaped him as a person. Noah's mom sounds like an absolute badass lady, and after reading this book I can see why he mentions her so often. I've read plenty of history but this is the first memoir I can remember reading that explicitly addresses some of the complications of growing up under apartheid -- it's worth reading for the history lesson alone, but Noah's heart and unique perspective on life really come through in his writing. It reminded me why I had been so excited for him to take over The Daily Show in the first place.

Trevor Noah is an interesting person. His memoir is unusually structured. He tells and re-tells his story from slightly different points-of-view about four or five times over. I couldn't help but to think that he might have just put down his comedy routines on paper and really didn't edit it into a whole. He is very entertaining and seems very smart.
The audio version is great. Love hearing the accents.

I am not big on non-fiction. I am not big on audio books either. So for me to give this book five stars is pretty surprising. 
 As I said, I listened to this on audio book, which I recommend. Noah is narrating it and I always like when that's the case with autobiographies. He does a great job, and hearing him imitate accents and talking in different langagues gives life to the whole thing. 
 I think this autobiography was really skillfully crafted. The way he jumped back and forth in time, making associations, telling little side-anecdotes, but always driving the chapter home in the ens was impressive. I also really enjoyed the topic: I know very little about South Africa and Apartheid, so I was eager to learn. And so I did, thanks to the way this was told. 
 Noah found a great balance between political, personal, funny and emotional and I am glad that I took the chance on him.
Really 4.5. I probably wouldn't have found my way to this book myself but I got it as a gift and couldn't put it down once I started reading. Thanks, Kerri!

Good narrative of a funny man's life - which doesn't come out when you see Trevor on the screen cracking all the jokes. It's a motivating story of a man who overcame all the hardships and tribulations living in a third world country torn apart by apartheid, and eventually becoming such and international success. All I felt after reading the book was well done Trevor, you deserve all the success!

This was so much more than a comedian memoir. A story of understanding South African apartheid, coming of age, making trouble, loving his mother, and suffering domestic violence. I listened to the audiobook narrated by Trevor, and I couldn't believe how he kept his composure. But it was a lovely reading, and hearing the Tonga and Zulu spoken was wonderful. The ending was shocking, heartful, and satisfying -- very intelligently arranged as mostly chronological, but slightly out of order for maximum plot development.
I laughed so much while reading this but there are many moments that made me realize just how much we have in common with South Africa.

Holy shit. If there is one book that you need to read this year, let it be this one. 
 Been trying to prolong the lifespan of this book by limiting myself to only a few pages a day. That's how good it was. 
 Though far from being lyrical or poetic, this was beautifully written in a raw and honest way. Hilarious and illuminating throughout. The last chapter where he talks about how his mother survived a shot to the face gave me chills. 
 This book cannot receive too much hype and I now have mad respect for Trevor Noah.

Very enjoyable and insightful read. Noah gives an entertaining account of growing up in South Africa as a mixed child in different communities: black, white, colored. At heart is his relationship with his mother, who seems like a wonderful woman and a great influence on his life.

Full 5 stars. This was just fantastic for me! It feels trite to say "I laughed, I cried," and it wouldn't be entirely accurate; I not only laughed, I fucking howled. I not only cried, I sobbed like a little baby. I am not used to this level of emotion on my commute.

Funny and sad. Amusing and frightening. 
 Growing up in South Africa during Apartheid, Trevor Noah gives a first-hand experience of the struggles of everyday life. Some stories are funny, others will make you cry.
Repetitive at times but otherwise a great read!
Highly recommended. Get the audio version - it makes all the difference.

I have to admit, I wasn't expecting too much when I saw that Audible was giving away this book for free. I honestly have not seen The Daily Show since Trevor Noah took over, and I'm pretty unfamiliar with him. That being said, it only took the first chapter of Born a Crime for me to be hooked. 
 Trevor Noah is an incredibly gifted storyteller, and his recollections of his childhood are vivid and amusing. I thoroughly enjoyed listening to this book, and would highly recommend it.

Seriously wonderful. I can't remember the last time I read/listened to a book that made me cry both tears of laughter and sadness. Trevor's gift for storytelling, cheerful humor, and frank observations about race and life during apartheid make for a truly remarkable book. Don't pass this up as just another comedian's witty memoir; the depth here is stunning.
Amazing autobiography. I listened to the audiobook and Trevor Noah is a truly incredible storyteller.

This book was truly terrific! Part of me wished I had listened to the audiobook which I believe Trevor Noah narrates, but the book was a super-quick, engaging read that brings to life a post-apartheid world. Growing up during the time of apartheid, I had some vague awareness what it was but Noah does a masterful job describing just how oppressive the regime was while still introducing humor, perspective and admiration for what he and his family endured. His mother was a major influence in his life and you cannot help but to respect and empathize with this incredibly strong and resilient woman whose love for her children was undeniable. I internalized much about relationships, race, language and poverty and look forward to watching more Daily Show after this which will be all the more poignant because of the additional context I have now about Trevor Noah's life.

Outstanding memoir! Its organization was a little all over the place for me at times (it wasn't chronological, and in that respect, it could at times be hard to follow), but this is a small complaint when compared with the feat that Trevor Noah has accomplished!

I very much enjoyed this book - I listened to the (self-narrated) audiobook which was very enjoyable, sometimes disturbing, often amusing. I would recommend this book to anyone who wants to understand more about life in apartheid and post-apartheid South Africa. 
 I only rated it three stars because I'm not comfortable with some of the timeline and authenticity of this book. I was astonished to learn, after reading, that Trevor Noah's mother converted to Judaism when he was a child. He had a Bar Mitzvah that was ill-attended. Was he unable to reconcile this part of his mother's life with the rest of his story? I want to know whether she was, indeed, still calling on the name of Jesus by the time he was 19 (at the end of the book). 
 South African reviewers question whether he was really hidden away until the age of six; when anti-mixing laws were overturned when he was two years old. I can accept his version of these facts, because this was the impression he had when he was a child. I still recommend this book, with the understanding that his reality may not have been the average reality of a mixed-race child in South Africa during that time period.

I really enjoyed reading about Trevor's life. His insight in the life of South Africa are very eye opening and his explanations make you want to learn more. It just makes sense. He has had an amazing life. No wonder his perspective on life is so sharp. I would definitely recommend this book!

Audible. Read by the author. 
 Full disclosure: I really like was Noah's been doing with The Daily Show. This memoir offers a means of illuminating his occasional detached perspective on American politics (that I assume bothers some viewers. I like it. I don't necessarily need older men yelling at me through a screen to understand what's ludicrous about a situation.)

The audiobook, narrated by Trevor Noah himself, felt like sitting next to a friend with a drink in hand, enraptured, unable to peel yourself away, listening to him talk into the early hours of the morning.

Inspirational, smart, wonderfully honest and thought-provoking... 
 It's also funny but that's the least of its qualities.... 
 How this young man built his worldview through transformative live lessons from a complicated childhood...
Excellent. Loved it. Fascinating story of his early life and his relationship with his mother. Would recommend.

You see Trevor Noah and you see a man who's funny, successful, suave and brilliant. Until you read this memoir, you don't know much about the life he's lived--one filled with issues and conflicts of class, race, politics, language, power and gender. This is a must read book, not just because it's funny but because it'll teach you about empathy, tolerance, and negotiating his particular life, schools, childhood and youth in South Africa.

Enjoyed this a lot. Listened to this - the only way to do it, with Trevor Noah reading in the multiple languages he speaks. He captures the voices of his family and friends in such interesting ways. It's quite a story. The timeline jumps around a lot which was a bit confusing and his sometimes flippant tone was in stark contrast to the content which was funny at times and unnerving at others.

"But the real world doesn't go away. Racism exists. People are getting hurt. And just because it's not happening to you, doesn't mean it's not happening. And at some point you have to choose; black or white, pick a side. You can try to hide from it. You can say, oh I don't take sides, but at some point, life will force you to pick a side." 
 -- Trevor Noah, Born a Crime 
 Just finished listening to Trevor Noah's book "born a crime" which is narrated by Trevor Noah and well, it is a damn good book. Trevor has a masterful way of using humor to make strong and powerful statements about the way he and others view race and identity. Through his humor and careful selection of poignant moments in his life, Trevor is able to give us insight into the world of a boy trying to find his way in a world where he was born a crime. This is the first audiobook I have listened completely and while I find his stories relatable and clever; the intimacy of hearing these words spoken from his own voice was what made this experience more powerful.This book made me laugh, made me think and also made me cry. Everyone should give it a chance.

Terrific! So glad I listened to this. Who better to tell the funny and heartbreaking stories of Trevor Noah's life than Trevor Noah? So much to laugh about in this and so much raw truth about racism and violence. Interesting to read about life in South Africa, not a subject that I know much about. 
 I especially loved the insights about language in this book (go figure) and I have been talking to everyone about this...a true sign of a great book.
Funny, shocking, and heartbreaking stories from a uniquely biracial South African perspective. Interesting and entertaining read.
It is a great book.

Warning: there's some very troubling domestic violence in this memoir. 
 Trevor Noah has taken his unique experience of growing up a mixed-race kid in South Africa during and after Apartheid and relayed it with the surprising mix of good humor and cynical insight that seems to be his style. So interesting, so touching. Definitely worth reading.
So entertaining yet so insightful and thought provoking. I look forward to hopefully more from him!
Really this provides a perspective so rare in American culture. It's intelligent and beautifully insightful on poverty, oppression, and racism.

This was awesometastic 
 If you want to laugh, read this book 
 If you want to cry, read this book 
 If you want to know more about life in South Africa, read this book 
 If you want to read about a real-life heroine, read this book!!!

I had the wrong expectations going in, expecting more humour from the well-known comedian. The value of the book surpasses that though, by far. It is an earnest revelation of the day-to-day realities of Trevor Noah's childhood, which is clearly something that will be familiar to many South African readers. It was helpful for me as a pale male to get that insight of a life I didn't live. 
 There is great great sadness in this book, and the praised love of the author's mother is a shining light in the midst of it. 
 It's worth the read.
I thoroughly enjoyed this memoir having little knowledge of Trevor Noah. He is a fantastic storyteller.

Gives so much dimension to Noah's view on life. He comes at what we would describe as a challenging, sometimes scary childhood with humour and a direct stare. He is both guileless and cynical; entrepreneurial and incredibly awkward. 
 He should write more.

I listened to this one, and it was wonderfully read by the author. This is an honest look at Trevor Noah's youth in post apartheid South Africa, and a love letter to his mother. At times he had me laughing, at times crying, at times so angry I cried. I highly recommend this.

I truly enjoyed this entire read. It was a funny and touching series of stories that had me laughing and smiling and even tearing up. I really enjoy seeing Trevor Noah on the Daily Show as host and this book just cements that respect I have for him.

This is one of the best books I've read in years. I did the audio and Noah reads it himself and is spectacular doing his mother's voice. 
 This is not a book about humor and fame and glitz. This is an honest, gritty story about how Noah grew up in apartheid South Africa and the aftermath. There are humorous anecdotes, but the story in its honesty settles down with a emotional tale of growing up in violence and poverty. 
 By the end of the book, Noah hasn't even touched on his life as a comedian and I look forward to his next book explaining how he developed that part of his life.

I listened to this in its audiobook version and it was nice to hear the stories through Noah's eyes. 
 It's a super-detailed, almost unbelievable beginning, relaying his childhood. At first, I was having moments of boredom, but then a weird story or "Holy crap!" moment would service....like his story of burning his landlord's house down, of wearing a Matrix-style leather jacket on a date with a girl he realizes ON THE DATE...can't speak English (or any other of his languages). 
 His is the epitome of survival and overcoming obstacles and transcending barriers...and this became a welcome partner on my long runs and it uplifted my spirit. 
 Funny, definitely at times, but more poignant and historical than you'd expect. A very well-written book. 
 4.5 stars.

One of the best essay collections I've ever read. I did get a little lost about timeframes because he relates to so many things in each essay, but it's beautifully written and a fantastic connection to Trevor. I wish all memoirs were this poignant and relatable.

Wow. This book is an absolute roller coaster. Trevor Noah gives us a glimpse of what life was like growing up in South Africa at the tale end of apartheid. Some crazy things happened. Some hilarious things happened. I had no idea (and still don't, really) how things are in South Africa. 
 Don't get me started on his mom. Absolutely amazing person! 
 I highly recommend this book, especially the audio book read by the author. Warning: language and violence.

I WISH I COULD GIVE THIS BOOK MORE THAN 5 STARS! If you want to laugh loudly then 2 pages later gasp in shock and 2 pages later cry so much you can hardly see the words BUT YOU SIMPLY MUST 
 Do yourself a favor and read this. Noah's a good writer, hilarious at times, thoughtful and reflective often, but the bottom line is the bare facts of his life are a collection of things no one would ever make up for just one fictional person. The things his mother did to survive (eating dirt! Getting arrested for having a mixed race child! I could go on and on but you should "meet" Patricia yourself- she's a true superhero.) Then she survives more abuse than 5 people could live through and raises a young man who successfully escapes the incredible odds stacked against him two stories high and you just can't believe it. But you must! This is not "based on true events" it's as for real as you get, and immensely entertaining and educational.

Incredible. Like most Americans, I don't know much history and I knew almost nothing about apartheid. I knew it was racist and horrible but none of the details. This book is equal parts history, memoir, and tragicomedy and I loved every second of it. The bulk of the story is about his relationship with his mom and he doesn't shy away from the tough or embarrassing stories. I love books about parent/child relationships, I love books about people's lives, I love memoirs, I love comedians writing/reading books, and this was everything I could have wanted. 
 I highly recommend the audiobook, because he is the narrator for the story and as a comedian and the person everything actually happened to, he makes the story come alive. It's as if he's sitting there with you telling you everything in person. There are also a lot of lines/passages in various languages of South Africa, and it would be difficult to read and absorb the languages without hearing them. 
 If you're looking for something kinda tragic and kinda hilarious at the same time, or something that will teach you something, or something to diversify your bookshelf, you should read this book.

Trevor Noah is a gifted story teller! 
 This collection of funny and poignant stories from his childhood and youth collectively recount his life story. He was born under apartheid in South Africa to a black mother and a white father; A legally forbidden combination. He was mostly kept hidden in his youngest years and then, as he got older, left to forge his own path through a world where he didn't really belong anywhere. 
 Resourceful, Clever and very Mischievous.. . he got himself into (and out of ) unusual predicaments.

So good I couldn't stop and plowed right through it. Trevor Noah's harrowing account of a life growing up during and after apartheid in South Africa and the forces that molded and shaped his young life before becoming a successful comedian. This dude is a survivor. After reading I have a new appreciation for the mans comedy and his point of view sitting in the chair of The Daily Show. Wow.

An utterly compelling memoir that leaves you savouring every word till the very last page, one that actually imparts wisdom and teaches you a thing or two about race and relationships. 
 Firstly, I didn't know much of Trevor Noah prior to reading "Born A Crime" but now I feel like a buddy of his who has been alongside with him in his youth. Except let's be honest, I couldn't possibly be because of how unique his perspective and coming-of-age story is (and that I'll never be cool enough to be part of his entourage). His personal accounts were very anecdotal, jumping through different ages of his life, which sometimes made it hard pin-pointing at what stage of his childhood it was happening in yet that never felt like an obstacle in wanting to know more about Noah's life. He is so genuine in his eloquence in conveying the thoughts and reasonings of his younger self, which ultimately provides a glimpse into who Trevor Noah is as a person now. 
 Secondly, I didn't know much of South Africa's history outside of the Apartheid, and even then, my knowledge of the Apartheid was superficially slim. "Born A Crime" is of the voice of someone who lived through that period, and not just any voice, but of a voice of someone straddling and struggling amongst multiple identities as a mixed child. Noah shares his keen insight into the circumstances in which he was born into within a much larger context of a country and her people looking to establish their own identity after times of turmoil. 
 There are just so many of Noah's anecdotes that I want to talk to with people. About that time his mom threw him out of a moving vehicle, or the one about his very eventful prom night, maybe about his CD-burning business or that DJ dance job with Hitler at a Jewish school, and definitely about his mom's miracle. There is plenty to take away from "Born A Crime", from the everlasting ties between a mother and son, to the injustices inflicted on the vulnerable by the society they are meant to be a part of, even to something that boils down to this: "I understand that you have a culture and identity that exists beyond me. I see you as a human being."
funny and powerful stories

This "type" of book is one of my favorites to read. If a comedian writes a book about their life, I read it as soon as I can and always love them. This book though was by far the best and probably my favorite book of all that I read this year. Definitely go for the audio, he does it wonderfully.

"I don't regret anything I've ever done in life, any choice that I've made. But I'm consumed with regret for the things I didn't do, the choices I didn't make, the things I didn't say. We spend so much time being afraid of failure, afraid of rejection. But regret is the thing we should fear most. Failure is an answer. Rejection is an answer. Regret is an eternal question you will never have the answer to. "What if..." "If only..." "I wonder what would have..." You will never, never know, and it will haunt you for the rest of your days."

** spoiler alert ** 
 I loved this book. Noah illustrates his complicated childhood in apartheid South Africa through a narrative that is all together witty, historical, political, comical, and serious. I listened to it on Audible, which he reads, and I'm sure I made a good choice. I am both left in awe by the insidiousness of apartheid and the triumph of the human spirit-- notably Noah's and his mother's. It also gives me new appreciation for the clever commentary Noah offers as host of the Daily Show, as he has had such varied experiences to draw from in his young life.
Enjoyed the stories and learning about life in South Africa

I enjoyed, suffered, learned and admired through his stories, the life people who are victims of hatred, ignorance and cruelty can create for themselves. 
 Trevor has the ability to take us by the hand, introduce us to his most intimate relationships with humor and love. We get to meet the family, neighbours, friends, policemen, father, stepfather as well as the places where he spent his childhood and teen age. And-at least I did- smelled the leaves, felt the dust under my feet, heard their music, their voices. I even had bouts of happiness as I sensed the kindness and protection family and networks can give. 
 But most of all I was left with his wonderful mother whom I adore, enjoyed and laughed at her, admired her love of life, her attitude to keep on going thanking every step of the way her connection with whoever she believes in. 
 It is a great testimony of coping passionate and lovingly with all kinds of adversities. Standing up as they face injustice,discrimination, violence, poverty, and doing it with integrity and humor. 
 A great life!

Loved that he included historical references and notes to this memoir. Loved all the talk about white and colored and black and how fucking arbitrary it really is. And, while I didn't do this in audiobook, you can betcha bottom dollar that I heard his voice in my head reading it.

The stories in this book are amazing and gives a deeper view into the life of Trevor Noah. His standups and monologue of daily show are amazing. I think reading the personal story of his struggle and his life puts things into perspective. While he says that his story may seem like an average South African kid's story, it isn't an easy one. It makes you appreciate the efforts and struggles he has made in his life.

Fascinating, funny and terrifying. I can't believe Noah is still young, after reading all that he has survived -- prejudice, domestic violence, and a substantially criminal youth. This is a very well-written book about a culture very different from ours, and yet with some frightening similarities.
I listened to this on Audible. Amusing, interesting and very honest stories. I enjoyed hearing it read by the author himself.
I loved and learned a lot more than I thought I would when I opened this book. A worthwhile read about Apartheid, whether or not you are a fan of Trevor Noah.
Do yourself a favor and listen to this one. I found myself wanting to re-tell nearly all of his stories to anyone that would listen and I was sad when it ended.

If there is one non-fiction, autobiographical memoir that you have to read, make it this one. In fact, if there is one audio book you choose to listen to, make it this one. 
 This was my first foray into the audio book world, and man, was it good. Narrated by Trevor Noah himself, he takes you into an incredible journey back in time during South Africa's apartheid. The different dialects, accents, languages, voices and inflections he uses during his narration are a thing of wonder and beauty. He transports you into his world, he makes you feel everything, and you will find yourself laughing, shaking your head in incredulity and weeping tears of pain and heartbreak - and in no particular order. 
 I never thought of myself as a huge fan of Trevor Noah. I never watched his stand up comedy, and only watched a handful of episodes since he took over from Jon Stewart. I thought he was intelligent and entertaining, but no Jon Stewart. I picked up this book after hearing about it from my sister, who couldn't stop praising it. When I did purchase it, she insisted I listen to the audio book, promising me that it was a 100 times better when you listen to it because you get to truly experience his world and his childhood. So I did. 
 Trevor Noah became my friend during my long commutes to and from work. I was engrossed in his life, and fell in love with his mother, who is my hero in so many ways now. 
 Trevor Noah has a knack at explaining things to you in uncomplicated terms so you leave knowing more than you ever have about pre- and post- Apartheid in South Africa and about the complex system that divided people (white, black and colored), and about the communities he grew up in. He allows you to listen to his story and come to your conclusions, make your own judgments, and root for whomever you chose to root for. I always rooted for his mother, and for him. 
 I admit that I enjoyed his early years a lot more than the later ones. I thoroughly enjoyed his interactions with his mother as a child, their conversations, their arguments and their love for each other was a joy to listen to. Being a mother to a naughty boy myself, I found myself relating to his mother in many ways and laughing out loud at how his naughtiness was dealt with. I loved their conversations about Jesus, and you could immediately tell that Noah was quite a clever boy from very early on. The letters they wrote each other when they were fighting about something were simultaneously hilarious and endearing. I cannot begin to tell you how much I loved this book. 
 The last few chapters, when he gets into the business of hustling, were interesting, but I felt it went on for a little too long. It also seemed slightly abrupt how he went from hustling and DJ'ing to comedy. There was never any explanation on how he got into comedy, why he chose that path, or how he started. I would have liked to know more about that part of his life, because we know that when he gets the call from his brother Andrew at the end, he's already doing stand-up, but we don't know when or how it began. 
 The end tore me to pieces. The pain and heartbreak in his voice made my heart twist and squeeze itself and my eyes flood with unshed tears. 
 A beautiful story, told by a wonderful human being. I have a lot of respect for someone who has been through so much pain and struggle to come out a successful and humble person, and to be able to look back at his life and see it from a comedic perspective.
Excellent!
Audio book was read by Trevor Noah and brought so much life to an already engaging biography.
VERY poignant, well-written, and (currently) relevant story. I really enjoy Trevor Noah's way of telling stories about his childhood in an intelligent, humorous, and relateable way.

It is truly amazing to see what humble and difficult beginnings Trevor came from and how far he has come. Even with all the difficulties in his life he has come out on top and with an attitude and perspective that amazes. I recommend this read!
Wow. Reading this, it seems a wonder that he even survived his childhood, let alone made himself the man he is today. Interesting read, for sure.

I don't know the author, as I don't live in US. I picked this book as I always wanted to know more about South Africa. So far, I've only been to Northern part of the continent. This book is amazingly honest, raw, funny and sad at the same time. The author provided a glimpse into a life of the mixed race child during and after the apartheid.

This is not your usual celebrity memoir. Noah writes about race, education, domestic violence, and the near impossibility of improving one's life when the deck is truly stacked against you. Trump's new education secretary should read Noah's bits about separate school systems for blacks and whites under apartheid. There's so much in here that, unfortunately, relates on-point to what we are experiencing and fearing here in America right now. I wasn't expecting this to be an important read, but it is. I'll be recommending it to many people.

This wasn't a typical comedian's memoir because Trevor Noah had a pretty tough childhood. I had the print copy and then I got a free copy of the audio version so I read some of it and listened to other chapters. It was great to hear it in his voice. The best parts involve his mom, who must be pretty amazing. And even though parts of it are difficult there's still a lot of humor.

Wow. This book was amazing. 
 So, I don't read a lot of non-fiction or memoirs. It's just not what I normally gravitate toward. However, I've been wanting to dip my toes into more of these and I really like Trevor Noah. I've of course seen him on the Daily Show, and also several stand-up specials he's done where he speaks relatively openly about his upbringing. 
 This book expands on that in an incredibly candid way. We learn about the history of South Africa and the disgusting practice of institutionalized racism (Apartheid). We learn about how he was able to navigate this society where he never felt like he belonged because of the circumstance surrounding his birth. And we learn about his amazing relationship with his mother, a woman who is strict, stubborn, determined, loving, devout, and fierce in her convictions. 
 I loved the way he structured this book. It skips around to different time periods in his life, but it never feels choppy or confusing. There is a really steady pacing and the stories tie back into each other really nicely. 
 I also loved the tone of this book. There are some truly awful things described in this book. I can't even imagine what it must have been like to actually grow up like this. The fact that he is able to relate these stories in such a straightforward and candid manner while not coming off as dismissive or flippant is very compelling. The intense things are still intense. But for him, that was just the way it was, and the book's tone reflects that very well, in my opinion. 
 I really loved this book. I feel like I learned something and was also entertained...two of my favorite things about books.
Listened to this one on Audible! It was hilarious and informative. The story was so rich and gripping. I will listen again and write a complete review

Wow, I was already a fan of Trevor Noah to start with, but I really didn't know what to expect from his book. Now that I know his life story and experiences I definitely have a newfound respect for him and everything he had to endure to get to where he is. The book covers a lot of ground, from apartheid in South Africa - which made segregated USA look pretty good! - to self-esteem, to domestic abuse. Through it all, he even manages to make it funny here and there. If you do get round to reading it, I highly recommend the audiobook that Trevor narrates - he gets all the voices and accents just right! Solid 5 stars.

Book club selection for July 2017. 
 Very readable. Trevor Noah makes some lovely observations about life and love, and he's a very charming writer. The sporadic style, jumping around the timeline, is a bit disconcerting, and there are a couple of inconsistencies to be honest, but who cares. It's a memoir, not an encyclopedia.
Funniest book I have read in years!

Wow. Such an interesting and informative book. I learned a lot about apartheid and race in South Africa that I never knew. I listened to the audible version and Trevor does a great job with the different accents and languages he references. This book is only a portion of Trevor Noah's life - it doesn't get into how he got into comedy or how he made it onto the Daily Show. I hope there's another installment coming. Oh, and the real hero of this story is Trevor's mom. She's amazing.

The combination of personal stories with real information about life in post-apartheid South Africa was a fascinating read. Trevor Noah's humor comes through in what is really not a funny story. I highly recommend this book.
The audiobook was spectacular. Noah telling his story is brilliant.

Trevor was literally born a crime to a black mother and white father during South Africa's apartheid. For most of us childhood is a difficult time, but for Trevor it was dangerous. I appreciate his hilarious anecdotes about surviving childhood. I would recommend this book to anyone who appreciates a bit of history with their humor.
Definitely recommend the audio version, beautifully read by the author.

Sweet-bitter stories about growing up in South Africa with his rebellion mother and white father at the time, when this was a crime. It's the story about the search for identity, a feeling of belonging and story of life without the possibility of choice. The book is the perfect blend of the cruel truth of life in the time after apartheid with humour brought by a daily life. Book for tears and laughter.
He's a very good storyteller, I just wish he liked cats more.

I listened to the audio version of this memoir which was a terrific way to learn about Trevor Noah's life in South Africa. He was raised by his black mother, occasionally seeing his white father, in the last days of apartheid. I am fairly well informed about that history but to be educated from the perspective of a mixed race child living through it is invaluable. Noah is funny, candid, smart, and insightful, not to mention a really good writer. I only wish the book had gone on a few more years - the story stopped before his move to the Daliy Show.

Witty, funny, and in places, extremely honest. Trevor Noah's biography will have you laughing and crying at the same time. Filled with anecdotes from his South African childhood, the book provides an insight into the life of a colored kid growing up under Apartheid. Noah beautifully describes his naughtiness at school, the difficulties he had with girls, making friends, his perception of religion, and getting to know his biological father. But what is truly beautifully woven into this thread of stories, is his relationship with his mother. 
 A compelling read at times, this book is sure to teach you a great deal about love, life, and the world.
I really enjoyed this book. The only thing that I didn't love is the skipping around of the story line. I love Trevor Noah manages to talk about serious subjects without being a total downer.

Born a Crime by Trevor Noah-4/5. A great book with some eye-opening insights for Americans into the lasting effects of Apartheid and so the power of a strong mother! Loved that while I was reading it, I could hear his voice in my head. I'm guessing it would be really fun as an audio book.

Being the same age as Trevor I was fascinated to learn how growing up in South Africa at the end of Apartheid was so different yet somewhat similar to my own 90's childhood after the end of Soviet Union. This book is a masterpiece memoir!

Sometimes while reading a book, I debate with myself what to rate it. I was all over the scale while reading this one. Sometimes I loved it and sometimes not, but I think when I wasn't liking it, it was more because I wasn't approving of the author as he was at that time. 
 I don't watch The Daily Show, and I have no idea whether I like a Trevor Noah as a person or a personality, but he does have a good story to tell. I love reading about other lives and cultures. What struck me most is that although his life in Johannesburg and its environs at the end of Apartheid is very different from middle class American life, some things, especially growing up boy things, seem to be universal. Being a mom of two teenage boys, I think I get the Trevor Noah of this memoir. 
 And he is funny. Not split the sides clown funny, but his telling of his stories makes me smile.

Trevor tells his childhood story with humor and honesty. He showed what it's like to grow up as a colored kid in South Africa under apartheid. His family, despite all obstacles, provided support to him under hardship. 
 Trevor grew up under poverty and racism. In the book, he was able to tell the story both subjectively and objectively. I learned a lot about social conundrum facing South Africa and how divided it was, or maybe still is today.

I have read books and seen movies about apartheid but I still learned so much from this book. Trevor's writing is very conversational and it had a lot of funny parts but also a lot that was really sad and horrible as well. 
 I had hoped the book would have shown a little more how about his career but it was more about his family and background. Maybe he will write more in the future which would be great! 
 Quotes 
 "People love to say, "Give a man a fish, and he'll eat for a day. Teach a man to fish, and he'll eat for a lifetime." What they don't say is, "And it would be nice if you gave him a fishing rod." That's the part of the analogy that's missing." 
 "In America you had the forced removal of the native onto reservations coupled with slavery followed by segregation. Imagine all three of those things happening to the same group of people at the same time. That was apartheid."

This was just made of win - the chapters are by turns hilarious, thought-provoking (I certainly learned a lot more about apartheid from this than from any late-night Wiki binge), self-deprecatingly personal and quite often horrifying, but Trevor never veers towards bitterness or self-pity, even when recalling the grimmest of stories. He was also a delight to listen to, as he does voices, demonstrates his mad multilingual skills, and generally performs his shapely arse off. Loved it!

I don't watch political shows...or comedy shows...or talk shows, so I'm somewhat embarrassed to admit that I didn't even know who Trevor Noah was when the ad for his book popped up on my Kindle. But it sounded intriguing so I bought it and read it and loved it. It's simple and honest and never boring. It's also personal and has nothing to do with his career or public life. I'd recommend it to anyone who enjoys reading memoirs. I learned a lot about South Africa under apartheid and the various peoples who make up the country. I also learned a lot about Noah and his relationship with his mother who seems to be a most remarkable woman.

i think this was one of my favorite memoirs ive ever read. 
 the way Trevor relates his very unique personal story with overarching humanity and themes for society is almost poetic. i felt so many conflicting emotions and i raced through each chapter. 
 i recommend this book to anyone and everyone

I've never watched Trevor Noah's version of The Daily Show and my knowledge of him prior to reading Born a Crime was pretty minimal, but I'd heard this memoir was great and -- hey! it is! 
 Noah's recollections of growing up during and after apartheid are bracing and thought-provoking, but also funny and infinitely readable. Especially in the UK, comedy can be the preserve of the privately-educated, Oxbridge graduate, so it was refreshing to read a comic memoir from someone who's actually Lived A Life. 
 My criticisms of Born a Crime are basically the same as everyone else's: the timeline jumps around in a way that's confusing, and too many of the stories have the feeling of standup bits, hitting the big laugh and then ending abruptly. I also could have done with a mite more about Noah's post-18 life. Late in the memoir, when Noah is an adult, he pays for his mother's hospital treatment, and my reaction was, wait he's rich now? how/when did he get rich? Lil bit confusing. 
 Nitpicks aside, this is a rare book that's educational and entertaining in equal measure. Recommended. 
 P.S. Still a bit jarred by the revelation that Trevor Noah once burned down someone's house and gave no fucks whatsoever, though. Er, okay.

Trevor Noah's intense and unforgettable memoir of growing up in post-Apartheid South Africa is beautifully written. Full of tales both hilarious and heartbreaking, Noah takes readers from his birth to his early adulthood with grace and humor far beyond his age. In addition to learning about his own experiences and life, I also learned much more about Apartheid than I previously knew - I clearly need to do some more reading on this - while I knew it was awful, I had no idea of the magnitude of its systemic evils.

I'm not sure how to describe the way I enjoyed this book. It was different. I normally devour books, especially ones I like in as few sittings as possible, sometimes it's only one sitting. But when I started this book although I tried to do it all in one sitting there were times I had to stop and take it in. It's like you are eating at a 5 star restaurant and you can't just scarf down the food you have to savor each course slowly. That was this book for me.
great as a listen

4.5 stars! What a wonderful book. Equal parts hilarious and horrifying. To think of what Trevor Noah had to overcome to become the person/ celebrity that he is today is really quite remarkable! He is such a funny, talented, intelligent man and after reading his book I respect him so much more! Great read !!

This was a fantastic book. Really helped me understand apartheid, which was something I only had a passing knowledge about prior. Trevor has had a really interesting life. It's really interesting to me because we're the same age. I can't imagine going through the things he went through. He came out a really decent, smart, interesting, thoughtful person. His mother is an amazing woman, and you could feel the love he has for her through his writing. The strength of character she has is so cool, but it's so interesting to me how she ended up with Trevor's step father. The whole story was really just super interesting, and really funny. My favorite story in the book was probably "Go Hitler." This is really worth the read, I can't say enough good things about it.

Read this for my book club. I don't watch his tv show and really knew nothing about him so went into the book pretty blind about the subject. I was pleasantly surprised at how much I enjoyed his memoir. He tells a good story and he had a lot of good stories to tell. 
 I know very little about South Africa so my favorite sections of the book were those where Trevor spoke about his country. The racial classifications under Apartheid were NUTS. The whole system was just terrible. Trevor explains it clearly and even humorously at times. I thought the parts dealing with the language situation - 11 official languages!- was fascinating. It is impressive he speaks so many languages. His polyglot status also lends itself to several funny stories. I think my favorite was overhearing some guys planning to mug him and Trevor being able to answer them in their own language, making a joke and thus defusing the situation. 
 I wish the book has talked about how he got his start in the entertainment business. How on earth did he make the leap from selling counterfeit goods in the ghetto to hosting an American tv show??? That is quite the change! Maybe he is saving those stories for another memoir down the road? I also wanted to know what has happened to his mom & brothers. I hope he has moved them far away from his horrible ex-stepfather. 
 Glad I read this even though I knew nothing about Trevor Noah. It's worth the read whether you watch his show or not.
This is an amazing read that will leave you both in awe of Noah's struggle and apt to say some inappropriate things at a dance party. Well worth the time.

They were giving this away for free to audible members, so I downloaded it. I had heard Trevor Noah talk about his background so many times on radio programs and in stand up, so I didn't really think I would like his book. But I LOVED it. Especially on audio. His experience growing up is just so different from anyone I know's experience. And he's such a talented writer and narrator. Definitely recommend this on audio.

If this book were a movie, one could write it off as far-fetched or even "Oscar bait". Fascinating, inspiring and at times shocking, this is a remarkable and engrossing memoir. 
 I never expected a memoir to, at the same time, challenge my views, teach me and move me as much as this book did, but it happened, and I love Trevor for it. It's a lesson on the importance of family, community and empathy. It is a lesson for anyone who, like me, had no idea about what life under apartheid or in the ghetto actually meant, of what the conditions are and of what that culture entails. It's also a lesson on how perseverance and optimism can lift people from the toughest environments, against all odds and in spite of any cultural or economical disadvantages. 
 And finally, it's a lesson for memoirs, because Trevor Noah actually has a story to tell. Unlike the countless other toilet-book time-waster celebrity-memoirs on the market that are just filled with silly stories and celebrity anecdotes, this is a true bildungsroman in every sense of the word.
So good. This book is a treasure.
Everyone should read this book. I laughed, I cried. I recommend the audiobook - Trevor Noah is a great writer and a great narrator.
I enjoyed this book so much I finished it in two days. Could not stop listening to it. I especially loved hearing it in his own voice.

This is my 2017 Reading Challenge book by a person of color. 
 This book was awesome. I was glad that I got the Audio version and listened to Trevor reading it. 
 The ending, WOW! That was a powerful testimony. My opinion is if you doubted Jesus before, I think. for a little while anyway, you'd have a hard time doubting Him longer.

This was an incredibly moving, inspiring and gut-wrenching read. I'm so glad this was my first read of the year as this perspective will stick with me. This is one of those books that if everyone read would positively impact how we treat each other and the assumptions we make about race, gender and access.

We listened to the audio version on a car trip and loved it!! Trevor Noah is a fantastic, funny storyteller. His life is fascinating. I highly recommend this book, especially if you are able to listen to the audiobook that is narrated by Noah.

This book is amazing and I'm upset I didn't make myself read it sooner. I'm glad I've read it because it's changed me in the way good books do. Trevor Noah thank you for telling your story and showing the world what kind of mom you have. I hope I can be a mother with such faith

I loved the way Trevor wove together the stories of his childhood to give us a sense of what it was like to grow up in South Africa during apartheid. Born to mixed race parents, Trevor had to learn to lie at an early age as his birth truly was a crime against the government. I did not realize all of the racial categories that apartheid designated---especially the huge differences between colored and black. People were constantly asked to defend their color. Getting out of the ghetto was not even a dream for many families/colors. 
 Trevor explained apartheid as apart- hate. "You separate people into groups and make them hate one another so you can run them all." Trevor's strong will and hustling prowess allowed him to survive the streets. At times, it was his mother that almost took him down. She often beat her lessons into him but it was easy to see that she was his strongest positive influence. His survival and eventual success was thanks to her. "My mom did what school didn't. She taught me how to think." I was frustrated with her when she kept letting Abel, Trevor's stepfather, beat her. It wasn't until I saw how the policemen treated her that I understood. Talk about a good old boy's club. Men protected men. When Trevor questioned her about why she stayed she replied that he would kill her if she left. As the story unfolded, I understood that fear. 
 This book unfolds in a way that kept my interest throughout. There's no pretense or mincing of words to save face. In addition, there were some golden nuggets that I need to hold on to. Here are just a few: 
 "You tell people to follow their dreams, but you can only dream of what you can imagine and depending on where you come from, your imagination can be quite limited." 
 "Language, even more than color, defines who you are to people." (I had no idea how many languages/dialects existed in South Africa during this time.) 
 "People say give a man a fish and he'll eat for a day. Teach a man to fish and he'll eat for a lifetime." What they don't say is, "and it would be nice if you gave him a fishing rod." 
 "In society we do horrible things to one another because we don't see the person it affects." 
 "Comfort provides a floor but also a ceiling." 
 "Being chosen is the greatest gift you can give another human being." 
 "Relationships are built in the silences."

Wonderful, moving stories enhanced by listening to Trevor read them himself. Some serious laugh out loud moments while offering a glimpse to growing up black, white, and/or colored in South Africa. 
 I am a fan of the Daily Show and was not sure if Trevor would be able to successfully take over for Jon Stewart. He won me over during the election season, but after reading about what he went through growing up, I'm ready to go to war for him! 
 Keep up the good work Trevor, and may you never have to eat bone marrow again.
This quirky assemblage of stories of survival in South Africa is well worth reading. Highly recommended.

What a smart, thoughtful, funny and well-written book. Noah is honest and revealing, and the unexpected bonus (aside from learning so much about South Africa under apartheid) was the lovely portrait of his fierce and uncompromising mother.

Trevor Noah tells his story (and reads it himself on the Audible version) of life in South Africa after Apartheid ended. But it's not just his story, it's his mother's as well. And there is so much strength and candor and humor woven into every chapter. 
 It's no wonder he's such a brilliant Daily Show host. 
 The things he has seen are extraordinary, and he tells the story beautifully.
One smart cookie.

I'm (obviously) a fan of Trevor Noah; I think he's done well to fill the big shoes of Jon Stewart, his predecessor on The Daily Show. So I was already predisposed to like this memoir when I picked it up, but I think it could entertain the average open-minded nonfan as well. 
 Each chapter opens with a page about the history of colonization, oppression and apartheid that South Africa was steeped in over centuries of European rule. About half-way through, these mini-history lessons became less general and more personal in how they applied to him, but not less informative. I have never learned so much broad history from a such scant offerings. 
 His breakdown of the relationship between racism and language is beautiful and succinct: "If you spoke to me in Zulu, I replied to you in Zulu. If you spoke to me in Tswana, I replied to you in Tswana. Maybe I didn't look like you, but if I spoke like you, I was you." 
 Trevor's love for his mother comes through clearly and constantly, even when he is numerating all the ways they clashed (his mischievous ways as a child, his devil's advocate stance in regard to her piousness, etc.) He foreshadowed the violence they would face at the hands of his stepfather early on and that hung over every interaction he wrote about her like a vulture waiting to swoop in - it was bittersweet to read about the funny moments he had with his mother, knowing she would soon be a victim of domestic abuse. The acknowledgement of both his original anger at why she stayed and his ignorance of how abusive relationships worked is unusual, but I think it exemplifies the good man he grew up to be, the good man his mother raised against so many odds. 
 M's rating: 4/5
Interesting read about growing up in South Africa at the end of Apartheid.
From start to finish I was enthralled; funny, sad shocking and eye-opening.

Everyone should read this book. I listened to Trevor tell stories of growing up as a mixed-race kid in South Africa. He covers race, religion, his relationship with his mother, poverty, hustling, fear, pain, being embarrassed, having fun, speaking different languages. Sometimes he throws in a little humor and removes himself, somewhat stoically, from the action, but the rawest moments Trevor tells with a frank clarity that brought me to tears. 
 Trevor doesn't talk much about his start in comedy or anything about how he started at The Daily Show, which is the only place I knew him from. And as someone who grew up on Jon Stewart, I wasn't sure I liked this young, smug (but beautiful, gorgeously accented) guy. His humor seemed a bit ... smug's the best word I got. I see him differently now. Man, what a story.

The story background sets the stage for a really interesting story, but the vast majority of the events happening throughout the book are quite frivolous. 
 In addition, the writing style is too simplistic, more suitable to a blog post, than to a published book.

I never watchedThe Daily Show with John Stewart and took a while to see it with Trevor Noah as host but from the first time I watched it I was hooked by his humour and of course his dimples. I've rarely missed a show since. And ever since have been curious about where he came from. I soon knew the basics of course but I really wanted to learn more. 
 So when I saw this autobiography I knew I'd be reading it. It's been years since I've read non fiction but judging by how much I loved this loving, tender, at times sad and at times humorous tribute to his mother, I'm glad I did. 
 I could say lots of things but boiling it down, this is a compelling book about a fascinating man.

Very informative and entertaining book that sheds so much light on growing up as a mixed race person in a changing South Africa. Not the funny man book that I expected. Instead this is a thoughtful take on race, identity and culture from an incredibly smart man with a remarkable mother. Really a delight. I listed to the audio version which was so wonderful because Trevor is so adept at voices and it is a delight to hear the different languages spoken out loud.

I highly recommend it to everyone and anyone who is looking for a good book, or something to listen to in the car. I'm not normally an audio book person because I'd rather read than listen to a story. But even with that said, I think it's one of those books which may be better to listen to than to read since he narrates it himself. His narration adds a personal, genuine feel; it just feels like he's just telling you stories about his life. Plus I've learned some things about South Africa and apartheid that I didn't know about before, and it's really engaging to listen to his experiences. Even though he talks about some pretty hard and frustrating topics, the story can be pretty hilarious in some parts because he's funny. But you don't really have to be completely familiar with Trevor Noah or watch him regularly on The Daily Show to enjoy it either. It's a really sweet story in parts too particularly the parts about his mom. It's a really engaging, moving book and I'm so glad I experienced this.

I listened to the audiobook for this one and loved it. Trevor Noah does the narration himself and it was definitely the way to go for this book. Normally I'm not an audiobook fan, but he is multilingual and uses many phrases in the book. If I had read these myself, I wouldn't have any idea what they sound like. But he grew up speaking Afrikaans, Zulu, Xhosa, usw, and I felt like I got more out of it by hearing someone say the phrases correctly. 
 My only critique/comment is that the stories weren't always in chronological order. It's not necessary, just a personal preference, so I just paid more attention to dates/ages.
Loved this book so much, I did not want it to end. I learned so much about Trevor, his family, Apartheid and South Africa. I'm glad I can enjoy Trevor on TV!
I really enjoyed this book on all levels.

Noah is a brilliant storyteller, and this book is among the best I've read this year. Stories range from funny to harrowing, recollecting memories from childhood and teen years growing up in South Africa. The audiobook was particularly good as you could hear Trevor Noah telling his own stories, and saying and explaining phrases in many South African languages. 
 Don't miss this one. It's a treasure.
This book is so important. Funny, honest, beautiful, real. So important. Go read, seriously.

I enjoy Trevor Noah's take on The Daily Show and clips of his stand-up on YouTube so I found this book fascinating. Growing up in South America during apartheid and then after is so totally different from anything I've experienced.

I don't really enjoy memoirs, but I think Trevor Noah is really funny so I gave it a shot. Also, he is biracial as are my children, so I was interested in his perspective since that is mostly what the book is about. 
 While the setting is in South Africa, it's a lot like any coming of age story. He gets in trouble and is awkward with girls, just like every teenage boy you know. He talks a lot about his abusive, alcoholic stepfather. Without telling my own personal details, much of this struck a chord with me. 
 I really enjoyed this book.

There was so much to love about this book. I am new to the comedy of Trevor Noah. He is one of the few that can make me laugh about the current state of affairs around #45. When I came a cross a review for his memoir, I knew I had to get it. I'm so happy that I did. An insightful and often funny memoir about a mixed-race child growing up in Johannesburg during apartheid. He lived a life of unbelievable racism, poverty, and violence, yet is able to offer a collection of life stories that pulls you in and doesn't let go until the final page. His ability to reflect on these experiences with love, humor and a deep sociological understanding of what was right and so very wrong with the world he was a part of was magical.

I loved this book. I listened to it on audio and I think I liked it even more because Trevor Noah was the narrator - he added a lot of personality and emotion to the book that I would miss just reading to myself. I listened to this book first, in the office as I was doing data entry stuff and found myself almost laughing out loud in places which I would have done if I didn't share an office space with others. Then my husband and I took a road trip so I restarted the book so he could enjoy it as well. I'm glad I did this because I had missed some of the stories when I had been interrupted at work. I liked Trevor Noah before this book but I admire and respect him even more now that I know more about his childhood and where he came from. It was an eye-opening experience reading his stories, hear where he came from, and see where he is now. And can I just say how much I love his mother! What a character she is! So strong! I recommend this book and would strongly recommend you listen to it on audio.

This is not an simple read, it is fluid in its time line and I expected that but it still threw me a couple of times. This was heartbreaking and exhilarating all at once. I adore his mother and wish I could offer her one huge knuckle bump for what all that she stood up for and did for herself and her son. So many take aways and reminders for me of just how blessed I am to have been born in the circumstances that make up my life. 
 The things I must remember: 
 "Language brings with it an identity and a culture, or at least the perception of it. A shared language says, 'We're the same'. A language barrier says, 'We're different'. The architects of apartheid understood this. Part of the effort to divide black people was to make sure we were separated not just physically but by language as well. Because of this, we'd fall into the trap the government had set for us and fight among ourselves, believing that we were different. The great thing about language is that you can just as easily use it to do the opposite: convince people that they are the same. Racism teaches us that we are different because of the color of our skin. But because racism is stupid, it's easily tricked. If a person who doesn't look like you but speaks like you, your brain short-circuits because your racism program has none of those instructions in the code." 
 "So many incidents in my life made me realize that language, even more than color, defines who you are to people. Maybe I didn't look like you, but if I spoke like you, I was you." 
 "My mom did what school didn't. She taught me to think." 
 "My mom raised me as if there were no limitations on where I could go or what I could do. When I look back I realize she raised me like a white kid - not white culturally, but in the sense of believing that the world was my oyster, that I should speak up for myself, that my ideas and thoughts matters." 
 "The only authority my mother recognized was God's. God is love and the Bible is truth - everything else was up for debate. She taught me to challenge authority and question the system. The only way it backfired on her was that I constantly challenged and questioned her." 
 "Relationships are built in the silences." 
 "The hood was strangely comforting, but comfort can be dangerous. Comfort provides a floor but also a ceiling." 
 "I know you see me as some crazy old bitch nagging at you," she said, "but you forget the reason I ride you so hard and give you so much shit is because I love you. Everything I have ever done I've done from a place of love. If I don't punish you, the world will punish you even worse. The world doesn't love you. If the police get you, the police don't love you. When I beat you, I'm trying to save you. When they beat you, they're trying to kill you." 
 "I grew up in a world of violence, but I myself was never violent at all. Yes, I played pranks and set fires and broke windows, but I never attacked people. I never hit anyone. I was never angry. I just didn't seem myself that way. My mother had exposed me to a different world than the one she grew up in. She bought me the books she never got to read. She took me to the schools that she never got to go to. I immersed myself in those worlds and I came back looking at the world a different way. I saw that not all families are violent. I saw the futility of violence, the cycle that just repeats itself, the damage that's inflicted on people that they in turn inflict on others. I saw, more than annoying, that relationships are not sustained by violence but by love. Love is a creative act. When you love someone you create a new world for them. My mother did that for me, and with the progress I made and the things I learned, I came back and created a new world and a new understanding for her. After that, she never raised her hand to her children again." 
 "You're lucky to be alive," I told her, "I still can't believe you didn't have any health insurance." 
 "Oh but I do have insurance," she said. 
 "You do?" 
 "Yes. Jesus." 
 "Jesus?" 
 "Jesus." 
 "Jesus is your health insurance?" 
 "If God is with me, who can be against me?" 
 "Okay, Mom." 
 "Trevor, I prayed. I told you I prayed. I don't pray for nothing." 
 "You know," I said, "for once I cannot argue with you. The gun, the bullets - I can't explain any of it. So I will give you that much." Then I couldn't resist teasing her with one last little jab. "But where was your Jesus to pay your hospital bill, hmmm?"I know for a fact that He didn't pay that." 
 She smiled and said, "You're right. He didn't. But he blessed me with a son who did."

Trevor Noah's autobiography stops when he's 20 or so, his comedy career is mentioned only in passing. The book starts with the Immorality Act of 1927 that made his parents' relationship, and him, a crime. 
 "The genius of apartheid was convincing people who were the overwhelming majority to turn on each other. Apart hate, is what it was. You separate people into groups and make them hate one another so you can run them all." (3) 
 Noah's mom is Xhosa and his dad is Swiss. As a baby and young child he was kept indoors, because his parents could be arrested and he could be taken to an orphanage, for living in the wrong neighborhood. I fear I am making the book sound grim, well, sometimes it is, but mostly this is a fun, thoughtful and funny book; like the guy who hosts "The Daily Show." 
 I borrowed this from my public library.

This is so so good. It's especially interesting to read after recently finishing A Long Walk to Freedom. Trevor is the following generation. Apartheid was abolished when he was a child, but still defined his life growing up. These are stories from a family just living day to day in this world. His mom is basically the baddest MF ever. Read this book to learn about her if nothing else. She is an amazing, inspiring woman. In some ways, his childhood reflected things I'm familiar with, but just when you get a tiny bit comfortable, you realize no no... this is very very different. Anyway, yeah. Everyone just read this.

Although I feel comfortable with memoir genres, this book was clearly out of my comfort zone. And that's a good thing. If you think your life is rough, read this. 
 It is upsetting and inspirational at the same time. Entertaining and educational. Clearly a recommended read.
Liked it. Good to know more about him, and his story.

This was one book I was dying to read when I heard about it. Because I LOVE TREVOR NOAH. I think he's one of the most insightful, witty journalists/comedians that are there today. Basically, I'm in love with him. 
 However, I was in love with only his work - his stand up shows, his work with The Daily Show (which I watch daily). I didn't really research his life, except to see if he has a girlfriend (which he does ). Which is why things that he said in his book were so shocking to me. I knew he lived in apartheid, I knew about his family and him being mixed - I just didn't understand the ramifications of having to live through that. 
 Having read the book I feel as though I'm in love again, but this time with his mother. What a pillar of strength, a force to be reckoned with, a rebel and a crusader of her times and ours! Basically, I love his family. 
 There were times I laughed and laughed, times when I was solemn and times I simply bawled. The painting that Trevor Noah painted of his life was fresh and you didn't have to look too closely to see the cracks, the bumps. But it was these cracks and bumps that made the painting so beautiful. 
 I would recommend this book to anyone - even if you haven't followed Trevor Noah's work because after this, you sure will.
OMGOD. So good!! hard-hitting but laugh-out-loud funny in parts!
Alternately hilarious and moving, and always told in Trevor Noah's distinctive voice, I'd say this is definitely the best memoir I've read.

an entertaining memior written in a breezy, easy to read style that is most effective when Trevor relates incidents from his past with apartheid policies. So much of his life has been effected by fact of his biracial heritage which often isolated him from other ethnic groups. I also thought the author said very little about any successful significant relationships except for his mother which seemed very strange to me. A good vacation read
Fantastic!
hilarious and insightful.

I truly enjoyed this book. I love Trevor Noah's writing voice. 
 And the ending. 
 There are no words.

I thoroughly enjoyed listening the audio version of this book! It is read by Trevor Noah himself - 'nuff said on that count. 
 If you are looking for a glitzy Hollywood memoir, move along. This is not it. In fact, it doesn't bring him in the U.S. or on television. This is his story of growing up the child of mixed race parents during the waning years of apartheid and beyond. 
 I've shelved this as a memoir or autobiography, but it is not a linear story as you would usually think of in those genres. As the subtitle says, these are stories from a South African childhood. They are told more around ideas/themes that ran through his life. Rather than following along chronologically, Noah follows one train of thought from his youngest years into his early adulthood and then moves on to another to do the same. The first time starting a new chapter with him returning to his younger years, caught me off guard for a second - perhaps because of listening to it - but it was the perfect way to tell the various stories. With this structure Noah was able to follow a line of thought and really make meaning of where it started and how it impacted his life. 
 This is one of the audio books that I now need to go and find a hard copy of because there are some places that I want to go back to find and reread! He really hits home on some profound things that he learned growing up in the conditions and in that time and place. I related to some of these things on a personal level. However, there were some that are applicable to much of what we see going on in our country right now. At the very beginning of the book he says, "The genius of apartheid was convincing people who were the overwhelming majority to turn on each other. Apart hate, is what it was. You separate people into groups and make them hate one another so you can run them all." 
 While this is a very personal narrative to Trevor Noah's life, it has implications that can be seen in the lives of others, in other countries, on other continents. Loved this one!

I thought I knew generally about apartheid South Africa, but turns out it's much worse than I thought. I was surprised by how organized and intentional and architected it all was. It wasn't just subjugation and hatred, it was very well thought-out subjugation and hatred. I can't imagine how Trevor Noah and his incredibly strong-willed and amazing mother lived through it, especially since he was born mixed race. Which meant he didn't belong anywhere and was technically illegal. 
 You'd think this would be a sad story but it's an incredibly uplifting story. Especially entering into dark times now, it's nice to see that even in the worse of times one can make the most of life. For Trevor and his family, it almost seems like they didn't know anything else, so of course they wouldn't spend much time moping about it. They just worked hard, found all the loopholes, and fought the system whenever and wherever they could. Did I mention, his mother is truly incredible? 
 The book is basically a memoir, but written in episodic chapters, each one telling a poignant or funny story about growing up. It's not entirely chronological, and it doesn't cover Trevor's rise as a comedian. I would love to read a sequel where he talks about that, especially what it's like to move to the US where he'd automatically be seen as an African American instead of a mixed race South African. 
 In story after story, Trevor uses humor to dissect the concept of race, to show that it is really just a social construct. I really enjoyed reading these stories, as they are very relatable and charming. I loved reading about the young Trevor as a chameleon kid, not really aware of the way the world works, but just trying to figure out a way to thrive in it in any way possible.
Listened to the audiobook read by the author. Excellent storyteller!

A piece of advice, please don't read this book in public. 
 Because chances are: 
 1) You will be laughing out loud, like REALLY loud, because Trevor is that hilarious. 
 2) Trevor's life story will touch your heart dramatically, enough to make your eyes fill with water (especially the part about his mother, or it's just me who is very emotional when it comes to family). 
 3) The way Trevor describes apartheid system in South Africa from his perspective as a mix person, is very critical (even in his own way). Your eyes and mouth will (probably) open widely because you realize how tragic the system was, how that system affected South Africa today and many parts of the world today still enforce similar system. 
 You don't want to make any of those faces in public.
