I realized in listening to Trevor Noah's "Born a Crime" how little I know of apartheid and South Africa in general. While listening to Noah's memoir of his childhood and the injustices he saw was at times devastating, his sense of humor and insight made this a fantastic--and informative--read.

Intelligent. Moving. Charming. This book MUST BE READ... Or, better yet, this book must be listened to because Mr Noah narrates himself and he does so with humor, heart and texture. 
 Mr Noah shared these stories from his childhood which will astound and move the reader. His story is often horrific. The title sets the story from the beginning because Mr Noah was born to a Caucasian European man and a black African woman. During Apartheid. His birth was a crime. And his childhood was as terrible as you would expect. It was also far more wonderful than you would expect thanks in large part to a strong, funny, kind and loving mother. She is a force and she propelled him forward. His love for her is palpable in these stories. The reader goes away from it marveling at her spirit. 
 I think many men surviving this childhood would be embittered, controlling, abusive and angry men. But Mr Noah is full of humor and wisdom. The book made me think, laugh, gasp in shock. But mostly this book made me FEEL. It should be required reading for young adults and politicians. If you have not read it, do so. And if you have read it but have not listened to it, do that. You will not regret it.
Fantastic read. A truly clever, moving, and powerful book. I highly recommend everyone to read it.

I read the audiobook and it's absolutely brilliant ! At the beginning I felt it was hard to concentrate because everything was going upside down, with no chronology, yet Trevor caught me after about 40mn of listening. From then on I could not stop listening. And at the end I shed up some tears. As an African girl with a really close relationship with her mom, that really talked to me, even though I never lived under Apartheid. For that the story was enlightening and for everything that looked my own life in Africa it was refreshing and funny. Well, Trevor, thanks for that piece of brilliance. I loved it.

Love, love, loved this book. I need to buy a copy so that I can reread it. I'm even going to use excerpts of this for my class. I don't read a lot of memoirs, but this is one not to miss. Even if you can't relate to his story, Noah makes his experience accessible by using great analogies and funny anecdotes.

Enjoyable look into growing up outside any group in South Africa transitioning from Apartheid. Mr Noahs self narration of the audiobook added considerably to a book strong in humor, but also lessons about looking at the world through the eyes of the 'other'.

I really enjoyed learning a bit more about Noah and his life coming up in South Africa at the end of apartheid, it made me really want to delve a bit more into that history (which is crazy and we need to talk about more), and he has a great voice. My only nit-pick is that the stories were not told in chronological order, so I was never really clear on what the historical context of a particular moment was in his life. Look, this may not bother everyone, but in one chapter he goes on and on about how no one has a cell phone, and then in the next chapter he talks about talking to friends on his cell phone while driving to try to find a dance, and then in the next chapter talks about saving enough money to buy a cordless phone that had a strong enough signal that he could walk down the street to McDonalds and still have a connection (and did not have a cell phone). These type of discrepancies make me crazy and there were quite a few of them in the book, so I found myself being slightly skeptical about how 100% accurate the book was. That being said, at a certain point, I just started thinking of the book as a fictionalized version of his life and enjoyed it a lot more.

IMMORALITY ACT, 1927 
 "To prohibit illicit carnal intercourse between Europeans and natives and other acts in relation thereto" 
 This is a book full of laughs and full of feels. An amazing coming of age tale of currently the world's foremost comedian. Actually its less of his biography and more of a tribute to his mother and i guess that is the reason i liked this book so much. Trevor Noah is an amazing comedian, this book gives insight to where his comedy comes from, an almost absent father, an abusive drunkard step father, trying to find his identity as a mixed boy into a racially divided(White and Black) South Africa, being a crime under Apartheid and then an anomaly in the free South Africa, just him and his mother against the whole world, and finding comedy in every situation they ever found themselves in, no matter how absurd or bizarre or dangerous. 
 This is a splendid book and a testament of what a truly indomitable and a strong woman can do against all odds and in a world full of violence i.e raise a remarkable man like Trevor Noah.

This book should be a must read for anyone trying to gain a deeper understanding into race relations. I must say that as much as I like Trevor Noah, his writing was a bit choppy in areas throughout the book but the level of understanding that he's able to communicate is worth it. If you decide not to read the book, just read the chapter "The Cheese Boys". Mind blown.

Amazing!!! Completely amazing! I loved every word of this! The strength of his mother was very inspiring. I also love that she was determined to let him be a child and experience the world in a much different way than she did. There were many quotes that stood out to while reading this, however these two resonated with me the most. 
 "People love to say, 'Give a man a fish, and he'll eat for a day. Teach a man to fish, and he'll eat for a lifetime.' What they don't say is, 'And it would be nice if you gave him a fishing rod.' That's the part of the analogy that's missing." 
 "We tell people to follow their dreams, but you can only dream of what you can imagine, and depending on where you come from, your imagination can be quite limited."

Truly amazing telling of his post/pre- Apartheid South African history. I laughed, I cried, I listened intently (listened on Audible). Trevor Noah is such an amazing performer, author and narrator. I highly recommend the audio version.
If I could date a book, this would be it.
I wasn't thrilled with the transition between chapters, and I thought the last chapter was odd, but overall it was a fascinating personal account into the devastating consequences of apartheid.

Absolutely fantastic. Funny, unexpectedly poignant, and an honestly amazing book. You must read this on audible to hear Trevor Noah tell his story and seamlessly transition between languages and voices. Top notch. Highly recommend.

Loved every page of this book. Like most fans of The Daily Show with Jon Stewart, I tried to keep an open mind and open heart for his relatively unknown successor, Trevor Noah. I've come to enjoy his humour, perspective and grace as a comedian and host so I sought out his book. His thoughtful way of weaving his own history with the history of South Africa was brilliant. He told his own stories with insightfulness, humour, pride and compassion. What is perhaps more noteworthy is the absence of bitterness and resentment - emotions most people would forgive knowing what he has survived.

I truly loved this!! 4.5* 
 It's true that one of my favorite genres is memoir- I love finding out more (or in some cases anything since I'm not familiar with said person at all) about individuals & hearing stories- especially childhood ones. That being said, this mostly applies to people in the medical/music/historical/any background that doesn't automatically associate you as a household name. I'm not against celebrity stories in the slightest- I just find myself walking away being disappointed most of the time, feeling that it just barely skimmed the surface. I admit being a bit reluctant to try this- I knew who Trevor was, but I would not consider myself a massive fan in the slightest. I was nervous this would be another famous person talking about superficial things that I couldn't relate to. However, after seeing multiple glowing reviews & how this was supposedly about him growing up in Africa, I decided to give it a go. This anxiety completely dissolved within the first 10 minutes of speaking. 
 I immensely enjoyed hearing about the tight bond between Trevor & his mother, what it felt like always being an outsider, trying to figure out girls, dealing with his abusive stepfather, etc. All things I could connect to & FELT his connection to. (This cannot be said for everyone as some people will talk about their lives but you can still make out a distance from.) It was like he sat down & said "Pull up a chair. I'd like to share with you my life." All of this felt very authentic & honest. No B.S.; the way it should be. 
 Like I said, I'm not familiar with Noah's work. I know he's a comedian, but I was unaware of his technique. To just have this guy sit there, talking about his upbringing without TRYING to be funny & making me laugh (a lot)- that is very impressive. I am kicking myself for not paying attention to him sooner & looking forward to checking out his other works. But on the other end of the spectrum, this book wasn't all shits & giggles. As Trevor describes things such as: getting hidings, being in the midst of Abel's terror, being so poor his family had to eat caterpillars & suck bone marrow- he brings a lighthearted, optimistic tone to the table, but never so much that it overbears what these words truly mean. Basically he didn't treat the serious stuff like it was a joke, which I probably should have never thought would happen in the first place, but hey. You never know. 
 I don't really have a favorite story here, they're all great. Perhaps the Hitler one; that was both hilarious & enlightening. There were a lot of things I learned about African culture & liked that he took the time to explain these things. The only complaint I have is that there's inconsistency to the chronology here. He would go back & forth several times; it's not too much that it gets in the way, but it's definitely noticeable. He leaves the door open for another book & I would like to hear more stories about his career, if he chooses to do so. Overall highly recommended & if you have the option, choose the audiobook! Trevor's narration perfectly conveys the emotions invoked in the book, ones that I'm not sure would be felt with the same effect in text. This is absolutely a worthy memoir & I'm really glad I went with the GR community on this one. One of the best audiobooks I've heard in a long time.

I listened to the audio version, read with excellence by the author. Would absolutely recommend listening rather than reading. 
 The book focuses on the childhood and adolescence of the author. He seems to have been an interesting kid doing interesting things, and he also describes the family circumstances and the culture of apartheid in which he grew up. As a "mixed" kid he was neither black, white nor colored, and observed them all with the closeness that was particularly available to him. The book describes the events of apartheid particularly well. He also describes the structure of domestic violence very well. And of course, the author being a very successful comedian, the book is very funny. Though more funny read by the author. 
 The book has continuity issues which are not bad enough to harm the reading experience, but the editors sure let the author down. I would not expect these kind of continuity issues to exist in a book put out by a professional publishing house.

very enlightening story of a young man growing up in South Africa during a time of major change. 
 I did not find it particularly funny, just a very good read. 
 the human race are the meanest race in the universe!

This book is a memoir of Trevor Noah's childhood and young adulthood in South Africa. His story gives you an inside view of growing up during apartheid, in which your very existence is a crime. His black mother chose to procreate with his white father on purpose, knowing that miscegenation was considered a criminal offense, their child would have to live a somewhat hidden life, and never having any idea that apartheid would end. (I believe that his mother is the key to this story. She is so brave, so funny, and so ridiculously stubborn that you can't help but wish you knew her personally.) His memoir is a treatise on the absurdity of race, racism, and the human condition. He talks about the various ways that different races are treated in South Africa, and as a result, how they see themselves, and how they behave toward each other. Along the way, you find out that Trevor was the naughtiest boy, and a somewhat heedless young adult. The book also details the misery of being left out as a child, the challenges of extreme poverty, and the horrors of domestic abuse. The book does not get into his comedy career, so perhaps that will be another book. I loved listening to this as an audiobook, which Trevor Noah narrates. He has a compelling voice, and even does consistent voices for the people in his book, which I found to be adorable. I highly recommend this book.

*Born a Crime* was a wonderful book. It helped me better understand the people and culture of South Africa, and opened my eyes. Noah's book was funny and tragic, shocking and inspiring. I'm so glad it was recommended to me.

Loved it! Captivating from the beginning to the end. Sincerely written through the lense of humor to make wrongful life of South Africa to be understandable and readable. Not just a story of a struggling life of a family but educating in so many ways at the same time. Highly recommend to read.

My Thoughts 
 Even though Trevor Noah grew up relatively poor in South Africa, it seems that the story of his youth isn't much different from growing up relatively poor in parts of the United States. What makes his youth so decisively different is that he had the strength to go on when it would have been much easier to surrender to his fate than find a better life. I mean can you imagine that when he was born, it was a crime for his black mother to marry his white father? Just his existence was cause for his mother to be unable to walk with him down the street. He didn't fit in with the whites, the blacks or even really the colored people since he was brought up to question authority. 
 Noah talks about his special treatment because of his white father but more importantly, how his mother fought to make him better. A lot of the stories that he tells make you reflect on how being poor and without education can doom a life. All of the stories are told with humor and a part of "how did I survive" type awe. I really enjoyed this and had no idea that his life was so full of horror since what he presents on television is completely different than his background. This is definitely a feel good book.
Really enjoyed this memoir! Highly recommend.

This book lives up to all the hype. 
 Vividly written, gritty and explosively true. I'll never see Trevor Noah's smile again without wondering what goes on inside him. 
 One of the best autobiographies I've ever written. 
 I wish he would have gone into his current life a little more.

I think what is amazing about this book is that it's doing so many things simultaneously. 
 - It gives a bare bones history of South Africa. Enough history is provided to give a context to the things that Noah was dealing with in his life. 
 - It explains the complexities of being mixed and never belonging anywhere you go. 
 - It talks about his mother's life and her choices from Noah's point of view as her son. But he goes beyond his own perspective and tries to imagine her point of view as well. I felt he showed his mother so much honor in this book. 
 - It talks about the emotional life of an abused family. For me, these portions were told with such truth and depth. 
 - It talks about the failings of the justice system towards women. "They were men first, and police second." This quote chilled me to the bones. 
 - It talks about labor and work that happens in poor communities. And how poor people's labor never leads to wealth. 
 - It talks about the role of faith in his mother's life. 
 That is the mind trip of this book. It's talking race, systematic oppression, apartheid, labor, education, policing, prisons, domestic violence, feminism, masculinity, family, childhood, adolescence, etc. And Noah is able to talk about all these things from the point of view of his lived experience with complete candor. And his writing style is one of those where it sounds so conversational, so casual, -- until you notice how intricately humor is woven with pathos, and how effortlessly historical fact is melded with emotion. His writing style is amazing. (And this book was a page turner. I read it in about three days.) 
 I left this book feeling educated about South Africa and also moved. Moved by Noah's mother-- her courage as a young woman and her consistency and strength as a mother. And also I was moved by Noah as a writer and as a son. I really respect Noah for the beautiful way in which he depicted his mother's life. 
 The only thing I wish was that there had been a trigger warning for domestic violence --I was not aware of that going into the book, and it was quite frightening to read.

I listened to the audio version and it elevated the book to something wonderful. It was like Trevor was just hanging out telling stories about his life. He had a very hard upbringing but he is able to tell it in a way that doesn't provoke pity. There were some really funny parts, I laughed out loud more than a few times, but overwhelmingly it's a story of the connection between mother and child. I love Trevor even more now.

This book is SO GOOD. So, so good. What an incredibly fascinating and funny insight into growing up in South Africa. It was quick read that perfectly balanced some hard truths with the antics of a young man growing into adulthood. Absolutely phenomenal.

If you're an American, you probably know Trevor Noah as the guy who replaced Jon Stewart on The Daily Show. Unless you've already read this book, I'm guessing you don't know about his childhood growing up in South Africa. 
 Trevor was born to a black mother and a white father. In South Africa, a person of mixed race is called colored. Under apartheid, it was illegal for a black person to have sex with a white person. Having a colored child was concrete evidence that this had occurred. Thus, Trevor was "born a crime." 
 Born a Crime is not a chronological time line of Noah's childhood. Rather, it's organized of snippets related by themes such as going out in public with his white father, church with his ultra-Christian mother, school life and so-on. 
 I was constantly amazed at the events Noah recounted from his childhood - the extreme poverty, his abusive step-father, life during apartheid. Through all of this, his mother remained a steadfast source of unconditional love and support - the kind of mother who would literally take a bullet for her child. 
 Noah's memoir ends when his childhood ends and young adulthood begins. He briefly mentions that his traveling the world performing as a comedian but only because it was essential to understanding a story about him and his mother. He makes no mention of any details about why he chose comedy, how he got his start, nothing. Don't go into this expecting to get any scoop on his career. But here's the thing: Even if Trevor Noah wasn't famous, his memoir would still be extremely compelling as a glimpse into growing up as a colored person in South Africa. It's a miracle that he turned out to be as successful as he is with everything he went through growing up. I was thinking about him for days after I finished this book. 
 I listened to the audio version of this book which made me feel like I was having a conversation (albeit one sided) with him. I love his accent and the accents he did of all the people in his life. Hearing him speak in his mother's accent was delightful. I also liked knowing the correct pronunciation of all of the unfamiliar African words. 
 Born a Crime is one of the best memoirs I've ever read and I predict it will have a high spot on my best of picks for the year. I highly recommend it to all.
Excellent. It's amazing that he is only like 32 years old. love The Daily Show.

I was honestly surprised by how much I loved this book. As a big Daily Show fan who fell off when Trevor Noah took over, I wasn't sure if his humor would be up my alley. I was dead wrong. As I was reading this, I kept telling friends that The Daily Show isn't doing justice to his humor. This book was laugh out loud funny while never minimizing the bizarre and disturbing circumstances of growing up illegal in apartheid South Africa. 
 The book is an incredible tribute to his mother, who is portrayed as bossy, fearless and whip-smart. She's honestly inspiring in how little she cares for the social structures of apartheid that try and hold her back. The two of them are a united front against the ups and downs of life, which Noah writes about eloquently and hilariously. 
 Noah does an especially good job of introducing the structures of apartheid, the geography of his youth and the ups and downs of being someone who never fit in anywhere. Despite the serious nature of the topics, Noah is a world class comedian and makes even the darkest of stories hilarious. I definitely recommend picking this up and reading it, no matter who you are. 
 I received a copy of this from the publisher through NetGalley in exchange for my honest review.
Great insider perspective on growing up Colored in South Africa during Apartheid. It's sincere, funny, and also really sad at times.

Trevor Noah has had an extraordinary life. The fact that his very existence was against the law in apartheid South Africa shows the strength and resilience of his character that he has made it as far as he has in comedy. But more than anything, this book is a testament to the love of a mother and son. You learn very quickly in this book that Noah learned his resilience from his mother and while they didn't always see eye to eye, he clearly got his spunkiness from her.

I'm a long-time fan but I wasn't sure I wanted to read about history; regardless he writes well and it's a great book! 
 I hope he writes more about his career!

What a book. At times laugh out loud funny (like, literally) and other times heartbreaking, Noah writes in the same simple, direct way that he speaks. This may not answer the questions that you may have had about his life, but it explains much of what you need to know about him. 
 Also, his mother is a kickass woman. 
 This is another book that I'm glad to have read during Lent. Highly, highly recommended to any of my friends who see this review.
http://cdnbookworm.blogspot.ca/2017/0...

I really had no idea that Trevor had spent so much time under apartheid, I ignorantly would have thought he was too young for that without thinking about the timeline. His book is a tribute to his mother and begins and ends with his life as her son. I would have loved some more about how he went from traveling stand up to the Daily show. I saw Trevor at a Boston show and he was razor sharp, speaking about race and oppression, witty and thought provoking.

Wow! This is an awesome book, which explains so much of how Trevor runs the Daily Show now. He is a testament to the ability of people to rise up out of oppression, racism, and segregation to become a positive role model. The book does not get to the point of his coming to the US or performing on the Daily Show.

This will go into the annals of best audiobooks for sure! I didn't have much of an opinion on Trevor Noah one way or another before reading this, but his stories are amazing, by turns hilarious and heartbreaking, all told with a deep sense of empathy.

An absolute eye-opening read. Trevor's perspective of his life during and after the apartheid was both frightening and saddening at times to see him as a child and adolescent struggling to find his place in the world. His mother, while at times her choices baffled me, you could easily see that everything she did was in the best interest of her children. Her love and devotion to provide them with a better life is all we all want for our children. It made me laugh, tear up and question my own views. I highly recommend everyone reading Born A Crime.

This is probably one of the best books I've read. Typically, I wouldn't read books about one's life, but it is such a powerful story. Didn't know much about Trevor Noah before, but now I want to know everything. The story came full circle.

I discovered Trevor Noah on Youtube a few months ago while I was preparing for an American politics exam. With his videos, I understood the process of Trump's election and all the insight he had, communicated in his comedic style. 
 With this book, I highly recommend the audio version read by Trevor himself; he quoted his childhood incidents with such a fervor which made me laugh out loud on more than a few occasions. His impersonations are spot-on, which the reader might miss out on if they read the book/e-book. 
 All in all, growing up in the backdrop of the apartheid, it is a story of a motivated young man who beat the odds and succeeded, maintaining his intelligence and brilliant sense of humor all along.

This is one of the first "Celebrity memoirs" I have read, but it is so much more than that. I listened to the audiobook on a recommendation and his narration truly brings the book to life. His stories are enlightening and informative about a time in South Africa's history that we don't seem to learn much about in the United States. The end is gripping and unbelievable (in a good, mind-blowing way). The only slight downside is that I wanted more, I would be interested to learn how he got to be a comedian and eventually the Daily Show. This was an eye-opening experience and everyone should listen to this audiobook.
Trevor Noah has led a very interesting life. I wanted many more details of what happen to him but can understand why he shared what he did.

This book was surprisingly good. Better than good. I didn't know much about Trevor Noah before picking this up, other than the fact that he now hosts The Daily Show. I've never seen him interviewed, I've never seen him on his program, I've never seen his stand-up routine. But I was totally engrossed and emotionally engaged in his story, which he tells with frank honesty combined with humour that isn't flippant. His experiences as a mixed race boy growing up in apartheid and post-apartheid South Africa are unique perhaps to him, but shine an important light on things we white people here in the West glibly assume are not our problems. He has thoughtful reflections on issues of race, language and poverty that do translate to societies outside of South Africa. But the book is not an anti-racism lecture, it is a deeply personal tale-telling of love, loss, family and community. I highly recommend this.
I enjoyed the book! I understand the audio is great because Trevor Noah is the reader! I usually never do audio but would like to listen to him reading.

Heartfelt from start to finish. 
 Listening to Trevor narrate his story is an experience. 
 The book is focused exclusively on his childhood and early adulthood, with little talk on his road to comedic fame. 
 There are reflections about how languages overcome colour, blending in to feel less of an outsider, why it is so difficult to escape the hood, the futility of dwelling over sadness, and even love and relationships through an experience he had with his dog Fifi 
 What this man and his mother have gone through is nothing short of remarkable. 
 The Christian faith his mother has is unshakeable. 
 The last chapter is especially moving, and heartbreaking. 
 Don't read the book, listen to Trevor narrate it.
Amazing on so many levels. Read it.
I loved every second of this book. Gave some interesting perspectives on racism. Highly recommend.

This book explained so much to me about what it was like to live in South Africa during and immediately in the aftermath of apartheid. It should be required reading. Specifically, the relationship between the city, the townships, and the homelands was something I had never understood before. Although parts of the book were funny, other passages were extremely gut wrenching. Trevor Noah is a comedian, but his memoir is not comedy. The way the book is organized is also interesting. It's not chronological; I read it from cover to cover, but one could easily dip into it and read almost any chapter.
Wonderful stories about Trevor Noah's life in South Africa which provide insight into that culture, but a bit chaotic and uneven.

If you know very little about Apartheid, South Africa, growing up where others see you as "colored" and neither black or white or you don't know how funny and heartbreaking Noah is or how much a mother can love a son..... read this book!
Really a great read. Noah provides a lot of background information of South African History which provides context for his story. I highly recommend this book.

I really love this book because the author has led such an eventful life and describes it with great humor. He has a fun style although, at times, the book is sad. He grew up in South Africa in poverty and colorfully describes that experience. I felt touched and inspired by his story and must also add that it's a real page turner. Highly recommended.

A compelling read--I enjoyed this memoir and a look at growing up during Apartheid from the perspective of someone that could not fit in to either white or black culture. Though the chronology of the book was extremely mixed up and confusing, the Noah's insights, stories and perspective were extremely valuable to me as an American who only had a superficial understanding of South Africa's recent history. 
 The editing of this book is the only negative. Trevor's story is cobbled together in a disordered jumble that jumps all over the place in the book's timelines. In spite of the chaos of the book's organization--it was well worth reading. Noah's memoir was in turns heartbreaking, hilarious, hopeful, and frustrating. The lessons learned are insightful and thought provoking.
One of the best books I've ever read. So enlightening, educational, and entertaining.
Fantastic! Refreshing, honest and accessible. Couldn't put it down.

I'm one of Trevor's biggest South African fans, for sure. I love his comedy, particularly his home-grown variety. So it was interesting to read about his childhood growing up my home town, Johannesburg. He gave me a glimpse into a life very different to my own. As the child of a black mother and white father, Trevor was literally 'born a crime' in the Apartheid era, and even after the laws had changed, still struggled to fit in to a society delineated along racial lines. He describes himself as a chameleon, taking on the characteristics of each group he was with at the time in order to fit in. It helps me understand his remarkable gift for getting voices and mannerisms so spot on in his comedy. The book is not as funny as I would have expected, but a rather serious look into a life growing up in a divided society. Ultimately, it's also a tribute to his remarkable mother.
Liked the book. Not sure if I like him.

Very good book with lots of life lessons packed into the humor. This book is also awesome in audio form because it is read by Trevor himself. He brings a levity and authenticity to the read that only he could
If you think Trevor is awesome, meet his Mom.
Both hilarious and heartbreaking. I highly recommend listening to the audiobook, as Trevor Noah narrates, using various accents, speaking in various languages.
I'm really glad I listened to this book via audiobook. It just made the whole experience better (the voices, the accents, the narration itself and the poignancy of the last chapter).

Yet another amazing African memoir. I wasn't terribly familiar with Trevor Noah before listening to this, but I was curious about the "South African childhood" bit of the tagline. Spoiler: Apartheid is/was insane. 
 Noah is an amazing storyteller, and the audio narration is outstanding. He speaks multiple languages, and the accents add to the experience. 
 Only complaint: a smidge of repetition between stories/essays and, at the same time, he failed to tie together stories.

Life is never all bad in spite of circumstances is Trevor's Noah's description of growing up poor, surrounded by poverty, discrimination, and poverty. Trevor Noah, a bi-racial child born during Apartheid in South Africa. Trevor describes his growing up years with humor, and with reflective wisdom that comes after one looks back at events through adult eyes. His life stories are interesting, entertaining, and meaningful. 
 Trevor's rise to stardom is amazing enough, but so is the fact that he survived his childhood. Read the story. It's a quick worthwhile read for anyone who wants a firsthand account of what it was like for a black or colored person during the Apartheid; read it if you are a fan of Trevor Noah.
Really enjoyed this book. It is Trevor's story, but it is really the story of his amazing mother. He would not be where he is today without her.

This was a surprising one. I had heard good things and started reading and found the author to be quite witty. I had no idea when I started who he was and am now looking into him further. Noah's life story was pretty fascinating and gave me a peak inside a world I pretty much knew nothing about. While the background is pretty depressing he tells the story in such a straight up humorous way it was inspiring to see what he's overcome and really made me stop to think about "white privilege". While it was there in the background he doesn't preach or judge on it but rather just tries to show how it is so matter of factly which in turn really made me pause to consider some things.
Excellent.

A fantastic memoir, and you learn a bit about South African politics during and post-apartheid. He touches on so many heavy topics, but his anecdotes from childhood about fitting in and using language to connect with people really struck a chord with me. 
 "Nelson Mandela once said, 'If you talk to a man in a language he understands, that goes to his head. If you talk to him in his language, that goes to his heart.' He was so right. When you make the effort to speak someone else's language, even if it's just basic phrases here and there, you are saying to them, 'I understand that you have a culture and identity that exists beyond me. I see you as a human being"

I'm struggling to put into words the kind of emotional roller coaster Trevor Noah put me through, but it was indisputably worth it. Born into a South Africa of apartheid, yet coming of age after its end, Noah developed incredibly unique perspectives and opinions. Through quirky, hilarious, and often heart-wrenching stories of his boyhood, Noah delves into the complex social and political power struggle that occurs between black and white South Africans--and throughout all of it, tries to find his niche as the product of both.

An amazing book taking us not only through the early life of Trevor Noah but also the craziness and danger of South Africa approaching the end of apartheid. 
 Some bits horrified me, other bits made me laugh out loud (often inappropriately on public transport/when I should have been working etc. etc.). 
 I would thoroughly recommend it. He only way I think it could have been improved for me is that apparently the audio book is read by him. I don't really listen to audio books but I think this one would have been worth it in that format.

Born a Crime was a pure delight to read. Trevor Noah is very witty, charming and of course, funny. I was riveted by his childhood stories and couldn't wait to read more. You may think you know what living under Apartheid was like, most likely, you probably don't. Read Trevor's memoir and you will definitely have a better understanding from his first-hand account. His very existence could have landed him and his entire family in jail. Trevor had to live in isolation and estranged from all races because he didn't fit into any of them but, through it all had the love and support of his fiercely independent mother who made sure to instill good values. This is an uplifting story of a young man who persevered and survived adversity and develops into a very successful man.

Humorous, heart-breaking, and an interesting account of Noah's childhood in South Africa living under apartheid and the aftermath, and his life with his remarkable mother. 'Ass-whoopings' aside, I highly recommend this enjoyable read.

This was a fun but informative memoir by the new host of the Daily Show, who grew up in South Africa under apartheid, surrounded by violence, strong women, and many different cultures and races. Noah is funny (of course, he's a comedian) but clear-headed when it comes to race, and I think this is a painless way for a lot of people to learn a bit about the history of apartheid and race relations there and poverty and segregation. Plus it's a great coming of age story, and a lot of the book is a tribute to his mother, which is awesome.

I read this after seeing it recommended by an author I admire - and I'm so glad I did! Knowing next to nothing about the apartheid in South Africa (and having only a vague awareness of Trevor Noah as a comedian), I not only learned a lot but also connected emotionally to Trevor and his force-of-nature mom. What sets this book apart is the occasionally startling honesty of its narrator. I can see this book as appealing to not only adults but to teens, who will connect to Trevor's conversational way of relating joyful and painful memories alike. Worth a read!

From this book I have found for the first time what apartheid was/is. I have heard the term before as a child but never bother to look it up. Nobody that I know ever talks about this. Makes me question whether it's me being ignorant/totally oblivious or if it's a systematic problem with the western world. 
 The amazing parts of this book are not only Trevor's story but the world in which he grew up. As a true comedian Trevor manages to find the hilarity in all the tragic situations. I have laughed with tears in bed many times as this book has kept me awake. The delivery of the audiobook by Trevor himself has been flawless.

This was the best memoir I've ever read. It's funny and insightful and endearing. The last chapter is worth reading the whole book. Highly recommend. I listened to it on audio read by the author which I think made it even better.

Compulsively readable. Well-crafted and thoughtful; hands down the best memoir I've read. It doesn't fall into the traps of self-pity, self-justification, self-aggrandizing. It tells a story and tells it well. Noah's love and admiration for his mother, as well as the impact she had on his life, shine through. For readers with only a basic (dim) understanding of South African life during and after apartheid -like me- this book offers a window into that place and time. Noah connects the dots between South African racism and US American racism, going straight to the point: race is a social construct, racism is illogical, racist systems steal choices and lives. But this is not a book of theories and definitions; it vividly illustrates those points by describing life for Noah in between the boundaries of color and race, left out of any one category and sometimes benefitting, usually losing out from this murky position. It's enjoyable to read even as it tackles difficult topics, because Noah is so adept at infusing humor everywhere (and he's a great storyteller).

Being the hyperactive, didn't-fit-in kid, the stories Noah tells are incredible--to the point that you finish most every one shaking your head and smiling. And he provides a historical backdrop of South African history of apartheid and race relations. Growing up multi-lingual, his love for his amazing mother shines through.
insights on race and identity and gender in the US and South Africa with great warmth and humor.

I was blown away by this collection of stories. Engaging and honest, with bits of comic relief here and there. I appreciated that Noah didn't try to force all the stories to be haha-funny (a problem I felt with Amy Schumer's book), opting more often for refreshing candor or dark humor. Of course, some of the stories are hilarious (like the one about taking a dump on some newspaper in the kitchen while his blind great grandmother calls out trying to figure what's going on and what's that smell, all because he didn't want to go out in the rain to the outhouse. I was rolling). But the tone is conversational, so it just felt like I was hearing the story from a spectacularly funny friend. Noah offers a lot of insight into race, culture, and society in South Africa. The tales of his life thus far are well-crafted and really interesting. 
 This book is also very much an ode to Noah's mother. She features in nearly every story, offering him guidance and love (and also sometimes weird advice or tough love). It's a loving tribute to her. 
 Highly recommend the audiobook. Noah is an excellent narrator, and it was great to hear him speak so many of the different languages of South Africa.

In Born a Crime, Trevor Noah has done a great job mixing funny anecdotes and first hand South African history. It's a great mix of touching family history and a social commentary on apartheid. While Trevor Noah's youth was never easy because of his mixed race he never let that keep him down. In fact he is the opposite, because of his intelligence and the love and support of his mom, he was able to make the life he has today. Trevor Noah would make his point and move on. He never dragged things out making it virtually impossible to lose interest at any point. He did a great job sharing his early life while still protecting his family's anonymity. I would have liked to know more about his mom and brothers today, just curiosity,but completely unnecessary to the book. It's also a great place to start if you want to learn more about the history of South Africa.

This is the best sort of memoir...funny, sad, educational and inspiring. I have a lot of respect for Trevor Noah after hearing about what sort of life he had growing up. Highly recommend the audiobook version, read by Noah himself.

A memoir that's hard and funny, as well as a quick primer on some of the details of apartheid for audiences who might not be entirely familiar. I feel like I learned a lot, and while parts of it were difficult to listen to, I had a lot of fun. 
 Two minor complaints: 
 1. He does this thing where he starts talking about the next chapter's themes or subject matter at the end of the previous chapter. It started to grate on my nerves by the end of the book, because it was so unnecessary, like a next, on TREVOR NOAH'S MEMOIR tagged on to a thematically different set of stories. 
 2. His stories about his friend Hitler are funny and thought-provoking, but I think it's disappointing that he doesn't give even a sentence over to discovering that Hitler's name was incredibly offensive to people in other parts of the world, or coming to understand why chanting "Go, Hitler! Go, Hitler!" would stop a dance show in a Jewish school. He writes with clarity on the reasons Hitler isn't history's greatest monster for peoples who suffered other atrocities. However, I think that including a line or two about the way his understanding of the Jewish school story changed over time would have kept the incisive point while showing a little more compassion all around. It also left the story feeling a little unfinished for me. He obviously understands now why things ended the way they did--so when did that happen? 
 Highly recommend the audiobook, perhaps to the exclusion of the printed editions. Trevor Noah's as good a reader as he is a news comedian (and a better interviewer than Jon Stewart was), and his way with languages is incredible. I listened to him move between accents and languages for eight hours, and I'm still impressed by it. 
 ALSO PLEASE BE WARNED: TWO CATS SUFFER EXTREMELY UNPLEASANT HARM IN THIS BOOK AND IT WAS UPSETTING. SPECIFICALLY, they're murdered in a violent, horrible way. It's not described gorily, but the description is clear enough that it's easy to picture what happened. It is not fun to picture what happened. I DIDN'T LIKE IT.

Trevor Noah's "Born a Crime" is an outstanding book that everyone should either read or listen to the audio book (as I did). Noah combines personal narrative of his childhood with social, cultural, and political analysis of South African immediately before and after apartheid. Through his own life, he also tells the story of his mother, who fought hard against racism and sexism to give her sons the best lives possible. This is by far one of my favorite nonfiction books to date.

My Review: 4.5 stars 
 Born A Crime tells Trevor Noah's wickedly arduous journey growing up in South Africa as a colored child, half white and half black. He was by law, born a crime, and knew he could be taken from his parents or they could be jailed as well. I don't live under rock and I adore living in fiction, however, I must admit, I had NO IDEA who Trevor Noah was. I was repeatedly asked if I'd read this yet and after each no, I was told, "Good, you must listen to it because of his excellent narration." So I did. 
 First and foremost, I learned so much about apartheid that I didn't know before. I knew the basics, Mandela, the Dutch, the ANC, but this book taught me new information just from his storytelling. Isn't that the best way to learn? Add to that his humor, smarts and charm, and I just wanted to drive all day to hear more. 
 His antics seem to fit the bill that the truth is stranger than fiction. From being thrown from a car, having to attend black church, white church and then black and white mixed church on Sundays, pushing his mom's Volkswagen down the road, driving when he was 6, going to prom with the 'prettiest girl in the world' that wouldn't get out of the car are just a examples of his hardships and sometime humorous trials. On top of this, he was poor, hungry, acne ridden, had low self-esteem and was lonely for friends. 
 His mom was a woman to be reckoned with and I'm certain her life lessons which were often arbitrary and sometimes cruel, were instrumental in making Trevor who he is today. I adored their letter writing back and forth. Honed his writing skills and required thought during an argument! 
 This memoir is not just about The Daily Show host, Trevor Noah, but also about South Africa's tragic history being wrapped up inside him. 
 For more like this visit www.goodbookfairy.com

Excellent! BEST "celebrity" memoir because Trevor Noah actually has a lot to say and recall! He does it with humor, dignity, honesty and hilarity. I listened on audio and it was FANTASTIC. This was very close to five stars but towards the end it felt a little repetitive and needed some editing. Still all the praise, I have the deepest respect for Trevor Noah and especially his mom!!!
Read on audible. Really interesting and entertaining story told by the author.
Hilarious, had me laughing out loud. Yet also moving. Highly recommend.

Wow! This story was beautifully written with the perfect amount of humor and history. It is about growing up under apartheid, not belonging anywhere, but fully belonging to a loving mother. "I chose to have you because I wanted something to love and something good that would love me unconditionally in return-and then I gave birth to the most selfish piece of shit in earth and all it ever did was cry and eat and shit and say, 'Me, me, me, me, me.'" "I became a chameleon. My color didn't change, but I could change your perception of my color." "We tell people to follow their dreams, but you can only dream of what you can imagine, and, depending on where you come from, your imagination can be quite limited."
Good detail of life in post-apartheid Africa for black people. I had never heard of the author but really enjoyed hearing his story. Too much swearing, especially much unnecessary use of the f-word

I listened to this memoir on audio. Trevor Noah reads it himself which definitely added to its impact. 
 It was a fascinating insight into the early life of a mixed race Xhosa-Swiss/German boy growing up in South Africa as the apartheid regime crumbled. He is very insightful, smart and funny and describes some very difficult and challenging situations he faced without bitterness or taking on a victim mentality. 
 Definitely one my top reads of the year and highly recommended

Being the host of the Daily Show, proves that Trevor Noah has "made it." This book gives you a sense of how far he has come. Born in South Africa, the pairing of his black mother and white father was literally illegal. His birth, a crime. Arpatheid was extreme segregation, and the goal was to deny rights, power, and economic success to a majority of the citizens. How do you succeed in a situation like that? Trevor's mom was not having any of it. She was going to do her thing no matter what system of oppression was in place. She is really the most amazing part of this story. Of course Trevor gets some credit too. His mom a great influence, he also knew his father. During his teen years, he lived with a step-father and lost touch with his biological father. The step father was also an influence on Trevor but not a positive one. Regardless, all of our experiences make us who we are and Noah must have needed it all to become himself. This book is really a great love story between mother and son. I found it inspiring.
This was easily one of the best books I have ever read. It is so inspiring and not at all what I thought it was going to be but everything I didn't know I wanted. READ IT!!!!!!

Listened to audiobook - fantastic. One of those books that make you sad when they end because you want to keep on reading. Beautiful stories and lessons from his mom, funny and unbelievable stories about the country and society he grew up in. Loved the honesty and openness about the stories - like who else talks about shitting? :) This book made me laugh out loud but also brought tears to my eyes. Highly recommend.

Hands down, the best read of the summer so far. Engaging, funny and personal story of growing up under Apartheid in South Africa. The book is perhaps unintentionally educational from its many accounts of how racism and prejudice works in a system set up to govern on those merits of birth. Noah was, under the apartheid system, born a crime, since his mother was black and his father was white. Trevor Noah is the comedian who took over Jon Stewart's Daily Show after Stewart's "retirement." One will come away from this book with the upmost respect for Noah's rags to riches story. It is chock full of stories that can be used for any number of discussions on race, crime, politics, domestic violence, and schooling with teenagers 13 years to seniors. The culmination of the book is really as a love letter to his mother; a single mother who against all odds raised a son to be a free and independent thinker in a society of tribal mentalities.

This was such an intriguing look at South Africa. The racial and tribal divisions, the odd housing, and the economic realities of apartheid are all depicted with Trevor's clever humor. His very difficult and dramatic youth is never dull, and just like on The Daily Show, his narrative is peppered with profanity, including F-bombs. If you can get past the latter, this is really worth reading.
This is a fascinating book that explains apartheid like no outsider could. The book sometimes has the quick knock-off feel of a celebrity biography, however.

If you have an issue with language you won't like it but I'd encourage you to get through that because the story was incredible. It's so valuable to me to hear stories like this from people who have lived lives so different from my own.

Trevor Noah coming of age grows up in the hard times of apartheid in several villages of South Africa. 
 His father was a prominent white & his mother of black Xhosa. 
 He also had a stepfather they had to deal with. 
 Taboo at that time & still frowned on somewhat today, you can only imagine. 
 Warning: This book is for adults only & contains extreme violent or graphic adult content or profanity &/or sexually explicit scenarios. It may be offensive to some readers. 
 I did not receive any type of compensation for reading & reviewing this book. While I receive free books from publishers & authors, I am under no obligation to write a positive review. Only an honest one. 
 A very awesome book cover, great font & writing style. A very well written cultural memoir book. It was very easy for me to read/follow from start/finish & never a dull moment. There were no grammar/typo errors, nor any repetitive or out of line sequence sentences. Lots of exciting scenarios, with several twists/turns & a great set of unique characters to keep track of. This could also make another great cultural memoir movie, college PP presentation, or better yet a mini TV series. There is no doubt in my mind this is a very easy rating of 5 stars. 
 Thank you for the free Goodreads; MakingConnections; Spiegel & Grau (Random House LLC.); AUCP; paperback book 
 Tony Parsons MSW (Washburn)

I loved it. So close in age and yet so far in many ways. And then again, so intimate and echoing. What a dance. What a love letter to his mom. What a story of dexterity, of uncertain and yet robust growth. I am so glad he can now shows us how humanity can excel and shine. Thank you Mr Noah. 
 PS: This story will resonate strongly with TCKs...

Born a Crime is the new (and first) book by Trevor Noah in which he tells about his childhood growing up as a mixed child in South Africa during apartheid. In numerous chapters, he recounts stories and anecdotes from his childhood, interspersed with political information, historical background information and commentary. 
 Surprisingly, Noah's career jump to host of the most popular political satire show in the world, The Daily Show, is not mentioned. This isn't an American "from rags to riches" story. This is a story about how comedy, resiliance and creativity can get you through even the worst hardships in life. 
 You can read my full review on my blog: https://www.kimberley-jackson.com/bor...

I listened to the audiobook version of this book. It is narrated by the author, which I fully expected since Noah is a comedian and tv personality. 
 I will freely admit that I was most interested in this book because of Noah's position on The Daily Show. Without that, this book would have never made it on my radar. That being said, I'm glad that I got this book. 
 Hearing about Noah's life growing up in South Africa was fascinating, and I know more about apartheid now than I did before. It is a great book if for nothing else than the first hand account of life under apartheid, especially for a colored boy (that is the term used by Noah and the government of South Africa to describe people who are neither all black nor all white. I apologize if my use of it is offensive.) 
 Read the rest of my review on my blog --> http://justanothergirlandherbooks.blo...

This biography of the author takes place in South Africa after apartheid, and he does a good job of describing his life during it and right after Mandela was released. I don't want to spoil the story with a description of his station in this time period, but you will learn what the title means and its effect on his life. His family situation is tenuous, but his relationship with his mother is fascinating even as her decisions become harmful to all around them. 
 I listened to this book on way to Baltimore this weekend, and one of it's strong points is that Trevor Noah narrates it himself!

Other than his hosting The Daily Show, I knew very little about Trevor Noah before reading Born a Crime. I thoroughly enjoyed it! His writing was very descriptive and frank...even raw at times. I felt as if I were right there with him experiencing his life in South Africa. Definitely a worthy read.
His reading of his brutally honest book with his voices and characterizations was outstanding. Well-thought and sometimes humorous. He brought the situation in South Africa to life for me.

Until I read this book , I had no clue who Trevor Noah was. I don't watch much television (I'd rather read). I bought the book because I was interested in learning more about the people of South Africa , their cultural divisions and unity, and the era he grew up in. Trevor Noah gives a deep , first-hand view of it all. The thing I was most impressed with was his ability, or better said...GIFT, as a true storyteller. This is a book to recommend to friends. Note: If you are easily offended by curse language or the name of Jesus then tread carefully.
Hilarious!

I never sit down and watch The Daily Show, but over the years I have seen quite a lot from people just sharing the videos. Since Trevor Noah took over, very few clips have made their way to me, so I wonder how well the switch from Jon Stewart is going. I imagine it'll take some time for him to find his stride on there, and I do hope he's given the chance, because, from watching his stand-up and reading this book, it's clear he's the type of person that needs to be on American television right now. 
 Trevor Noah was born in South Africa during the apartheid. His father is a white Swiss man and his mother a black Xhosa woman, which is where the title comes in. It was illegal to have a child of mixed-race at the time, and the stories of him growing up with parents who were not allowed to be seen with him in public are heartbreaking, but he also manages to make them hilarious. This whole book is a testament to finding the humour in dire situations. 
 If you're Native American and you pray to the wolves, you're a savage. If you're African and you pray to your ancestors, you're a primitive. But when white people pray to a guy who turns water into wine, well, that's just common sense. 
 One thing I really found interesting was how racial lines were handled during that time. There were, of course, black people and white people. Those of mixed race are classified as coloured in South Africa, which isn't the derogatory term that it is in North America. There are obviously racist attitudes towards those people, but the term itself apparently isn't treated as a slur. But just to drive home how ridiculous the classifications get, for convenience sake everyone was placed into one of these three categories. So Japanese people were labelled as white and Chinese as coloured, for example, and people could apply with the government to have their classification changed depending on their skin shade and economic standing. It really was idiotic, and I believe a lot of those attitudes still exist to a certain extent in the country. 
 This is his story of growing up poor in a country that didn't think he should exist. His father couldn't be seen with him, and his mother had to pretend he wasn't her son or risk him being taken away. He grew up with a violent and unpredictable drunk of a step-father and had a lot to struggle through, but he also grew up with an incredibly strong mother who clearly had a huge influence on him. It's not just his story that's interesting; it's his outlook and the lessons he learned from his family and his life experiences. This isn't a comedy book, it deals with some very dark subject matter, but it's written by someone who can't help but be funny. 
 I would highly recommend the audio book. Trevor Noah is a natural storyteller, his narration of this book is brilliant, and you also get the added bonus of listening to him speak phrases in Xhosa. That's the language with the clicks that you may have occasionally seen Robin Williams mimic, but it really is beautiful and mesmerizing to hear. 
 Nelson Mandela once said, 'If you talk to a man in a language he understands, that goes to his head. If you talk to him in his language, that goes to his heart.' He was so right. When you make the effort to speak someone else's language, even if it's just basic phrases here and there, you are saying to them, 'I understand that you have a culture and identity that exists beyond me. I see you as a human being. 
 Loved every minute of this. If you enjoy memoirs, I don't think you can go wrong with Born a Crime.

When I told people I was reading this, I frequently heard, "yeah, but I don't really like his comedy." 
 This is NOT a comedy. Yeah, it's funny and there were moments when Trevor's mischievous antics had me laughing out loud, but this is a story about being mixed race during Apartheid. 
 This is a fantastic memoir, and everyone should read it.
Loved it. First book I've read that explains what apartheid was like and the politics once Mandela was released. Funny, serious, sad....I'm a Trevor Noah fan.

Probably the most informative book I've ever read. It was an eye opening experience, to learn so much about the apartheid, racisim, misogyny, and the South African culture. Trevor is one amazing story teller, and his experiences are filled with knowledge. What an interesting childhood, what an interesting perspective. 
 My only concern is the order it was written, it could sometimes get confusing since it is not in chronological order. 
 I recommend listening to this book on audiobook, that made the experience way better.
4.5 stars. Parts of the organization felt disjointed, but oh, I loved the storytelling. And it was definitely eye opening to how racism and race relations work in other countries.

I think it is so important for everyone to learn about other cultures and how lucky we are. This is such an interesting story of growing up in the ghetto and learning how to survive in such difficult times and circumstances. What he took from his experiences, he turned into humor and was able to come out the other side as an inspiration to everyone.

I'd been looking forward to reading this memoir, but wow-- I was not prepared for how good it actually was. With so much of the news this past year or so being of the elections here, I had trouble watching the news, (even The Daily Show became too much for me) so my interactions with Noah have been limited. This book, however, confirmed that he is, indeed, a remarkable man, raised by a remarkable woman, and gave me a window into yet another slice of South Africa. I've already retold at least 4 of the stories to different people. 
 (For some reason, I am not getting stars to do a star rating. I would say 4.5, but would round up to a 5 in the rating and add a tag that I did so.)

How did I not review this? I got the audiobook ages ago. This is not a funny book. Well, except maybe the part about his friend Hitler. It's not particularly funny that his mother threw him out of a moving car. Noah's life skirted tragedy. He wasn't white, nor black, nor fully part of any other ethnic group. He did, however, learn all the languages he needed in South Africa.
4.5 stars, Trevor Noah is one of my new favourite people

I must admit that I know embarrassingly little on the subject of apartheid. I was fairly young when Nelson Mandela was freed and I was so far removed from that side of the world that it meant little to me. It wasn't until I read J.M. Coetzee's Disgrace that I took it upon myself to learn something about South Africa and its turbulent history. I still feel woefully unequipped to comprehend, let alone discuss, the ramifications of apartheid, so it was with open, knowledge-hungry arms that I grabbed Born a Crime, Trevor Noah's memoir of growing up as a half-black, half-white citizen in South Africa during and after apartheid. 
 The title is literal: during apartheid, it was illegal for a black person to have sexual relations with a white person. As such, Noah was treated differently than the other children he grew up around. He was kept indoors, so that others wouldn't see a light-skinned child running about. When he went for walks with his mother, she walked behind him and a colored neighbor whose skin more closely resembled his. His grandmother wouldn't punish him like the others because his skin showed bruises, and his grandfather called him "Mastah," though Noah didn't know what that meant at the age of five. 
 What is so interesting to me, as a fellow half-black person, is how different the mixing of races can be perceived depending on location and political environment. While I've certainly had to answer my fair share of "What are you?" questions, I've never felt the intense divide that plagues Noah throughout his life. I've had the luxury of refusing to choose a side, but Noah did not - at times it was literally a matter of life and death for him. Yet, owing to his dual ethnicity, he is privy to the machinations of a society that works to oppress those with darker skin. He can see how arbitrary these ethnic classifications are and how striving for whiteness only furthers animosity between these groups. I was gobsmacked by the idea that individuals could promoted to white: "Your hair might become straight enough, your skin might become light enough, your accent might become polished enough - and you'd be reclassified as white. All you had to do was denounce your people, denounce your history, and leave your darker-skinned friends and family behind." Although I am familiar with "passing" (that is, being light-skinned enough to pass for white), I am not aware of any such promotional system ever existing in the US. But in a way this still hits a bit of truth for me, for this is the plight of many mixed race people - society forces you to choose a side and deny a part of who you are. 
 For all of the brilliant edification Noah gives us on living in and after apartheid, rest assured that he also includes a fair bit of self-deprecating humor in these pages. His pawn-shop hustle is impressive, though ultimately self-defeating, and I've rarely felt so embarrassed for a person as I did when he talks of a major social blunder during his days as a DJ doing dance battles (I won't spoil it, but it's a good one). But even within the humor, Noah manages to excavate a lesson in humanity in every story. He is admittedly not smooth with the ladies in high school, and even though he managed to get the most beautiful girl he and his friends had ever seen to go to prom with him, he couldn't convince her to get out of the car because he never bothered to find out that they didn't speak the same language. It's a fitting metaphor for the environment in which he grew up. 
 This is a story about politics and social strife, but ultimately it is one about family. For all his bad behavior as a child, Noah is always in awe of his mother's strength, and never more so than when he talks about the period of their lives where they suffered at the hands of his abusive stepfather. The story he tells will chill you, and though it should not be surprising that a society still living in segregation would also work to subjugate its women, I could not help but be appalled by the events he chronicles. And then I was saddened, because I know that this continues to go on today and I know this is happening here, just as much as it is happening there, and we are still so far from finding a way to fix it. Noah isn't so bold as to suggest a cure for the patriarchy any more than he is to suggest a cure for systemic racial oppression, but in talking about his mother's abuse so openly, so plainly, he gives voice to those who cannot be heard. He is doing for others what his mother did for him: 
 My mom raised raised me as if there were no limitations on where I could go or what I could do. When I look back I realize she raised me like a white kid--not white culturally, but in the sense of believing that the world was my oyster, that I should speak up for myself, that my ideas and thoughts and decisions mattered... the highest rung of what's possible is far beyond the world you can see. My mother showed me what was possible. The thing that always amazed me about her life was that no one showed her. No one chose her. She did it on her own. She found her way through sheer force of will. 
 Many of you already know Noah from his assumption to The Daily Show's throne and you may have already formed certain opinions of him. I encourage you put aside whatever feelings you have about his work to read this informative, heartbreaking, and inspiring book. 
 (Note: I was able to snag a free copy of the audio during an Audible promotion and listened to it while reading along. I highly recommend it, as Noah's voice adds to so much his own story. It was also great to hear his pronunciation of names and words I wouldn't even begin to know how to say.)
