This book should be mandatory reading for everyone! Not only is Trevor's life story fascinating, he is also a master at describing the social, political, and cultural context of his childhood. I learned so much about apartheid, race, and class in South Africa. Trevor is charming, funny, thoughtful, and intelligent all at once in this first memoir. I strongly suggest the audiobook version; because he himself narrates it, the audiobook adds another layer to this already wonderful masterpiece. I hope he goes on to publish the rest of his story!

I was not expecting much from this, but it's a great read. Very entertaining, lots of laugh-out-loud parts especially in the beginning, and more serious stuff in the second half. Very educational as I knew nothing about apartheid or life in South Africa, and filled with thought-provoking insights. His mother is quite a woman, and Trevor himself quite the man. I highly recommend this.
Fascinating!

I thoroughly enjoyed this book. While telling a story about himself, Noah ultimately wrote a love letter to his mother, who became as much the center of the story as the author. It's hard to imagine being "born a crime" (or maybe not in the current political chaos and burgeoning xenophobia in this country). Having been born to a black mother and Swiss father, Noah was kept hidden for his early years for fear of being taken by the government. The majority of the book deals with him trying to figure out his place in society----with the black kids, white kids, Indian kids and so on. More often than not, as a child he finds that because of his lighter skin, he has trouble fitting in but finds ways to do so with humor and an ability to pick up many of the languages spoken by the different groups in South Africa. Along the way, though, the reader is introduced to his mother and her strong dedication to faith, her fierce independence and the fight she faced as a woman in a male dominated society---one in which it was considered okay to strike your wife without fear of legal action. (Spoiler: The step father even attempts to kill his mother and got 3 years probation and walks free today!) 
 The book is a charming, quick read and gives you a sense of how Trevor Noah ended up where he did. He's an intelligent, hardworking young man who was backed by a mother who shaped him that way. If you enjoy his late night talk show or just enjoy a good biography, you will not be disappointed. Highly recommended!

I didn't even know who Trevor Noah was before grabbing this audiobook when it was free on Audible. I'm glad I downloaded it, though; his mom seems like a treasure to know and he seems to have a good attitude about life. I enjoyed listening to it.

You have to read this book. And when I say read, I mean listen to it because the audiobook is the way to go. It's filled with insight and wisdom, hilarious, laugh out loud anecdotes, and vivid descriptions about a life and culture many of us can't even imagine.

4.5 stars for opening my eyes. Noah shares perceptive, intelligent and compulsively readable stories about his childhood and race in South Africa during and post Apartheid. This is an important book to read and apply to discussions of race in America today. The best thing is that it's so enjoyable to read. Noah is hilarious and was admittedly a very naughty child. 
 One of my favorite parts is where Noah talks about how everyone says if you teach a man to fish, he'll be able to eat for the rest of his life. Noah points out that if that man is poor he still needs someone to give him a fishing rod or he's not going to catch any fish. 
 One of the best books I've read all year.

A really insightful look into what it was like to grow up in South Africa during apartheid and coming of age as Nelson Mandela was transforming the country. Full of Trevor's marvelous humor and astute understanding of social relationships. Great read!

Wow. Just incredibly moving. I listened to this on audible and loved hearing all the accents and languages that populated Noah's childhood. I wasn't prepared for how sad and tragic the story was (which upon reflection was silly... I mean he grew up poor under apartheid in South Africa). I loved his analysis as well as his story. He deftly explains the effed up logic of apartheid, living in the slums, 'milder' post-apartheid racism, the deficiencies in his education, and petty criminality.
Amazing. Funny, poignant, well written and really well told by him in the audiobook. I actually really recommend the audiobook for his bits of various spoken African languages. Really interesting.

I didn't want the stories to end! 
 I loved everything about this book and story. Learning more about the humble beginnings of Trevor Noah, about apartheid, about segregation by colour and township and so many other nuances about growing up and existing in South Africa during and after apartheid. His Mom's faith, traditions, Trevor's antics and many different stories keep you captivated from beginning to the end. A highly recommended read via Audible for Trevor's voice and dialect of him and others. So many languages. A truly fascinating book.
3+ I'm a big Trevor Noah fan. The book was very interesting and showed South Africa in a way I hadn't read about it before.

Trevor Noah is the guy that took the place of Jon Stewart on The Daily Show. I mostly saw him on Facebook pre-election and thought he was hilarious so decided to check out his book. He was born in South Africa and he talks a lot about Apartheid. During Apartheid, it was illegal for a white person and a black person to be together and a person could go to jail if they were found out. Trevor was born to a white father and a black mother, hence the title of the book. Trevor loves his mother and she is hilarious. You can see where he gets his sense of humor, although I don't think his mother even knows she is funny. I wish there would have been pictures, but they were so poor they maybe didn't have money for film or even a camera. Trevor really doesn't get into how he came about coming to America or how he came to get the job at the Daily Show. Perhaps, that is for another book.

There was so much more to this book than I expected. I picked it because I was looking for something easy and entertaining. It was that, but it was also informative and compelling. Trevor Noah is the real deal.

I enjoyed hearing about his growing up in Apartheid South Africa and the changes that have happened since then. He has given so much credit to the positive support of his mother and family. An enjoyable read.

To be honest, before I read this book, I knew little about Trevor Noah or, more embarrassingly, apartheid South Africa. This book was completely enlightening and one of the best memoirs I have read in years. I would also highly recommend listening to the audiobook. Trevor Noah reads it himself and because he is fluent in so many languages, he uses different languages to tell his story. Hearing those words in his own voice brought something special to the story and made me appreciate it so much more. Even though apartheid might sound like a depressing and somber subject, Trevor Noah tells the story of his upbringing with a lighthearted humor that I really enjoyed. Excellent book.

LOVED the audio book version... this book is definitely best listened to rather than read. I've never really known that much about apartheid, so this was a great opportunity to learn more about it. Plus Trevor is right about my age, so it was cool hearing about his growing up experiences in the 90s in comparison to mine. Very much recommended!!!!

Born a Crime by Trevor Noah was a good read. This is Trevor Noah's story of being born to a white Swiss father and a black Xhosa mother. He was born at a time when this union was punishable by five years in prison. I enjoyed reading about Trevor Noah. There was not only some serious parts but many comical ones.
His narration is great - I listed to the audiobook. Learned a lot about South Africa.

Trevor Noah is an engaging and funny storyteller, which should come as no surprise to Daily Show fans or those who've followed his career in comedy. What was surprising was the variety and depth of the stories he had to tell. Noah grew up the son of a black mother and a white father, during and after Apartheid, and his experiences chronicle not only his own history, but that of the country, as both he and his nation try to untangle the changing race signifiers and relationships that form the core of South African identity. 
 While the historical context is certainly absorbing in itself, the memoir is at its best when Noah is taking his time to let a small tale unfold, like the one about his six-year-old self electing to shit on the floor of his one-room house, rather than face the cold and rainy walk to the outhouse, only to find himself the center of a circle of hysterical women convinced the turd was the work of an evil spirit. These anecdotes illuminate daily life in a general sense but also create the specific history of Trevor's own life trajectory, which is both informed by the cultural touchstones of his childhood and also unique to him, with his unusually strong-willed mother and movement among various class, race, ethnic, linguistic, social, and economic groups.

Smart, sweet, tender, and funny - Trevor Noah's memoir looks at his early life, growing up in South Africa during & right after the apartheid. He writes just like he talks, and you can hear him narrating the book as you go (or you can get the audiobook & literally hear him narrate the book). I read a review a while back that said this book was like a love letter to his mother - and I honestly can't describe it any better than that. 
 Definitely recommend this to everyone! 
 Huge thanks to Penguin Random House Canada for the book!

A great and interesting memoir. One filled with humor and so much love. I am astounded and impressed with Trevor's mother, who is central to this book, and his love and gratitude for her and all she did for him. I also found his reflections on race timely and relevant to race issues here in the states. An excellent book!
Loved this book. I thought the author wrote in a unique, insightful voice. Funny and powerful stories of his life growing up in South Africa

I believe Trevor Noah is a great comedian and obviously a great story teller. He told a great story about life during the apartheid and technically being a considered a crime. I love his Mom and her free spirit especially when she married Abel and proved that NO MAN is going to run her over. I appreciate how his Mom used humor in everything especially with raising him. I do that with my son. Overall, I laughed, cried (at the end) and reflected deeply about myself and my life. So thank you Trevor for that. #ForeverAFan
Very interesting and well done. A little slow for me but I enjoyed learning about cultures that I previously knew next to nothing about.

I loved this book. I don't know that much about South Africa, so a lot of the words and cultural references were brand new to me. 
 On the other hand, some of the sections describing being mixed race resonated with me really hard. "I saw myself as the people around me" is a line that has stuck with me. 
 The relationship with his mom is really touching and I also remember this line "Love is a creative act." 
 Overall this book is funny, and heartfelt, and informative. Also, audiobook is definitely the way to go; he does voices and accents, and it's a great performance too.
4.5 - I listened to the audiobook of this, and I highly recommend it.

I listened to this book on audiobook - and it's absolutely the way to go. Trevor Noah is a masterful storyteller, and his voice brings the characters to life. There were lines in this book that have quite literally changed my life and how I view the world. It's perfect for an entry-level into examining privilege and what it means to be "different." I haven't stopped thinking about this book since I started it.
Absolutely WONDERFUL!

Had to read it nonstop bec it was due. Fascinating - a love letter to the townships and a bracing indictment of oppressive police state if Apartheid. It's a society we Americans know almost nothing about viewing it as we do from the outside. 
 This book is the ultimate in showing how the political is personal. But the reason it's stayed so poplar is that it's a nostalgic, sweet and funny remembrance of his childhood and youth. Episodes are recounted that anyone can identify with. Then he shows you the twist- how the situation is actually quite awful due to institutionalized racism or cultural sexism or practiced colorism. This guy cannot escape the ramifications that come with the color of his skin no matter where he goes. It's absolutely CRAZY but every one goes along with it so he deals and hustles as best he can. 
 His personal reflections coupled with the history lessons he gives- with a full context so you can understand the devastation caused and how it underpins present inequities- well I like to be educated about what has really happened- don't you? - make this book truly unique. It's both a readable irreverent personal history and a cry of rage and bitterness at the loss of all that could've been and could be in the aftermath of Apartheid. 
 READ IT!!

This book was awesome. I listened to it and Tevor Noah does an amazing narration (not always true of the author, even when the author is in show biz). His story is fascinating and I learned so much--not just about South Africa and apartheid, but also life lessons that seemed to apply to me and where I'm at now. 
 So, so good. Highly recommended. Can't sing it's praises enough.
Superb, funny, very real.

great listen; read by the author. only covers his life to his early 20s, much more about his family of origin, experiences growing up in South Africa than fame and success as a comic and TV personality. offers some great sociological insights on the stupidity of racism, the value of literally speaking another's language, and the blowback of segregation and poverty. 
 an homage to his mother
The audiobook made it what it is, the voices and languages were brilliant. Amazing stories, great history, fantastic people.

As soon as I read the first chapter of this book I had to buy it. I have never been a fan of Trevor Noah's stand up work but this memoir of truly remarkable. The book shines a spot light into the horrible living conditions in South Africa during the Apartheid era. For those who don't know what Apartheid it's a system of racial segregation in South Africa enforced through legislation by the National Party (NP), the governing party from 1948 to 1994. Under apartheid, the rights, associations, and movements of the majority black inhabitants and other ethnic groups were curtailed, and white minority rule was maintained. What makes this book so good is that its full of facts of this dark era in South African history. He manages to bring humor and yet remain stern on his true feelings on how South Africa in itself has been a racial battle ground since the 1st and 2nd Boer war. 
 The book is full of quotes some funny and some sad but they leave the reader thinking. 
 "Language, even more than color, defines who you are to people." - Trevor Noah 
 This is a good example of one that stuck to me. Being a bi-lingual minority Trevor hit a nerve in me while reading this. I have shared those same thoughts and feelings of confusion while being judged for various difference. One of my favorite parts of the book is when Trevor speaks about selling mix-tapes and illegal pirating music to sell to locals. This same chapter speaks of his friend nicknamed "Hitler". Who in their defense, they had no idea of the genocide that Hitler was doing in Europe. They were never taught such history, rather in fact they were convinced that Hitler was just another powerful "White man" attempting to gain power. 
 If you read essays and books such as Africa's World War: Congo, the Rwandan Genocide, and the Making of a Continental Catastrophe. You'll understand that what happened to Jews during WWII has been on going issue in this Continent so to a South African Hitlers WAR was just another historical fact to memorized for a school exam and quickly erased and replaced with the new Western Hip Hop influence. 
 "I was blessed with another trait I inherited from my mother, her ability to forget the pain in life. I remember the thing that caused the trauma, but I don't hold onto the trauma. I never let the memory of something painful prevent me from trying something new. If you think too much about the ass kicking your mom gave you or the ass kicking that life gave you, you'll stop pushing the boundaries and breaking the rules. It's better to take it, spend some time crying, then wake up the next day and move on. You'll have a few bruises and they'll remind you of what happened and that's ok. But after a while, the bruises fade and they fade for a reason. Because now, it's time to get up to some shit again." - Trevor Noah

This is an AMAZING book!!!! I listened on audio so I got the full benefit of Noah reading and portraying his family and the people of South Africa. I highly recommend this version-- or any version!! I will never forget this story.

4.5/5 
 Before reading this my knowledge about Trevor Noah was next to nothing. I ended up laughing out loud and was fascinated by his stories. At first the bolded tidbits before the beginning of the stories were slightly annoying but as the book progressed I found them more and more insightful. I thoroughly enjoyed this book and the end had me reading frantically in the best way. it's not all humor and it's not all sad stories and it all blends together seamlessly.

Born a Crime is a perfect mix of hilarious, heartbreaking, and introspective stories of tough childhood. Trevor's misadventures as a kid are relatable, his insecurities as a teen draw a knowing smile, and yet he shows the reader a world so different to anyone who has not lived through South African apartheid. I am so very moved by Trevor's mother Patricia Nombuyiselo Noah, who has so much wisdom, kindness, and faith in goodness of people. Through all the things she went through, she remained strong and selfless; she was driven to succeed despite odds and circumstance, and gave the best life to her family that she could get. That woman is a hero, and she raised a good son.
Good book - sometimes skipped around too many times and left me with many questions, but enjoyed it

Within the first twenty pages of this book, I regretted just two days earlier writing the sentence "Trevor Noah, while smart and funny, doesn't feel like a must-watch" while lamenting how much I miss Jon Stewart. 
 This is perhaps the most remarkable celebrity memoir I've ever read. I am a hyperbolic person by nature, but I'm really hard pressed to remember one that's made this big an impression on me. Not just because of the content--which is at times heartbreaking and mindblowing--but also because of the humor and warmth with which Trevor Noah's managed to convey some very difficult life experiences. 
 Born in South Africa in the mid '80s, Trevor Noah's very existence as a biracial child was illegal. Even though apartheid fell while he was still a child, he faced unique challenges due to his ill-defined racial identity. He stood out as light-skinned in the poverty stricken black neighborhoods, but that didn't mean that he was spared the poverty or the prejudice faced by anyone who wasn't white. 
 Noah introduces each of his stories with a little bit of background information on the political climate and culture of South Africa. Then he describes different phases of his life through that lens, looking at how his childhood friendships, early attempts at romance, and a sometimes turbulent family life: His mother remained single by choice until Noah was around 10, then she married a man with a violent temper and he lost touch with his birth father. 
 It's not all bleak, though. Some of the stories are just about the hi-jinks that a teenaged Noah got into with his friends. It should not surprise you to know that he was a bit of a troublemaker and a hustler in his youth. 
 But even when he's describing some unimaginable difficulties, Noah managed to make me laugh SO MUCH. His solution to his fear of using an outhouse shared by several other families in his grandmother's neighborhood? Ridiculous. The time that he didn't realize that his date to the school dance didn't speak the same language as him? Hilarious. His response to his mother throwing him out of a moving vehicle because she was afraid that the driver of the minibus was going to kill them? Shouldn't be funny, but it was. 
 But, the story that killed me was the one where he realized just how problematic his friend Hitler's name is. 
 This is the kind of book that knocked my worldview around a little bit. I always knew that, yes, life under apartheid was hard, but Noah showed me just how hard, in a very visceral and personal way. He also showed how the shadow of apartheid lingered long after Nelson Mandela walked free, something that's easy to forget. But what he really does so well here is demonstrate the power of human resilience. He gives so much credit to his mother, which seems to phenomenally deserved. But as amazing a portrait as he paints of her, I'm left with a newfound respect for Trevor's own ability to overcome and succeed against the odds. And to do so with a straight head and an amazingly funny sense of humor? Blows my mind. I gotta start watching The Daily Show every night again.

What an outstanding book, made even more meaningful, since I listened to it on CD, read by the author. The book is heartfelt, heartrending, funny, and riveting from beginning to end. And, there are many ruminations on life and society that are spot-on. This is one of the best books I have ever listened to, and I have been listening to books on tape or cd for almost 22 years. This book is one of the best I have either read or listened to in the past several years.

I chose to read Noah's autobiography because biracial stories are so rarely told. As Noah said, our lives defy a system of racism, point out its flaws, and thus are outcast. Listening to Trevor's stories of the isolation and difficulty of being biracial made me feel less lonely.
Review for audiobook ~ 4 stars story * 5 stars narration

I am not sure there is any voice more relevant than Trevor Noah's at this moment in history. I just finished Born a Crime: Stories from a South African Childhood and I am more fascinated by him than ever. If we want to learn anything about how to handle our current political climate, we should listen to him. Growing up first under apartheid and then in the shadow cast by apartheid, the child of a black Xhosa mother and a white Swiss father, he was seen as an outsider in every group in South Africa, but he found a way to relate on many occasions to every group on a personal level. His commentary on what a common language will do for understanding and building relationships is astounding. His sense of humor, his relationship with his mother, his perspective on life in South Africa are all highlighted in this book and it is endlessly fascinating. This book focused on his life before his success and I really hope he writes another book on how he started his stand-up career and became a success. He is so smart and so introspective. As I finished his book today, the New York Times published an op-ed from him about how we need to start finding a middle ground because division is being used to destroy us. Listen to him folks. He is the real deal!

One would be forgiven for thinking this book was written by a full time author. It was only after reading that I checked and discovered the author was a comedian. Well, that should explain the humour aplenty in the book... 
 Born a Crime tells the story of a mixed boy growing up under South African Apartheid. Although littered with plenty of funny quips and rib cracking statements, Born a Crime does not fail to give a vivid overview of the racial system that so dominated the entire South African system. 
 The book is written from the POV of the author, who is the subject of the book. The writing is not static, neither is it progressive like normal prose. The prose jumps from different events and scenes, following a trend of linked themes, rather than chronicling events in a linear manner. 
 The story is an apartheid eye opener. The evils, intricacies, ironies and grim facts of the system are in stark contrast with the matter-of-factly manner in which it is delivered. The end result is a hilariously chilling expose into the unbelievably tough upbringing of a young boy of mixed heritage in South Africa. 
 As I commence my post-read mullings, I cannot help but wonder how it would have been for me, growing up in such circumstances. The ironic thing is that many Africans can draw parallels with Trevor Noah's upbringing, even if only in the slightest of ways. One begins to realise that the African experience is quite similar even in places as distant from the other as Nigeria and South Africa. 
 Highly recommended!

Definitely in the running for my favorite book of 2017. Must have read at least a quarter of it out loud to my husband, "Listen to this...!!" I think it would be a great text for U.S. classrooms - a tool to talk about racism and discrimination here, by comparing our history to South Africa's. (It might make the topic feel more approachable, with a kind of side door into the conversation.)

If, like me, you know basically nothing about Trevor Noah except that he's cute and has a peculiar accent and replaced your favorite guy ever on TV, this memoir will blow your mind. What a crazy life he's lived.

** spoiler alert ** 
 Trevor Noah has taken a lot of heat for not "getting" the issues that face Black America. Not being a black American, I couldn't say whether or not that heat is justified, but I think it bears reminding that this man grew up a mixed race child in South Africa during apartheid. It's just possible that his perspective is valid. 
 In the final chapter, and I'm not marking this as a spoiler because it's also on his Wikipedia page so it's not like it's a twist ending, Noah describes the abusive marriage that led to his mother being shot in the head by her ex-husband. This whole episode is absolutely miraculous. The gun misfires several times when he holds it to her head and as she tries to get away and the bullet actually fires, it misses every major artery and vein and her brain and she spends only 4 days in the hospital. And yet Noah talks about the incident wondering why God allowed it to happen, rather than considering the miracles that saved her life. He acknowledges that he can't explain what happened, but treats it as a "silly mom, thinking it was her prayers that saved her." God is trying to get your attention, Trevor! 
 Also, I love Noah's accent. Listening to this on audio definitely increased my enjoyment of it. Thanks, Goodreads and Audible, for the free audiobook!
Absolutely fantastic book!

Trevor Noah tells of what life was life growing up in apartheid South Africa. He was considered an outsider with a Swiss father and black mother. He was a curious boy and always getting into trouble. He shared lots of funny stories that open the way to understanding poverty, violence and racism. I loved listening to him talk about his mother and how much faith she had. I listed to Trevor Noah narrate his story and was not disappointed. A great listen. 
 "We live in a world where we don't see the ramifications of what we do to others because we don't live with them. It would be a whole lot harder for an investment banker to rip off people with subprime mortgages if he actually had to live with the people he was ripping off. 
 If we could see one another's pain and empathize with one another, it would never be worth it to us to commit the crimes in the first place." 
 -- Trevor Noah, Born a Crime

This book is an absolute must read. It's entertaining to the max. He has had the most colorful existence, abundant ups and downs. It's full of unique views that I've never witnessed. I felt inspired and uplifted. Even though, he's been through tragedy and hardship, he never looses his easy going personality. These personal stories are truly great, lots of comedy and phenomenal storytelling. Also, I respect him for being such a go getter in life.

I listened to the audio book version of this performed by Trevor Noah himself(Highly recommended) and it was enjoyable. The accents were great and consistent for all the different characters in the book. As a book about his life, I was so grateful that he gave us the glits and the grit with the grit dominating and I was largely surprised at how rough he had it growing up. Patricia Noah is AMAZING! She's an original African tiger mum and her story is incredible. 
 Thank you for sharing so much Trevor.
Interesting, funny, and insightful about a boy's life in South Africa
Learned a lot about South Africa. Excellent examination into defining race.

I am such a huge fan of Trevor Noah and was also surprised he became Jon Stewart's predecessor but I now see why... Trevor Noah is an extremely intelligent and funny individual. This book is one of the best I've ever read, well written and definitely put a descriptive picture in my mind as I read cover to cover. I also can appreciate how he grew up in such a tumultuous time in South Africa. As a Native American, his story parallels with my up bringing growing up on a reservation and going to the city for economic reasons. An excellent read.

I am glad that I got this as an audio book because hearing Trevor Noah read it definitely added to the story. This book had me laughing out loud more than any book I've read in a long time, but is also touching as well as a no-nonsense look at the after effects of apartheid and racism.

I never watch TV. Consequently I had never heard of this guy. But when a friend with a general good taste recommended it to me (probably without having read it) I followed her advice. And I must say that the result is rather good. It's a biography, which is far from my preferred genre, and an autobiography, just to make it worse. I was wondering what a young comedian can tell about himself. And the answer is quite a lot. In many instances it's more a story about apartheid, about being a mixed race guy in a society which was structured by clear colour lines, which colour is his? It's an honest description of late-apartheid South Africa and early post-apartheid South Africa. It's a story of female rebellion and gender violence. It's a story of poverty and fight for success. It doesn't have high moral intentions other than telling. Noah is not the redeeming kind, but has a sense of lawfulness and right. He succeeds in making a book out of his life with enough pep to keep you alive and wanting to read.

This is so good. SO GOOD! I listened to the audio version, which Trevor reads, and I expected a somewhat light/funny book. There are funny moments, but this is a truly good memoir about a fascinating childhood in South Africa. I will never look at him the same way (and I look at him most days because I am a faithful viewer of The Daily Show.) If you have access to the audio version, definitely listen to it. It feels like you are sitting down with him over coffee as he tells you his life story, and it's riveting. Highly recommend!
Incredibly interesting and a fascinating look at not only Mr. Noah's life, but South Africa, and race.
Couldn't put it down! Brilliant storytelling!

This was such an interesting and entertaining book. I learned so much about apartheid in South Africa and the horrors of it with truly funny stories intertwined. It is amazing how Trevor can see the good and funny in such a horrible time in history. I would definitely recommend this book, it taught me so much I never knew while making me laugh out loud along the way.

I anticipated a funny, light book, and it wasn't that at all. It was better. In fact, it far exceeded my expectations, with Trevor Noah's effortless braiding of comedy and tragedy. I'll be thinking about these stories for a long time. 
 I highly recommend the audiobook, because Noah's narration adds so much to the experience.
Honest and hilarious. I am now a fan of the author and his show.
A humorous look at Noah's upbringing in apartheid South Africa. Personal stories are mixed with reflections on that society. His mother's love is the predominant theme.

"Truth is stranger than fiction, but it is because Fiction is obliged to stick to possibilities; Truth isn't." - Mark Twain 
 I feel like Trevor Noah's life embodies and proves that quote true. He's an incredible human being who has thus far lived an incredible life that is so crazy, funny, heartbreaking that it feels like it's made up, but it isn't. 
 I loved this book. It was great, almost as great as the man who wrote it and the mother who raised him.

Trevor has managed to own together a great memoir of his formative years in South Africa. Not only was I was shown a very realistic image of apartheid but also of life in the slums. The many stories in the book made me laugh as well as brought tears. Which would definitely make this book a 5 star experience.

I received an advanced digital copy from NetGalley in exchange for an honest review. 
 Trevor Noah writes a very absorbing and straightforward memoir that talks about the atrocities of apartheid, what it was like to grow up feeling like you don't belong, and figuring out at a young age that the world is not confined to what you see around you. This could have very easily been a very solemn read but Noah infuses this light-hearted quality throughout all these stories that he recounts in his book. Even the very end when his mother is in the hospital, he and his mother are able to laugh at the horrible things that have happened to them. 
 On that note, Noah's mother is one of the strongest and most resilient people I've ever encountered. Her upbringing truly transformed Noah's perspective on life and you can very clearly see the influence she's had on his life. I really enjoyed reading this memoir because it not only talked about the hardship and obstacles Trevor Noah faced but also brought out his uniquely distinct situation. All the ups and downs in this book made it a very engrossing read.

A lighthearted and sincere memoir by Trevor Noah, a South African comedian and current host of The Daily Show. In Born a Crime, Noah details his experience growing up in apartheid South Africa, where his parents - a black Xhosa mother and a white Swiss father - committed an illegal act just by conceiving him. Throughout this memoir, Noah shares many funny coming-of-age stories, ranging from his awkward first romantic encounters with girls as well as how he once set a neighbor's house on fire. While he maintains a jocular tone throughout the book, he also delves into more serious topics, such as the racism and discrimination he faced and witnessed as a child, the negative effects of colonialism on South Africa, and his mother's abusive second husband. This quote captures the concept of "the black tax," and it features just one slice of how much Noah cherishes and commemorates his mother in Born a Crime: 
 "So many black families spend all of their time trying to fix the problems of the past. That is the curse of being black and poor, and it is a curse that follows you from generation to generation. My mother calls it 'the black tax.' Because the generations who came before you have been pillaged, rather than being free to use your skills and education to move forward, you lose everything just trying to bring everyone behind you back up to zero. Working for the family in Soweto, my mom had no more freedom than she'd had in Transkei, so she ran away. She ran all the way down to the train station and jumped on a train and disappeared into the city, determined to sleep in public restrooms and rely on the kindness of prostitutes until she could make her own way in the world." 
 I only have a couple of criticisms of Born a Crime. Its structure felt a bit disorienting, as Noah jumps back and forth in time without any real reason for doing so. This jumbled chronology, while not super appealing, does leave room for another book by Noah, as he does not explore his comedic career in depth. His consistently cheerful tone also did not sit well with me at times. While Noah may just be a generally bubbly and optimistic person - which I respect a lot, considering the hardships he's overcome - there were chapters in which I wanted more introspection, more nuance, and more emotional vulnerability. For example, the last chapter that focused on his mother's abusive relationship moved me, but it felt odd that all of those events got squeezed into one sequence at the end, when they could have been woven in throughout the book. 
 Overall, a great memoir from an important voice in society today. Recommended to fans of Trevor Noah, to those who like coming-of-age stories, and to those who do not mind a lighter memoir with more humor than melancholy. Glad to see so many Goodreads folk getting into this one.

Such a wonderful read that offers a glimpse of life in South Africa but also a look into how complicated choices around identity can be when intertwined with state-sponsored racism and it's aftermath. Trevor Noah's life has been a fascinating one thus far and I'm so glad that he chose to share it. His descriptions of living and "working" in the slums seem to parallel what our young people struggle with in the states as well and I think the insights he offered in this book have made me a better teacher as a result.

To be honest, I didn't really have the highest expectations for this book. I was expecting the whole "I always had dreams to be big and here's my journey to my Hollywood career." Those stories can be great, however this even better. The Daily Show was never mentioned. This book had its funny moments where I was laughing so hard I had tears forming. But it also had the parts which explained the political, social and economic impacts of post Apartheid South Africa. It gave a brief overview of the history of European invaders and tribal rivals. Those are the parts that really stuck with me. 
 One of the most important things reading can offer us is to force us to stop and think. This book made me do that many times. I highly recommend.

What a beautiful, beautiful book. I thoroughly enjoyed reading Trevor Noah's story, learning a lot about South African history and apartheid that I never knew. Growing up in such a divided society made Noah who he is today; never knowing what group to claim made him able to put his feet in all circles. This was as much a story of survival as it was about climbing out of poverty through hard work and industry. Born a Crime is really a dual story: one of not only his life, but that of his mom's. Noah is blessed to have the mother that he has. This woman? Ferocious love. Tough love. Strong, independent and hard working, his mom is someone I want to know. His mom is someone I want to be. Highly recommended.

I strongly recommend the audiobook. Hearing Trevor Noah's voice do all the different accents, speak in different languages and even sing adds another dimension to this passionate and well written childhood memior. 
 As an added bonus, I learned so much about apartheid and South Africa's history!

As good as everyone said it would be. Trevor Noah is smart and funny and a fantastic storyteller. Can't tell how much of the book was ghostwritten (he gives credit to someone else for helping him get it on the page) but the book transports you to his childhood in South Africa and immerses you in the culture. The descriptions and characters are incredibly well-wrought and I learned a lot about apartheid that I didn't know before. His insights on race and class are eye-opening and thought-provoking; and his stories about family and friendship are entertaining and poignant. Can't wait to see how he and his career evolve.
One of the finest biographies. The narration was great and the success he achieved after all the hardships was phenomenal. Big fan of Trevor.

It was a thoughtful and funny book in which Trevor Noah bears his soul. There were fabulous stories about his growing up in South Africa through the end of apartheid. Made me really see how impossible the living situations were before and after apartheid through humor and honest evaluation. Noah said something that I hadn't thought about. He talked about the analogy of teaching a person to fish instead of giving them a fish, but he took it a step further by saying that in South Africa the people were taught to fish but no one gave them fishing poles. It was at turns heartening and heart-breaking.

It is hard to say anything bad about this book. Noah, is painfully honest, and gives a look into a life that Americans cannot even fathom. His humor works through the bad times. And the story stays engaging. 
 The one negative I would say about it is the book feels like a bunch of separate chapters that are connected, but he forgets that he has introduced you to people earlier in the book. The reader does not need a recap of who each person is, especially when they were talked about just 10 pages earlier. Noah does a great job of painting pictures of the world he grew up with, but doesn't seem to trust the reader to remember what he just told them.

Trevor Noah's life as the host of the Daily Show seems almost impossible to reconcile with his recent life growing up in the slums of apartheid. This memoir covers the unusual circumstances of his birth, a history lesson in South Africa, stories of his juvenile delinquency and domestic abuse, but most of all it is a love letter to his fierce and religious mother. The story ends with brief mentions of him starting to do stand up comedy, but there is no way to predict his success based on his past, except that he was smart and well loved. The book had a story-telling style to it that was very easy to read. (A-)
One of the best books I've read in a long time.

For some reason, I was not anticipating this memoir to be as funny as it was. Not that it is just one hilarious romp after another--I'd say it's pretty evenly balanced between some of the harsher realities of South African history and culture and his own humorous recollections--but I was preparing myself for a starker read. I am so glad they got him to read on the audio--his delivery was necessary and spectacular. 
 ******** 
 Read Harder: Set more than 5,000 miles away from you
Favorite book of 2016. I listened to this on audio and it was amazing. I relished every minute of it.
Very easy read and interesting

Enjoyable and eye-opening book about the early days of TV show host Trevor Noah. 
 At times funny, at times very poignant, it shows an upbringing very different from from the one most of us enjoyed. 
 Very glad I read it.
This book is incredibly good, and I don't watch The Daily Show to be biased by Noah's fame/celebrity. Eye-opening and insightful in all the right ways.

This book was really great. I wasn't sure what to expect, because it is a comedian writing a memoir which can be hit or miss. But this one hits, and hits hard. It has its funny parts, many of them, but it's also just a really good example of a South African memoir and it's the first one I've read of a mixed person in South Africa, so I appreciate its existence on that factor alone. And would have read it even if it weren't written by a famous person. 
 So this was a good memoir because it had some good historical points (and will get a lot of Americans to learn something about South Africa) and from a very interesting perspective - someone who didn't really fit anywhere in South Africa. It also showcased his incredible mother, who defied any stereotype you could think of of an African woman. It had poignant parts, heartbreaking parts, funny parts, and brutally honest parts. All the best things that memoirs should have, especially when they are done well. And in this case, I think they were. 
 Really, the one thing that kept me from giving it five stars was the at times confusing linearity of the stories. A series of childhood stories don't need to be linear necessarily, but there were a number of stories that overlapped in time quite a bit and so I got confused a couple times, but also there were some pretty heavy events in his life that come up in some stories, but not others that happened at the same time and I would think some of those events would affect others in the same timeframe. So, the disjointed nature of some of it made me not give this a resounding review. 
 However, I still highly recommend it, even for people who aren't obsessed with South Africa the way I am. It's just a good childhood memoir.

Noah was born in South Africa in 1984 to a white Swiss father and a black Xhosa mother. Thanks to the Prohibition of Mixed Marriages Act of 1949 under the tyrannical apartheid laws, their union was illegal, which made Noah himself a crime. 
 His mother was a devoutly religious woman and Noah's stories of attending black church, white church, and mixed church all on the same day were guffaw-worthy. They were poor, but his mother was fearless, rebellious and determined to give Trevor a life of education, opportunity, and love. She was an indomitable spirit in his life and worked tirelessly to raise him to be a good man. 
 The stories aren't in linear order. They bounce around quite a bit, but this doesn't detract from the flow. Tales of first love, lack of friends, and not fitting in as a mixed race ("colored") boy segue into years spent hustling pirated music, shoplifting liquor-filled chocolates, becoming a dj, and then a comedian. Noah is adept at weaving together his own personal history, some of which is unquestionably heartbreaking, with warmth, laugh-out-loud humor, and insight. He's a charmer and a master storyteller. 
 It's not every book that teaches you about South African life during apartheid AND makes you laugh. But this one does. And it's awesome.

I'll admit it. Along with many Americans, I was skeptical when Trevor Noah took over the reins of The Daily Show from Jon Stewart, an American treasure. I mean, who is this guy from South Africa and how the hell is he going to understand the nuances of our political system well enough to satirize it at the level of excellence to which we have become accustomed? Luckily, he has proved us all wrong (and I do not readily admit when I'm wrong) and made The Daily Show his own while maintaining the sincerity that we love. Then I stumbled upon his memoir and became an instant 100% true believer in Trevor Noah - skepticism shattered. 
 Listen to any of Trevor's stand-up, and you will most likely hear him use the phrase "born a crime". His birth was, literally, illegal. He was born during the last few years of apartheid, under which blacks and whites were not allowed to mingle, much less procreate. Trevor is a "colored" person - the term used in South Africa to describe individuals of mixed race. His mother is native South African of the Xhosa tribe, while his father is a white man from Switzerland. Imagine your mother and father having to pretend they don't know you (or each other) in public. That was Trevor Noah's reality for the formative years of his life. 
 The book is full of tales about growing up in a starkly segregated society, even after the fall of apartheid, descriptions of unbelievable poverty, language barriers, domestic abuse, and feelings of alienation from both races. By the way, Trevor can speak about 10 languages at various levels of fluency - makes you feel ridiculous for blowing off that college Spanish course, huh? What makes this book so enjoyable, and what I believe makes Trevor Noah a great Daily Show host, is his ability to understand and appreciate the myriad of cultural factors and intersections that underlie society's failures, flaws, and yes, successes, because he has witnessed so much of humanity's worst. In one of my favorite passages, he brings up the old adage "give the man a fish, and he'll eat for a day; teach a man to fish, and he'll eat forever" or something along those lines. He points out that it sure would help if you provided that man with a fishing pole. All the education in the world makes no difference if you don't have the proper tools to succeed. 
 Although it's Trevor's life laid out on the page, the true star and heroine of the book is Trevor's mom, Patricia. She is there in every story, usually at the forefront but other times as a background presence. Her unwavering love (usually of the tough variety) and support is evident, and Trevor never fails to give his mom the credit she deserves for guiding him in the right direction. She is a feminist in a patriarchal and segregated society refusing from the get-go to conform. The woman even survives a gunshot to the head, thereby cementing her membership in the bad-ass women society. 
 It's easy to write off celebrity memoirs as sensational self-affirming nonsense meant to amass more money and cement the author's fame. Many (if not most) of the books that fall into this category do fit the stereotype. This book is different, largely because Trevor's story is not the norm. It provides a brief look into a time and place of which most American's have very little knowledge. Along the way we are reminded that our Western-centric view of the world is skewed and narrow. I'm glad that the producers of The Daily Show took a chance on the kid from the other side of the world, and I'm especially glad that I took a chance on this book. I urge others to do the same - you won't be disappointed! 
 Thank you to the publisher for providing me with an advanced reader copy through NetGalley.

My first ever audiobook! Excellent both as an introduction to audiobooks and the material itself. Loved Noah narrating his own book and such a lovely voice as well. Outstanding story and a lovely tribute to his mother who really, really thought outside the box (literally and figuratively), given the political and social climate in South Africa during and after apartheid. Enjoyed immensely.

What an wonderful book, both as a coming-of-age book, a subjective account of a defining period in the history of South Africa and a riveting narrative as well. I was hooked once I started it and I'm happy to rate it a 9 (out of 10).
If you are a fan of Trevor Noah, you can clearly hear his voice in the narration. It is his story, told from the heart. It was a look into an exceptional start of a life. I recommend it.
I would give a fourth star, but I found Trevor Noah to be an unsympathetic character in his own life story.
Parts of this book are very good parts not so much. Beginning and the end are well written skip the middle

South Africa is an amazing country - beautiful landscape, exotic african culture and full of potential. But it has a horrifying past and you cannot talk about South Africa without a discussion on apartheid which literally means 'separateness'. This separateness, as we all know, was based on race. But how many races were there? Colored, Blacks, Whites and occasionally Mixed (which was technically a crime). 
 Trevor Noah was a mixed child and per the law of land at that point in time, a crime. Hence the title. We all know Noah as this comedian who has taken over big shoes of Jon Stewart (and is doing a decent job of the same) but we do not know how he turned out to be who he is today. He has lived in shanty townships, conducted illegal businesses in hoods, DJed night parties, sold pirated CDs and spent a week in jail on carjacking charges. This book is a collection of all these stories which are actually grievous in nature but are narrated humorously, generating occasional laughs. I spent most of the book thinking how hideous a regime can be to subject an entire race through this for so many years and what rationale they must have in their minds for doing so. 
 Trevor's biggest influence is his mom and by the end of this book you will also end up respecting her, who made sure her son does not turn out to be a patriarchal black male she always despised and rebelled against. Her lessons for Trevor should be mandated upon all moms. Read this book for his mom, if for nothing else.

I listened to the audiobook of this, so I will say this was a well told (rather than written) story of being born during Apartheid and growing up in the aftermath of Apartheid ending. 
 Funny, eye-opening, heart-wrenching, and definitely worth reading/listening to.
What an amazing, funny, complicated, and well told story! Even better on audible and listening to Trevor for yourself!

I can't even explain how good this autobiography is. This book touches on everything--race, poverty, abuse--in pre- and post-apartheid South Africa. It's amazing how relevant these issues are in 2016 America. 
 I really recommend listening to the audiobook with Noah reading it.
Love Trevor Noah! It is amazing to me that he managed to get where he is today after listening to this story! Wow!
Couldn't put it down, read in one day. My only critique is the story could be a little hard to follow in that Trevor jumps from point to point in his life not in chronological order
I filmed a review. I did not expect this book to be as amazing as it was. https://youtu.be/KzoVOcZAZyE

Noah grew up mixed race in South Africa, raised by his black mother, and in contact with his white father, at a time when it was illegal. He tells of looking "colored" (a different category than black) and how this impacted his life. It is also the story of the townships, of his mother' strength, of apartheid, and of domestic violence. Touching and unexpected, it was a good read.
Cliffhanging end
I laughed and cried at the same time while reading this beautiful "love letter" to Noah's mother.

This should be required reading in every high school. There was not one ounce of "poor me" in this memoir of growing up in S. Africa, but his life was not easy. Although the book is highly readable, the audio, read by the author, is also fantastic. 
 This book is worth reading for so many reasons, but getting to know Noah's mother was a gift and reason enough.
This was such a chilling read. Thoroughly enjoyed it!

"People love to say, "Give a man a fish, and he'll eat for a day. Teach a man to fish, and he'll eat for a lifetime." What they don't say is, "And it would be nice if you gave him a fishing rod." That's the part of the analogy that's missing."

A fascinating and at times, heartbreaking read. I didn't find it "funny" or "hilarious" as I'd read in some reviews, but as a memoir it is well-written and a very interesting story of growing up in South Africa

Audiobook - loved his voice! And his story... There is so much here, from laugh-out-loud situations to touching moments, to real insight into apartheid (something I know very little about) and race relations in general. Highly recommended.

I'm not a huge fan of Trevor Noah. I've watched only a few episodes of the Daily Show and, in all honesty, not hugely familiar with his views. I do know that he leans to the left and I also know I don't agree with a fair amount of his worldview. That being said, however, I truly enjoyed and learned a great deal about a culture which is completely foreign to me. The reason I picked up this memoir was because I have friends who mostly get their news from his show (a fact, since its a comedy show, in and of it self raises flags for me), and because I saw a decent review of it in a magazine I trust. Their is nothing marvelous in his prose, but I think that only serves his narrative more. He's not looking for elegance or finesse, he's looking to show the truth and reality of racism in South Africa through the example of his life. There is language, however, he treats all the subject matter with a conscientious respect that I like. I knew very little about the apartheid in South Africa, now I have a better understanding of a culture and nation's history that's applicable to everyday life.
I absolutely loved this book! I have a whole new level of respect for Trevor Noah.
Loved hearing about his background in his own voice.
Wow. Couldn't put this down, didn't want it to end.
The audiobook was fantastic.

I listened to audiobook for this one and damn it was good. 
 Trevor is a really good narrator he makes you feel like he's sitting next to you simply telling is life story, what I really liked is that he mentions very devastating incidents that he went through all through his childhood till he grew up in a very funny way, and I never knew how much do people of color suffer in a black/white majority community, how their ancestors history is almost non existent, I enjoyed how he addressed the problems they face and how he analyzes how their oppressors think, how their lives were pre and post the apartheid, how badass his mother was and how mothers love is almost always unconditional, and overall how eye opening the book was.

I basically knew nothing about apartheid in South Africa, and I picked up this book because of the hook and Noah's wit. Really worth your time. I can't offer any critique of his presentation of apartheid (and it's a memoir, so it's his experience anyway), but my eyes were opened (and now I need to go re-read Cry the Beloved Country). Noah tells his experiences with humor and candor. This isn't a story of someone who overcame and is now famous in America. It is the story of growing up in South Africa between groups racially separated in a way I think I can't truly fathom. It is a story you happen to know because the author is now famous, but which was worth telling anyway. Read this. You'll laugh, you'll be shocked, and you'll come away knowing more about the world, and maybe with a little wider understanding.

** spoiler alert ** 
 I first got to know Trevor Noah through his stand up (https://youtu.be/GgZYCj39M38). He's come a long way, and I loved learning about his past. The vignettes in this book are honest, funny, and subtly but incredibly insightful. Here are some of my favorite parts: 
 - His navigation of an in-between identity: "People are willing to accept you if they see you as an outsider trying to assimilate into their world. But when they see you as a fellow tribe member attempting to disavow the tribe, that is something they will never forgive." 
 - His reflections on awkward teenage love: "I don't regret anything I've ever done in life, any choice that I've made. But I'm consumed with regret for the things I didn't do." 
 - His hilarious, oblivious promotions of Hitler. This segment matches the tone of his stand up and I laughed out loud. 
 - His empathetic description of the hood life--the hustlers, the different notions of right and wrong, the sense of community and escape from existential doubt, and the rigged justice system. The portrait of the misunderstood thug he met in jail was especially powerful. 
 - His love for his mom. 
 Would recommend!

During breakfast every day, I watch the previous night's Daily Show starring Trevor Noah. I'm new to this routine, new to The Daily Show, but leading up to the election and then its fucking horrible aftermath led me to shows, websites, twitter feeds, etc etc that I never paid much attention to before. The Daily Show is one of these. 
 With all due respect to Trevor Noah, I had no plans to ever read this. Celebrity memoirs don't usually interest me. The celebrity memoirs I would read don't exist because the people are dead. Or they're assholes or incredibly private. Or both. However, I was gifted this book. 
 Noah never mentions The Daily Show. He mentions his comedy career only when absolutely necessary. That part of his life is fairly recent. His first twenty years or so were spent either under South Africa's apartheid system or dealing with the aftermath of being a "colored" (the name given to people of mixed race) man navigating a post-apartheid environment. 
 Noah grew up in the Johannesburg area of South Africa during apartheid and was literally "born a crime," as interracial relationships were punishable by law. He was a level of poor Americans cannot begin to comprehend. He was shut out from the world. "Black people were not properly educated. White people didn't talk to black people. So why would black people know what's going on in the white man's world?", Noah says on why no one knew who Hitler was. "Black people knew of Hitler as a powerful person. A tough guy. If you want your son to be tough, you name him Hitler." Noah knew more than one 'Hitler'. 
 Trevor Noah has a wisdom one can only get from growing up in apartheid South Africa. There were a few passages that were particularly memorable: 
 On the "black tax": 
 "So many black families spend all of their time trying to fix the problems of the past. That is the curse of being black and poor, and it is a curse that follows you from generation to generation. My mother calls it "the black tax." Because the generations who came before you have been pillaged, rather than being free to use you skills and education to move forward, you lose everything just trying to being everyone behind you back up to zero." 
 On crime: 
 "In the hood, even if you're not a hardcore criminal, crime is in your life in some way or another. There are degrees of it. It's everyone from the mom buying some food that fell off the back of a truck to feed her family, all the way up to the gangs selling military-grade weapons and hardware. The hood made me realize that crime succeeds because crime does the one thing the government doesn't do: crime cares. Crime is grassroots. Crime looks for the young kids who need support and a lifting hand. Crime offers internship programs and summer jobs and opportunities for advancement. Crime gets involved in the community. Crime doesn't discriminate." 
 How he became a comedian and then host of a renowned American political satire program, I still do not know. That's in the next book I suppose.

I've read a lot of memoirs by comedians. This one has the most heart of any I have read. His life could have turned out so much differently. I found the history in South Africa really fascinating. A great read, highly recommend it.

This is an amazing book. I laughed, I cried, I learned, I got to know a whole new culture and history. Trevor Noah narrates his own writing, with great empathy, humor, and most of all, a deep love for his mother. You can hear it in his voice. 
 He grew up as a mixed child in the apartheid, which punished interracial sex with up to five years of prison. He could only saw his father behind closed doors. He saw the regime change, the fighting on the streets. His mom is a strong, independent woman who raised him with tough discipline but also lots of love, humor and wisdom. Trevor is a smart and naughty child, and their relationship yields hilarious and touching moments. 
 Noah has many stories to tell, and he is a great storyteller and performer. There is never a dull moment. The stories are engrossing, educational, many have great lessons. My personal favorite was the one he told about Fufi, his dog - and the conclusion he drew from it: you don't own those you love. 
 A great book that must be enjoyed on audio!

I initally misjudged this book as being one of the typically run of the mill comedian biographies ( they seem to be on trend) but it was much more ! I love the mini history lessons at the beginning of each chapter. Perhaps Trevor's stories held more significance as a fellow immigrant trying to straddle the identity of black in the your country of birth and in the United States. I'm not sure I buy his claim of not absorbing the trauma he experienced as a child who was born a crime but it was a insightful and heartwarming read.

** spoiler alert ** 
 This was a very entertaining book. So entertaining that I suspect the truth may have been...um...tweaked a bit to maximize the entertainment value. I saw a documentary on Trevor Noah called You Laugh, But It's True, and in it a slightly different version of the story of his mother being shot is told - in the documentary it is presented as a random act of violence, and Noah does not say it was committed by his step dad. In this book the story is different - Noah is informed of the shooting immediately by his half-brother and it is clear who the shooter is. So why the two different versions? Is Noah using the story for different ends in the two tellings? There are other points in this book where I caught myself thinking that the stories just sounded enhanced...not "false", but certainly spun a great deal. A scene in which he is simultaneously so afraid that he thinks he may be about die, and also taking a nap. A hilariously funny scene at a Jewish centre seems more like a stand up routine than something that really happened - probably the truth is something much less entertaining than that story. 
 So three stars. Very entertaining, but I'm not so gullible as to confuse a stand-up act for reality.

Originally posted on Slow Reader's Blog 
 Glorious. This book is absolutely glorious. I'm so in love right now, I can barely function. This memoir is unquestionable one of the most engaging books I've ever read, filled with such greatly vivid and riveting anecdotes, made more profound and unforgettable by the fact that they're true. 
 I don't watch The Daily Show, other than a few occasional clips on social media, and I never followed this guy before, so I decided to read this book solely because of the title. I love it. Born a Crime--it just feels meaningful. And, it is meaningful. I'm walking away from this experience knowing now that I love Trevor Noah. I love his writing and I love his wit. He is a fantastic storyteller who told of his childhood, one that was layered heavily with sadness, but for the majority of the time while reading his journey, I felt joyous. 
 This memoir is a compilation of notable anecdotes, mixed in with short passages of African history for context against the very special circumstances of Trevor's birth and childhood. Let me tell you, his childhood is better than any fiction and there are too many humorous and affecting moments to count. Some of my favorites include, the time when a criminal, young Trevor, who was being held prisoner in his Grandmother's house (for his own good), crawled through a hole under a fence to get to freedom. Then, there's the time when his first dog, Fufi, taught him his first lesson in love and betrayal. Or, the time when, after growing up on the kind of creative diet that only the very poor are weaned on, Trevor was left completely unimpressed with high cuisine meals such as bone marrow, which are no different or better than the dog bones he ate at home. For more funny and interesting stories, read this book! 
 Born a Crime begins before his birth, when his impetuous and wise mother convinced her kind, white neighbor to give her a baby, during a time when there were strictly enforced laws that prohibited intercourse between Natives and Europeans. The stories he describe span from that time to the end of Apartheid, and further to a time when blacks and coloreds were free to live the life they could wrangle from the system. 
 Trevor's--I'm calling him Trevor because I feel like I know him now. His thoughts on race and power are spot on and made more impressive because of his ability to use humor to show the illogical and ridiculous nature of the whole enterprise. Trevor is very smart, and a very adept communicator. There isn't a single part of this memoir that doesn't pierce you, wound you with truths, yet it soothes you with humor. I laughed because it was impossible not to. I laughed so hard that I cried, and then I cried because I had to cry. 
 Trevor grew up on a divided country, and the numerous poignant moments show clearly a boy caught between the many cultures of South Africa, which he navigated by becoming a chameleon, fitting in everywhere and nowhere at the same time. He adapted to each new situation as many entertainers do, by being whoever the people want them to be. That's not to say that Trevor is disingenuous in any way; no, he's observant, and his musings on life and relationships make it apparent that he has a damn good understanding of the human condition. 
 What is most lovely about his coming-of-age story is how Trevor speaks about his mother. His mom features largely in his story, and his love and respect for her is obvious, not only in his words, but in the actions he describes. Their bond is a tangible thing, and the most moving pockets of this book are the ones filled with his mom. 
 Honestly, this memoir is so brilliantly insightful that there are many many pages I marked, so many gems and memories I've saved to revisit again and again. I don't read a lot of biographies, preferring fiction to real life, but I'm insanely delighted that I strayed from my norm and read Born a Crime. I recommend this book to anyone and everyone, sincerely, because it is truly glorious. 
 Audiobook notes: Just perfect. Trevor Noah pulls you in with his animated voice and more than brings this story to life.

Hilarious and poignant at the same time. Learn the effects of colonialism, apartheid and post-apartheid profligacy, poverty, violence, and racism from this book more than the history books I read back in high school. 
 "In society we do horrible things to one another because we don't see the personal effects--we don't see their faces, we don't see them as people. We live in a world where we don't see the ramifications of what we do to others, because we don't live with them."
I love this book ! the audiobook is a great ! I'd re-listen to this again.
