 I consider myself an unofficial expert on celebrity memoirs. I haven't read all of them (although I would like to - even the stupid ones, because I am incredibly nosy and devour celebrity gossip the way other people devour Dorritos or fake news), but I've read a fair amount, and they usually follow a typical narrative arc. In BORN A CRIME, Trevor Noah takes that arc, flattens it out, and beats you over the head with it. 
 I love Trevor Noah. I love what he brings to The Daily Show. I think he's incredibly funny, intellectual, erudite, and charming. I also think he's cute, but that's neither here nor there. I actually first learned about him through his (in)famous video with "she who shall not be named" (no, not Voldemort's sister - but close). I was really impressed by how he went about the interview. That could have been really ugly - but it wasn't; it was a somewhat civil discourse between two opposing views, about why the political beliefs of a certain demographic can be incredibly problematic. 
 When I found out that this Trevor Noah person, this cool political cucumber, had a memoir out, I immediately put myself on hold for it at the library. Unfortunately, so did about a billion other people. It took two freaking months for me to finally get my hands on BORN A CRIME. Normally, when I wait that long, I start to lose interest and by the time I get the book I sometimes forget why I even bothered to put it on hold in the first place. Not so, here. 
 Trevor Noah's memoir is not like other memoirs because he doesn't talk about his "famous" life at all. BORN A CRIME is about Trevor Noah's childhood growing up in South Africa while it was still under apartheid. He talks about slavery, segregation, racism, poverty, domestic violence and abuse, and all manner of other troubling topics, but he does it in a way that, while not exactly unpleasant, never becomes so graphic or unpleasant that I had to put the book down and take a deep breath. At times, he even manages to make the terrible situation he's describing funny, which is truly a testament to his amazing sense of humor. 
 There's a lot more I can say, but most of it would just be recaps from the memoir and more praise about Trevor himself. I really, really loved this book. It kind of reminds me of another memoir I read about a biracial man, THE COLOR OF WATER by James McBride, but I feel like BORN A CRIME is going to be a lot more accessible because a) he's a pop-cultural icon, b) Noah's book is broader in scope in terms of topics discussed, and c) he's a millennial so his language will resonate with a lot of people, especially the young bloggers, who are reading and reviewing this book. 
 Read this book. It was totally worth waiting for two months for. 
 5 stars
4.5 stars. Trevor's mom is sort of a badass. That's my main takeaway
Very interesting insight into post-Apartheid South-African society; that book helped me to understand race issues and life in South-Africa.
I didn't start out loving this book, but it got better and better as I kept reading.
Loved this book. Interesting insight into apartheid and the way people lived and survived. Trevor is an amazing young man.

Even if you are not familiar with comedian and Daily Show host Trevor Noah, his memoir is a thoroughly engaging and enlightening story of growing up in arpartheid and post-apartheid South Africa as a "colored" or mixed-race person. With touches of humor, he describes growing up in this unusual society under the care of his mother, who is a powerful force who loves her children and does whatever it takes to provide for them while navigating the boundaries of race.

I wish more books went this in-depth into the culture of a country or a people group (in this case, many people groups). I love that he tells his story with humor. I do feel as if the humor tapered off in the last third or so of the book which I wish had not been the case. I also wish that the book was organized more chronologically (there is a lot of jumping back and forth; instead the book is organized by theme). However, this book was great.

"Being chosen is the greatest gift you can give to another human being." 
 Very interesting story that gives insight to growing up in South Africa. Trevor describes his life under Apartheid and in the tension-filled post-apartheid era. This book is a tribute to his mother.

I'm not sure how to write a review of an autobiography. It feels like reviewing someone's life, which feels weird. 
 I listened to this as an audiobook, read by Trevor Noah, and loved every minute. Unsurprisingly, he's a great writer with a gift for being witty and insightful at the same time. The stories aren't told chronologically, but grouped together sort of thematically. School stories, church stories, dating stories, stories about his mom, etc. You get insight into what it was like living in South Africa at the end of apartheid. Spoiler alert: it wasn't so great for black folks or mixed folks.
This was really interesting. I really enjoyed reading it and I love getting glimpses into other cultures and perspectives. I would recommend it, especially to those who watch the daily show.
Outstanding. I listened to Noah read his own memoir making it all the more powerful. Why did this not get an Alex Award? Would be fabulous for teen readers, I think, in addition to adults, of course.

you can watch my review here : 
 https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HrtbA...

Oh my GOD! I don't see why I can't call Trevor's a story of love. The comedian in him is clearly in the words but the content!!! I feel like he is one of the few men SA raised who learned and know love - he loves people, he loves life, he loves everything and everyone without reserve, but most importantly his love for his mother - and his story is told with unique detail and transparency. I could almost feel how her roughly cocooning him actually prepared him for all things life and I can't help but feel jealous. If I could have half as much patience, faith and love as she did... if I would be as open to letting my child learn not from what I say but what I do. I don't think we're fortunate enough to have mothers like her, I stand corrected. I also don't think we have raised our boy children as he was raised. I can't help but envy their collective hardened spirit that calmly progresses through life's hardest challenges - apartheid, separation, poverty, domestic abuse and near death. I'm happy to have read this book.
What a story! What a life. Great read for sons and mothers and those seeking to understand a different world.

I'm torn about my feelings for this one. No, I wasn't expecting "Long Walk to Freedom" here, but the hype would have me believe that this was "Long Walk to Freedom"-lite. 
 It's not. 
 I listened to the audiobook version, as was recommended, and I kept waiting - waiting for something spectacular to happen ... but I don't think it ever did. Some of what Noah says definitely makes you stop and think, lines such as "the genius of apartheid was convincing people who were the overwhelming majority to turn on each other. Apart hate, is what it was," but he repeats his main themes ad nauseam. I don't know how many times I heard him say "the genius of apartheid was ..." again after this initial one - but it was many. You want to be like, okay, I get it - bad times. Many, many, many bad times. Such is growing up in apartheid - and immediately post-apartheid - South Africa. That's more or less assumed in the title. 
 My problem wasn't that, but that the book never really seems to delve deeper into these issues. "Stories From a South African Childhood" is exactly that - anecdotes, some more interesting than others, about a childhood that likely seems incredibly foreign and bleak to most who will read this. Perhaps, when recalling such childhood traumas, it's only natural to emotionally disconnect from the events at hand? Listening to Noah tell his story often feels like he's telling someone else's story. I'm also not sure why he's put them in the under he has. He'll tell a story about the search for his Swiss father as a young adult, and then the next story has him as a nine-year-old again. There doesn't seem to be any rhyme or reason for this, and these stories don't ever seem linked by any overarching theme. The story that closes the book doesn't give the closure that a story closing a book should, and leaves us with an awkward aftertaste ... is Noah suggesting, by ending with the story of his mother's near death, that divine intervention is actually responsible for her still being alive? I don't think so, yet the fact that he closes with lines that could have come straight from some Christian bestseller left me confused. 
 To be sure, some of these stories were amusing. The "Hitler" story was especially funny. But "Born a Crime" leaves us with more questions than it does answers. What is Noah's relationship with his father today? What happened to Abel? Certain stories are left feeling unfinished, and in a book with such potential, that really is a crime.

I don't even know where to begin. Trevor Noah is a natural storyteller, and his stories of growing up in South Africa are eye-opening, hilarious, and thought-provoking. He was born an illegal mixed child during apartheid and raised by a strong and independent mother (who I loved from page one). His stories brought life to a place and time I knew so little about. I didn't want to stop reading. Even if you don't watch Trevor Noah on The Daily Show, I highly recommend reading this book.

I love Trevor, so I was excited to read his book and I was not disappointed. Trevor is extensively knowledgeable; he makes history much more relate-able, and reading it less a drudgery. He knows how to use words: where to make them light, where to make them heavy. 
 A different chapter arrangement might make for a smoother read, though. Regardless, it's funny and very insightful. 
 In/with this book, Trevor follows his own rule of not laying all your cards out: "You don't ask people to like you based on everything you are, just the parts of you you're willing to share.." 
 I know more books will follow, and I cannot wait to read them.
I love Trevor Noah, and this book just made him more wonderful. How amazing, and horrifying, to think that his birth being a "crime" happened this recently. This is simply a fabulous read.

Trevor Noah is a very engaging writer, and the performance of the audiobook is obviously fantastic. I actually recommend listening to it instead of reading it if you can. This book managed to capture the sweetness of childhood even amidst the struggle of some very difficult times. I also learned a lot about Apartheid and appreciated seeing the societal effects from a personal point of view. This book gently reminded me of my privilege (living middle class and white in the US) while touching on universal experiences. This book sometimes made me quite emotional. I have been recommending it to everyone.

If you can, try and listen to this book rather than read it. The stories that Trevor Noah shares about his childhood are incredible. What he came from, what he had to deal with, and where he is now is an amazing story.

One of the best books I have every listened to on Audible. Not a book I would normally have chosen, but so glad I did. Gave me great insight to what it was like growing up in South Africa during Apartheid.

Having seen Trevor Noah on the Daily Show I knew this would be interesting and entertaining, but I had no idea how much so. Especially the audiobook version is very good, because not only can the author get across what happens best, you also get an idea of what the different languages mentioned sound like as he reads them effortlessly. 
 That said, South Africa during apartheid sounds utterly terrifying and the story of his mother's life one of immense courage. Re-read (or rather, re-listened) right after finishing.

I listen to audiobooks all the time and enjoy alternating serious literature with comedians' memoirs. So when Trevor Noah's book came out, I added it to my list. Little did I know that this "comedian's memoir" would actually turn out to be one of my favorite pieces of literature published this year. This book is remarkable in its pacing, storytelling, and editing; in its restraint, frankness, and depth. Yes, Trevor Noah is a comedian, but he is also a brilliant satirist and (multi)cultural analyst. Had I bought the actual book, I would shelve it next to Desmond Tutu's No Future without Forgiveness as a complimentary volume on post-Apartheid South African. However, I'm glad I didn't because Noah's range of languages and accents make the audio version a must. Listen to this book.
Surprisingly kind and lacking in anger given his horrible experience.

I'm putting this book right up there with the autobiographies of Tina Fey, Alan Cumming and Agatha Christie! Loved every page of this book - well written, compelling, touching, hilarious and horrifying at the same time.
Very engrossing memoir. I liked Noah much more after reading it.

This was not the book I thought it was going to be. I have heard so many good things, but it was so different than I expected. It kind of blew me away. 
 It reminded me that there are whole worlds out there with histories that I can't even begin to fathom. Books like this open your eyes up to something completely different, yet familiar. It makes me what to read more about South Africa and the horrors its people went through. It makes me want to read more about the whole world! 
 Trevor Noah was the perfect person to shed more light on this wondrous, horrible place and its history. He was funny and real and honest. His story was very personal, and yet he spoke volumes about his country and the social issues that plague it and the world. He told his story in such a way that makes you empathize with not only him, but the whole country.

Funny and effective. Trevor Noah is a good storyteller, and this memoir avoids the typical boring comedian-talking-about-growing-up stuff, focusing on the specific weirdness of life in South Africa a few decades ago. And it still finds moments to be relatable, too. It felt like a nice introduction to the region, and to the comedian - I am in the camp of "It's hard to replace Jon Stewart" still, but this book definitely made me respect him more.

Trevor Noah's memoir of his childhood in South Africa is compelling reading for anyone who wants to know more about South Africa and apartheid. At times humorous and at times devastating, Noah brings his unique voice to this story. He writes like he speaks, and many times in this book it felt like I was hearing him narrate. I appreciated this book for how much information it conveys, and because it's told in a way that's understandable and sympathetic. Noah clearly isn't just trying to entertain; he wants us to understand his native country. 
 You may know him as the host of The Daily Show. Noah was born in South Africa in 1984, at a time when apartheid was in full force. Nelson Mandela was released from prison in 1990 and apartheid was abolished in 1991. As the title suggests, Noah was born from the illegal relationship of his black Xhosa mother, and his Swiss father. Children of mixed race were strictly illegal, yet his mother deliberately set out to conceive him. Noah's mother is really the star of this memoir, and clearly his strongest inspiration. She defies societal rules about what she can do, who she can talk to, and where she can live. But tragedy is ahead, as Noah tells us early on in the book that she will be shot by her abusive husband. 
 There are very dark moments in this book, but they are told in a matter-of-fact way that doesn't make light of the issues. Noah grows up in a time when the color of his face defines what he can do and how he is treated. By some black people he's treated with more deference, but white society sees him as evidence of a crime, which means for years he can't be seen in public with either his white father or his black mother. As he gets older, and after apartheid is abolished, he struggles to fit in with all racial groups. He grows up in a black family so he feels closer to them, but he isn't one of them. He learns over time to reach out to all three groups, and often it feels he's always playing a part, but he learns adaptability and that people of all races have something to offer. As an outsider, he sees the things that divide different groups of people, and he focuses on learning their languages so he can communicate with them. 
 If you're thinking this is the story of a serious, hard-working student who succeeds against all odds, you'd be wrong. Noah succeeds because of his strength, creativity and humor, but isn't always a nice kid, or a good student, or a law-abiding citizen. He isn't always nice to his mom. He spends most of his teen years learning how to bootleg music and sell pirated CDs. Oh, and he actually burns a house down. By not making himself out to be the perfect kid, you feel like he's telling you the truth. 
 Noah moves easily from telling us about the humiliation of his senior prom to describing a time he had to live out of a garage and sleep in cars. He endures great poverty and racism, but also encounters love, friendship, and inspiration. I was moved by his enduring relationship with his birth father, which is greatly restricted first by apartheid, and second by Noah's stepfather. 
 There are times the book is a little hard to follow, for the reason that it's written more thematically than chronologically, although he does move us from birth to childhood to young adulthood. Throughout the book I found I had to pay attention to where he is and how old he is, in order to put it all together, but that's not too much to ask of a reader. 
 This book gave me great insights into Noah's character and South Africa's history. He reminds us how little Western audiences (American audiences in particular) know about apartheid. It's clever, funny, informative, and emotional, and a book I highly recommend. My full review can be found at http://thebookstop.wordpress.com.

I suggest listening to the Audiobook, Outstanding performance by Trevor Noah! ( The highest rated book on Audible in 2016) 
 An exemplary-narrated story with deep insights on the South African culture during/after the apartheid. 
 A five star book !
Fantastic memoir! Smart, funny, educational. A great read!
Very interesting and touching. I recommend listening to this book to hear him speak the different languages.

I would really like to listen to Trevor Noah read this book - there are so many moments where I could imagine his voice and wished he was reading it to me! This is at once a history of Apartheid in South Africa and a humorous, heartfelt, and emotionally challenging read both for those who are fans of Noah and those who may not know him.

This was so fascinating! I loved learning about what it was like to grow up in South Africa. 
 Trevor is such a good storyteller. I was so captivated by everything he said. And he was able to turn very tough experiences into funny stories. I highly recommend listening to this on audio as Trevor narrates it himself and does a fantastic job!

New "Daily Show" anchor Trevor Noah's memoir about growing up in South Africa both before and after apartheid is more informative than entertaining. Unlike Obama who was raised by his white mother and maternal grandparents, Trevor was raised by his black relatives, especially his mother. His Swiss/German father had to be hidden because it was a crime for a white man and a black woman to have sex during apartheid. Trevor had to pass for "colored" and occasionally white instead of identifying as a mixed race child. His discussion of South Africa's absurd racial politics was interesting and at times amusing.

I'm so glad I picked this up! By turns hilarious and heartbreaking. I learned so much not only about Apartheid, but the power of the human spirit. Noah is a gifted storyteller. Listen on audio if you can!

Before I start my review, I want to take a minute to praise Trevor Noah's stand up shows because they're one of the few that don't rely on being ignorant. His shows are one of the enlighten ones focusing on race, white-privilege, police brutality, hate speech, prejudice, and so much more. 
 I'd highly recommend watching a few before reading this riveting memoir. 
 In Born a Crime, Trevor Noah takes us on a journey from his childhood being born a crime in apartheid South Africa. Trevor was born to a white Swiss father and a black Xhosa mother at a time when such a union was punishable by five years in prison. This memoir is the story of a mischievous young boy who grows into a restless young man as he struggles to find himself in a world where he was never supposed to exist. It is also the story of that young man's relationship with his fearless, rebellious, and fervently religious mother: his teammate, a woman determined to save her son from the cycle of poverty, violence, and abuse that would ultimately threaten her own life. 
 Side note: Patricia Nombuyiselo Noah - his mother - was a powerhouse, a strong woman in every sense. She's a warrior and I only wish I could be a half of the person she is. Also, I love the advice she gave her son--I even wrote a few pieces down to remember: 
 "Abel wanted a traditional marriage with a traditional wife. For a long time I wondered why he ever married a woman like my mom in the first place, as she was the opposite of that in every way. If he wanted a woman to bow to him, there were plenty of girls back in Tzaneen being raised solely for that purpose. The way my mother always explained it, the traditional man wants a woman to be subservient, but he never falls in love with subservient women. He's attracted to independent women. "He's like an exotic bird collector," she said. "He only wants a woman who is free because his dream is to put her in a cage." 
 This passage had pretty much changed the way I think, the way I precept the world. 
 "She'd tell me not to worry. She always came back to the phrase she lived by: "If God is with me, who can be against me?" She was never scared. Even when she should have been." 
 The piece stuck with me. 
 Truly though, this memoir was enlighten, brimming with emotion, and I love it when children pay tribute to their hard-working mothers. 
 "There was no stepfather in the picture yet, no baby brother crying in the night. It was me and her, alone. There was this sense of the two of us embarking on a grand adventure. She'd say things to me like, "It's you and me against the world." I understood even from an early age that we weren't just mother and son. We were a team." 
 My mind and heart were fully transported while reading everything Trevor went through to get to where he is today and everyone that took part of that journey. 
 And even though some of the stories kind of broke my heart, Trevor Noah always managed to bring in his gold humor to ease the tension. There are a couple of chapters that have taken a hold of my soul and won't let go because either they were extremely hilarious (TREVOR, PRAY & LOOPHOLES) or entirely heart-shattering (MY MOTHER'S LIFE)... or both. 
 Slowly and surely, I came to admire Trevor Noah's character and honesty even more than I did before. And I'm pretty sure that I'll end up watching and rewatching his stand-up shows so that I can stop tearing up at the mention of his name. 
 ARC kindly provided by the publisher in exchange for an honest review. 
 5/5 stars

It's hard to put into words how impressive Trevor Noah is. So it's a good thing he wrote a book.

I will give it a 3.5 
 This is a story of Trevor's childhood- growing up in post apartheid South -and what an insightful memoir it is. You look at a person( celebrity) and based on how they look and speak you make a subconscious and harmless assumption of what their childhood must have been like. Then they write about themselves and you are forced to rethink all assumptions ever made. Ha, I shouldn't be making assumptions in the first place but we will deal with that human characteristic later. 
 I was laughing one chapter in. I however could not point out if the story was funny or if my reading it in Trevor's voice catalyzed the humor. I'll say its a bit of both. 
 The book is written the way Trevor speaks and specifically the way he delivers his jokes. The disadvantage being that a point will be put across by many redundant statements. Reading a paragraph of a bunch of sentences saying the same thing can be off putting. 
 The story is told in a non linear manner and that annoyed me as I had to start analyzing what age Trevor is and what events have and haven't happened when the chapter starts and progresses. It is however readable and for the simplicity it is narrated in, I easily shelved the annoyance. 
 My highlight was falling in love with Patricia Noah aka Mbuyi the minute she made him jump out of a bus and more so loved the relationship between mother and son. Learning more about South Africa's culture is a plus and the reason why I would recommend this book- the laugh out loud moments aside.

Trevor Noah was handed what was probably the most challenging opportunity every afforded a performer -- taking the helm from one of the most revered people on one of the most iconic television shows. Jon Stewart, so closely identified with The Daily Show, made a bold choice in Noah - a young comedian of mixed race from South Africa and thus virtually unknown to Daily Show viewers. Over the ensuing year, Noah has found his footing and through his charm, humor, and intelligent "reporting of the news," garnered his own following that is his alone without sacrificing the biting satire that is the hallmark of The Daily Show. In this book, Noah shares his life generously, and it becomes apparent where a lot of the qualities he displays before camera came from. 
 His Xhosa mother Patricia decided to have someone she could love unconditionally and who would love her back, and had to ask Robert, his Swiss father, several times before he agreed to fathering a child. A gutsy move since this was South Africa during apartheid, and Trevor's very existence was proof of a crime, his light skin could be cause for either parent to be imprisoned for up to five years. This book tells of Trevor Noah's early life, and he was a very spirited rascal of a kid -- but the lessons he learned from his mother were firmly rooted in tough love, providing him with resilience and strength. There are experiences I won't reveal since they would give away too much of the narrative, but only to say such events provide the impetus for the passion he shows on the Daily Show about violence against women in particular. 
 He alludes to his career as a comedian, but does not address how he arrived on Jon Stewart's radar and to his current status. That's fine. It means there's another book, some day, that we can look forward to.

I am a slow reader, and I usually read at bedtime. My reading pace has slowed even more since I became obsessed with watching Trevor Noah every night on The Daily Show. It is because of watching him that I got through this book written by him slower than expected. Still, I'm so glad I read it, and I hope at some point to get the audiobook and listen to it again. He is such a talented, well-spoken, bright, and funny (not to mention handsome) man. Reading the struggles that he had to overcome as a boy growing up in South Africa heightened my respect for him to intense levels. I also am extremely impressed with his mother. What a strong, brave woman! Knowing that a boy could come from such a place of poverty, racism, crime, and abuse to somehow rise above it all to become a comedian and now a host of a popular TV show? How motivating! It makes me believe that things are possible and gives me hope. I highly recommend this to everyone, especially teens and young adults.
Excellent writing, incredible story, highly recommended.

I loved this book! Trevor Noah is a great writer and he knows how to bring you into the story and make you feel like you are actually there. This book will make you smile, make you go "oh no", and just get you all kinds of good vibes. Seeing how he grew up and all the things he went through in his life it makes you admire that he went through all of that and still rose above it and made such a great name for himself. I would definitely recommend this book!

I love Trevor Noah, so this was a must-have for me. I don't usually read memoirs/autobiographies, but having heard some of his life story before, I was interested. And I'm so glad I got to read this book. It was such an eye-opener for white people who I think often take their situation for granted. It gave me so much respect for the cultures in South Africa and what they endured, and continue to endure there, and it was a little daunting to read about Trevor's experiences as a mixed child who identified as black more often than white. The book carried his whit and humour (I could hear his voice every time I read a line), and he managed to bring a little light to certain dark situations in his past. For me, the highlight was reading about his mother. What an incredible woman, a force of nature who bowed to no one and gave everything for her children. This was such a joy to read, and it definitely brings to light how different some worlds are from each other. I recommend it to pretty much everyone, to be honest. This makes you think twice about the world and the role that race plays in it, and is a great tale of courage and love. Definitely worth picking up!

Hilarious, I must say!!! I loved Trevor's short essays and glances into his childhood and early adulthood. Being in South Africa whilst reading his book has truly changed my perspective on my current environment. 
 How he comes to claim his black identity is also intriguing to me. "I didn't belong with the white kids...the black kids embraced me". He straddles a strenuous line when explaining how he came to grasp with his cultural and racial identities. The way in which he describes his experience is also similar to the experience of black / african-americans in the states. From explaining only understanding the colonizers language to his mother disciplining him because "if she doesn't, the police will", there are several parallels to the South African experience. 
 The parallels of the history of coloured people vs. black people is portrayed in a statement in which he quotes, "The history of coloured people in South Africa is, in this respect, worse than the history of black people in South Africa. For all the black people have suffered, they know who they are. Coloured people don't". For some reason this statement deeply resonated with me and also helped materialize the cultural dissonance I felt as a black person in Africa. 
 OVERALL this book is a great read! Quick and funny!!!

This fine young man has shared what it was like growing up in apartheid Africa with a courageous mother who raised her son, with unconditional love, as a victor and never a victim. Because of her determination to rise above racism, abuse and sexism, she created a man with a heart of gold. I have more love and respect for him having read his life's story. He brings to television a part of that beautiful, curious, energized and intelligent little boy.

This might actually be one of the best books I've ever read (or listened to) in years and years. An amazing story, an amazing writing style, and an even better narrator. I'd recommend this book to anyone and everyone.
This is a great book, read it.

A must-read. Easily one of my favorite books of 2016. I laughed and cried. Not only does this book give valuable insight into post-apartheid and Noah himself but it highlights a beautiful relationship between mother and son.
Could have been 5 stars but the timeline was so OFF in this book. I don't know who edited it, but I want to find them and slap them for how oddly put together the storyline of his life was.

My first real introduction to (or really awareness of) Trevor Noah occurred when he took over The Daily Show from its creator, Jon Stewart. Then I saw him perform live. Following which, a few weeks ago, I watched a documentary on his first solo stand-up show Daywalker in South Africa ... the documentary is called You Laugh, But It's True. I did not walk into this biography without any ideas about his life. 
 But this work illuminates more about his personal experiences as a half-black half-white kid growing up in South Africa during and after apartheid. It really doesn't detail the rise of his career. It focuses more on his relationship with his fearless mother, his relationship with the concept of race (" ...and race is a social construct, so..."), and a large part is actually dedicated to South Africa's cultural, racial, and socialized gender relationships. 
 I think though that Noah's mother, Nombuyiselo, "she who gives" is actually the true subject of his book. His mother chose to bring him into the world, actively. She wanted a child. And as a result, his life was obviously shaped by this relationship between mother and son. She is definitely where he gets his sense of humor. After listening to Trevor tell his mother's story, about her life thus far, I deeply respect her. Even to the point where reconsidering religion and its power in people's lives became part and parcel of my thought processes throughout the book. At first, Noah talks about the three different churches his mother attended every Sunday ... and I was like, "Jesus, I remember that" in the sense that church as a kid for me was actually 3 times as long as mass as other people's churches (uggghh, what a waste of time). And his continually arguments with his mother about why Jesus would rather he rest and take medicine when he was sick on a Sunday than be healed at church were hilarious. His mother's belief and optimism is nothing short of impressive and something to be admired. I, in the meantime, will continue to be a heathen. But she has made me rethink my stance (which is always a interesting and good thing, in my own belief). 
 If you want to read this book, I would actually suggest that you listen to the audiobook. In his own voice and with his own emphasis with the many languages that Noah speaks, this book is indefinitely better.

This book is a difficult book to put down. Trevor shows himself to be a master storyteller. I highly recommend this book to anyone, especially to get an insight into life during apartheid and having to deal with abuse and poverty during the era and just after. 
 *won as a GoodReads Giveaway*

Can you imagine taking over Jon Stewart's seat on "The Daily Show?" 
 Who would want that particular challenge? 
 If you watched Trevor Noah early on and found yourself heading elsewhere for your political skewers and laughs, it may be time to check back. Trevor Noah has hit a groove. His humor is sharp. His "news team" (including Michelle Wolf, Roy Wood Jr., Lewis Black) are terrific. Plus, his interviews are smart. His passions and brainpower come through with his interviews. He is not afraid of a tough question. 
 Reading Born A Crime: Stories From a South African Childhood will make you wonder: how in the world did a guy with that upbringing end up in that chair every night on Comedy Central? Born A Crime doesn't cover that particular transition. The narrative only hints at Trevor Noah's leap to a national television stage. Most of this memoir is focused on his early days in South Africa, particularly the utter poverty in Soweto. Born A Crime is deeply personal. In turns, it is harrowing, funny, and wild. 
 The best stories involve Noah's status as half-black, half-white. Well, the stories seem to all revolve around his status (or non-status). Noah is the son a Xhosa mother and a Swiss-German father. Black. And white. Not white, not black, not from the complicated heritage known as coloured. Born A Crime is a story of survival--among authorities, on the streets, in church, among scrappy teenagers, in the dance clubs, and among the opposite sex. Noah's strong mother, Patricia Nombuyiselo Noah, dominates Trevor's world. She's the woman with a three-church Sunday routine. She's fearless, exacting, and determined. 
 Frequently, Noah leans on his multilingual skills to overcome tight social and personal situations, particularly one harrowing moment in prison. Noah knows Zulu, Tswana, Tsonga, English (and more) and shows the power of language and its ability to soften potentially tricky situations. Noah grew up as an eternal outsider with his light skin in a sprawling black township of Soweto. That outsider status forced him to make tough social and personal decisions over and over again. 
 As a teenager, Noah built a business copying and selling pirated CD's and then transitioned into a wildly popular D.J., throwing massive dance parties in a nearby shantytown called Alexandria. (The "Go Hitler" chapter offers a compelling reminder that the title of World Despot Ever goes to different people depending on where you live.) 
 Noah lived with death all around and, ultimately, violence comes home in the final gripping scenes as Noah's drunken stepfather turns on Noah's beloved mother with a gun. Riveting. 
 The book is as much about Noah's mother as it is about Trevor. It's clear that his mother wanted Trevor to set his sights on a distant horizon--and also wanted him to make good choices (even as he spent his formative years making poor ones, stealing candy or learning how to hustle stolen goods). 
 I listened to Trevor's narration on Audible. He is a very good storyteller. He knows how to set the scene and build dramatic tension over and over again. He's also a sharp observer. Of people, class, race, authority, religion. 
 And himself. He's also, it seems, fearless. No wonder he felt like he could step into Jon Stewart's shoes.

Such an amazing story; really fascinating glimpse into (a) life during apartheid. I laughed at some of the stories, was heartbroken by others and was impressed by the positivity that seems to be a foundation of his personality.

2ND TIME: I listened to the audiobook for this novel and it was just as amazing as I expected it to be! 
 _____________________________________________________________ 
 This book was something I'd been looking forward to reading for quite a while now. Ever since I watched that first Trevor Noah comedy special on Netflix, and then the next, and the one after that, I've been interesting in the life he lived in South Africa. 
 Hearing about what people in South Africa went through, for the first time in my life, was a real eye opener. It's shocking to me that it's not something we hear much about, other than the stories of Nelson Mandela. 
 This book was so incredibly honest, and at times heart-wrenching. The strength of Trevor's mother is something to aspire towards, as well as her incredible determination to make her own decisions and live her life the way she wants to. 
 Trevor has only cemented my love for all he does through this book, and I look forward to following his career in the future.
Fascinating and well written. I was pleasantly surprised by how enjoyable this book was.

4.5 stars. 
 I hesitated to read this for the longest time because I have watched all of his stand up specials and thought this would just be the same stories (*cough* Amy Schumer). Instead I found an inside look into apartheid and the culture of South Africa. Incredibly interesting and is a book I highly recommend.

I discovered Trevor Noah's stand up a few years before he was named as the new Daily Show host and immediately fell in love with his unique perspective of comedy and the refreshing voice he has within the stand up world because of his upbringing. When his book was announced I expected the same sort of writing from other stand up memoirs but was pleasantly surprised by the book's tone. I found the memoir to be an incredible history of South Africa from the perspective of an outsider on the inside. I do feel that a majority of the book's success is how it is marketed more towards and American audience than to an international one. Being British with family from South Africa a lot of the history of apartheid explained in the book wasn't news to me. Although I thoroughly enjoyed the unique history lesson, I found that I was looking for an even deeper history of South Africa as the book is almost a narrative text book for those years. I listened to the audiobook and must say, Noah's voice lends itself perfectly to the genre and his use of different dialect accents and South African languages is wonderful in this medium and I definitely suggest checking out the audiobook whether you've already read it in print or not
Best audiobook this year.
Funny enlightening memoir about growing up in South Africa with a very strong mother. The audiobook version is read by the author and is excellent.

The Daily Show has taken on some added credibility as I read Trevor Noah's absolutely remarkable story. He tells it with much humor. It is personal, absorbing, and intimate with discussions of the realities of race and apartheid, then and now. For the society Trevor was born into, he was privileged, and this book is a paean to that privilege: his mother. I like this man, and I like his mother even more.

I already adored Trevor as a comedian before I read his book, but now I also admire him a lot as a human being. He's been through some tough shit and managed to stay positive at the end of it and even write about it in a way that is both humorous and heartbreaking, and sometimes rather philosophical. 
 I've learnt a little bit more about the world as well, since 20th century South Africa is not exactly well covered in school history lessons. 
 I recommend the audiobook read brilliantly by Trevor himself.

I'm a fan of Trevor Noah's commentary and intellect on the Daily Show and in his standup. His memoir demonstrates additional depth. He grew up as an outsider, using his observation to understand historical context in South Africa. Noah juxtaposes his personal experience with the political climate. 
 It's a really important read to understand how a government justifies racism, then creates an atmosphere where citizens redirect blame. "The genius of apartheid was convincing people who were the overwhelming majority to turn on each other. Apart hate, is what it was. You separate people into groups and make them hate one another so you can run them all." (3) 
 He also writes extensively about access to resources, and how that changed his trajectory. He understands that talent is not enough, and it is a privilege of the middle and upper class to think that talent is all one needs: People love to say, "Give a man a fish, and he'll eat for a day. Teach a man to fish, and he'll eat for a lifetime." What they don't say is, "And it would be nice if you have him a fishing rod." (190)

Trevor Noah's stories about growing up in South African right after apartheid ended offer a wealth of nonfiction mentor texts for teachers. 
 I read via an audio book w/ Noah narrating. Hearing his voice adds to the richness of these stories. 
 Each story subtly confronts social justice issues relevant to our time as well as common term themes such as "How do I fit into the world?" In one story Noah tackles gender communication in a surprising way.

To begin, I love listening to Trevor Noah. To listen to him talk about his life was both entertaining and heartbreaking. I feel as though I understand the way he seems to think now because of what came before. I recommend this book to anyone who wonders about life under apartheid and reality in South Africa.

A co-worker talked about this book, I picked it up to take a look and ended up taking it home. I didn't know much about Trevor Noah previous to it, and found I really enjoyed what he had to say. 
 I bought the audiobook, as he narrates it himself and I felt that'd be interesting to listen to at a later date. 
 The book itself covers his childhood/teens in South Africa. There are pieces of perspective, insight and wisdom interspersed with stories about his life, his mother, his stepfather and brother and his experience as a mixed race ("colored") child during Apartheid. Note: If you don't know much about Apartheid, this is a good introduction. 
 There's a lot of "real life" in this book and it could be a depressing read, but Noah saves it from getting too heavy with his humor and engaging storytelling.
i was laughing,crying, and laugh crying while reading this book
I absolutely loved this memoir by Trevor Noah. What an amazing life he has led! He's a terrific storyteller and the story he has to tell is amazing! I highly recommend it!

This was a fascinating book on a couple of levels. I've watched Trevor Noah in a stand up special and on The Daily Show and this gives a lot of insight into what shaped him growing up. It also gives a peek into South Africa during Apartheid. Being the white, suburban American that I am, I have been blessed in not personally experiencing racial discrimination but Noah's stories were both eye-opening and gut-wrenching. There is a good deal of humor here as well and I would love to meet his mother. The last hour or so is about a very difficult life event for Noah and it was a bit of a rough listen but I'm glad I heard it. Noah's talent at performance is on display in the audio version and made the story even more entertaining and immediate.

I loved this book. The only thing I would have liked was to hear more at the end that brought the story up to current time - how he came to America, how he got the job at The Daily Show. It was a bit of an odd place to end the book and almost made it more about his mother than about him. But it was a great book. 
 I love his thoughts on language and belonging. The historical information about growing up in apartheid and its aftermath was fascinating. His mother also sounds like a very strong, very determined woman. There was a lot of humor to be found, as well as darker moments. I read the book, but I'd also like to listen to it on audio because I understand he reads the text himself and I think that would add to the stories he tells. 
 Wonderful! 
 Book description: 
 The compelling, inspiring, and comically sublime story of one man's coming-of-age, set during the twilight of apartheid and the tumultuous days of freedom that followed 
 Trevor Noah's unlikely path from apartheid South Africa to the desk of The Daily Show began with a criminal act: his birth. Trevor was born to a white Swiss father and a black Xhosa mother at a time when such a union was punishable by five years in prison. Living proof of his parents' indiscretion, Trevor was kept mostly indoors for the earliest years of his life, bound by the extreme and often absurd measures his mother took to hide him from a government that could, at any moment, steal him away. Finally liberated by the end of South Africa's tyrannical white rule, Trevor and his mother set forth on a grand adventure, living openly and freely and embracing the opportunities won by a centuries-long struggle. 
 Born a Crime is the story of a mischievous young boy who grows into a restless young man as he struggles to find himself in a world where he was never supposed to exist. It is also the story of that young man's relationship with his fearless, rebellious, and fervently religious mother--his teammate, a woman determined to save her son from the cycle of poverty, violence, and abuse that would ultimately threaten her own life. 
 The stories collected here are by turns hilarious, dramatic, and deeply affecting. Whether subsisting on caterpillars for dinner during hard times, being thrown from a moving car during an attempted kidnapping, or just trying to survive the life-and-death pitfalls of dating in high school, Trevor illuminates his curious world with an incisive wit and unflinching honesty. His stories weave together to form a moving and searingly funny portrait of a boy making his way through a damaged world in a dangerous time, armed only with a keen sense of humor and a mother's unconventional, unconditional love.

This book is brilliant. I'll admit I am in ignorant American. I know of Aparthied other than it was bad. Trevor Noah gives us a glimpse of life post Aparthied for a mixed race child. This book was enlightening, heartbreaking, and eye opening. Trevor Noah is an effortless storyteller.

Loved the book, very insightful. I heard the audio book and really liked the fact that it was narrated by Trevor Noah himself. It was a wonderful glimpse into life in SA, some parts were very relatable to life in India.
Excellent storytelling, insightful discussion of race, language, and South African culture. I recommend listening to this one.

I remain iffy on Trevor Noah. I think his comedy can be hit-or-miss, and I think his views of American politics are naive. But, the story of his childhood is a fascinating one. Namely because Noah, the "colored" child of a black South African and a white Swiss, was a bad-ass child. 
 He ran his mother ragged. He set fire to a house. He committed petty crime. But, when you hear him tell his own story, you can't help but root for him. 
 The book does exactly what is written on the tin. It's a book about his childhood. If you're looking for a memoir about his career or his stint on the The Daily Show, you're gonna be disappointed. It's also clearly written for a non-South African audience; Noah does a great job at explaining the insidiousness of apartheid and systematic racism. 
 For the most part, this book is a pretty light-hearted collection of humorous anecdotes about school, friendship, teenage romances, parties and drinking. I recommend it, though, for the final chapter in which Noah recounts life with his abusive stepfather. The way he describes the household is spot on and I wished he'd been able to expand on this part of his life.

Smart, insightful, and addicting. 
 I've learned so much.

Do yourself a favor and get this book in audio version. Trevor Noah narrated the book himself, which really added to it. 
 Everyone has been telling me to read this. Now I know why. Where else can you read a first hand account of apartheid and be mortified and laugh at the same time? I highly recommend this incredible account of Trevor Noah's life. Spectacular.

For all I know, this book is absolute shit, but I read it during a really difficult time in my life and it made me laugh, cry, reflect, laugh and cry and laugh and cry simultaneously, so I am giving it 5 stars, because what more do I need from a book? I'll reassess after I read it again, because I definitely will read it again.
This book is hands down a great read. Trevor Noah's life story is compelling and his wit and intelligence shine. If you haven't read it go right now and do so.

I rarely read celebrity autobiographies, but since Born A Crime appeared to focus on an eventful childhood and issues of racism etc. rather than being about his career, I decided to give it a go, and I'm so glad I did. It blew me away. 
 I didn't get the audiobook, but it was it was so well written that in my head Trevor was reading it to me anyway. I was completely drawn in, and a vivid picture was painted to me of his world, his family and his relationship with his mother, who is a central figure in his story and an astounding woman in many ways. I know very little about South Africa, and I learnt a lot from the book, as there was a wealth of information woven deftly into and between chapters. It was compelling, moving, full of moments where I gasped or laughed, and will be on my mind for some time to come.

I already liked Trevor Noah, his comedy, his turn at the Daily Show desk...all great things!! But this book...wow! His writing is so conversational, I can hear the tone of his voice in every sentence. It's like he's sitting next to you telling the stories of his childhood in South Africa. 
 It's interesting to read his story because he is not bitter (he has a right to be.) He doesn't write out of anger (he would be justified in doing so.) He makes these insights into his past, into institutional racism, into apartheid that just force you to stop and think. 
 I recommend everyone read this book! I believe we should step into the shoes of other people who are vastly different from us in order to better understand them and in turn...ourselves as well!

One of the first things I learned about South Africa was my parents telling me they'd have been in separate hotels rooms if they'd gone for their anniversary like they'd planned to do, because one of them is white and the other is not. 
 As a child, I didn't compute the gravitas of that potential situation, and I certainly didn't consider what it'd mean for me as a mixed (or "coloured") person if I went there. And it never really has, not until I read Trevor Noah's startlingly insightful autobiography of growing up during apartheid. 
 There's racism, and then there's a racism that is so ingrained and systematic and institutionalized that it skewers and perpetuates everything about a person's existence, down to where they live, who they can live with, and the way they think about themselves, and that's exactly what apartheid looked it. The extent of which this ideology was driven into people's heads is disturbing as it is fascinating of how deeply entrenched an entire can be run based on the most arbitrary and ever-changing social constructs in existence. It was an evil so deeply rooted it's a wonder they ever managed to untangle it. 
 But this isn't a depressing or dark book, because Noah's humour, his wit and worldview is just as uplifting and full of energy as his stand-up comedy is. There's some genuine laugh-out loud moments in here, and his mother is the sort of person you wish you could meet in real life. Noah never gets didactic, he tells his childhood the way he lived it and it's an absolute blast to sit through. There isn't a dull moment in this rich and multi-layered narrative. If you didn't already like Trevor Noah and admire his work, you'll do so even more after this.

Mother/daughter-in-law book club pick. The anecdotes were interesting set against the backdrop of post-Apartheid South Africa. As such, I learned more about Apartheid than I ever have before. I wasn't very familiar with Trevor Noah before reading this book, so maybe that's part of the reason I had trouble connecting with it. Certain parts of the book were hard to read; that is, there was some intense stuff going on in Noah's life. And I almost thought about putting the book down when I came to the part about the cats. Trevor's mother, despite my distaste for corporal punishment, was pretty amazing and deserves her part as the central figure in this book. Noah's storytelling is also very good.

I was not too familiar with Trevor Noah, that is to say I knew he was the replacement on the daily show and he was a South African comedian. I read a brief bio and the book was recommended on Good Reads by a former student, so I said why not. I am glad I did. 
 For me I think the book worked better not knowing much about the writer, so I came to it with fresh eyes, and totally unbiased. It is a well written, well constructed memoir that uses some twists and plot devices usually found in fiction to tell his story, and tell it effectively. Trevor was born in a tumultuous time and place and survived some rather trying times and speaks about them elegantly and makes it possible to instill some empathy in the reader for an experience that one could not possibly know about, that is the power of the writing in this book. 
 I am impressed and thought that this book was great. Subsequently I did watch a few of his comedy specials and some Daily show reruns. You can see the spark of genius in them, and in this book.

** spoiler alert ** 
 There is only 1 comedian who can turn the harsh cruelty of apartheid & abuse from a heartless stepfather into a rib cracking laughing till tears come out joke. I thoroughly enjoyed reading this book. Even though 1 or 2 times I almost cried, I laughed all the way. Definitely highly recommended.

I listened to this book read by the author Trevor Noah. I learned a bit about apartheid in South Africa from the perspective of the author as a illegal young boy - as it was illegal to be mixed race. The book did a good job of getting inside apartheid and helping me to see what it was like to grow up in that horrible environment. Although the topic is hard this book also has many comical moments; it was nice to learn and laugh at the same time.

Trevor Noah is a great storyteller, and these episodes from his life are always engaging, often hilarious, and provide great insight into the legacy of South African apartheid - showing both its evil and absurdity. 
 I highly recommend listening to Born a Crime on audio; Trevor Noah is such a talented narrator that it seems almost a crime to enjoy this memoir in any other way.

Noah's comedic timing and writing style makes this memoir about apartheid, racism and some violence palatable and even funny! His writing is compelling and his mother is inspiring. I'm so glad I read this- I laughed, I gasped, and I nodded throughout his chapters. Great book!

I absolutely adored this. This is a memoir by a celebrity, but not a celebrity memoir -- if that makes sense. Noah tells us about his life growing up in Apartheid South Africa and the period immediately after Apartheid ended. He tells us of the realities of life when your very existence was a crime when you were a child and what it was like to not feel like you belong in any group. He is straightforward and hilarious, even when the situations break your heart. He was also extraordinarily ornery and his retellings of the scenarios he got himself into will make you laugh out loud. In many ways, this is a tribute to his wonderful, spirited mother who saw him through some very tough times and helped him to develop his sense of self. I listened to this on audio and loved the experience of hearing him tell his own story. I loved it so much, I bought a hard copy when the audio was over so I could revisit it any time.
I listened to the audiobook and loved it. I laughed and cried. Do yourself a favor and read this awesome book.

I confess I didn't know who Trevor Noah was, but I began seeing his book on many "best of" lists and in my Goodreads feed. When I found out the meaning of the title, that he was literally born a crime in South Africa under apartheid because his mother is black and his father is white, I knew I had to read it. 
 It was illegal to be "colored", the term used in SA for a person of mixed race. His very existence was a crime. His mother often pretended to be his maid so she could take him out in public. Noah tells us how he navigated extreme poverty and a social system where he never fit in anywhere, even after apartheid ended. But he was quite the enterprising, mischievous boy, which makes for much of the humor in the book. 
 What makes this book shine though is Noah himself narrates the audiobook. He's funny, intelligent and charming. He can make even a horrific situation funny. The tales of poverty, domestic abuse, and racism is sad yet Noah's comedic talents in telling the story blunts some of the horrors (at least until a particularly horrific event near the end). 
 How a boy raised in these difficult circumstances rises to become the replacement for Jon Stewart on the Daily Show is nothing short of amazing and is a testament to his resilience, grit, and the blessing of a loving yet tough mother. Yet Noah doesn't speak about his rise to fame, or his role on The Daily Show. His reason for writing was not to puff himself up, and regale us with tales on his road to fame. The reader leaves educated and more aware of the effects of poverty, abuse, racism, and how a political system like apartheid affects those who live under it. 
 I was both entertained and educated. It doesn't get better than that. Highly recommended, especially the audiobook - to hear Noah tell his story in his own words, with comedic timing, and the inflections and accents used for different people, is priceless.
I wish I could figure out how to express my feelings about this book, but I can't... just read it. Or better yet, listen to it.
Hell of a story.
A great story that is funny and heartbreaking.

Fascinating memoir of Noah's time growing up in South Africa. While the structure is roughly chronological, the storytelling loops back and forth in time, gradually filling in details and providing a fuller and fuller picture of the world and humans within it. It's not a funny book but a true window into a very specific world and time in the life of a comedian.

One of the most impactful memoirs I've ever listened to. And not least of all because I really had no idea what I was getting into. It's amazing how successful Trevor Noah has been, given the colorful experiences in his life. 
 More importantly, it prompted me to re-examine my understanding of poverty, crime, and the relationship between the two. A few years ago I was fortunate to travel to Nicaragua, to a beautiful resort...located just outside the poorest area I've ever seen. It was a life-changing realization. This book continues that changed trajectory in understanding what life is like outside my privileged bubble. 
 I'd recommend this as a "read" for anyone.
This is the best book I've read (listened to) in a long time.
It is an amazing book. His mom is the real hero in the book. Inspires to see the positive side even a very difficult condition.

Not knowing what to expect of this book, but enjoying Noah's brand of humor I threw myself into this book and soon found that I loved it! 
 The book only in the very briefest terms touches on his later career as a comedian (but not at all on his host gig at the Daily Show), it is an honest account of his upbringing in South Africa, at first under Apartheid, and later a country conflicted and confused in its aftermath. 
 The book comments on the confusing political, racial, and tribal undercurrents through Noah's experiences while growing up, going to school and a young man growing up. 
 He accounts for the situation of being a son of a black mother and white father, being the stepson of an alcoholic, abusive man that the police wouldn't hold accountable for his actions and his god-adoring, very religious mother. 
 This book gives us a fantastic view of what Noah's upbringing was like and what shaped him into the man and comedian he is today. 
 While I have always enjoyed his brand of humor, this book has further endeared him to me. I highly recommend this book, not just as an autobiography of comedian, because it isn't particularly funny, but deliver a picture of what life is like for less-privileged in South Africa.

I ended up listening this book through Audible, and I'm really glad I did. Hearing Trevor Noah tell his story made the book much more enjoyable for me. Especially because language factors so much into the telling. Since Noah speaks so many languages, I got to hear the actual sounds, something I would not have gotten had I read it. Trevor's story is an incredible one. Born under apartheid and growing up in the aftermath of its dissolution, Trevor tells a story that many of us in America know nothing about. He is insightful and sharp with his analysis of the conditions of his country, and is not afraid to represent his reality in all of its love, wonder, fear and difficulty. I also really loved the fact that most of his story centers around the relationship with his mother. Parts of this book were hilarious, like his stories about his dance crew being kicked out of a Jewish school because one of the dancers was named Hitler by his mother. Other parts were hard to listen to, like the stories of growing up with his abusive step-father. The only thing that I wasn't a big fan of was the way the story was structured. I liked that he didn't keep things strictly chronological, since many of the stories were thematically related, however, sometimes the jumps and transitions were hard to follow. Otherwise, loved this book.

Let's start with gushing about how I loved this book! I don't know why I didn't have higher expectations, but wherever my expectations were (and I don't think they were that low), this book totally exceeded them. 
 Noah writes this in a very natural, talkative tone, which at times I found slightly irritating, crass, or rude (some swearing seemed unnecessary, not to mention the slanginess - I think this book would have still been highly readable without it), but for the most part I think it worked. It made me feel closer to the writer and the story. 
 I particularly loved the early parts of the book, which had a lot of information on the linguistic diversity of South Africa, plenty of dialogue written out it a non-English language (and then translated in the narrative) and early adventures and misadventures experiences by Noah in the realm of language. The earliest pages also had a lot of casual background information on Apartheid and South African politics - no way near enough to make me think I knew anything, but enough to pique my curiosity, and understand the various situations presented in the book. 
 Parts of the book were just very funny. The main body of the book is just full of anecdotes and stories from Noah's childhood and young adulthood, and great fun to read about. 
 Noah did an interesting thing with the organization of the book: he talked about the world he was born into, and his specific situation, with some seriousness. Then he got into the generally funny part. He told the rest of the story of his life through his early twenties in chronological order. And then, once he was caught up, he went back to the beginning to tell the story of his abusive stepfather, going back to his younger years when the stepdad first showed up, and told that story with a level of gravity that had not been present throughout most of the book. I wasn't sure what I thought of this tactic, but in retrospect I think it worked out all right. As a comedian it seems Noah wanted to tell his story a certain way, and by using this structure he was able to do that, and still managed not to leave anything out. It is slightly awkward, but pretty effective.

This was really good. I have been a Trevor Noah fan since my sister told me about him a few years ago and I watched one of his specials on Netflix. Then for my 1 year anniversary with my now husband, we saw him live and he was even better than on TV. When I found out he had written a book, I couldn't wait to read it and I am so glad that I did. It was enlightening, insightful, funny and very honest. I loved hearing about his relationship with his mother, how he came to know his father, learning more about apartheid and how that affected him as a mixed child growing up in South Africa and how he came to be where he is today. I actually listened to it as an audiobook, which I really enjoyed because he has such a soothing voice and he is great at doing variations and inflections on his voice to make it sound younger, older or pretty much anything. Bottom line, it was a great read and it makes me respect and love Trevor Noah even more.

Wow! What a great read that was. I've always liked Trevor Noah, but his back story is really something. This book was funny, emotional, exciting, inspiring, just all around brilliant and, since I listened to the audiobook version, I must really commend Trevor on his narrating skills. The guy is a natural and should consider doing other voiceover work. Loved his different accents. Loved his version of great-grandmother, coco. I almost burst a blood vessel trying not to laugh out loud in my office listening to the poop in the kitchen story as he did her voice trying to figure out what was happening (it was dark and she was half blind with cataracts) and him, this little boy, pooping on newspaper because he was too frightened to go to the outhouse at night, in the rain. If you want a good hard laugh, but are also prepared for a lot of grit, drama, emotion and one heckuva plot twist, I highly recommend this book.

In this memoir, Trevor Noah describes his experiences growing up in South Africa during apartheid. With a black mother and white father, Noah never really fit into any one community, and was often labeled differently than he identified. His stories are funny and light-hearted at times, but also meaningful as he intelligently describes his observations of race, culture, language, belonging, family structure, domestic violence, crime, and implications of racism and sexism in modern society. 
 I really enjoyed his perspectives on language. He himself speaks many languages including English, Afrikaans, and Native tribal languages of South Africa, and he explains that by speaking another person's language we recognize that person as an individual and we make an attempt to respect him. I also realized how little I understood about life under apartheid and the hatred, ostracism, discrimination, and misunderstanding that still exist in modern times. 
 The essays seems somewhat out of order at times, and I would have liked to learn more about Noah's life after leaving South Africa and how he adapted to American culture, but overall I rated this book as 5 stars for his intelligent observations and entertaining stories.

Memoirs often make good audiobooks; comedians often make good audiobooks; people with non-American accents often make good audiobooks; comedian memoirs with foreign accents make THE BEST audiobooks. 
 Trevor Noah weaves political and personal history in this story about his upbringing in Johannesburg, South Africa. His narration is passionate and nuanced that include the many real life characters whose voices he has developed through his stand up. Noah can speak a handful Southern African languages and he often includes whole lines of dialogue in Xhosa or Zulu for example. Though, my Zim born husband finds his vocal character work not as interesting as my unaccustomed ear. I maintain for the moment that Trevor Noah is a VERY handsome man reading VERY handsomely. :) 
 This would make a good primer for anyone wanting to learn more about the realities of post apartheid life or race in a post colonial state. With caveats for language, I think this would also make a a very engaging upper highschool read (and probably came out too late in the year to get on the Alex Awards radar?) This is clearly written for an American market unfamiliar with South African culture and history and I thought did the job of explaining terms and concepts in a way that was respectful to both audience and subject manner. 
 Wished there was more about the beginning of his job in comedy; didn't get explained or explored at all. Though I see this mostly as childhood memoir and portrait of his mother rather than a memoir of one's life so far. Enjoyable and informative.

** spoiler alert ** 
 So strange that even though all he has bin through, you can still find pieces of a happy kid in the book. I mean abusive stepfather, not belonging anywhere, poverty. And still he seems like a normal kid who gets in trouble all the time and has difficulties talking to girls. I loved this book!

I love Trevor Noah, but did not know much about him before the Daily Show. I was amazed at what he experienced, and even more amazed at what a great man he evolved into. Thanks for entertaining us, and praise to your mother for bringing up such a person.

I do not listen to audio books, but I bought the audio of this one so I could listen to Trevor Noah tell his own story. I also wanted to listen to it with my son - also a fan - so he could hear a first account of what apartheid was like and what it is like to grow up black, or "colored" as Trevor Noah did. While some of the subjects may be heavy for a 9 year old, this book gave us so much to talk about, and it made my son more curious to want to understand more. It was entertaining at many times, but also touching and shared many life lessons. I also highly appreciate Noah sharing his mother's story and the lessons she taught him. Really really loved it.

Good car listen. Trevor Noah isn't funny so his delivery (Audible) is obnoxious. Fascinating first-person perspectives on living during the time of apartheid (and immediately following) as a colored person. Parallels between colorism in S.A and the US.

As a mixed person I was very excited to read Trevor's life story. I know what it was like to grow up around the same time in America but I had no idea of the hardships for a "colored person" in South Africa. Our stories were similar; a strong willed mother who refused to give into "cultural norms". I learned so very much about South Africa and feel more connected to my mother after reading about Trevor's relationship with his. This is a must read. Thank you for sharing your life !
Absolutely wonderful. Funny, sometimes sad, and hugely enlightening about growing up under apartheid. Highly recommend the audiobook!

Excellent book - weighty material written in a light enough style to still be extremely readable. Don't read this expecting a comedy routine - this is Noah describing how he became who he is, and in particular, the role his mother played in shaping him.

This book was highly enjoyable and very touching. It's easy to see how he's used humor to live through pain and his relationship with his mom is beautiful. I wasn't a fan of chapter 15 tho... other then that I really enjoyed it.
Read this in a day. Loved it.
I listened to the audiobook of this, which isn't normally my jam, but hearing his own voice totally made the book for me.

I couldn't put this book down. You know, I was never a big Trevor Noah fan (didn't hate him either - I felt like he was meh), but now I like him a lot after reading this. It had me going through an entire range of emotions but mostly I was laughing! This book was memorable and taught me a lot about not only him but South Africa in general. I really appriciate that.

This is an amazing story that you do not normally hear from celebrities about their childhood. I already enjoyed Trevor Noah very much on the Daily Show; but after reading this, I greatly respect the work he has had to do to make into stardom and success. For a comedian to do a book that isn't funny, it was a very defined change of pace. I am glad he took the time to tell us his story. I am sure he will put out plenty of funny books later in his career.

Fascinating and intensely personal. I highly recommend the author-narrated audio...it's a great collection of stories from a significant time in South Africa's history. I don't watch the Daily Show and have only seen random clips of Trevor Noah on social media. It's a quick read and incredibly interesting.
I laughed and learned the whole time then one part I bawled my eyes out. I was listening on audiobook so I was crying in my car
A beautiful and chilling autobiography. Trevor has such an interesting view of the world. I'm going to watch his show now because of his book.

Beautiful beautiful beautiful!! I loved this memoir. Trevor Noah is such a unique and amazing guy and I feel so honored to have had an insight to his life in South Africa. He gave us not only insight to his life but also into the world of apartheid and how it has affected the social political and economic atmosphere in the country. What's even more beautiful is the respect that this man has for his mother. Goodness it's amazing and beautiful. I have so much to say about this book and I can't wait to right a full review.

This book was a deep dive into Apartheid era South Africa. Trevor did a great job of narrating a very emotional growing up period with humor. Race or racism is an ugle spectre but in South Africa, the fact that he existed was a crime. 
 A very well written book that holds a lot of life lessons for anyone who can recognize the struggle of coming from a poor background. His background surely has prepared him for the roles he currently fills now. He now has the ability to relate to people from different backgrounds and his language skills definitely set him apart from many that have blazed a similar trail. 
 Being an only child gave him a strong imagination and a knack for being very observant that has served him well in his career. 
 I am a fan of his balanced philosophical approach to the turmoil in his family life. 
 A must read for any one who wants an insight into Apartheid era South Africa from a black African perspective. Hopes, dreams and aspirations of the people versus the system that was designed to keep them in a particular place of not being able to aspire to much in life.

This book has officially ruined all other celebrity memoires/nonfiction for me. It was too damn good. It is very unlikely any others will be this. damn. good. 
 Trevor's stories are hilarious and eye-opening. Better yet, they all shape the decision he has to make as a man at the very end of the book. 
 "Failure is an answer. Rejection is an answer. Regret is an eternal question you will never have the answer to. "What if..." "If only..." "I wonder what would have..." You will never, never know, and it will haunt you for the rest of your days." 
 You will regret not reading this incredible life story.
My jaw was on the floor when I put this down. Not the best writing, but a most engaging story.

I was pretty sure that I was going to both enjoy and be enlightened by Trevor Noah's Born a Crime from the first few pages, which were fill of witty, pithy, yet accurate and often poignant observations such as these: 
 "The genius of apartheid was convincing people who were the overwhelming majority to turn on each other. Apart hate, is what it was. You separate people into groups and make them hate one another so you can run them all." 
 "The Zulu went to war with the white man. The Xhosa played chess with the white man. For a long time neither was particularly successful, and each blamed the other for a problem neither had created. Bitterness festered. For decades those feelings were held in check by a common enemy. Then apartheid fell, Mandela walked free, and black South Africa went to war with itself." 
 "Like indigenous peoples around the world, black South Africans adopted the religion of our colonizers. By "adopt" I mean it was forced on us. The white man was quite stern with the native. 'You need to pray to Jesus,' he said. "Jesus will save you.' To which the native replied, 'Well, we do need to be saved--saved from you, but that's beside the point. So let's give this Jesus thing a shot.' " 
 "For a long time I didn't understand why so many black people had abandoned their indigenous faith for Christianity. But the more we went to church and the longer I sat in those pews the more I learned about how Christianity works: If you're Native American and you pray to the wolves, you're a savage. If you're African and you pray to your ancestors, you're a primitive. But when white people pray to a guy who turns water into wine, well, that's just common sense." 
 Noah's book is part autobiography, part South African history, and part social and political commentary, wrapped up in just enough wit and comedic structure and timing to make it flow smoothly and swiftly, until all of a sudden you're brought up short with a 'wtf?' feeling as you realise the full meaning of what you've just read.
