 I've had a lot of respect for Noah's presence on TV as a successor to Jon Stewart on The Daily Show. I now also have a lot of respect for him as an author - and as a man who lived through South Africa's troubled post-apartheid times and saw truths so clearly. 
 His account of his childhood, growing up as a child of mixed race, is lightly told, but horrifying. Under the segregation laws of South Africa, it was illegal for white people to have sex with non-white people; as a child of such a union, Noah was, as the title of the book says, 'born a crime.' His parents were not married - that would have been impossible - nor did they live together. Though his mother lived - quietly, secretly, illegally - in Johannesburg near his father's apartment, Noah could only spend time with his father in private. 
 "Where most children are proof of their parents' love, I was the proof of their criminality. The only time I could be with my father was indoors. If we left the house, he'd have to walk across the street from us. My mom and I used to go to Joubert Park all the time. It's the Central Park of Johannesburg--beautiful gardens, a zoo, a giant chessboard with human-sized pieces that people would play. My mother tells me that once, when I was a toddler, my dad tried to go with us. We were in the park, he was walking a good bit away from us, and I ran after him, screaming, "Daddy! Daddy! Daddy!" People started looking. He panicked and ran away. I thought it was a game and kept chasing him." 
 But it wasn't just his father who could not acknowledge him publicly. His mother, a dark-skinned Xhosa woman, could not be seen with a 'coloured' - the South African classification for person of mixed race - child without everyone knowing she had committed the crime of sleeping with a white man. 
 "It was illegal to be mixed (to have a black parent and a white parent), but it was not illegal to be colored (to have two parents who were both colored). So my mom moved me around the world as a colored child. She found a creche in a colored area where she could leave me while she was at work. There was a colored woman named Queen who lived in our block of flats. When we wanted to go out to the park, my mom would invite her to go with us. Queen would walk next to me and act like she was my mother, and my mother would walk a few steps behind, like she was the maid working for the colored woman. I've got dozens of pictures of me walking with this woman who looks like me but who isn't my mother. And the black woman standing behind us who looks like she's photobombing the picture, that's my mom. When we didn't have a colored woman to walk with us, my mom would risk walking me on her own. She would hold my hand or carry me, but if the police showed up she would have to drop me and pretend I wasn't hers, like I was a bag of weed." 
 It was just as much a problem when his mother took him to visit his black relatives in Soweto. A coloured child in a black township was just as much a threat to his family as a coloured child in a white city. 
 "My gran still tells the story of when I was three years old and, fed up with being a prisoner, I dug a hole under the gate in the driveway, wriggled through, and ran off. Everyone panicked. A search party went out and tracked me down. I had no idea how much danger I was putting everyone in. The family could have been deported, my gran could have been arrested, my mom might have gone to prison, and I probably would have been packed off to a home for colored kids. So I was kept inside." 
 Noah's memories of his childhood make one thing perfectly clear - that he attributes much of his own character to his mother's independence and choices to live as far as she could outside the legal and social limitations imposed by South African apartheid. 
 "My mom raised me as if there were no limitations on where I could go or what I could do. When I look back I realize she raised me like a white kid--not white culturally, but in the sense of believing that the world was my oyster, that I should speak up for myself, that my ideas and thoughts and decisions mattered. 
 We tell people to follow their dreams, but you can only dream of what you can imagine, and, depending on where you come from, your imagination can be quite limited. Growing up in Soweto, our dream was to put another room on our house. Maybe have a driveway. Maybe, someday, a cast-iron gate at the end of the driveway. Because that is all we knew. But the highest rung of what's possible is far beyond the world you can see. My mother showed me what was possible. The thing that always amazed me about her life was that no one showed her. No one chose her. She did it on her own. She found her way through sheer force of will." 
 Noah completed the book prior to his becoming an American TV host, and the book itself contains very little about his professional life, or how he made the transition from a teenaged boy hustling pirated CDs to get by, to a well-known and admired comedian and TV personality. Perhaps that's for another book. 
 This one is the narrative of a mixed race child growing up in one of the most oppressive and racist societies in the world, and surviving. And it's well worth reading.

Trigger warning for extreme domestic violence in this memoir. 
 Real rating is probably more a 4* for me personally, there was some very non-vegetarian friendly things that had me gagging, but I honestly couldn't give these stories less than 5*, how can you. We can say the extra star is for the effortless narration if you like. 
 I don't think I have ever felt so angry and ashamed as I have when listening to this book. It is an important and necessary read, and I got some understanding of apartheid that is a topic I'm not well versed in. 
 I would highly recommend the audiobook if you can get your hands on it, Trevor Noah is a brilliant narrator as I mentioned above.

I like Trevor Noah, star of the Daily Show. Trevor was an unknown quantity to me when he took over from Jon Stewart. Born a Crime is an autobiography that reveals much about his early life, and even more about the nature of a South Africa in transition from Apartheid.
I didn't know a lot about South Africa and apartheid.... now I do. I can also say that there is so much more to Trevor Noah than the Daily Show!

I loved this collection of stories about Noah's childhood and youth in South Africa. He's frank about his family's often dire circumstances: poverty, apartheid, crime-ridden neighborhoods, an abusive stepfather. But he also writes affectionately, and with great humor, about how his mother communicated to him her astonishing strength of character and perseverance. A delightful read.

Trevor Noah is a natural storyteller. A very easy going, comfortable read. I actually listened as Trevor did the reading of his new book about growing up during and after apartheid. 
 He does a wonderful job explaining how society in South Africa works, culturally, politically, spiritually and the inner workings of family along with racial structure and the caste systems within. 
 I especially love his relationship with his mother. What a wild and interesting character she is. A wholly unique woman who you can tell from Trevor himself loved him deeply and he her. She definitely is the power behind that young mans success. 
 What a hard childhood Trevor had to overcome. But having such a strong woman for a mom, I can see why he became the wonderful young man he is today. 
 I urge anyone to read this flawless account of ones life growing up in South Africa
4.5 stars

I've become wary with celebrity books. They have a couple funny stories, weird coincidences and advice that is worthless without a big checking account. But this book is totally different. Trever brings to light a world view that I would have never known without this book. He has a mix of funny stories growing up as an awkward boy and experiences hardly anyone can relate to as a mixed race boy growing up during apartheid. But what I really love is how he can take those stories and experiences and make us question our own world view. I am telling everyone I know to read this.

What a wonderful memoir! 
 I listened to the audio book which is read by the author. His South African accent adds authenticity as he tells the story of growing up biracial, both under apartheid and after it's repeal. 
 This very well written account is humorous, bittersweet, and uplifting. 
 Highly recommend.

Very interesting read/listen. I cheated and listened to the audiobook which is read by Trevor Noah. He really does a good job bringing the book to life which is no surprise. 
 Growing up in the US, I've never paid too much attention to apartheid as it seemed like here in the US we already had enough depressing race stuff without paying attention to the same issue in other countries. So, for me this was almost also a history lesson. 
 If you enjoy audiobooks, then this is one of those books that lends itself very well to being an enjoyable audiobook so I do recommend that format.
4.5 stars. A fascinating memoir about growing up in South Africa. Made even more special through listening on audiobook - brilliantly narrated.

This is not a funny book, it is a very personal book, that shares Trevor's childhood and growing up stories from South Africa. Extremely unique and magnetic book. 
 white Swiss father and a black mother from the Xhosa tribe, there starts his story where he was already born a crime, since during apartheid, one of the worst crimes you could commit was having sexual relations with a person of another race. Therefore, his parents committed that crime. 
 Trevor couldn't even go out to play with other kids, or even his own cousins. Children could be taken. Children were taken. The wrong color kid in the wrong color area, and the government could come in, strip your parents of custody, haul you off to an orphanage. 
 His mother was religious, and Trevor was questioning religion. "Look, Mom. I know you love Jesus, but maybe next week you could ask him to meet us at our house. Because this really wasn't a fun night." 
 The rules about communion at Friday mass, for example, made absolutely no sense. We'd be in there for an hour of kneeling, standing, sitting, kneeling, standing, sitting, kneeling, standing, sitting, and by the end of it I'd be starving, but I was never allowed to take communion, because I wasn't Catholic. The other kids could eat Jesus's body and drink Jesus's blood, but I couldn't. And Jesus's blood was grape juice. I loved grape juice. Grape juice and crackers--what more could a kid want? And they wouldn't let me have any. I'd argue with the nuns and the priest all the time. 
 Trevor was an entrepreneur (but not of the very legal kind). He got to the hood, and started making money selling pirate music, and then becoming a professional hustler. But he ended up using his life experience to his advantage. An extraordinary man with an extraordinary story. 
 Surviving poverty, crime, religious upbringing, domestic abuse, and so many tough conditions (eating Mopane worms for example). Just a few examples of what's inside. One story includes his mom throwing him out of a driving minibus. Another of how his mother was shot in the head. Crazy story, that shows how Trevor survived and became the man he is today. 4.5 stars.
Adult books for Young Adults

Amazing story of a boy who's very birth was a crime as he had a black mother and white father in apartheid South Africa. It is at times heartbreaking, but mostly hilarious, as Trevor tells his story and that of his family, co-starring his deeply religious but fiery, strong mother.
One of the most powerful books I have ever read! He might have been born a crime, but Trevor was born to also be a storyteller. My full review can be seen on my BookTube: https://youtu.be/f3SmWeXNFSY
Not at all my usual kind of read, but so funny and insightful.

Adult- memoir/autobiography. 
 Reading Trevor Noah's young life through his ear view mirror gives remarkably wide view of history, apartheid, social constructs, and philosophy without a grain of sugar-coating. 
 There are sections of this book I would read aloud to younger audiences (middle school) to share powerful messages from a pop icon- without an ounce of preaching. 
 I've already recommended this to a half dozen people, and will continue to do so. 
 Includes street language and harsh situations, but none are excessive or gratuitous.

I love getting audible books performed by their authors, it gives me that feeling of authenticity. And sometimes I'd get celebrity's books because they are funny and also fun to read. Other than personal stories and anecdotes I never am really none the wiser after reading them. Kinda like watching a funny rom com. But this is not that. 
 I only learned of Trevor Noah when he took the reign over from Jon Stewart. There was a moment in time I was like, this is the worst thing ever! Jon Stewart is the best! But Trevor Noah has been doing a good job and has earned my viewership so far. So when his book came out, I was like hmm this might be interesting, like Tina Fey's or Amy Schumer's book, which both were very enjoyable. Talking mostly about their personal story and how they got to where they are.. But this is not that. 
 This is about South Africa, about apartheid, about women in Africa. I never thought I'd learned so much about African history from a book by a comedian. Yes he wrote largely about his childhood and his early adult life. But his was also the life of a colored child, navigating the complexities of school and family at the time of apartheid. The book was insightful in a way that it shows what life was during and right after apartheid, how white, color and black people were segregated through time, the relationship morphing as apartheid ended. And it was moving. By writing his own story, I got a rare glimpse of who Trevor Noah really is, and respect him so much more because of it. And I cannot end the review by saying how awesome his mother is. She is a jewel of this book and of this world.

This is by far one of the best books I've read in a long time. I'm a fan of the daily show, I watched when it was hosted by John Stewart, and I watch now that Trevor hosts it. I was curious I wanted to know more about his life it seemed interesting to me. It was funny, it was sad, is was stressful, in some respects it was even relatable. Wonderful book.

Having read quite a few books on South Africa and the aftermath of apartheid I thought it was time to catch up on one of my favourite most inspiring parts of the world. Noah's autobiography is honest, funny, sad, gripping and full of energy. It is really a coming of age and depicts Noah's trials and tribulations as a child born from a white father and a black mother in a racially abusive regime under apartheid. His positive upbeat character and that of his mum's helped him through thick and thin and determines his life today as a comedian, presenter and writer with race at the forefront of his internal monologue and of his dialogue with his global audiences. I particularly appreciated this life experience as it lays bare the extremes to which the regime went to divide and conquer the different racial elements in the country. Being white was top, being black at least meant that you belonged to one community or another. But being coloured, that was seemingly an absolute negation of the purity of race at the time for the regime. It is a stark reminder of the Nazi influence on the apartheid government, and it is Noah's generation that is left to deal with the trauma of its consequences. Noah has come out of it well thanks to a wonderful tough mother and a sunny predisposition. I sit here and wonder how long still it will take for South Africans of all walks of life to write stories where race is not the central issue at stake. Maybe naive to hope that when nationalism is on the rise globally. The rainbow nation. Without it the whole world would be less colourful. From an outsider's perspective his story is shocking. And yet this is just one man. What of all the others? A gripping (not for the intellectually minded however!) read.

Completed Book 5: February 11. Admittedly, my entire knowledge of South African history I owe entirely to the Disney Channel original movie, The Color of Friendship." Comedian and The Daily Show host @trevornoah has given me an education, in the form of his book "Born a Crime." Wow. I barely knew anything about the man but this book is an education. Not just on South African history which is intricate and devastating and eye-opening about the reality of human capability (and not in the innovative, Pulitzer Prize winning, humanitarian way but in the "I can't believe human beings and governments perpetrate atrocities to other human beings" way). These stories are intimate beyond belief, and Noah pulls us into his personal memories of awkwardness, violence and convoluted racism. I simultaneously feel that I'm much better informed than I had been prior to reading Trevor's work, yet I remain completely ignorant to what every corner of this world holds in its past and in its present. These stories are unlike anything I've ever read. And I read a lot.
This was amazing on audio. I hope he writes another book about how he ended up here, that's a story I'd also love to hear. He is an excellent writer.
Husband and I listened to this together and both really enjoyed it. Funny, interesting, and well narrated.

The stories of his childhood are fascinating. He really has experienced so many crazy things in South Africa. This genre (memoir?) is not my usual but I liked it and I can see recommending it to others even if it isn't my perfect book. My daughter told me Trevor Noah is pretty liberal in his political views but that is not what this book is about.
I listened to the audio version, and Trevor Noah is a talented storyteller. Both humorous and heartbreaking, this is a worthwhile listen.
Wonderfully written, with Noah's signature sense of humor, given the reality of late 20th century South Africa. I loved this book---well done!
Good read, great insights of a victim of apartheid in S.A and funny too!

If you are looking for the tremendously funny and sarcastic Trevor Noah from Comedy Central, you won't find it here. Noah tells the story of his childhood in South Africa during and after apartheid. He was classified as neither black or white as his Mother was black, and his father was a white businessman that lived on the edges of little Trevor's life and then not at all. Trevor's story revolves mostly around his strict but loving mother, who would do anything for Trevor. The book follows Trevor's dilemma about what (if any) group he fits into. The story turns around when Trevor's Mom marries an abusive man, who hates Trevor because he is not his biological child. I loved this book, but I am giving it a 4, we all know that he came to the US and is a wildly popular comedian/commentator, but I wish this would have been explained. Maybe in another book that I would love to read.
Hilarious and tear jerking at the same time. Pleasantly surprised by how much I ended up liking it and how well written it is. Great story telling.
Quick, fun read. Trevor Noah's retelling of his youth had me laughing out loud and wanting to hear more.

I could listen to this man all day long. I'm so glad that I got the audio version of this book but I definitely need a physical copy for my library. His life story is one that is so intense. Looking at him, you wouldn't believe that he went thru so many things. As Americans we don't get the history or knowledge of what is actually happening in Africa. We only get mainstream, watered down verisons. Trevor gives you an insight of what life is really like over there even in the 21st Century.

Full review up on my blog Inside My Library Mind 
 Really, really great.

Poignant stories of the ultimate duo -- a young boy and his mother (the real hero of this story), as they navigate life post-apartheid, told with keen insight into South African racial politics and the history and enduring legacy of apartheid
Critical, laugh out loud funny, and heartbreaking. A needed voice in the often white-washed world of writing.

After reading a lot of books that left me disappointed, this was so refreshing. 
 As someone who reads a lot of celebrity memoirs (and I mean...A LOT), I thought I knew what to expect. Usually, it is a series of essays relying how they became the star they are now mixed with some humor in there. But this was different. I learned so much from this book, and would encourage anyone to read it as well (whether you know who Trevor Noah is or not). It had the self-depricating stories (like his failures with romance), and also included how he learned comedy but in ALL of the essays I learned something. I learned about South Africa, language/linguistics, community, and parenting. 
 The last couple lines in this book left me teary. Beautiful memoir, nice surprise.

I'm really torn about how many stars to give this read. I learned a lot about apartheid but developed quite a dislike for Trevor Noah. I respect his climb out of the cesspool of apartheid but without his mother he'd still be in that cesspool. His mother is a no nonsense religious woman who knew she wasn't going to stay in her home village and become like her mother and grandmother. And when her son was born she showed him that he didn't have to accept life as it was either. But Trevor Noah was a problem child with no regrets as to how many people he got in trouble or harmed or caused distress. To me he came across as whiney, petulant, and arrogant. The information about the reality of apartheid was fascinating. The hypocrisy of being able to determine your status strictly by appearance or by someone's subjective choice is appalling but frighteningly humorous.

I loved it. A great book that offers a lot of insight to a culture I wasn't familiar with. The stories told are fun, interesting and sometimes sad, but always come with lecture that was learned. It's about a strong woman making her way during a time you wouldn't expect this to happen. Very inspiring!

Wow. I've been a fan of Trevor Noah's from his stand up comedy, even before he became host of The Daily Show. I would never have suspected that his life had been filled with these occurrences and events, especially the ones on such a life-changing level. While his story is often tragic, he never tells it from a place of sorrow or victimhood. His matter-of-fact approach actually intensifies the emotions, recognizing this is just the world he lives in and knows. What an amazing life story, especially for a man who is so young. 
 So you have his story. On top of that, you have the very interesting canvas of an Apartheid/post-Apartheid South Africa on which this story is painted. I learned so much about South African history, which was far more about how the people were affected and how it colored everyday life as opposed to the political and historical constructs that led to it. It never overtakes the story, but it is always an engaging, enriching main character. 
 I highly recommend this book to everyone. You'll be glad you read it.

This is book was amazing! I've only seen a few interviews with Trevor Noah and he would slightly refer to his life in South Africa and how it was illegal for his parents to be together. He really shares what it was like living in South Africa under the apartheid being someone of mixed race. Also just fact that he grew up so differently from how we live in America just in the recent years of the 80's and the 90's. His relationship with his mother is another aspect that is so important to him, even when they have their ups and downs. Now that I've read his book and learned about his upbringing, I want to go rewatch the interviews of his that I've seen and just watch more of him in general.

I read this on my Kindle, but he's got a great voice and I understand he reads it for the audible version. At any rate, I found this book to be inspiring. I also learned more about South Africa and its recent history than I expected to learn, and this understanding was and is valuable. I'd rate the telling at 4.5 stars. Noah has a sense of humor that transcends the expected, and he has a sense of value very welcome today. Highly recommended!
I was surprised by just how good this was. Wonderfully interesting, adventurous, poignant and funny but written in simple and disarming style.
YOU GET ALL THE STARS, TREVOR.
This is a wonderful book. Please read it!
I thoroughly enjoyed reading this book. It was a perfect mix of humor and fact. Before reading this book, I didn't really know about life in South Africa under apartheid.
Really well done - liked the format of details and reaction by Noah.

The best autobiography told by a comedian that I've read. Okay, I haven't read many (4 or 5), but this is the best yet. Trevor has a way of telling a good funny story. Most of his childhood is not humorous, growing up very poor and having an abusive step-father, let alone the extreme racism in his country, and still he tells a good funny story. Actually the book is very eye-opening about what it's like to live in South Africa. Since there is that lighter side it isn't overwhelming in sadness. I hope his life only gets better. 
 I recommend the audio book which is narrated by Trevor. His voice adds another layer of enjoyment of the tales.

I really enjoyed this audio book as Noah's narration really adds to the experience. I find it most remarkable the stark contrast of his life compared to the life he must live now, and that I enjoy, in the US. I also found it interesting the reaction I was having judging those experiences of a culture so much at odds and yet with sad similarities to our own.

This is a fascinating view of what it was like growing up in South Africa during and after apartheid- especially in his case as a mixed-race child. It's also great storytelling, humorous, inspiring, touching, and offers a peek into the life and makeup of Trevor Noah. I actually laughed out loud at certain points. As a single mom of a boy, it personally resounded with me. His relationship with his mother is complicated and tender. 
 It's worth noting that he doesn't talk about the Daily Show at all. It kind of ends in his early twenties. So if you are looking for that, you might be a bit disappointed.

What an incredible book! I love Trevor Noah on The Daily Show, and his story is so amazing. He shared his personal experiences about growing up during apartheid as a "colored" person who didn't fit perfectly with any one group, along with context about the greater state of South Africa at the time. It's a blend of in-the-moment adolescent experiences and his grown perspective on why and how everything was the way it was. 
 With all of the discussions around race that are finally going on in America, this book told about another county's similar history in ways that demonstrates clear parallels. Noah's signature wit and brutal honesty, too, were alive and well. 
 New favorite celebrity memoir, for sure.
This book was so good. I haven't related to a book so much in a long time. Totally recommend the audiobook.

Wow! "Born a Crime: Stories From a South African Childhood." earns five stars for the wit and humor of the narration. Actually, it deserves five stars that Trevor has made it intact to adulthood! His descriptions about being of mixed race in South Africa are poignant as he delineates how Apartheid worked to suppress the indigenous society of black people around him. His prose has an elegance that is raw and unvarnished. He shows an ability for distilling important life-altering aspects with his inner, childish interpretation and again as a reflective adult. His story never falls into self-pity. 
 Ex.- "I didn't have any friends. I didn't know any kids besides my cousins. I wasn't a lonely kid -- I was good at being alone. I'd read books, play with the toy that I had, make up imaginary worlds. I lived inside my head. To this day you can leave me alone for hours and I'm perfectly happy entertaining myself. I have to remember to be with people." 
 My admiration for Trevor's mother is enormous. She is fiercely independent and has successfully raised a son to manhood despite all the obstacles along the way. She had a vision of her "family." She determined what she wanted for her son's future and the two of them were a team in that endeavor. She raised him to "be free to go anywhere, do anything, be anyone." (I suspect that of all the things that have gone into making Trevor, "Trevor", not even half were covered by this book...) His life, so far, has been exceptional, eventful, complicated, and complex. Thank you for sharing it!

I really liked this book. His writing style isn't super smooth, but very conversational (which is probably why I've heard such good things about the audio version, which Noah narrates). You can really hear him telling the stories as you're reading them. 
 I laughed at many parts (the poop story is amazing), but was also struck at the perspective provided by the background essays throughout the book. He tells the reader about South Africa and you come away with both laughter and learning. 
 Highly recommend.

So many celebrity memoirs feel self-indulgent- not this one. Noah is a gifted storyteller who has lived so much life in his few years. I left this book feeling like I understood an experience outside of my own better than I did before starting it, which is the highest praise I can give to an excellently-done memoir.
I really enjoyed this book! It was very funny while still discussing very important topics in a thoughtful manner.

Amazing, eye opening, informative and inspiring. An incredible read detailing Noah's childhood growing up in South Africa during and after apartheid. 
 I also see this book as an ultimate love letter of appreciation to Noah's unbelievable mother.

I can't adequately describe how much I loved this book and just how important it is. I laughed and cried. It's relevant, honest and there is no doubt that Trevor put all of his heart in to these stories. It is his life, and it is a love letter to his country and most of all a love letter to his mother.

I'd heard great things about this book, and it exceeded my expectations. It is a memoir, a cultural history, a famous comedian's biography, and then some. The subject matter is often heavy, but Noah's perspective and humour can lighten even the darkest moments, and his incisive cultural analysis sets everything in a firm historical context. This book was written for a North American audience and it's very easy to read from that perspective, as he explains anything unfamiliar by citing their American equivalents. For such weighty topics, the language is accessible and engaging. 
 Perhaps my favourite point that he makes is about the difference between physical discipline and child abuse. His mother used to beat him as punishment, but she made it clear why he was being punished, there was a beginning and end to the episode, and she made it clear she loved him and it was his behavior that was at fault. Later on, unfortunately, Noah gets to contrast this with the explosive and cruel temper of his new step-father, making clear the difference between discipline and abuse. This fits with my experience, and it's a point I've tried to make before; I appreciate having this explained in such a clear and accessible way. 
 I do agree with other reviews that the story ends earlier on in his life than I would expect. Hopefully Noah is hard at work on a follow-up book, one that chronicles the beginning of his stand-up career in South Africa and how he eventually made the jump across the pond. 
 This is not just a celebrity memoir. While there is an assumption that you know who Noah is, and that the writer has become successful, Born a Crime can easily hold its weight with other personal and political memoirs that study race, gender, and class. I highly recommend it!

An amazing memoir that not only makes you giggle, but addresses the true horrors of apartheid, poverty, domestic abuse, and addiction. There's a reason he's leading the Daily Show - it's because he could get through all this and still find life amusing. 
 UPDATE: Read this again in Noah's audiobook of this, in which he is the narrator. I could already hear his voice in my head when I read this book, but actually listening to him imitate the voices of those he grew up with was a real treat. I had also forgotten the real reason Noah is so good at comedy - he gets it from his mom. Anyone who could wake up from a gunshot wound to the head and tell her son not to cry - now he is the best-looking one in the family - is someone with humor in their soul.

Beautifully narrated by Trevor, I strongly recommend the audio version - such an interesting and enlightening life story - I learnt a lot about the ridiculousness of apartheid. Trevor's mother is a force of nature.
This may be my favorite memoir ever.

Well it's hard to separate things out re this book, because I like the talk show host SO MUCH! AND I went to see Noah in person at the Nourse Auditorium in SF this past fall. AND I just heard him again today on NPR. Each time I have found him to be kind, funny, honest and perceptive, and so he presents again, in "Born a Crime." 
 The story Noah tells is extraordinary, and no doubt more so for a secure inhabitant of the developed world. Life as a mixed-race kid in apartheid South Africa, was complex and challenging at every angle. But Noah is his usual good-natured self as he takes the reader through a fair share of harrowing tales. He is fully honest about the road he has traveled away from his mother's ways, and yet he clearly loves her very much. Since he is not presenting a political program here, he is free with his chosen subject matter. And perhaps what I admire most about him turns out to be his uncompromising stance on the unacceptable effects of patriarchy on the women we love, including ourselves.
Como lo disfrute!!!! Lo escuche como audiolibro y es narrado por el autor, por lo que lo sientes mas. Anecdotas sobre un nino creciendo en Sudafrica... extraordinario y fuerte a la vez.
I don't really give out five star ratings, but this book is amazing.

Fascinating, thought provoking, poignant and hilarious. Honestly I am so out of touch these days I had actually never heard of him until my friend Michele posted about his book. What she said intrigued me so I checked out the audio version. I must thank Michele for this, as from the very first word I was hooked. First off he has a lovely south African accent that I could just listen to for hours, but that is just the tip of the iceberg. Its a little bit coming of age, a little bit history lesson of Apartheid and what that really meant and a set of insightful essays that challenge your beliefs and perceptions of the world. His stories are at time hilarious, at at other times heartbreaking and sweet. Truly fascinating and a must read for everyone. Let me tell you, it will make you think of crime in a different way. Sorry this is so brief but things are busy these days, but I still wanted to bring this one to your attention. My fav so far this year. 
 Favourite Quotes 
 "it's easy to be judgmental about crime when you live in a world wealthy enough to be removed from it" 
 "My mother didn't believe in self-pity. "Learn from your past and be better because of your past," she used to say, "but don't cry about your past. Life is full of pain. Let the pain sharpen you, but don't hold on to it. Don't be bitter." 
 "In society, we do horrible things to one another because we don't see the person it affects. We don't see their face. We don't see them as people. Which was the whole reason the hood was built in the first place, to keep the victims of apartheid out of sight and out of mind. Because if white people ever saw black people as human, they would see that slavery is unconscionable. We live in a world where we don't see the ramifications of what we do to others, because we don't live with them. It would be a whole lot harder for an investment banker to rip off people with subprime mortgages if he actually had to live with the people he was ripping off. If we could see one another's pain and empathize with one another, it would never be worth it to us to commit the crimes in the first place."

DNFed at 60%. 
 This book is much loved so I'll be swimming against the current, but that's never stopped me from being honest with my thoughts so here goes: 
 Let me first start by saying that I was a huge fan of The Daily Show with Jon Stewart, and when Trevor Noah joined I gave it six weeks before deciding he was just not for me. Something about him rubs me the wrong way, so I wasn't planning on picking up this book, especially since it was a memoir. Then my local book club selected it for this month and I decided to at least try, maybe I would be pleasantly surprised. That did not happen. 
 I did not know going in that this was a collection of "eighteen personal essays" which explains some of the somewhat disjointed style of this book. It was interesting to hear about this mother and the decisions she made, and this is clearly an ode to his Mom, but why would I care about any of this? While I did smile at some of the humor, I found myself mostly annoyed both with him personally and how he talked about his experiences. Was this a difficult childhood, sure, but so what? As someone who grew up in Kenya, there wasn't much he described that was new to me, and the fact that he talks about his "mischievous" acts where there were no consequences without a sense of regret was something I found deeply disturbing. The longer I listened the more unlikable he become, and when I got the section of his Matric dance when it suddenly occured to him that he and his date didn't even share a common language I called it quits. 
 I was completely blown away when almost half of the book club members "didn't know about Apartheid." How is that even possible? The group had a mixed reaction to the book, with many feeling that he left out significant bits about how he got to host the Daily Show for example. However, given that this book might be a way to introduce people to some of what happened in South Africa I'm glad Noah wrote it. I'm just clearly not the target audience. 
 I listened to the audiobook which is well narrated by the author. I did enjoy listening to his various accents as he switches back and forth between South African languages. I would not have read this far if I'd read it in print, but if you're a Trevor Noah fan, or somehow who doesn't know anything about Apartheid this might work better for you.

This has been a fantastic listening experience. I typically don't do audiobooks but Trevor's narration has me converted. His autobio details life in South Africa. Trevor shares his upbringing and hardships offering a humorous angle on experiences that was otherwise terrible and shocking. He takes you through his childhood and teen hustling days with simplistic yet gripping social commentary. This book inspires and educates the reader, or in my case, the listener capturing my attention and heart right from the beginning. Born a Crime illustrates the history of South Africa and the effects of apartheid in an intimate way as I was able to confront the aftereffects through Trevor's life. The environment that he describes is almost tangible and I felt transported to his home country. I could feel Trevor's sincerity for the love of his country through his words and get a sense of this beautiful bustling community that he describes. My upbringing was so vastly different to the author's but the book didn't alienate me. He paints such a vivid picture I actually felt that I could almost touch and understand his environment. In a way this was a coming of age story minus the usual romance. The way the book was written allowed me to immerse myself in his personal growth and emotions through out his coming of age journey. Making sense of his life with the intensity of a strong culture was something I could relate to. His accepting attitude but funny outlook on his community's superstition was an engaging element in his bio that has echoes of my own experience growing up. I loved the real life characters that guest starred in this book. I tried to google a few of the names and I wanted a spin off to their lives too. This has to be one of my fav bios.
Great read!
I loved this beautifully paced, thoughtful, and fascinating memoir. It was funny, thought-provoking, and captivating.

You will laugh and you will cry a little. There is a lot of that in this heartwarming collection of stories from his youth. Mostly you will be astounded about the kind of life he led and what growing up in apartheid SA was like. Highly recommended.

Finished this in 2 days. Candid, captivating, entertaining and educational. This story is equally about a mixed child's experience in an unforgiving, segregated society and that of the South African female (his mother). An eye opener to say the least. 
 Would definitely recommend

This book was many things, inspiring, thoughtful, educational, and funny. Trevor's voice brings you right into his life and for me gave me insight into apartheid, and the "bloodless revolution" that took the lives of countless Black South Africans. Everyone should take the time to read this book!

Great story teller. Not what I expected, a more serious book of growing up during apartheid in South Africa without being heavy handed. No fake self deprecating needed with this one. And a movie about his mom is well deserved- she's a stubborn Jesus loving feminist who uses humor to her advantage. Definitely one of the better books of the year

Trevor Noah is the host of The Daily Show with Trevor Noah. This is his coming of age book written in the last stages of apartheid in South Africa. I enjoyed this book. I listened to it on Audible. Trevor Noah read it in the Audible book which added to the overall story. At times, I laughed out loud while at others times I got frustrated with his utter stupidity of being a teenager. Overall, it was an enjoyable story. The ending is unbelievable--his mother is truly a miracle.
You MUST listen to the audiobook!!

This book was fantastic. Noah has such a fascinating story and it's told in a compelling, humorous, and often heartbreaking way. I have gained so much respect for Trevor and the life he has lead. I can't recommend this book enough.
This was fantastic and not at all what I was expecting.

This book was fantastic! Trevor Noah has such an interesting perspective on race, culture and identity. His stories mix humour and insight and I thoroughly enjoyed them. I highly recommend this book to everyone. Being a fan of the daily show is absolutely not a prerequisite to loving Born a Crime.9
Trevor's memoir was amazing: I laughed, cried and cheered from page one to the very end.

"I believed that Foofy was my dog. But of course that wasn't true. Foofy was a dog. I was a boy. ... That experience shaped what I've felt about relationships for the rest of my life. You do not own the thing that you love." 
 "That's when I realized the police were not who I thought they were. They were men first, and police second."

What an incredible life so far. Trevor Noah shows us his life growing up before and after the end of apartheid in South Africa. Many great stories, all retold with Noah's humour shining through. 
 Trevor Noah doesn't shy away from difficult topics, but does show them in a sometimes different and amusing light. My favorite is when as a young child he didn't want to go outside to the outhouse to poo because it was raining, so he did it on the floor instead. The whole event outlines how poor the family was but shows it with great humour. 
 I love The Daily Show and don't think anyone could ever replace Jon Stewart, but Trevor Noah has done an admirable job so far. This book provides great insight to his life and what made him who he is today.

EVERYONE SHOULD READ THIS! The mix of personal experience, coupled with the history of racism and apartheid was a wonderful, enlightening, and unique read. I learned so much. I laughed, was disgusted, embarrassed by my ignorance, and yet loved it every step of the way. 
 The "lessons" or "background" pages before each chapter set up a very real sociological or human problem that is then exemplified in the stories in the chapter to follow. I really appreciated this style, and the language Noah uses. 
 Not only was this novel engaging and entertaining, but it was thought-provoking; and not in a abstract, academic kind of way, but in a very practical and challenging way.

Impressive, insightful work by Trevor Noah, sharing important info on what it was like to grow up in apartheid South Africa. I'd love to read more from Trevor, who obviously has tremendous talent. My only criticism about the writing was in the way it was organized - it jumped forward and then back again a few times and was redundant, and as a reader that was slightly confusing. The redundancies had the effect of talking down to the reader a bit - I'm not a huge fan of that type of reiterating info. All in in a excellent read. Highly recommended.
This was so well written and I loved how he grounded his personal stories in social and historical context. This was great on audio.

I'm not sure how Trevor Noah found any time in his busy schedule to write this book, but I'm glad he did. It was very clear from the first pages, Born a Crime wasn't going to be the laugh-out-loud romp I'm used to reading from comedians. Instead this book was a heartening autobiography of a young man growing up in post-apartheid South Africa. I learned more about South Africa from this book than from any other book I've ever read, including books for an African studies course I took in college. Overall, this book was an excellent read. I highly recommend.

3 and 1/2. 
 Extra fun if read imagining Trevor's voice.

Trevor Noah was born during apartheid in South Africa, a time when it was a crime for races to mix. He is evidence that mixing happened. His stories, then, are those of having to be hidden as a child and never quite fitting into any of the 4 categories of humans that are recognized in that country. His stories are heart-rending and, often, laugh out loud funny...and about the time the reader categorizes the incidents as a sort of comfortable travelogue of what-can-happen-over-there, it becomes obvious that all that he talks about is, in some way, relevant right here in the good old U.S. of A. 
 He is a great storyteller. The tone of the book is that of a guy telling you great stories about his mom, his schooling, his life of crime, his thinking about how to solve problems. Would that we all had moms like his. 
 This is a GREAT book, probably the best one I read during 2016

I loved this book. Of course I am smitten with Trevor Noah because of his wit and charm on The Daily Show, but this collection of essays made me love him even more. It was hilarious one minute, heart-wrenching the next. Even though it takes place on a different continent, a world away from everything I'm familiar with, it hit home with me: Noah's words about the struggle within his family and his own struggle to find where he belongs is universal. It just shows that even though the details and circumstances of our experiences can differ widely, in the end we're all more alike than we might think. The writing is sharp and smart (and the audiobook is a delight to listen to). I haven't enjoyed a memoir this much since Cheryl Strayed's "Wild."

I thought I was in love with Trevor Noah before, but this just confirmed it. The book extremely educational, but he still keeps it light and hilarious. A really good read. I hope he does another soon.

Trevor Noah's memoir is fantastic. Born a Crime shows a slice of what life is like in South Africa both before and after the fall of apartheid. Lots of humor - his poop story and the time he spent as a DJ for a dance crew led by a friend named Hitler - and also the disturbing - as someone who is half black, half white neither of his parents could be viewed as his parents while in public under the apartheid law. This was a wonderful book to listen to on audio, Trevor Noah narrates, and it was very compelling and difficult to stop listening.

Genuinely one of the best books I've ever read in my lifetime. It is funny and bittersweet all at once. Trevor Noah is clearly well-versed in the history and politics of South Africa (no surprises there) and weaves it into his intricate life story in such a way that you barely realise you've learned something new until you're telling your friends about your newfound lesson in apartheid. It's one of those books that you'll recommend to everyone you know and still read again and again
A great read, totally recommend it.

This book was incredibly easy to read. 
 Pretty straight forward autobiography that is written very well. An ugly duckling from Johannesburg who now (with not the easiest childhood) is an intelligent man with his own late night show in America. 
 I will admit that after reading this, I respect him a bit more and find him authentically charming.

Funny, brutally honest, and bittersweet. Trevor Noah's autobiography navigates deftly through politics, povery, and "otherness," while revealing his unusual status and his family's ability to stay alive and together in South Africa, both during apartheid and in its chaotic aftermath.
There are some almost unbearable parts to Trevor Noah's story, but boy is he an excellent storyteller. I highly recommend listening to him narrate the book.
Fantastic!!!

Born a Crime Stories from a South African Childhood by Trevor Noah is such an interesting look into the life of a talented young man. I am a big fan of Trevor and watched his special on Netflix where he speaks of his life growing up but this goes into so much detail, it is stunning all that this guy goes through and is not a bitter man. He describes the horrible laws and society he is born into and the way he is looked at in his society. How he tries to see himself. His life in poverty, with a very religious mother, an abusive step father, his struggles to find himself and diligent acts, his family, the horrible times in his life and the good times in his life. Through it all, he keeps his humor and love alive and shares it with us in this wonderful book. There is so much in here and he tells it so well. He has a good heart and it comes out in this book. He is not jaded by his past but seems to be inspired to be better because of it. Great job Trevor, we love you! Thanks NetGalley for allowing me to read this wonderful, touching book!

"KFC did not play games." 
 Trevor Noah's voice is exquisite, and just what the world needs right now, I say.

Sometimes I feel like I'm too lenient with my 5 star ratings, but this one really does deserve it. 
 If you're looking for a book on how he got into comedy this isn't the one, but you will learn so much more about his struggles as a "colored" South African. This book is funny only to lighten the mood when he talks about the terrible events that he faced. 
 It is very important to note that this book is solely Noah's perspectives and although he adds some specific facts it's mostly his thoughts and ideas. A lot of people have criticized the way he describes South Africa and it's politics, but guess what? This isn't a textbook. It's his experience.

Trevor Noah is a very funny man but if you're looking for his autobiography to be a very funny book, then it's likely that you'll be disappointed. The humour is not a key aspect of this book and I was rather disappointed. Having heard him on the radio talking about his childhood 'life of crime' (by being born mixed-race in apartheid era South Africa, even his birth was technically criminal) I was perhaps expecting a higher laugh count than I got. 
 His was an interesting childhood and the book does give interesting insights into growing up in the periods shortly before and shortly after the end of apartheid, with the added twist of being not quite black enough nor white enough to fit in to a society where pigeon-holing people was legally required. 
 His mother comes across as a remarkable woman, his step-father as a total pig, and his bio-father a fascinating but almost invisible man whose story would be interesting enough to make its own book. 
 The book is OK but if you're looking for laughs, it's not going to deliver.
Excellent read--

This book blew me away. It should be required reading for every high school student, and if you're not a high school student, it should be required reading for you and on your to-buy list as a gift for all the readers in your life. 
 I knew nothing about this book before I read it except it was by Trevor Noah, a man whose stand-up I've enjoyed and am now a fan of on The Daily Show, so I was expecting your typical humorous my-road-to-becoming-a-successful comedian memoir. That was not this at all. There is virtually no humor in this book. This is a history of apartheid and the technical end of apartheid, told from the point of view of a child who had a black mother and white father, which made his mere existence a crime. 
 The stories he told were so eye opening. Parts of it sound familiar to stories (in fiction and nonfiction books, fictionalized films and documentaries) of the American experience of the history of slavery and race relations and policing, but parts were jaw-droppingly eye-opening. For example, I never thought about the fact that not everyone is educated about Hitler the way we are today in the U.S. If your only options are to go work in a mine or as a maid or some other form of slavery, you have no reason to be taught history. However, your Dutch and British oppressors do deem it necessary to inflict their religious beliefs on you, and they want your children to have anglicized first names. Many of the kids were thus named after characters in the Bible, but other kids were given names of people that sounded powerful, thus, you might name your kid Hitler. (!) 
 His insights about the difference between committing crime and being a criminal, domestic violence--this guy can really write, and a lot more than just jokes. 
 There are dozens of passages that are quote-worthy--far too many to recount here (which is why you should read his book). 
 He mentions that he started touring as a comedian, and that's it. Not how he got his start, not how he went from being an outsider bootlegging CDs to becoming a headlining comedian. His insights on race are truly illuminating. An outstanding work. 
 Thanks to Netgalley for the opportunity to review this book. 
 For more of my reviews, please visit: http://theresaalan.net/blog

I wish he had given a bit more info about when things were happening. He was estranged from his mom...then she was shot but where they back in touch? The ending felt a bit rushed but overall an interesting story!
Fantastic audiobook read by the author. Hilarious.

Couldn't stop reading in his voice, somehoe made it even funnier. 
 Almost extremely funny, And eye opening too.

Like many people, I was first introduced to Trevor Noah through The Daily Show. And I liked him. So when his book came out I decided to pick it up, and I'm really glad I did. 
 Even though he's young, Trevor Noah has had a very exciting, if not unorthodox (at least compared to my own) childhood. That was one of the big things I liked about the book. It immersed me in a life that I can hardly imagine growing up in. It gave me a closer look at what life was really like during apartheid and helped me to understand just what apartheid really meant to the people that lived through it. 
 Even though the book deals with awful, hateful things, the tone is generally lighthearted, and there are quite a few funny moments. The end almost had me in tears though. There was what amounted to a huge spoiler right at the start of the book but I couldn't figure out the whole time whether...something bad was going to happen. And then I was dragged through the last 10 pages like I wasn't reading a memoir but a freaking thriller novel! 
 I would recommend this even for people who aren't the biggest fans of memoirs. Also, Trevor Noah's mom sounds like a total badass. 
 ~Ren
Truly a powerful memoir! My only regret is that I did not get an audio copy to listen to his words, hearing about his life in post apartheid South Africa and his family in his own voice.
A perfect balance of humor and vivid insight

This is perhaps my favorite book this year. It is at once a touching story of a boy and his mom, an illuminating social justice discourse and a hilarious memoir of a young boy coming of age in South Africa. This book made me laugh at least a few dozen times and cry and least once. Ultimately, I left the book with a greater appreciation of Trevor Noah as both a comedian and as a man of great profundity. I would highly recommend this book to most.

Don't expect a laugh-out-loud read--well except maybe the 'go Hitler, go Hitler cultural clash of errors--but more of a perpetual smirk as Noah provides perspective on post-Apartheid South Africa, as a native son with a unique vantage point due to his mixed race.

This is an incredible memoir. Trevor Noah's childhood is one few of us in the US could imagine. It was eye opening. He is a wonderful storyteller, and paints a vivid picture of his life in South Africa.

A few months after listening to it, I decided to change my rating from 3 to 4 stars. I don't really remember why I gave it 3 stars at first, but looking back at the books I've read so far this year, I keep thinking about how nice it was to listen to Born a Crime.

Born a Crime... 
 I never really had much interest in Trevor Noah. I wasn't even aware of him until he replaced Jon Stewart on the Daily Show. Once I saw a couple episodes around the 2016 election, I started to like him, so once I saw that he was releasing a memoir, I knew I had to read it. 
 By now, it's probably obvious that I love a good memoir, and a humorous one nearly always makes for an enjoyable read. I listened to Trevor Noah's book during the peak of the semester when I was too busy to be able to actually read, turning it on each time I got in my car. As I said, I never really knew much about him as a person before picking up his book, but now, I definitely have a new respect for him. 
 He starts out his story by discussing bits of his childhood, growing up in South Africa, born to a black, South African mother and a white, German father, making him a product of interracial relations, a crime punishable by law under apartheid. His story moves mostly chronologically throughout his life, with the exception of tales he inserts about his mother's past prior to his birth. 
 Integrating his wit whenever possible, Noah tells a beautiful story about a young man's journey through a life plagued by racism & poverty, and how the bond between a mother and child can withstand all of that and worse. 
 Even if you've never heard of this comedian before (catch his show weeknights on Comedy Central), his tales of a South African childhood will leave you laughing, crying, and in awe of the beauty in human differences.

Trevor, we are big fans of "The Daily Show" even though we are not your target audience. 
 Your life growing up in South Africa was fascinating. Also, I really appreciated the background briefings about South Africa as each chapter was introduced. Thanks for a great read!

This book wasn't just entertaining and interesting, it was also educational. I learned so much more about South Africa & the apartheid. Foreign, intriguing, at times hilarious, but also serious. If I wasn't so uncomfortably, heavily pregnant, I would've finished this book in one sitting.

I frequently watch Trevor Noah on The Daily Show and I wanted to read this book as soon I as I heard it was being released. This book is full of humanity and discusses how policies impact a family, a child, a mother. The books is a series of essays that discuss his years growing up South Africa, from apartheid to almost present. I love his insight into how he has been shaped by these experiences, and I appreciate his honesty. 
 I have a couple of quotes that I noted as I feel they are probably true for many. 
 "The hood has a gravitational pull. It never leaves you behind, but it also never lets you leave. Because by making the choice to leave, you're insulting the place that raised you and made you and never turned you away." 
 "In society, we do horrible things to one another because we don't see the person it affects. We don't see their face. We don't see them as people. Which was the whole reason the hood was built in the first place, to keep the victims of apartheid out of sight and out of mind." 
 I received this book through a Goodreads Giveaway.
Absolutely loved this book.

Pretty into this book. I previously had no feeling about Trevor Noah - I trailed off watching his Daily Show but I do think he's a talented comedian. It seems he's also a talented storyteller as well. The life he led in South Africa was crazy, filled with racism and violence and a class system that is difficult to comprehend. The best part of his essays were the ones centered on his relationship with his mother, who seems like the most boss bitch on the planet. Noah paints her in such a wonderful and warm way; I'd like to sit down and have dinner with her. The books ends a little abruptly, and left me wanting to know how he got from South Africa to hosting the Daily Show, but at the end of it all, that's not what this book is about. It's about he's evolution from the living embodiment of a crime to well-ish adjusted human.

I'm joining the club of other Rioters who have read and loved this one. Something you should know about me: memoirs are NOT my jam. I can count on one hand the memoirs I've read and enjoyed, so I was honestly shocked by how much I loved reading Born a Crime. Noah can tell a story like nobody's business, and very often his tales weave tragedy and comedy together in the best way imaginable. I also have to admire Noah's bare-bones honesty; he really doesn't front at all. If you're the type of person who wants a book that can make you laugh and cry in public, this is the one you've been looking for. 
 -- Tasha Brandstatter 
 from The Best Books We Read In February 2017: http://bookriot.com/2017/02/28/riot-r... 
 ____________________ 
 Never have I experienced such alternatively intense emotions as I have listening to this book, where Noah recounts stories of his childhood in truly terrible conditions with humor and matter-of-factness. I had moments where I felt crushed by the realities of Apartheid, wondering how humans can be so cruel, followed by long stretches of laughter where I must have looked batty while driving, such was my delight in a chapter about sneaky pooping (and the aftermath). I'm talking crying laughing, gasping for air, and then eased back into some more sobering tales of close calls, losing friends, running from those who threatened him or his family. It's only January, but this book is absolutely in my personal top 5 for the year. If nothing else, Born a Crime speaks in universals about human experiences, even simple things like learning to speak someone else's native language and reaping the social benefits. It's just set in a world that's very far from my own. 
 -Kristina Pino 
 from The Best Books We Read In January 2017: http://bookriot.com/2017/02/01/riot-r... 
 ____________________ 
 He might be the baby-faced host of The Daily Show, but he was also raised a mixed-race child during Apartheid. Listening to him narrate the story of his childhood and all of the dangers that came with his very existence showed me that he's a lot more than Jon Stewart's slightly-less-beloved replacement. I may be frustrated recently with his call for other people of color to be moderate in their reactions to the incoming administration, but getting a bit of insight into the pain and tragedy he suffered at the hands of similarly-minded people was informative for me and has changed the way I view him. 
 -- Elizabeth Allen 
 from The Best Books We Read In December 2016: http://bookriot.com/2017/01/03/riot-r...

A moving and funny story of a most unusual/frightening childhood! 
 Growing up as a mixed race child in South Africa before and after apartheid wasn't a picnic for Trevor Noah. 
 The descriptions of his coming-of-age, nonetheless, are highly relatable, even for those raised in more fortunate circumstances. 
 What's really at the heart of this memoir is his relationship with his mother--a strong woman who refused to be subjugated by her society's norms. 
 Everyone should read this book!

I'm generally not a fan of biographies, so I didn't go into this one expecting much, especially since I'm not a particularly avid fan of Trevor or his work. However, being from the same country and having my own knowledge to compare against, made this book more engaging than I expected. The humour, which as one would expect coming from a comedian, was good and got a few chuckles out of me. It did become quite dark towards the end, but I didn't mind it at all since it added some extra depth that the book needed by that point anyway. 
 I did the audiobook narrated by the author and I can't really imagine anyone else having done it since there were various cases of non-English phrases (which were followed up by their translation) which he did fluently and with the correct tone. He also used a certain tone and inflexion for when he was quoting himself as a child which was particularly funny. Overall, though, the writing was quite decent and I enjoyed that it was broken up by theme rather than being strictly chronological. I would have liked some info on how he got into his career, but I suspect there was nothing particularly funny about that, so he chose to focus on his various culturally unique quirks and childhood shenanigans. This book really is mostly a series of anecdotes from various stages of his childhood, which if you like that sort of thing, is well done and edited. 
 There really isn't much else for me to say though. It was a nice, short autobiography with a fair amount of humour and some more serious notes thrown in as well. I suspect most South Africans will enjoy it, purely from having that shared context to compare against. It's also definitely quite funny for the most part and so it's quite a light and fun read which is perfect if you need something to read between more serious books.

The more I read, the more I realized that Trevor Noah is my soul mate, haha. But, in all seriousness, this book is amazing. He does what most comedians try to do: combine honesty and comedy, but in an effortless way, that doesn't seem like he's trying too hard to be funny. As far as "memoirs" or "stories" or however it's classified, it has to be my favorite hands down.

I went into this book not knowing anything about Trevor Noah and his background, but I was really impressed with his life story and especially his mother. I learned a lot... I honestly was ignorant about how apartheid worked and I think I will have to read another book about it. And of course, great narration by the author!
This book made me cry...I love it when a book makes me cry!

Posted in my little blog: Gem in the Rough. 
 I don't usually read memoirs or non-fiction (though that has radically changed these past two years). After seeing Trevor Noah take the spotlight of one of my favorite shows, The Daily Show and hearing his stories of his childhood and South Africa I couldn't help but press the 'buy ticket' button when I found out he was going to be in LA to promote his book, Born A Crime. I'll talk about the event later in this post, but suffice to say before and after the show I was devouring the pages. 
 The title pretty much sums it up, really. Trevor talks about various stages of his life during and after apartheid. The voice of the book is perfect. I don't have the audiobook, but when reading this I could hear Noah's voice perfectly. His life experience filled me with amazement, horror and at times, disbelief. Like the majority of Americans, atrocities outside our borders are something we read in textbooks, the reality of it vanished by time and distance. To hear Trevor's personal account of apartheid is sobering and the only way I managed to swallow the horror I felt was through laughter at Trevor's humorous take on his life. 
 And yet, despite the book having his name splashed on the cover along with an image of his own face on a street wall, the real star of this book is Trevor's mother, Patricia Noah. 
 Sure, reading about Trevor's life is the main reason to sit with this book. But in between the youthful shenanigans of the future comedian are mic drop moments of Patricia Noah spittin' words of 'lit' wisdom to her son (or just beating it into him) and she just steals the scene. I remember getting excited every time Patricia showed up again in the book. As Trevor says, they were more than just mother and son: they were partners. He is the Robin to her Batman. Patricia Noah is larger than life. She jumps out of a moving car with Trevor and his baby brother to escape a violent taxi driver. She gets shot in the face by her husband and returns to work a week later. Hell, she even conceived Trevor on her own terms. She asked the only man she trusted and spent time with at that point (a white expatriate man who lived on the same floor as her) to help her have a baby and she got it. She didn't give a fig if Trevor's father stuck around. She just wanted a child. A true lioness, that one. There are too many awesome moments with her that I would end up quoting the majority of the book if I kept going. So I won't. 
 Verdict? 
 Come for The Daily Show. Stay for a badass woman named Patricia Noah. And when is she going to come as a guest on The Daily Show? I think we all could learn a thing or, you know, a thousand from her.

Hoping for a sequel..... 
 Trevor Noah has been a great replacement for Jon Stewart on the Daily Show. He is intelligent, quick, funny, and talented. This book gives a look into the incredible story of Noah growing up in South Africa. 
 The stories are an eye opener as to what it was like living under Apartheid, having a black mother and a white father, and having one amazing mother. Using humor, Trevor documents the hardships, struggles, and prejudice that forged him into who he is today. 
 Some of the stories are described in lengthy detail, some are too long, and some details are repeated unnecessarily. My only objection is that I was hoping to read more of how he became the comedian he is today. Maybe that will be in the next book. 
 At a time when this nation is facing a resurgence of racism, bigotry, and hatred, this story is even more important for everyone to read. It shows just what can happen when those attitudes are carried to the extreme. 
 This one gets four stars, and is a must read.

This book came to me via a recommendation. I was not ready for the emotional roller-coaster this has taken me on. 
 Trevor's writing masterfully intermingle stories that makes you sad, happy, and uplifted. Often interwoven together, I am constantly surprised by the turn of his life. 
 It's a book of stories from his childhood but reads like a novel. 
 The audiobook version is extremely good. Read by Trevor and you can tell the effort he's put into the performance. Indeed, that's what the reading is - a performance. 
 highly recommended.
A fresh perspective told with humour. I've enjoyed Trevor Noah's stand-up for some time but had no idea about the history that shaped the man. Well worth the read!
Great book! I

A fantastic memoir! Witty, poignant and well written. I found it incredibly eye opening as someone who knew precious little about South African apartheid. Noah intelligently weaves its history with his own.

Absolutely riveting. I read the whole book in one day. It was just so compelling, heartbreaking, inspiring and interesting a read. I doubt too many other celebrities can say they've had the childhood/background of Trevor Noah. 
 My only complaint about "Born a Crime" is the lack of details as to how Trevor Noah began his showbiz career. Yes, mention was made from time to time about him appearing on television shows, or mentioned in newspaper articles, but no true a-ha! so that's how he got into comedy and his "big break". It just seems Trevor went from DJ-ing to stand up comedy/tv appearances with no transition. 
 Another very minor quibble is the lack of resolution with his biological father. I know they didn't have a traditional father-son relationship, but it just seemed to have stopped completely after the entrance of Trevor's stepfather - who intensely disliked Trevor and his mother having any interaction with the Swiss-German. You would have thought that after Trevor left his mother's/stepfather's house, he would have had some level of relationship with his natural father since they did seem to have intermittent familial interactions in the past. Thus, I would have liked more of an epilogue to this. 
 But my complaints are minor. Overall, this was a fascinating read into how Trevor Noah has been shaped by his upbringing and experiences. Definitely worth a read!

I simply loved this book. i have never listened to any of Trevor's standup routine but I really enjoyed this book and I'm so glad that I listened to the audio and that Trevor was the narrator. After I finished the audiobook, I wanted to start it over and listen to it again.

I don't often read celebrity autobiographies, but this on appealed in part because Noah grew up in South Africa under apartheid. The title comes from the fact that his mother is black African and his father is a white Swiss. Under the laws at the time, his very existence was a crime that could have sent either or both of his parents to jail and put him in foster care. This did not happen due to their careful construction of his upbringing until apartheid was removed. 
 Since I have become a fan of Noah's on "The Daily Show" (comedy network), I could hear his voice inflections in his writing. It was very well done.

Born a Crime, is more than anything a love story to Patricia Noah, Trevor's mom. It is a story of Trevor's experiences prior to becoming the comedic, mellenial icon we see every week night on the daily show. This may not appear to be directly fixated on his mother, but that's only because a love story can only be genuine when you put your story first; that's so much more intimate than telling someone else's story. It's funny because the title is very political- the beginning is very much like that. Heck! The very legislation that explains the title of this book is cited at the very beginning. It only starts to gets touching when Trevor explains the underpinnings of his birth: his mother's desire to have someone love her unconditionally. Trevor proves throughout his stories that he was perhaps naughtier than expected; he shits where he shouldn't (whatever you think I mean by that- yes), talks back, steals, gets arrested. May not sound morally just on his behalf, but he grows from all these experiences. Noah also puts a good deal of story telling towards explaining the racial underpinnings behind his experiences. He brings up the freeing of Nelson Mandela, race tensions, and legislation throughout this book. And all I have to say is that he did so in such a poignant and memorable matter. I was expecting this book to be as political as the ones endorsed by his Daily Show predecessors, but he managed to make it so personable, humorous, and (wonderfully (the best stories in life are the boring ones you make interesting!) mundane. It reminded me of I know Why the Caged Bird Sings at times. It's for this reason, I can't help but love this book. Much like Trevor, I credit must of my development to my mother's wisdom and dedication. I relate to him on the level of having an absent father figure, as both a result of politics and a cold disposition. I'm a sucker for stories that preach for the power of mama! I cried at very obvious and ridiculous points in this book because I relate to him mocking his mother for her religious reasonings. I relate to him learning how to read and speak English from his mom and not a school (it's big when all he other kids don't speak it). I relate to his frustration with his mother for constantly welcoming people into her life who treat her like crap. I've never willingly written reviews for this site before, but I thought this book deserved it because I only read it because I'm a fan of Trevor Noah- love him, hate him, this book is worth reading.

The reason I listened to this on audiobook is because Trevor Noah himself was narrating it. It added to the experience. After all, it would be weird to hear someone else telling the biography of another person. 
 A year ago, I learned a little bit about the apartheid that happened in South Africa. It was interesting to read a first-person perspective on someone who's been affected by the apartheid. 
 Trevor Noah also talks about the corruption of power. Not just in the government, but also in people. The apartheid gave more power to some than others, and that made people act a certain way. Sometimes they give back, but others just take and take and take. 
 One quote that really stood out to me was this: 
 "I don't regret anything I've ever done in life, any choice that I've made. But I'm consumed with regret for the things I didn't do, the choices I didn't make, the things I didn't say. We spend so much time being afraid of failure, afraid of rejection. But regret is the thing we should fear most. Failure is an answer. Rejection is an answer. Regret is an eternal question you will never have the answer to. "What if..." "If only..." "I wonder what would have..." You will never, never know, and it will haunt you for the rest of your days." 
 It made me pause and think. Because of that quote, I've decided to try and stop worrying what other people think of me and try new things. Who cares if I fail at it? At least I had the experience of doing it. 
 I've got to admit, Trevor Noah had an eventful childhood. I loved the banters between Trevor and his mother. It's clear throughout the book that Trevor loves and admires his mom despite the hardships they've gone through together. 
 Overall, it was a solid biography. It was funny, eye-opening, and serious all rolled up into one book. 
 Full review: https://theawkwardbookblogger.wordpre...

Thrilled this was my 50th book for the year. Phenomenal read. So sad it's over. 
 Review to come.

I picked up this book on a whim when I saw it at a library over the holidays. I knew it had been on the "best books of the year" lists and I had ordered a copy for my library but I didn't pay much attention to it. I didn't even know who Trevor Noah was. I'd just heard the book was good so I thought "why not?". 
 Born a Crime is a series of essays about Trevor Noah's childhood and youth growing up in South Africa during Apartheid and afterwards. Trevor is (as the rest of the world except me probably knew) the host of The Daily Show so while the stories cover some heavy and sad topics like racism, poverty and domestic abuse, the essays are also infused with humor.
