I laughed out loud several times while reading this book and also felt sorry for his mom because he was such a rascal as a kid! 
 Born a Crime focuses on Trevor's youth from his early childhood to his teens. Trevor tells a lot of funny stories about his behavior as a kid and young teen but through it all, it is clear how much he loves and respects his mom. She is smart, caring, loving and deeply religious. She was also a fast runner (and so was Trevor when he got into trouble, which happened a lot). I enjoyed the stories of Trevor's misbehavior and awkward teen years and also the sweet relationship he had with his mom. 
 While this book is entertaining it also looks at some important topics. Trevor talks about the history of racism in South Africa and how ridiculous the whole concept of Apartheid was. Even the differences between the various groups of nonwhites and how the white South Africans set people against each other to keep the system of Apartheid working. Growing up, Trevor had to be hidden by his mom during Apartheid because his existence was illegal as a biracial child. He also talks about not quite fitting in with the blacks (whom he chose to identify with), the "coloured people" (people with multiracial ancestry as well as those that the white South Africans decided were "coloured" based on random criteria) or the whites. Trevor used his gift of languages to find common ground with his classmates. It helped them realize he is the same as them. Sharing a language brought unity and shows that people are not so different which is why the government did its best to keep everyone segregated. 
 Apartheid ended in the 90s while I was in high school but I didn't really know much about it. I don't think it was something we learned about aside from news coverage on Channel One. Of course we were teens with our own self centered concerns. Reading this book helped me understand more about Apartheid and what life was like under Apartheid. 
 I was able to listen to the audio version of this book as well as reading the print version. Trevor narrates the audiobook which is fantastic. He does a great job with the various voices and accents, especially the Afrikaners (white South Africans of Dutch descent). We had several Afrikaner library patrons at my old library and Trevor's accent was spot on (unlike Leonardo DiCaprio in Blood Diamond). I recommend listening to the audio version if you can. Trevor is a great storyteller. 
 I hope you will consider giving Born a Crime a try. It is funny, educational and inspiring and likely to be one of my favorites.

** spoiler alert ** 
 I have never before left a review on Goodreads about a book I've read. However, this book taught me so much that I feel I need to leave a review. Because after finishing the book all I really want to say is: Thank you Trevor Noah for writing down your story. Thank you so much. 
 The book touches on many topics. One of the parts I appreciated the most was his view on apartheid. I was never taught much about it in school, and Trevor paints a clear picture of what apartheid was like. And how it continues to hurt South Africa, because it isn't just gone from one day to the next. 
 I also really appreciated Trevor's view on life. For one, he broke a lot more rules as a kid than I did! He is more daring I guess. Somewhere in the book he writes: 
 "I was blessed with another trait I inherited from my mother, her ability to forget the pain in life. I remember the thing that caused the trauma, but I don't hold onto the trauma. I never let the memory of something painful prevent me from trying something new. If you think too much about the ass kicking your mom gave you or the ass kicking that life gave you, you'll stop pushing the boundaries and breaking the rules. It's better to take it, spend some time crying, then wake up the next day and move on. You'll have a few bruises and they'll remind you of what happened and that's ok. But after a while, the bruises fade and they fade for a reason. Because now, it's time to get up to some shit again." 
 I highly recommend this book to everybody :)

This book is much like Noah's comedy or work on TV: nothing is going to change your life, but there's enough wit, engaging story telling, and genuine laugh out loud moments to make you enjoyable continue watching/reading. And I will note that there's some real eye-opening wisdom to issues like domestic violence, race, crime, and even language that comes from someone who is 100% qualified to critique each of those social constructs (read this book and you'll see just how qualified he is to comment on those issues). As such, this book is sincere, valuable, and intriguing to any one who reads it, especially for any American thinking their perspective on social issues is adequate. These stories from South Africa bring an entirely new light to societal conflict that just isn't well understood elsewhere in the developed world (outside of Germany, that is...For obvious reasons). Well worth the read on ideological grounds, and a fantastic memoir with funny and enlightening stories as well.
The audiobook was amazing!! Highly recommend it! Trevor Noah adds such a richness to the story through his narration that wouldn't come through when reading a physical copy!
I listened to this book because it was narrated by the author. Trevor made me laugh a lot :) Enjoyed the story!

This was INCREDIBLE. I'm not even really a fan but this is a book everyone should read, particularly in this political time, as he discusses in depth how apartheid worked and why. I can't believe this isn't everywhere. a must-read
Listened to the audio book and absolutely loved it. Trevor Noah is an amazing and effortlessly good narrator. It feels like a story told to you by an old friend.
Incredibly funny and poignant essays about growing up in South Africa. Thoroughly enjoyed it and found a few similarities to life in India.
The audio read by Trevor Noah is fabulous.

This book took me by complete surprise. I'm unsure of what I was expecting, but I learned more about South Africa and apartheid from reading Born A Crime than I ever did from any other source. Full review to come!
Noah has such a sweet, vulnerable voice. Great memoir.
nice funny well done ....and the audio book by trevor voice is even better

Trevor Noah is at once real, funny and deeply honest about how and where he grow up in South Africa. Growing up during the ending of Apartheid wasn't easy. Especially when you have to learn 4 0r 5 different languages just to get by. Racism built on the slavery model of the US and the precepts of Hitler Germany is a hard idea to dismantle. If you don't like Non fiction or bios and you have to read one this is the one to read. Or listen too. (if you do audio books) I really enjoyed listening to the many voices of his family, friends and the people around him.

This is the first time I've listened to or read an autobiography of someone younger than me! 
 I enjoyed this one from the first word to the last. Each story was captivating and gave a deeper glimpse into Apartheid and Post-Apartheid South Africa as well as the complex social dynamics of the townships. 
 The only issue I had with the book was the organization. Most autobiographies tend to be fairly chronological however this one bounced around in time. A few more edits and it would have been 5 stars - Grammy Award material. 
 I doubt the written book would of had the same effect. He was an excellent narrator and listening to him speak the many different languages created a genuineness that would have been lost in the written work. 
 Trevor Noah as well as his amazing mother earned a new fan. I wish him well as his career progresses. For the record, I've never seen any of his stand-up routines.

I received an ARC from Netgalley in exchange for an honest and unbiased opinion. 
 This was a truly fantastic memoir that I think everyone should read. There were times when the timeline seemed a little disjointed and jumped around, but overall this was a solid memoir. The lessons that Trevor's mom imparted in him about how to treat people and the lessons about the importance of language are lessons that can not be stressed enough.

I had no idea who Trevor Noah was before I read this ARC from Penguin Canada. I don't have cable and I didn't want to google him before hand and taint my experience with this book. 
 His crime isn't a crime he committed, it's the archaic laws of the oppressor on the oppressed. Trevor Noah who is South African is a product of a mixed race relationship... that put himself and his family in dangerous situations growing up in a pre Apartheid South Africa. 
 But the memoir is funny and it does show that if you want something you can attain it. It does show stories of his childhood and when you research him, you can see how this childhood made him the guy he is now.

Trevor Noah, I didn't even really know that I loved you until I heard you say "margarine." 
 This book was really wonderful. If you're looking for an excellent and poignant memoir, look no further. Noah cleverly breaks down life in South Africa. I laughed. I almost cried. I am a more enlightened person because of it.
Race is a construct and no where is that more evident than in pre and post apartheid South Africa. Trevor's story about he and his mother is fascinating. What a courageous, witty duo.

This book is by far the best book I have heard recently. I heard Trevor Noah's narration on audible and it was simply amazing. I've heard friends downplay audible in favor of reading a physical book but you will not get the same experience reading it, that I can promise. Trevor Noah, with his brilliant performance, takes you straight to his childhood. He will make you cry and laugh and at times hold your breath for what would come next. I am able to understand a little more about Apartheid through his eyes and able to appreciate my life a whole lot more with the added perspective. Thank you for sharing your story Trevor!
I really liked the book. I found it very interesting to learn about south African culture.

A fantastic memoir that was moving, captivating and inspirational! I'm really glad I chose to listen to the audio book, rather than read the physical book, because Trevor Noah's voice 
 a) Is beautiful to listen to 
 but also 
 b)Made the story more personal and heartfelt 
 A highly recommended read, even for those who don't typically enjoy or read non-fiction books!

A must read. I read this in one sitting and can't stop thinking or talking about it. I had never seen the Daily Show so I wasn't a fan of Noah's before reading the book. His life and his ability to tell such a remarkable story is unreal. He can cut through the bias and filter out everything but the honest to goodness truth. He says it like it is but is so insightful and it's powerful. 
 Trevor Noah reminds me a little of Haven Kimmel, in that they tell it like it is without getting weighed down or distracted by sentimentality or themselves, even when they wrote about their own lives.

I am not usually a fan of memoirs written by people in their 30s. It seems at worst, pretentious and at best premature. This isn't a conventional autobiography though, more like essays and thoughts on Noah's life to date. In part I was curious about his background and how it led him to the Daily Show. That part is not included, so you would imagine I was disappointed, but far from it. This is a fascinating story and not just the Trevor Noah parts. Surprisingly (to me), he grew up quite poor and even more surprisingly, his Swiss father does not really provide him with much in the way of advantages, as I had imagined before reading the book. Noah's genetics mean he is an outcast everywhere. Not black, white or coloured (the latter forming a very distinct racial grouping and heritage in South Africa). Each group has its own distinctive culture, heritage and languages and this book is a real eye opener when it comes to the realities of day to day life for all the groups. At various times in the memoir he tells of a time he identified with or joined each colour group. By skin colour alone he belongs with, and is often assumed to be part of the coloured group but this is the group he identifies with least. Issues of race, colour, heritage and discrimination are scattered through the stories but skillfully woven in through the narrative. As always, what you imagine or believe from afar turns out not to be quite the case in every day life, especially in the townships. Regardless of whether you are interested in Trevor Noah, or even South Africa, this is a thought provoking read. It does however include some disturbing elements of child, animal and domestic abuse. This is real life and an honest and intelligent account of growing up in South Africa. Not at all what I expected.

This is definitely one of the best books I have read. Within the funny, engaging stories, Noah has given a true sneak peek into the life in South Africa under the Apartheid. Some instances are heartbreaking but the courage and character of Trevor's mother is definitely the fascinating part for me. 
 For Audible users: Trevor has done an exceptional job narrating the book himself and with his funny vocal variety he brought the characters to life.
inciteful, heartwarming and funny!
A must read for all men and mothers out there.

This is a really wonderful, funny and informative book. It gives you such a great insight to worlds others than the one you currently live in. It shows how people in South Africa live, it takes you closer to their culture through funny, thoughtful moments. It has a great sense of humor and a lot of stories to take notes from. I really enjoyed listening to the audiobook!

This is a fascinating read, both of one person and one family's life and of an entire culture. 
 Many Americans have come to know Trevor Noah through his work on The Daily Show. In Born a Crime, we can see much more; that Noah's birth actually was a crime in apartheid-era South Africa; that his black Xhosa mother risked imprisonment and expulsion from Johannesburg back to her homeland of Soweto if Trevor's existence were discovered. So Trevor lived a very careful life as a child, rarely seeing his father at times. Subversion was a well-played life game. If Trevor's existence had been discovered he would have been taken away to an institution for mulattoes or coloreds, for labeling was an apartheid pastime. 
 This is the story of one life but also of a country with severe identity issues. And Noah personifies so many of the issues at the forefront of South African life during his lifetime. He was never an acceptable person to many because he wasn't black or white and not accepting of the colored label because he self-identified as black. He didn't know where he fit in, didn't look like his black mother and her family and not like his father. He did not feel he fit the colored label that sometimes included Chinese or Japanese (who at other times were considered white). And he wasn't black enough to be acceptable by many blacks outside his family. The end of apartheid changed all of this legally but not identity-wise for a boy trying to fit in among his school mates, etc. 
 Trevor seems to have been an intelligent child and teen who lived on being funny, acting outrageous at times. Of course nothing about his early life computes for someone not raised under apartheid and then a country trying to find itself after throwing off apartheid and developing new systems. He writes of so many moments that not only bring his life alive for the reader, but bring the reality of life in South Africa for non-whites more into focus. I believed I knew a bit about South Africa's recent history and the end of apartheid. This book has shown me that I know little. 
 I thank Trevor Noah for sharing his story with us, for all of the personal and South African societal detail it provides, that closer look it is important to take. 
 One note on the narrative itself. It does not read in a continuous arc time-wise, and you will find time shifts occurring between what are essentially more separate essays than sequential chapters of his life. Occasionally I found this slightly bothersome but probably wouldn't have had I known up front this was the structure. However Noah centers you throughout with his wit and his much-loved mother. 
 A copy of this book was provided by the publisher through NetGalley in return for an honest review.

Hands down my book of the year for 2016. So much more than an autobiography. 
 The storytelling takes you through whole ranges of emotions. I laughed hysterically, cried uncontrollably, felt anger surge through my soul at the injustice this world contains, and also beamed at how beautiful this life can be. 
 This book had me look at myself introspectively and think so deeply, and I learned. so. much. 
 I chose to begin this book on first read as an audiobook, and I'm glad I did because Trevor Noah's eloquence and ability to recount his memories and experiences are unparalleled. Just beautiful. He can also pronounce and explain a lot of South African dialect and colloquialisms that I probably wouldn't have been able to fully understand had I read them in a physical book for my first read. 
 I'll be buying the physical book ASAP though because there are some sections and specific quotes that hit me incredibly hard. 
 I'll be taking this with me for life. 
 10/10 would recommend. 
 BRAVO.

His ability to slip in and out of cultures, groups, tribes, languages, and traverse other delineators makes Noah an exceptionally compassionate person with an understanding of human nature that few will attain in one lifetime. I love him.

As funny as a broken bone. This book has nothing to do with comedy at all. This Trevor Noah isn't the comedian we know, this is some other Trevor Noah the sociologist. I don't know why they're using his face. This Trevor Noah the sociologist had one heck of a tough life man, let me tell you that. But I'm guessing he'd be the first to say, "Nah, that was nothing. It's very common where I'm from."
Fascinating and howling personal stories from an insider's perspective. The tales told and

An exceptional audiobook by comedian and Daily Show host, Trevor Noah. Honestly, I didn't know shit about Trevor until I started reading this, the cover didn't look appealing and I may have never picked this up had it not been for my friend's insistence that it was great. She was right, and I highly recommend that this is listened to rather than read, because the author narrates it himself and will even sing, speak in other languages and do fantastic impersonations. It was a laugh out loud experience. Even though his memoir is quite hilarious, it's also eye-opening and a little horrifying as well. Born during South Africa's apartheid, Trevor grew up in a hellish environment that most people aren't even familiar with. It's a great memoir and mini-history on the South African troubles. Fantastic read, will definitely check out again.

Enjoyable but lacks cohesiveness and chronology. Would've been better without some unnecessary content and language. 
 I listened to it and found Noah's accents enjoyable.

This is by far the best autobiography I have ever read. Trevor wrote about his experiences in a way that was less about making him look good and more about being truthful while making his readers feel the full spectrum of human emotion. This book will make you laugh out loud, think about your values, rage against human injustice, and feel more love for your friends and family.
I listen to the Audiobook and I have to say this is one book where the author actually did amazing job narrating it! This book just made to top ten of my favorite books!
Trevor Noah is very funny and this book can really uplift your mood! One of the most inspirational books I've ever read.

Beautifully, rendered personal history on apartheid in South Africa grounded through Noah whose existence is in itself a crime. Navigating his criminal racial identity and living under a take no nonsense mother, we get such an intimate exploration through Noah's life. Spend some time in Noah' world, and listen to this humorous story that is full of heart and wisdom.
Wow!

Loved this book! Trevor Noah does a wonderful job narrating his own story, and he should. After all, he has his own show on Comedy Central in which he narrates his take on the day's news. 
 I learned much about apartheid that I did not know. His stories about what it was like growing in South Africa during that time are a real eye opener. 
 I received this audiobook free of charge from Audibe.com as part of a promotion from another company who's name I cannot now remember.

Absolutely one of the best books I've read all year, quite possibly now one of my favorite books. As someone who is basically the same age, it was quite an eye opening experience to read about his childhood and life in South Africa under apartheid. The book is very well written and if you didn't know he was insanely smart by watching the Daily Show, you would be even more convinced by this book. The guy speaks 9 languages! Highly recommend!

Really enjoyed this book. I listened to it on audible and was not at all disappointed with Trevor Noah narrating his own book. It was funny and insightful. I don't watch The Daily Shoe regularly just clips here and there on the internet so I don't know his whole story but he had such a crazy and inspiring upbringing. I highly recommend reading/listening to this book.
There are no words deserving enough for me to write to describe this book..

4.25 stars 
 I listened to this on audiobook and I strongly recommend for other people to do the same. 
 Trevor Noah is an amazing narrator. I felt like he was telling me his story rather than narrating his book. 
 The story itself was very interesting and I feel like I've learned something about an era and country I know extremely little about. 
 I do however have one pretty big issue with this book: It's narrative structure and rather lack of. Noah jumps from his childhood to his young adult life and back very frequently and amidst it all the chronology of it became a mystery to me. I could very well deal with it on audiobook because of the verbal nature of that medium but I know that it would have bothered me a lot more had I actually read the book myself.
I have so much respect for Trevor Noah, especially after reading about his youth in South Africa.

THIS WAS SO GOOD. I wish it would've talked a little more about his time between being a kid and coming to America/starting his standup career, but I'm guessing he's saving that for another book. Which I will absolutely read, because this was great. Lots of info about the Apartheid and what it was like to be raised in it - but not dry whatsoever.

"Born a Crime" is by far the best celebrity memoir I have ever encountered. Trevor's mom is my new feminist icon. 
 Read it.

Born a Crime opened my eyes to a lot of things I didn't know and expanded my knowledge of things I thought I knew. I decided to pick up Trevor Noah's memoir because I LOVE watching The Daily Show. He's charismatic, approachable, insightful, and hilarious, so I wanted to get to know him as an individual rather than a television personality. Noah gives the reader an in depth look on the woman who taught him to be the man he is today and how growing up in South Africa shaped his world views. 
 What Born a Crime does best is educating its reader in a brief history about apartheid in South Africa and what that meant for the people living there. The novel accomplishes this by giving the reader straight up facts about it then framing it within Noah's owe childhood and experiences in a comedic tone. Noah touches upon religion and how it shaped those around him, education, language, race, ethnicity, domestic violence, gender roles, and more. Each of these topics influenced Noah in specific ways that are highlighted throughout the text. A lot of them are introduced through funny stories, but some of them are given the serious weight they deserve. 
 As much as I laughed while reading Born a Crime, it broke my heart just as often. Noah's story is not unique because it happens all too often. Stories like these shed light on topics that would otherwise remain hidden in the shadows. 
 Overall, Born a Crime is a fantastic memoir that does more than tell funny stories. It educates the reader about South Africa's recent past, the injustices faced by many everyday, and the consequences of those injustices. If you're looking for a truly insightful memoir, look no further. Trevor Noah will take you on a journey through his childhood and young adult life that will leave you forever changed.

4.5 
 I've loved Trevor Noah since 2009, long before he became the host of The Daily Show. His comedy is so insightful, intelligent, thought provoking, and perceptive. My only "complaint" about this book is that he didn't talk about his rise to fame and experiences and stories from his life once he started becoming successful. Hopefully that will be covered in a second book!

3.5 stars 
 I have no connection to Trevor Noah and I mildly know of him. As someone not afraid to pick up a celebrity memoir by someone I know nothing really about, I went in with little expectations. 
 Noah's life is fascinating, especially the time in his country's life where Apartheid was officially over but not really over. There were some points where it jumped around for no real reason (listening to the audiobook; I don't know if there were breaks and it was separated into sections). I did lose interest here and there but overall found it engaging and enjoyable for someone with no context to Noah. 
 His narration is also fantastic.
An amazing read! I would encourage everyone to check it out Adam audible book- Noah reads it which really takes the story to a whole new level.
4.5. I listened to the audiobook, and if you're planning to read it, listen to it. Trevor Noah narrates, and he is excellent! He really makes the stories come alive.
My 11 y.o. read this and he says "Great stories about a different sort of childhood".

This is one of those books you read when you think you have it bad and then you read this and decide you'll just be grateful for what you have. 
 This book is solely about Trevor Noah's childhood and young life in South Africa, nothing about his career rise in the US. Trevor Noah has lived ten lifetimes already, and at least that many nightmares. The book is not a comedy, there is absolutely nothing funny about any of his early life. The horrors he experienced daily are beyond what we can imagine, and the book ends on one of the worst real life events I can think of. It's a dark story about a boy who grew up with unimaginable horrors just an expected part of daily life. 
 But throughout the book you can feel Trevor's strength, which he got from his mother, and his ability to look on the bright side of life, which he also got from his mother. 
 It's an extraordinary book about an extraordinary life.
Noah's mother is the true star of this book

Really interesting story, and I enjoyed Noah's narration in the audiobook. However his story often skipped around chronologically and lacked an emotional through-line to justify the time jumps. His story is truly best when his mother is in the story, and suffers during the chapters that are just about him being a "naughty" school kid. Definitely worth the read for a unique perspective on apartheid and post-apartheid South Africa!
Really interesting read and fascinated by the historical background of Trevor Noah growing up in post-Apartheid South Africa.

I picked this up expecting something similar to the autobiographies of other actors and comedians - a story about a scrappy underdog who grew up in adversity, followed his dreams, and made it big. This isn't anything like that. Noah mentions his career maybe twice. Instead, he offers stories on the realities of race, poverty, faith, and family in South Africa. Parts of the book act as a survey of South African history, from colonization through Apartheid. Personal stories about tribal politics or witchcraft offer a distinctly South African perspective. But the stories about racial injustice and the cycle of poverty are the hardest hitting, because they remind you of things that happen in the US every day.

I am a huge Trevor Noah fan and as I hoped, this book did not disappoint. It is hard to imagine his life growing up in South Africa and how he ultimately ended up where he is now. Born of a white father and a black mother during apartheid, he truly was a crime!

Probably more like 4.5- I didn't know anything about the author before I read this book, and I found his story to be incredibly interesting. I found myself feeling thankful for his vulnerability and what he shared. I also appreciated the moments he stepped away from his story and gave a few pages of history and context for what was happening within apartheid, and then placed his story in that context. A must read.

After reading this book, I am richer in several dimensions. 
 1. I didn't knew a damn about apartheid, my schools did not taught me anything about it. I know a lot about nazi, about American decimation of Indians, about slavery in southern states, I knew bits about destruction of Australian aborigines, but I hadn't had the slightest idea that it had been distilled into apartheid. 
 2. The way Trevor was raised gave me a lot of though on how am I rising my own children, am I showing the wide enough horizon to dream off, am I raising them into conscious beings that challenge the system instead of blindly accepting and following the imposed rules. 
 3. I didn't know the distinction between black, mixed, colored 
 4. and finally again related to my girls, I've had a lot of thought on how to raise them and avoid programming them with stereotypical roles of a women, but instead teaching them on deciding about themselves without being reckless in relationships, approach to money, approach to defining their own value.

This is a book that every teen should read. It's honest. He writes with a clear understanding of the logic behind his choices at that point in time, and not with "So that should be a lesson to you" tone. If there was ever a story of perseverance, this is it. It is not just a memoir of a growing up in South Africa, it's so much more. It's about being young with the a certain skin tone, finding a place to fit in, hustling a living in difficult circumstances, dealing with domestic violence, and still keeping your sense of self and sense of humor. This book is funny. Just get it and read it.

"We tell people to follow their dreams, but you can only dream of what you can imagine, and, depending on where you come from, your imagination can be quite limited." 
 This was such an amazing autobiographical novel. I watch Trevor on The Daily Show every single night, so being able to learn about his childhood in South Africa really allowed me to gain such an insight into not only his life, but also into an entire culture. The respect I have for Trevor's mother is so significant and this novel emulates how much of a bond she and Trevor have and I really appreciated that aspect of this book. Reading this book was the first time that I also utilized an audiobook whilst reading and I think that in of itself enhanced the my reading experience even more because hearing Trevor talk about his first-hand experiences growing up was hilarious, emotional, and, overall, truly inspiring.

Enjoyable yet thought provoking read. Trevor discusses important themes such as racism, poverty, South Africa's social structure from a unique perspective drawing from his childhood experiences, which is beautifully contrasted with a casual, colloquial writing style bringing the reader a sense of reliability and comfort.

This was an excellent book all around. It was a fascinating story, often hilarious, sometimes heartbreaking, and riveting in moments, particularly the last chapter. It has made me respect Trevor Noah even more than I already did for his comedic skills to hear how he grew up and somehow rose from property, pain, and abuse to become the man he is today. He has excellent insights on race, religion, culture, and world views. He is thoughtful in his writing and can spin a good yarn. His audiobook is narrated by him and is excellent as well. Highly recommend!

This is not a funny book. Noah writes with humor and wit, but it is a completely serious book about his (and his mother's) amazing story. It is thoughtful and does a great job of teaching about South Africa, although the vignettes occasionally seemed out of order or a bit disconnected. Otherwise, an excellent read.

Wow. Just, wow. 
 I heard the book was good - and it was the Michiko Kakutani's review that really caught my attention- but even with those high expectations, I was still blown away. Born a Crime is storytelling at its best: extraordinary experiences told by someone with an impeccable sense of comedic and dramatic timing. Trevor Noah is both hilarious and tragic, informative and at the same time moving. 
 While some of Noah's anecdotes may resonate with third culture or mixed kids more than those who are neither, the core message of a son's love for his mother, will resonate with everyone. 
 I won't continue by reiterating the praise everyone else has already said. You should just read it. 
 -- 
 What I do remember, what I will never forget, is the violence that followed. The triumph of democracy over apartheid is sometimes called the Bloodless Revolution. It is called that because very little white blood was spilled. Black blood ran in the streets. 211 
 "But aren't you afraid?" I'd say. 
 "There's only one of you and there's so many of them." 
 "Honey, I'm not alone," she'd say. 
 "I've got all of Heaven's angels behind me." 
 "Well, it would be nice if we could see them," I'd say. "Because I don't think the rioters know they're there." 
 She'd tell me not to worry. She always came back to the phrase she lived by: "If God is with me, who can be against me?" 
 She was never scared. Even when she should have been. 232 
 When the British took over the Cape Colony, the descendants of the original Dutch settlers trekked inland and developed their own language, culture, and customs, eventually becoming their own people, the Afrikaners--the white tribe of Africa. 320 
 In America you had the forced removal of the native onto reservations coupled with slavery followed by segregation. Imagine all three of those things happening to the same group of people at the same time. That was apartheid. 332 
 If you stop to consider the ramifications, you'll never do anything. 361 
 It was illegal to be mixed (to have a black parent and a white parent), but it was not illegal to be colored (to have two parents who were both colored). So my mom moved me around the world as a colored child. She found a creche in a colored area where she could leave me while she was at work. There was a colored woman named Queen who lived in our block of flats. When we wanted to go out to the park, my mom would invite her to go with us. Queen would walk next to me and act like she was my mother, and my mother would walk a few steps behind, like she was the maid working for the colored woman. I've got dozens of pictures of me walking with this woman who looks like me but who isn't my mother. And the black woman standing behind us who looks like she's photobombing the picture, that's my mom. When we didn't have a colored woman to walk with us, my mom would risk walking me on her own. She would hold my hand or carry me, but if the police showed up she would have to drop me and pretend I wasn't hers, like I was a bag of weed. 451 
 Temperance lived with his second family in the Meadowlands, and we visited them sparingly because my mom was always afraid of being poisoned. Which was a thing that would happen. The first family were the heirs, so there was always the chance they might get poisoned by the second family. It was like Game of Thrones with poor people. We'd go into that house and my mom would warn me. "Trevor, don't eat the food." "But I'm starving." "No. They might poison us." "Okay, then why don't I just pray to Jesus and Jesus will take the poison out of the food?" "Trevor! Sun'qhela!" 547 
 As a nation, we recognized the power of women, but in the home they were expected to submit and obey. 587 
 In America the dream is to make it out of the ghetto. In Soweto, because there was no leaving the ghetto, the dream was to transform the ghetto. 618 
 The spaza shops were informal grocery stores. People would build a kiosk in their garage, buy wholesale bread and eggs, and then resell them piecemeal. Everyone in the township bought things in minute quantities because nobody had any money. You couldn't afford to buy a dozen eggs at a time, but you could buy two eggs because that's all you needed that morning. You could buy a quarter loaf of bread, a cup of sugar. 623 
 The thing that I couldn't handle about the outhouse was the flies. It was a long drop to the bottom, and they were always down there, eating on the pile, and I had an irrational, all-consuming fear that they were going to fly up and into my bum. 652 
 Growing up the way I did, I learned how easy it is for white people to get comfortable with a system that awards them all the perks. 792 
 If you're black in South Africa, speaking English is the one thing that can give you a leg up. English is the language of money. 825 
 That, and so many other smaller incidents in my life, made me realize that language, even more than color, defines who you are to people. 853 
 When she was old enough she stopped working on the farm and got a job at a factory in a nearby town. She worked on a sewing machine making school uniforms. Her pay at the end of each day was a plate of food. She used to say it was the best food she'd ever eaten, because it was something she had earned on her own. She wasn't a burden to anyone and didn't owe anything to anyone. 989 
 My mom told me these things so that I'd never take for granted how we got to where we were, but none of it ever came from a place of self-pity. "Learn from your past and be better because of your past," she would say, "but don't cry about your past. Life is full of pain. Let the pain sharpen you, but don't hold on to it. Don't be bitter." And she never was. The deprivations of her youth, the betrayals of her parents, she never complained about any of it. 1006 
 It was when we moved to Eden Park that we finally got a car, the beat-up, tangerine Volkswagen my mother bought secondhand for next to nothing. One out of five times it wouldn't start. There was no AC. Anytime I made the mistake of turning on the fan the vent would fart bits of leaves and dust all over me. Whenever it broke down we'd catch minibuses, or sometimes we'd hitchhike. She'd make me hide in the bushes because she knew men would stop for a woman but not a woman with a child. She'd stand by the road, the driver would pull over, she'd open the door and then whistle, and I'd come running up to the car. I would watch their faces drop as they realized they weren't picking up an attractive single woman but an attractive single woman with a fat little kid. 1066 
 But as shitty as our car was, it was a car. It was freedom. We weren't black people stuck in the townships, waiting for public transport. We were black people who were out in the world. We were black people who could wake up and say, "Where do we choose to go today?" 1075 
 On Sunday afternoons after church, we'd go for drives out in the country. My mom would find places with beautiful views for us to sit and have a picnic. There was none of the fanfare of a picnic basket or plates or anything like that, only baloney and brown bread and margarine sandwiches wrapped up in butcher paper. To this day, baloney and brown bread and margarine will instantly take me back. You can come with all the Michelin stars in the world, just give me baloney and brown bread and margarine and I'm in heaven. 1086 
 My mom would always say, "My job is to feed your body, feed your spirit, and feed your mind." That's exactly what she did, and the way she found money for food and books was to spend absolutely nothing on anything else. Her frugality was the stuff of legend. Our car was a tin can on wheels, and we lived in the middle of nowhere. We had threadbare furniture, busted old sofas with holes worn through the fabric. Our TV was a tiny black-and-white with a bunny aerial on top. We changed the channels using a pair of pliers because the buttons didn't work. Most of the time you had to squint to see what was going on. We always wore secondhand clothes, from Goodwill stores or that were giveaways from white people at church. All the other kids at school got brands, Nike and Adidas. I never got brands. One time I asked my mom for Adidas sneakers. She came home with some knockoff brand, Abidas. "Mom, these are fake," I said. "I don't see the difference." "Look at the logo. There are four stripes instead of three." "Lucky you," she said. "You got one extra." 1091 
 As modestly as we lived at home, I never felt poor because our lives were so rich with experience. We were always out doing something, going somewhere. My mom used to take me on drives through fancy white neighborhoods. We'd go look at people's houses, look at their mansions. We'd look at their walls, mostly, because that's all we could see from the road. 1112 
 My mother took me places black people never went. She refused to be bound by ridiculous ideas of what black people couldn't or shouldn't do. 1119 
 We tell people to follow their dreams, but you can only dream of what you can imagine, and, depending on where you come from, your imagination can be quite limited. 1126 
 My mother showed me what was possible. The thing that always amazed me about her life was that no one showed her. No one chose her. She did it on her own. She found her way through sheer force of will. 1128 
 People thought my mom was crazy. Ice rinks and drive-ins and suburbs, these things were izinto zabelungu--the things of white people. So many black people had internalized the logic of apartheid and made it their own. Why teach a black child white things? Neighbors and relatives used to pester my mom. "Why do all this? Why show him the world when he's never going to leave the ghetto?" "Because," she would say, "even if he never leaves the ghetto, he will know that the ghetto is not the world. If that is all I accomplish, I've done enough." 1136 
 Apartheid, for all its power, had fatal flaws baked in, starting with the fact that it never made any sense. Racism is not logical. Consider this: Chinese people were classified as black in South Africa. I don't mean they were running around acting black. They were still Chinese. But, unlike Indians, there weren't enough Chinese people to warrant devising a whole separate classification. Apartheid, despite its intricacies and precision, didn't know what to do with them, so the government said, "Eh, we'll just call 'em black. It's simpler that way." Interestingly, at the same time, Japanese people were labeled as white. The reason for this was that the South African government wanted to establish good relations with the Japanese in order to import their fancy cars and electronics. So Japanese people were given honorary white status while Chinese people stayed black. I always like to imagine being a South African policeman who likely couldn't tell the difference between Chinese and Japanese but whose job was to make sure that people of the wrong color weren't doing the wrong thing. If he saw an Asian person sitting on a whites-only bench, what would he say? "Hey, get off that bench, you Chinaman!" "Excuse me. I'm Japanese." "Oh, I apologize, sir. I didn't mean to be racist. Have a lovely afternoon." 1144 
 Note: LOL 
 My mother used to tell me, "I chose to have you because I wanted something to love and something that would love me unconditionally in return--and then I gave birth to the most selfish piece of shit on earth. 1161 
 She taught me to challenge authority and question the system. The only way it backfired on her was that I constantly challenged and questioned her. 1344 
 "It must have been strange for your family living with a dog that was deaf," he said. "What?" "You didn't know your dog was deaf?" "No, we thought it was stupid." 1444 
 Fufi was the love of my life. Beautiful but stupid. I raised her. I potty-trained her. She slept in my bed. A dog is a great thing for a kid to have. It's like a bicycle but with emotions. 1448 
 He just never understood how white people could be racist in South Africa. "Africa is full of black people," he would say. "So why would you come all the way to Africa if you hate black people? If you hate black people so much, why did you move into their house?" To him it was insane. 1540 
 My dad's house was simple. Nice, but nothing fancy. I feel like my dad had enough money to be comfortable and travel, but he never spent lavishly on things. He's extremely frugal, the kind of guy who drives the same car for twenty years. 1564 
 You might get a toy, but it wasn't wrapped and it was never from Santa Claus. The whole issue of Santa Claus is a rather contentious one when it comes to African Christmas, a matter of pride. When an African dad buys his kid a present, the last thing he's going to do is give some fat white man credit for it. African Dad will tell you straight up, "No, no, no. I bought you that." 1574 
 Being chosen is the greatest gift you can give to another human being. 1636 
 That's what apartheid did: It convinced every group that it was because of the other race that they didn't get into the club. It's basically the bouncer at the door telling you, "We can't let you in because of your friend Darren and his ugly shoes." So you look at Darren and say, "Screw you, Black Darren. You're holding me back." Then when Darren goes up, the bouncer says, "No, it's actually your friend Sizwe and his weird hair." So Darren says, "Screw you, Sizwe," and now everyone hates everyone. But the truth is that none of you were ever getting into that club. 1726 
 Even when I thought I was liked, I wasn't. One year I got a brand-new bike during the summer holidays. My cousin Mlungisi and I were taking turns riding around the block. I was riding up our street when this cute colored girl came out to the road and stopped me. She smiled and waved to me sweetly. "Hey," she said, "can I ride your bike?" I was completely shocked. Oh, wow, I thought, I made a friend. "Yeah, of course," I said. I got off and she got on and rode about twenty or thirty feet. Some random older kid came running up to the street, she stopped and got off, and he climbed on and rode away. I was so happy that a girl had spoken to me that it didn't fully sink in that they'd stolen my bicycle. I ran back home, smiling and skipping along. My cousin asked where the bicycle was. I told him. "Trevor, you've been robbed," he said. "Why didn't you chase them?" "I thought they were being nice. I thought I'd made a friend." 1747 
 "Trevor, remember a man is not determined by how much he earns. You can still be the man of the house and earn less than your woman. Being a man is not what you have, it's who you are. Being more of a man doesn't mean your woman has to be less than you." 1842 
 "Trevor, make sure your woman is the woman in your life. Don't be one of these men who makes his wife compete with his mother. A man with a wife cannot be beholden to his mother." 1844 
 "Trevor, don't forget: You're having sex with a woman in her mind before you're having sex with her in her vagina." "Trevor, foreplay begins during the day. It doesn't begin in the bedroom." 1853 
 Maylene was also the only colored girl in school. I was the only mixed kid in school. We were the only two people who looked like each other. The white girls were insistent about me asking Maylene to be my valentine. They were like, "Trevor, you have to ask her. You're the only two. It's your responsibility." It was like our species was going to die out if we didn't mate and carry on. Which I've learned in life is something that white people do without even realizing it. "You two look the same, therefore we must arrange for you to have sex." 1880 
 I liked Maylene as much as I liked anyone, I suppose. Mostly I think I liked the idea of being liked. 1890 
 There were times when we would be in traffic and we had so little money for petrol that I would have to push the car. If we were stuck in gridlock, my mom would turn the car off and it was my job to get out and push it forward six inches at a time. People would pitch up and offer to help. "Are you stuck?" "Nope. We're fine." "You sure?" "Yep." "Can we help you?" "Nope." "Do you need a tow?" And what do you say? The truth? "Thanks, but we're just so poor my mom makes her kid push the car"? That was some of the most embarrassing shit in my life, pushing the car to school like the fucking Flintstones. Because the other kids were coming in on that same road to go to school. I'd take my blazer off so that no one could tell what school I went to, and I would bury my head and push the car, hoping no one would recognize me. 1938 
 Note: LOL Edit 
 I don't regret anything I've ever done in life, any choice that I've made. But I'm consumed with regret for the things I didn't do, the choices I didn't make, the things I didn't say. We spend so much time being afraid of failure, afraid of rejection. But regret is the thing we should fear most. Failure is an answer. Rejection is an answer. Regret is an eternal question you will never have the answer to. "What if..." "If only..." "I wonder what would have..." You will never, never know, and it will haunt you for the rest of your days. 2021 
 After suffering my Valentine's Day heartbreak at the hands of Maylene and the handsome, charming Lorenzo, I learned a valuable lesson about dating. What I learned was that cool guys get girls, and funny guys get to hang out with the cool guys with their girls. 2042 
 The white neighborhoods of Johannesburg were built on white fear--fear of black crime, fear of black uprisings and reprisals--and as a result virtually every house sits behind a six-foot wall, and on top of that wall is electric wire. Everyone lives in a plush, fancy maximum-security prison. There is no sitting on the front porch, no saying hi to the neighbors, no kids running back and forth between houses. I'd ride my bike around the neighborhood for hours without seeing a single kid. I'd hear them, though. They were all meeting up behind brick walls for playdates I wasn't invited to. I'd hear people laughing and playing and I'd get off my bike and creep up and peek over the wall and see a bunch of white kids splashing around in someone's swimming pool. I was like a Peeping Tom, but for friendship. 2119 
 While I downloaded music and messed around in chat rooms, I'd dabble in porn sites here and there. No video, of course, only pictures. With online porn today you just drop straight into the madness, but with dial-up it took so long for the images to load. It was almost gentlemanly compared to now. You'd spend a good five minutes looking at her face, getting to know her as a person. Then a few minutes later you'd get some boobs. By the time you got to her vagina, you'd spent a lot of quality time together. 2273 
 In my mind nothing was cooler than the leather coats everybody wore in The Matrix. The Matrix came out while I was in high school and it was my favorite movie at the time. I loved Neo. In my heart I knew: I am Neo. He's a nerd. He's useless at everything, but secretly he's a badass superhero. All I needed was a bald, mysterious black man to come into my life and show me the way. Now I had Bongani, black, head shaved, telling me, "You can do it. You're the one." And I was like, "Yes. I knew it." 2397

very enlightening. Noah's observations are insightful and thought provoking.His unique vantage point as an observer makes him able to express things in a way an audience, no matter their cultural frame of reference, can connect with.

Born a Crime is a truly fantastic memoir from The Daily Show host Trevor Noah. This book chronciles Noah's childhood and adolescence in South Africa beginning with his birth, which gives the book its name. Noah is mixed race, born at a time when sexual relationships between white people and black people was illegal; he was born a crime. This led to a number of difficulties throughout his life; he was too white to hang out with black kids, and too black to hang out with white kids. Yet, Noah grew up surrounded by black people and culture, and found it difficult to understand why he wasn't readily accepted by his peers. 
 Noah is a truly fantastic story-teller, blending the serious topics of race, bigotry, prejudice, and feminism, with his brilliant sense of humour. Anyone familiar with his comedy will recognise this quality. His voice shines through his writing. However, while we may come to this book for Noah's story, the truly fascinating individual of Born a Crime is his mother. Noah's relationship with his mother was paramount in this life, and when you read this book you will understand why. She was a remarkable woman. 
 The book skips around a lot in time frame, and often it was very unclear what age Noah was in particular sections, and this is my only criticism of Born a Crime. It is an absolutely brilliant read, and I am reluctant to paraphrase any of the remarkable stories he tells, because I will do them no justice. This is a book I want to put in the hands of everyone I know. It is intelligent, it is funny, and above all; Born a Crime is important.
This is honestly one of the best books I have read. I laughed, cried, and felt for him. I really want to give him a hug. I would love to read more from him.

What a book. And what a crazy, amazing story this man has. This should be required reading for everyone just to gain a better understanding of the world. You'll learn a lot about apartheid and a lot about the incredible bond between Trevor and his mom. You'll read really funny stories and then some not so funny ones that will make you shake your head and gasp. Read this. And then share it with the people you love.

I once read that a great book is one that you want to recommend to everyone you know, especially the fellow readers in your life. Fellow readers, "You need to read the memoir, Born a Crime: Stories from a South African Childhood, by Trevor Noah! It is absolutely brilliant." 
 I can confidently say that Trevor is an incredible story teller. I would love to tell you all about the book, but that would just ruin the moments of learning, laughter, and WTF (what the fuuuuuh?) moments that you experience in the process. 
 For those of you who have read my reviews, you know that I often pair my novels with the audible version. It's just something that I enjoy doing for various reasons such as making my morning and afternoon commute enjoyable. Also, when reading memoirs I enjoy hearing the author's voice! Let's be honest, if you wrote your story, who else could tell your story with the proper emotional inflections and tones, better than you. Mr. Noah took the time to perform his own book and the South African accent didn't hurt the performance one bit. 
 That being said I'll write to you my 10 WTF moments encountered while reading this book: 
 1. Trevor's mother, "Nombuyiselo" is a remarkable and EXTRAORDINARY human being. You will learn about her from the beginning of the book all the way until the end. I loved her spirit. I loved her courage. In all honestly, she is the one who needs to write a memoir. 
 2. "GO HITLER! GO HITLER! GO HITLER!" I almost peed in my pants. This story is too good not to read. 
 3. The Chinese are considered black in an apartheid South Africa yet the Japanese were labeled as white. WTF! 
 4. WTF...black church service is just as long in Africa as it is in America! Is long service in the black church a worldwide epidemic? DAMN, what's going on? 
 5. WTF...Trevor, you saw charred bodies in the streets as a child. I could never imagine. 
 6. "Witchcraft + Trevor Pray + Koko" THE ABSOLUTE BEST! Couldn't stop laughing. 
 7. "Two times two is four. Three times two is six. La la la la la. We're talking about fully grown teenagers being taught this way for generations." WTF....this was education in apartheid South Africa!!!! DAMN! 
 8. WTF...is a smiley? And did you just describe eating an eye? 
 A smiley is goats head. 
 9. WTF are mopane worms? I'm sorry you had to eat them. My goodness. 
 10. "She was a free-roaming spirit." Did I mention how remarkable and extraordinary Trevor's mother is? Her keen perception. Her thoughts...she blew my mind over and over again. 
 READ.THIS.BOOK. 
 P.S. I loved hearing the words "Mazda and Volkswagon" in a South African accent. I smiled every time.
Interesting, funny, compelling. I highly recommend this memoir. Listen to the audiobook for perfect narration by the author. I don't think it would have been the same to read it.

Born a Crime by Trevor Noah is a perfect example of why I love book clubs. Belonging to a book club has made me read many a title I wouldn't have considered reading. Don't get me wrong. I read nonfiction, but I knew nothing about Trevor Noah outside of he is a comedian and I'd seen a few clips from The Daily Show. I had no idea he had written a book. 
 Anywhooo, when I read the blurb about the book, I was like, "Oh no, a depressing book about apartheid in South Africa. At least he's a successful person, so it won't be all bad." I know, I'm a horrible person, but there you have it. Now that I've read the book, I believe everyone should and it should be assigned to high school classes. This is how history should be taught. I found Born a Crime extremely entertaining and educational. Reading the book felt like watching an amazing movie. I'm going to order the audio because it's the closest I can get to turning the black and white movie in my mind into full color. 
 My favorite aspect of his story is actually his mother. An incredible woman, she was the star of the movie in my mind. Extremely religious, yet progressive in many ways, she refused to be held back by the chains of apartheid. You know how people say if you could have someone over for dinner to pick their brain, who would it be? Well, Trevor Noah's mother would be the person I picked. 
 I wish I could give Born a Crime ten stars, but they only allow five. Read the book, folks, and you'll see what I mean. 
 Deatri King-Bey

This book was amazing. I highly recommend it.

There are a lot of crap celebrity memoirs out there. Either because the person in question lead a pretty average life (until they became well known) or because they just have nothing interesting to say, or share, about themselves or the world. A lot of the time, celebrity memoirs are just a cheap way to cash in on a person's popularity. 
 Born a Crime isn't one of those books. I've never watched Trevor Noah on TV, or seen any of his stand-ups. But that wasn't necessary for my enjoyment of this book. 
 Most of all I found this book to be interesting. Learning about Trevor's experience of growing up poor in South Africa during and after Apartheid was something I knew little about prior to this. It wouldn't be false to say his life may have been quite average in many ways, but from my own perspective it was so far removed from my own upbringing as to be interesting. 
 Something I thought about when reading the book was the different experience of Apartheid it showed in comparison to Nelson Mandela's autobiography. Mandela spent much of the time in prison so in a lot of ways his experience of Apartheid was abnormal. Whereas Trevor speaks about his regular life before and after which is almost more interesting.

I don't know much about South African history, but this book made me crave to learn more. In the middle of reading this, I watched YouTube videos on apartheid so that I'd feel less ignorant about the subject. Trevor Noah's personal stories about his mother, racism, his funny childhood antics and his not-so-funny encounters with violence are all so valuable to understanding other parts of the human experience. The writing is fantastic, and the author's narration is even more so. 
 This is an insightful and emotionally satisfying memoir that I wish everyone would read.

3.5/5 based on what I read. 
 Okay so i have realized that the odds of me actually ever finishing this audiobook are slim and that makes me sad. dY~z 
 I really like Trevor Noah and I definately think that the audiobook is the way to go with this one but I dont really tend to like memoirs like at all. I made it a fair bit through and really enjoyed all i had read/heard but i found myself getting bored with it. Which is totally my fault and not this books. I think it was informative and interesting to hear about what it was like for a mixed child being raised in Africa. Maybe someday I will finish it?

Great share of small stories encompassing Trevor's childhood. I learned a lot from reading about his upbringing to learning he lived in his stepdads garage, or that his humor comes from his mother. It doesn't dwell into his fame and how he got where he is today. It's not about that. These stories are what built the Trevor Noah we know today. Why he is who he because of his life experiences growing up in South Africa at the aftermath of Apartheid while being an anomaly.
Charming, excruciatingly honest, powerful.

From the moment he was born, Trevor Noah was an "other" - someone who defies cultural norms and doesn't fit into established patterns. Combine this with apartheid's racist restrictions in his South African home, and Noah has plenty of stories to tell. Through each story, the reader learns both funny and touching details of his reality. 
 Noah could have become an angry young man, but instead he chose to find humor in the difficulties. That instinct came directly from his mother, who mixed tough discipline with deep love as she raised her sons. He dedicates his book to her, and it's clear that she shaped the man he is today. 
 I laughed heartily over and over. With both the audiobook and hardcover, I felt like I was almost immersed in his story over a few days time. Trevor gives an incredible performance as narrator, as if we were in his living room sharing funny stories about our lives. Except he is way better at doing accents and voices. 
 Towards the end of the book, the story takes a dark turn as Noah tells about life as the stepson of an alcoholic, abusive man. The laughs slow down, but the heart and soul of the story get stronger. It's the perfect blend. 
 I had the pleasure of hearing Trevor at an author's reading a few weeks ago. He told us a story that's not in the book, and I'll share it here. He asked his grandmother why his mother never wanted to leave South Africa and come see him in the other places he's lived, like New York. His grandmother said (imagine Noah going into her voice here), "Trevor, some people are butterflies and other people are flowers. You are a butterfly. Your mother is a flower." 
 I think that story, along with the entire book, will stay with me for a long time. 
 2017 update: I decided to re listen to this during a stressful week, and everything I said above holds true on a second lesson. The laughs are funnier, and the poignant moments are deeper and more touching. I'll never stop trying to understand the perspectives of people from around the world, including those of all colors, and Noah does a wonderful job of sharing his.

Trevor filled this book with his essence, which is made of sterner stuff than what comprises most Americans. I'm a fan, I like his comedy and I like him as the Daily Show host, and I feel like I finally understand why he was tapped to replace Stewart. 
 Jon had the political background for Crossfire and to defang Ailes' ilk, Trevor has the depth of perspective to steer us through the boomers' last blows. Nothing he encounters in today's America can hold a candle to what he has made it through. 
 I also admire and find edifying how Trevor steers us deftly through his faith and worldview, and yet he doesn't expend a single word in this book trying to sell the reader any of it. Not one iota. Many might read his memoir and be able to shrug, cluck about what an experience he's had, and move on. Many more, I think, might be able to adopt or adapt Noah's experiences into our worldview and be richer for it.
Incredible childhood.

Loved it. 
 I listened to this book on Audible while driving and even after 8 hours I was still captivated. Even as I was listening to Noah read, I could see the substructure to his chapters (as only a professor/writer would) and I liked his pacing and unfolding of his narratives.

Wow. Born a Crime: Stories from a South Africa Childhood by Trevor Noah was such a great read. I didn't do a lot of research into this book before I started reading it. All I knew was that Trevor Noah, the host of The Daily Show, wrote a book and it was about his childhood growing up in South Africa. For some reason I thought that this book would ultimately end with him starting his stint as the host of The Daily Show, while also talking about his experiences in South Africa. However, Born a Crime doesn't discuss at all his comedy career, and focuses completely on his life growing up in South Africa. And I captivated every minute of this book 
 I found Born a Crime to be a really powerful book. Each chapter is a little essay on something that happened to Noah growing up in South Africa. The thread tying all these stories together is Noah's mother. She is really something special, and I could feel how much love and respect Noah has for his mother. I really loved that. 
 I learned so much about the country of South Africa. It was interesting, but often sad and disturbing, learning about South Africa. Noah was born when Apartheid was still going on, and I was moved hearing about his experiences under Apartheid. But even when Apartheid ended, things didn't magically become fantastic. 
 Noah had so many poignant things to say. He speaks a lot about poverty, about being black, about racism. He's so intelligent, and that really comes through in this book. I found Noah's comments on language incredibly interesting. He talked a lot about how even though he didn't look black (his mother is black, his father is white), he was raised in a black family, and he would show other black children at school he belonged in their group by speaking the same language. 
 I really loved Born a Crime by Trevor Noah. I cannot recommend it enough. The audiobook especially was fantastic, as it is narrated by Noah himself. He is a fantastic narrator in general, but he really excelled here, as one would expected.This review was originally posted on Quinn's Book Nook

It captured my soul.;}

I used to be generous with my five stars. Lately, I've been trying to cut down, but at the end of the day? Four stars means a great book, something I would recommend. Five stars means it made me feel something new. And this made me feel that. This felt like fiction, and even though I knew a little bit of his story I was constantly surprised with how things turn out. Just.... read this book. If not for Trevor, for his mom.

Uncover the absurdities of Apartheid in South Africa, follow Trevor Noah and devour his autobiography, honest, brutal and comical at this same time. Him being born was a crime, yet his extraordinary mother set him to be free in spite of all the cultural, legal, sociological, linguistical obstacles.

4.5/5 stars. 
 This is a really good book, and I read it based on a friend's recommendation (Thanks Yazeed!). To be honest, I wasn't expecting much when I started, but I was immediately surprised and engrossed, and this is coming from a person who almost aggressively stays away from memoirs and biographies. You will laugh out loud; you will feel emotional (if not outright cry at times); you will learn things; and you will enjoy it. And no, I'm not doing a Jedi mind trick, but merely stating facts. 
 I only reserve 5 star ratings exclusively for books I would read over and over again, and I guess since this is a memoir book, it's not the type of book I would go back to. 
 But this is still a very good read and I would highly recommend it. In particular, I would recommend that you listen to the audiobook which is narrated by Trevor himself. Not only is he an excellent storyteller, but he's also an excellent narrator. Hearing him share his stories definitely adds to the experience. You won't be disappointed.

I listened to the audio version of this book and was floored by not only Trevor Noah's story, but his amazing performance. It's an honest and moving exploration of family, self, and society. I don't often claim that I will listen to a book twice, but I will with this one.

This was a really interesting book, told in a voice that is not usually heard. I learned a lot about apartheid and South Africa. The reason why I gave it four stars instead of five is the way that the book was structured. For the first 120 pages or so, each chapter read more like an individual essay than a complete book. While each chapter was interesting, I did not feel compelled to keep reading. After about 120 pages, there was more continuity between the chapters and it was more difficult to put the book down.

Listened to the audiobook of this. Absolutely amazing. Such an incredible look into a different culture and society but with so many ties to right now. Everyone should read this right now. Go. Go get it now.

I listened to this book on audiobook and I'm so glad I did. Listening to Trevor Noah talk about how it was to grow up in South Africa under and after apartheid and the way he captures the nuances of language and accents in South Africa really, I believe, brought a different level to the book. He does an incredible job of capturing the accents of the family and friends in his life. I found the book fascinating and enjoyed it from start to finish. I have enjoyed catching Trevor on The Daily Show when I have the opportunity but after reading this book, definitely plan to watch it more often as I feel he brings a unique perspective due to growing up in South Africa. Highly recommend.

Never have I ever read such an amazing book that is so light-hearted yet engaging. I was laughing hysterically at every single chapter (chapter 3 is the best btw). The last part of the book hit me hard and was very emotional for me to even imagine but thats what I loved about the book. It had humour and it had rawness that I wasn't able to find in many books. I couldn't put the book down and ended up finishing the whole book in 4 days. I highly recommend this book to anyone who wishes to read a fun entertaining book.

Smart. Funny. Moving. 
 I really can't praise this enough. At times, Trevor had me doubled over with laughter. Minutes later my eyes would well with tears. And central to it all, the amazing story of a son and his mother, and the incredible bond between them. 
 I highly, highly recommend the audio version of this book. While I believe the stories are fantastically compelling on their own, hearing the different languages Trevor uses as they are meant to sound, and his impressions of his friends and family, makes the essays even better. (Plus, he's got a great voice.)

It took me a while to warm up to Trevor Noah on The Daily Show, mostly because - as with many people, I guess - I was so sad to see Jon Stewart leaving. The end of an era! Why, I remember when Jon Stewart started in the early 00s. I remember the moments of Zen; even Stevphen; all those wonderful moments when one of the anchors would corpse. 
 Ho ho ho. How silly and paltry that 'end of an era' feels now! After the threatening reality of other, much more important eras ending... But I digress. 
 Anyway, so I've been warming up to Noah for the last few months (his Trump is America's first African President skit was genius), and this memoir comes, MAN, JUST AT THE RIGHT TIME. It is sharply observant, socio-politically aware, heartwarming (!?), fun and funny. It ends on a bit of a terrible note - Noah's stepdad was an abusive alcoholic nightmare of a man, and we end with (I guess) the worst day of Noah's life (?) - but it also ends on the same themes it had been weaving in throughout: the stupidity of racism (and the evil of its institutionalization - or its uses for political gain), and the frustrating additional stupidity of sexism. You learn a lot about South Africa along the way, and the realities of growing up before and after apartheid. And you also realize - damn, this dude is a lot more talented than you initially realized. 
 Definitely recommended; and I recommend the audiobook, to get the full breadth of Noah's polyglot abilities and amazing imitations. The dude's only 32 - let's have an update memoir! MORRRE.

This book is incredible. I have listened to the audiobook version twice, and I could listen to Trevor Noah read his own story a third time. I really enjoyed his style of storytelling. I also love the way in which he weaves the history and politics of South Africa and apartheid into his story. I was able to enjoy his narrative and learn more about that part of the world. I highly recommend this book. 
 As a side note: The author's mother is an absolutely amazing, strong, independent woman. I love the way he writes about his mother's strength, faith, and independent spirit. 
 So. Read this book.

avtoris gamo, sasac`ilo cigni megona da magis imedad davicqe. gamodga kidec`, alag-alag mxiaruli. t`umc`a imdenadve mz'imea da noas cerac` shesz'lebia. amast`an, ch`veni da postaparteiduli samxret` ap`rikis respublikis ganvit`areba ert`manet`s caagavs, rac` kidev up`ro sainteresos xdis. 
 caikit`xet`, samxret` ap`rikeli hitleris ambis gamo mainc`

"We tell people to follow their dreams, but you can only dream of what you can imagine, and, depending on where you come from, your imagination can be quite limited." 
 I was super excited when I finally saw this in a bookstore as I'm a huge fan of Trevor Noah and I was really interested in learning more about his South African heritage as apartheid isn't something I knew very much about. Going into this book I expected to laugh a lot and to learn a lot and let me tell you: I was not disappointed. 
 "Language, even more than color, defines who you are to people." I loved the insight into how Noah tackled the negative afteraffects of apartheid as a young colored person. By learning multiple tribal languages within his country, Noah was able to connect with people from all walks of life and really bridge the gap between cultures. "Language brings with it an identity and a culture, or at least the perception of it. A shared language says "We're the same." A language barrier says "We're different." 
 Having grown up as a third culture kid (meaning I grew up in a culture different to that of my parents), I really connected to Noah's feelings about growing up and not always feeling welcome in your own country. It's a point of view you rarely get to see in literature or film and I really appreciated it. 
 I also really loved how he expressed that women held the South African communities together. The entire book really focuses on the impact his mom had on his life and all of her triumphs against where she started. I think it's really important for the significance of women in society to be highlighted, especially by men. The importance of women is written across the pages of this book with such definition, it's empowering. "Wathint'Abafazi Wathint'imbokodo!" "When you strike a woman, you strike rock." 
 There are some pretty hilarious stories in here from Trevor Noah's teenage years (such as the one of his break dancing friend, Hitler) but there's also some really difficult to digest moments that he retells for us. I learned so much through reading this book, not only about Noah, but about racial identity, politics, history and language. Every essay is incredibly thought provoking and I was often left wondering about all the other people in the world with similar experiences to Noah's and how we don't get to hear enough of them. 
 As you can probably tell through my review, this book is incredibly quotable. It's full of insight into life surrounding apartheid in South Africa, but it also captures the essence of adolescence and growing up. Born A Crime read very similarly to how Trevor Noah speaks on The Daily Show and it still held the same wit and humor, even when talking about incredibly serious topics. Born A Crime was impossible to put down and is a must read for everyone. 
 Born A Crime is inspiring, hilarious, tear jerking and real. It's the story of Noah's humble upbringing and how his experiences shaped who he is today. Noah's relationship with his mom and their entire lives in general are truly miraculous and I have so much respect for both of them. This book is worth the read, more so than most. So give it a chance. It won't let you down.
I would recommend this book to every person to read.

"We tell people to follow their dreams, but you can only dream of what you can imagine, and, depending on where you come from, your imagination can be quite limited." 
 "People love to say, "Give a man a fish, and he'll eat for a day. Teach a man to fish, and he'll eat for a lifetime." What they don't say is, "And it would be nice if you gave him a fishing rod." That's the part of the analogy that's missing." 
 "If you're Native American and you pray to the wolves, you're a savage. If you're African and you pray to your ancestors, you're a primitive. But when white people pray to a guy who turns water into wine, well, that's just common sense." 
 This book was filled with remarkable quotes. Trevor's observations on race and class are articulate and insightful. His anecdotes are both entertaining and thought provoking. Not only do they open up our American perspective to South Africa's history of apartheid, but he seamlessly parallels that with the struggles we currently face in this country. The color of his skin allowed him access to various worlds and he was observant enough to notice how the power structure worked and how it didn't. His quote about teaching a man to fish really resonated with me. The US not only has a profound problem with addressing race, but its also not even close to addressing class. I liked the guy okay from his Daily Show hosting, but this book made him someone I respect for their wokeness. If you want to think critically about these subjects while enjoying some often funny and heartfelt stories, I highly recommend this book.

Trevor Noah has been on my favorite funny guys list for some time now, but he's moved to my most highly respected celebrities list as well after listening to his harrowing, heartbreaking, joyous story of growing up in South Africa. (One of the rare books that I recommend actually hearing rather than reading - it wouldn't be the same without hearing it from Noah himself!) Born on the brink of the country's decision to end apartheid, Noah was a biracial child - highly unusual then AND now. His warm retelling of growing up poor but highly optimistic in various neighborhoods is absolutely enchanting.
