The love and respect Noah has for his mom practically jumps into your ears, and his use of different voices to mimick various family members (including little Trevor) are beautiful and, in the case of his childhood self, frankly adorable. He's able to keep you fully engaged and smiling even as he delves into deep issues that include racial identity, domestic abuse, endemic poverty, and racial violence. I literally could not stop listening to this book despite the many hardships he and his mom endured together, even when I saw what was coming and wanted desperately to avoid it. 
 Thankfully, the book ends on a happy note. You'll be shocked and horrified at what Noah and his family lived through even while laughing at his youthful pranks and antics. You'll giggle and cry, and close the book full of gratitude and hope for humanity. A truly remarkable bit of storytelling here from a young celebrity who is here to stay.

The audiobook version of this book was great. I'm sure reading the print book would also be good but I loved the added benefit of hearing the story in the author's voice. I had no idea how difficult his childhood was or much about the history of South Africa. I knew about Apartheid but his explanations of the realities were powerful. Funny and heartfelt. Great read.

Solid writing. Good organization, good pace. Great balance of humor, personal tragedy, and literal crimes against humanity: while certainly dark and disturbing, it was never unbearably so. 
 Trevor's voice shines throughout. I'd love to hear him read it. 
 I'd like to hear the omitted part of this story, which I assume is Trevor's meteoric rise to international fame. His (legal) career is mentioned hardly at all, and I find his success all the more interesting given his tough breaks and illicit activities as a youngster. (Host of the Daily Show? How's this kid not in prison somewhere?) I think there's one bit where he's like, "I did a little stand up" and another where he mentioned he had hosted a (television?) show. And that's it. 
 In retrospect, it was almost like the story he wanted to tell was that of his family and friends, and the politics that shaped their circumstances. And he included himself only as much as necessary to tell that story. 
 Anyway. 10 out of 10. Recommended to everybody. 
 Oh, and, I'll quote @Mel here for you, because I didn't heed her warning, and I regretted it, and I don't want you to make the same mistake I did: 
 When you get the part where they're riding around on a bus looking for lunch, skip the next two paragraphs. 
 It's because of graphic descriptions of eating actual, literal goat heads. And it gets way gross from there. Gross enough that I squeezed my eyes closed really tight, but my book down in my lap, and whispered, "Ewwwwww," out loud to myself.
So enjoyed this one, especially on audio! I highly recommend it! Funny, thoughtful, heartfelt and offered a peek into a part of the world so few of us know much about.

Just finished the book, wow, it brought all kinds of emotions, sadness and laughter from reading the dysfunctional stories of growing up during Apartheid in South Africa. Where it was against the law to have parents of mixed race (particularly a white and black parent), growing up with his mother and growing up with a sense of wanting to belong, but was not accepted in any group. Somehow Trevor Noah managed to tell some of these stories with a great sense of humor. I loved his mother and what a strong figure she was! So stubborn but independent, trying to do the best for the family and do her best job in raising her child. She had such strong faith that nothing could break her spirit. It was also interesting to learn more in depth about living during Apartheid, and their everlasting dysfunctional and confusing rules and laws. You also get the feel of the culture, and the every day life throughout different classes in the same country. All in all I thought it was a great read!
Very Interesting.
Everyone needs to read this so I can stop annoying everyone by forcing them to listen to me talk about it.

This book left me with tears, awe, laugh, and a deep reflection on race. It is by far the funniest, yet sincere memoire i have ever read. Such a well-written piece and i can't emphasize enough how well it shadows upon a dark history by unwinding a personal story.

So good! I learned a lot, I laughed, and I loved getting to know Trevor Noah. He really does have a story to tell and he does it well. Do yourself a favor and listen to it on audio so you don't miss out on his lovely accent, pronunciation of occasional phrases in various South African languages, and engaging storytelling ability :)

Born a Crime lives up to the hype. Trevor Noah masterfully tells his story of loss, hardship, coming of age, and growing up in South Africa during apartheid. It's incredible to think that Trevor Noah, now host of the Daily Show, has lived through so much. This read has it all, gut wrenching sadness, laugh-out-loud adventures, and moments of "I can't believe that happened". This story also weaves in the history and cultural background of South Africa, which alone is incredibly interesting. I can't recommend this one enough, you should definitely pick it up.

What a great book! I love Trevor Noah. I watch him on the Daily Show and have watch his stand up. I had an idea of what I was going to get with this book and was not disappointed. I find his life, resilience and sense of humor is amazing. Highly recommend!

The author is an incredible storyteller and narrator and this book was one of the highlights of my year. Serious but never smothering, honest, self aware, charming...I'll definitely be reading this one again.

I loved this book. Fascinating stories, his as a mixed race child before and after apartheid, and a good brief history of South Africa. As I read it, I could hear his voice in my head. But it's a poor substitute, so I'm going to listen to him read the audiobook version. I must admit, knowing so much more about him, I'm truly smitten with this funny, brave (and yes, good-looking) man! His Netflix special was good, but it left me wanting more, and it was so mild compared to the wild, true stories in this book.

This book covers Trevor Noah's life in South Africa, being born during apartheid, and ends before he came to the United States and started hosting The Daily Show. Noah's great humor comes through the most horrible things that happened to him and his mother and how running has saved his life--and good humor--from toddlerhood onward. I want to know more about how Trevor Noah has developed so much world wide knowledge and what his life is like now. I think of him as one of my favorite comedian/political commentators (although in this book he claims he identifies neither with the left nor the right).

Read it. 
 Don't argue. Just do it.

This book was recommended on Book Riot's All the Books podcast. It was pitched as being a funny but also important look at what life was like for Trevor Noah growing up during South African apartheid. The way it was described, it sounded like it was going to be more of a comedian-memoir than a serious examination of race issues... Indeed, it was funny at times, and Noah did discuss racism with a compelling perspective from his personal experiences. I would sooner say this book has more serious and thought-provoking content than humour. He does strike a precise balance of bringing in comedy at the right moment to lighten the mood, though. Also, he does indeed get up to some pretty ridiculous shenanigans during his childhood and adolescence. It was very well done and I was astonished by what a tough background Trevor Noah has. He has been through a lot of things that I was not expecting to hear about in a comedian's memoir. 
 I was not completely satisfied with the ending, because it stopped somewhat abruptly. There was some sense of conclusion, but I suppose a book about a young person's ongoing life is unlikely to end with a happily ever after. I won't give it away, but some crazy things happen, some twists that I did not see coming! 
 This book was great on audio and I recommend this book! A very interesting read!

Trevor Noah is my new celebrity crush! He is so incredibly smart AND funny! This book is educational and entertaining at the same time. I learned so much more about South Africa and apartheid and the intricacies of race and culture there. I especially love how self-aware and reflective Trevor Noah is. He is able to sum up his experiences into one or two sentences that are universal human truths. HIGHLY recommend this book if you're looking for an engaging memoir/biography!

This was a great view into the worlds of Colored and Black people in post-Apartheid South Africa. I was fortunate to visit Johannesburg in the mid-90s and as an outsider, I was not privvy to many of the hidden stories of the people I met. Trevor Noah was able to share stories that answered many of my unanswered questions. Noah has the ability to tell stories about "uncomfortable" things in a way that made me want to learn more. His voice is clear and non-apologetic.

Excellent fantastic outstanding read! This man knows how to tell a story. I knew very little about Noah (haven't watched The Daily Show regularly since Craig Kilborn was the host) but picked it up because it looked interesting. It was all that and then some. Actually made me almost tear up at the end.
Loved it! Trevor Noah is gifted with both storytelling and language. Do yourself a favor though, get the audio book - he does all the accents and different languages himself.
great read! I highly recommend to anyone.

Book #33 this year 
 Born A Crime By Trevor Noah 
 I had hard bits and pieces of this memoir before I read it so I knew this was not going to be a funny romp but rather Noah telling mesmerizing, moving, powerful stories about everything from how his birth was literally a crime (it was illegal to have mixed race babies), how he had trouble feeling like he belonged either with the whites or the blacks in South Africa to even darker topics like dealing with domestic violence in his family. 
 This was an awesome, sobering book with much reflection and thought in it. 
 I give it a rare (from me) 9 out of ten
Funny, insightful, sad and wonderful.
This has been one of the best books I've read before! I laughed, cried, got upset, felt disappointed and felt hopeful throughout the book. I highly recommend it to everyone!

Wow wow wow! 
 So I was browsing through audible's "best sellers" list last week, looking for anything that had ratings of 4.8 stars or greater. This book had tons of wonderful reviews. 
 Now I don't normally read autobiographies, but I was already a fan of Trevor Noah so I decided to give it a shot. Honestly I'm so so so glad I did. The audio book is written and performed by Noah, and is full of a wonderful variety of stories from his childhood in south africa; some heart-breaking, some shocking and edifying, some... absolutely hilarious. It's not too long (About 8 hours listening) and was very entertaining. Noah's narrative skills are impressive. Would recommend to anyone.

Illuminating look at Trevor Noah's childhood living as a colored kid under apartheid. Funny and tragic, full of wisdom and insights. I listened to the audio version read by Trevor Noah. Recommended for all.
Great insight about growing up under apartheid, poverty and violence. The resiliency of the human spirit is remarkable.

I am not a big fan of biographies and especially autobiographies. But I loved this one. Through the eyes of someone who experienced Apartheid and the ensuing transition, this is less an autobiography and more a very personal history lesson through the eyes of a child and the story of a strong woman raising a young man to rise above all the forces arrayed against someone who was literally born a crime. And he does it with his own unique, truly entertaining and yet also profoundly truthful voice. I couldn't put the book down.
A quick, brilliant read on a sunny day.

How can a person who has been subjected to racism throughout his life make jokes out of exactly those racist, sexist ideologies? The capacity to laugh at our own helplessness is the biggest gift life can ever give you. 
 Trevor Noah has hilariously made the readers aware about the pathetic principles of the racist regime. In a country where you have to choose sides basis your skin color and if you choose the wrong side you might even die, Noah's mother Patricia chose her life on her own. Neither white, nor black, a "colored" Noah never fit in, so much so that he did not fit in his own home. 
 "Because I don't know how to hit a white child," she said. "A black child, I understand. A black child, you hit them and they stay black. Trevor, when you hit him he turns blue and green and yellow and red. I've never seen those colors before. I'm scared I'm going to break him. I don't want to kill a white person. I'm so afraid. I'm not going to touch him." And she never did." 
 Despite being the naughtiest, Noah escaped his granny's whipping and many other punishments just because he was colored - biracial, a near-white born from a white father and a black mother, but didn't escape some other punishments which might have cost him his life. The ridiculous, inglorious law mechanisms during and post Apartheid in South Africa stare in the readers' face like an exasperating, impotent truth and Noah doesn't mince words while mocking them. 
 "Only Catholics can eat Jesus's body and drink Jesus's blood, right?" 
 "Yes." 
 "But Jesus wasn't Catholic." 
 "No." 
 "Jesus was Jewish." 
 "Well, yes." 
 "So you're telling me that if Jesus walked into your church right now, Jesus would not be allowed to have the body and blood of Jesus?" "Well...uh...um..." 
 - So goes one of the conversations of Trevor with a catholic nun. 
 Patricia Noah's character has sparkled so beautifully throughout the book - her fight against the patriarchal system, domestic abuse, her thirst to ensure her child doesn't turn out to be a weakling amidst the chaos of the society - she has shone brightly and gracefully. 
 Trevor Noah is not a great literary writer, neither has he attempted to sound like one. The memoir is lucid, straightforward, blunt as blunt could be and yet doesn't fail to give much learning about the country and its long tryst with mistreatment. It has some beautiful anecdotes from Trevor's childhood and some wonderful lessons he learnt and the book is absolutely not devoid of some amazing quotes. 
 "I believed that Fufi was my dog, but of course that wasn't true. Fufi was a dog. I was a boy. We got along well. She happened to live in my house. That experience shaped what I've felt about relationships for the rest of my life: You do not own the thing that you love. " 
 "I don't regret anything I've ever done in life, any choice that I've made. But I'm consumed with regret for the things I didn't do, the choices I didn't make, the things I didn't say. We spend so much time being afraid of failure, afraid of rejection. But regret is the thing we should fear most. Failure is an answer. Rejection is an answer. Regret is an eternal question you will never have the answer to. "What if..." "If only..." "I wonder what would have..." You will never, never know, and it will haunt you for the rest of your days." 
 Abel wanted a traditional marriage with a traditional wife. For a long time I wondered why he ever married a woman like my mom in the first place, as she was the opposite of that in every way. If he wanted a woman to bow to him, there were plenty of girls back in Tzaneen being raised solely for that purpose. The way my mother always explained it, the traditional man wants a woman to be subservient, but he never falls in love with subservient women. He's attracted to independent women. "He's like an exotic bird collector," she said. "He only wants a woman who is free because his dream is to put her in a cage." 
 "And that's the problem with the world. We have people who cannot police themselves, so they want to police everyone else"

A great humorous enlightening read of how it was growing up colored in a place that see's you for the pigment of your skin full of light moments that made laugh out loud to dark personal moment that show the reflection of life and what Trevor Noah went through. 
 Adore very piece of it from the dark to the light moments and everything in between. 
 4.5 out of 5 stars

By far the best memoir(?) I've ever read. Trevor Noah is an intelligent, insightful, funny, talented author who balances wisdom, sorrow, injustice, heart, and love. I don't even really know what to say, it was awesome.
Love love love this book. Born a Crime is easily in my top 3 favorites of 2016. Go for the audiobook! You will laugh. You might cry. You'll gain so much knowledge from this man's story. Enough said.

Amazing stories from Noah's life in South Africa, during and after apartheid. His mother's love and faith are constant, a balance to his many tales of mischief. A must read for those who love the Daily Show.

Read this book. Better yet, get it on audio and listen to Trevor himself read it to you. 
 Read this book again and again. Pick up and start in random places... 
 The stories...even the tough ones...are told with such human appreciation, understanding and just the right amount of humor. Trevor's childhood world is just like all of ours in a familial sense...we understand the precocious boy and the diligent tough love mother. At the same time, his world is so far removed from our own (place/culture/influence) but Trevor has pulled us in with him and made us a part of his childhood landscape. We don't feel like foreigners in his story. 
 What I really appreciated about this book is that had little to basically nothing to do with Trevor Noah popular comedian...this really was a love letter to his all mothers everywhere who do the best they have with what they have out of love for their kids.

Having recently seen him doing stand-up comedy, I picked up the audiobook of Trevor Noah's Born a Crime. Expecting more of his eloquent comedy, I got a much more complex story. Certainly it is still eloquent and funny, but the story of his childhood is shadowed by the terrible end days of apartheid in South Africa. The title is literal, being bi-racial makes his very existence a crime in the eyes of his government. Noah highlights the absurdities of life while making it clear the impact of apartheid placed a heavy burden on every strata of society. His family life resounds with love, particularly from his strong-willed mother. He reads his book himself, which adds striking nuance to his life story. His beautiful accent makes for a lovely listen but his stories will stay with you as funny, heartbreaking, horrifying and life affirming in turns. - Bethany R.

Wowza. That was excellent. A fascinating glimpse of a specific time on South Africa. Hold your sides, wipe your tears funny. Insightful commentary on language, race, relationships, government, family, violence, abuse, poverty, gender and love. Essays from this would be great supplementary texts for history and language classes, as well as TOK, I imagine.

I received an ARC of this book from NetGalley in exchange for my unbiased opinion. 
 Born a Crime is Trevor Noah's memoir of growing up in South Africa. His Xhosa mother decided she wanted a baby with his Swiss father, despite knowing that it was a crime at that time, punishable with up to 5 years in jail. Apartheid came to an end during his childhood, but he still never fully fit in with any group because there were no other mixed-race people his age. 
 This book allowed me a deeper understanding of how apartheid worked and the years after it ended. Trevor Noah's experiences growing up would have held a lesser man back, but he thrived despite or because of them. The stories are at times horrifying but are also interspersed with Noah's humor, keeping it from getting too heavy. Noah's mom sounds like an amazing woman. I highly recommend this book!

I'm not sure I had expectations, but following Trevor Noah the comedian, and because I am also mixed race (my book sited next to his on a tweet) I wanted to read Born a Crime from the first time I heard about it on some talk show. Expectations or none, I was surprised by Trevor's story, as much as I was appreciative of the historical/geographic details relating to South Africa and apartheid. From light heartedness to intense drama, the memoir played havoc with my emotions. I highly recommend Born A Crime, especially to Trevor Noah's Daily Show fans who, like me, might have no insight into who he is. But something was missing, that maybe I did expect, but I won't say because that might be considered a spoiler in an off-handed way. I'm hoping for book two. 
 *after reading other reviews I realize there was no need for me to be subtle-this memoir doesn't delve into Trevor's journey to becoming a comedian, and I hope, Trevor, you are working on writing that story.
Excellent book!

I just toured Soweto where Trevor Noah grew up in South Africa. Soweto has 50 plus townships where blacks, Indians, and colored people were displaced or forced to live during Apartheid. Nobel Peace prize winners Nelson Mandela and Bishop Desmond Tutu lived on the same block in Soweto and its face has changed over the years reflecting a growing black middle class. Trevor's raw look growing up in post-apartheid Soweto in the 1990s, whose population is over 1 million today, is riveting. 
 "Born a crime" is how he describes his birth as it was illegal for a white man and black woman to be together in the 1980s. His Swiss dad and Xhosa mom didn't marry when he was conceived, but even then his life was dangerous because of his light skin. He didn't know anyone else whose heritage was of black-and-white descent making unique situations for him and his mom. If he was with his dad, his mother had to walk on the other side of the road. Or if his mother was walking with him and the police came by she'd have to drop his hand and pretend he wasn't her child or else she would be accused of kidnapping a white person's baby. 
 The overarching theme in Trevor's book is honoring the tenacity, cleverness, and education his mother gave him growing up during a time when there were not many opportunities for South African blacks. He gives personal details interspersed with nonfiction facts that are helpful in understanding the current climate and culture in South Africa. For instance, I'm baffled as a foreigner by the crazy minibus taxi drivers that overload their vans with passengers and drive through lights, drive on sidewalks, drive on walkings paths, drive through fields, stop anywhere they want to pick up passengers, block lanes, and seem to pride themselves in their maniacal driving. In six months I've seen them almost hit a person walking as they spun out of control on the shoulder, tip a van over on its side driving too fast on a roundabout, and go over an embankment trying to pass another van, to name a few. There has been a turf war too, where drivers from two groups shot and killed each other because one group was taking what others considered their routes. Turf wars are common and Trevor describes this hell-on-wheels, gang-like transportation system that most of the population uses to get to and from work. His harrowing experience in one of these taxis and getting tossed out of it while it was moving as a nine-year-old is one of many stories that will keep you flipping the pages. 
 Trevor's experience in different schools shows the variety of learning experiences that influenced him and his gift with languages that allowed him to be liked by different groups of people, while at the same time, remain an outcast. I didn't understand when he wrote about the Bantu education system and had to look that up on my own. Basically, the 1953 Bantu education act extended Apartheid to black schools and implemented an inferior and racist education system that denied black children the same educational opportunities as white children. 
 The chapters about Trevor's abusive stepfather shooting his mother execution style and threatening others is frightening in its portrayal of the violence Trevor dealt with in his life. It's amazing that his mom survived her gunshot wounds and joked about it with Trevor in the hospital. The mix of humor and seriousness helps balance the dark spots and makes for an engrossing read. While I enjoyed the book I did think the pacing was off. The end felt rushed and too much time covered leaving me with questions. 
 Also, some parts of the plot are not always in context and the last chapter repeats a beginning part, but none of this takes away from an easy-to-read authentic tale. In the last chapter, I wasn't quite sure if the mom was engaged. And did others in the group get shot at like her fiance? It sounded like it. His brothers and his relationship with them are not always clear and Isaac's age conflicts with the age Trevor says his mom was at this time. The editing seemed sloppy in parts. But these are minor details. The excellent character development of Trevor's stepfather's dual sides of being charming and violent show a complex person. The relationship with his biological dad is heartwarming and heartbreaking. Many things are done well such as how there was no recourse for his mother with the police and how the justice system didn't serve her. Trevor's love for his mom holds the plot together giving it cohesiveness even if the context is uneven. I hope he pens another book explaining his journey to the US and breaking into national media.

Trevor Noah answered every question I had about his rise to fame and why Jon Stewart chose this young man to take over his very popular television program.........it answered these questions precisely because it didn't mention America or late-night television at all. Not even a little. No Jon Stewart name drop. Nothing. This was about Trevor's family: particularly his infinitely strong and capable mother who dedicated her life to showing her son a world of possibility despite their many struggles. 
 Sure, there is humor in this book - but really, it's the book on race, privilege, religion, etc. that our country needs. It doesn't take an empty stance on race - it drills holes in the very concept of race and stereotypes: it explores how people are victimized but also how they allow themselves to be victimized. It shows racism in many forms - and Trevor is the perfect narrator - because he was a kid who defied easy stereotypes and easy grouping. He was a kid who could blend into almost any group but never be considered a natural member of a single one. He was a kid who found himself EVERYWHERE on the grand spectrum of power and privilege at different points of his life and in different situations. 
 I have never known even a moment of my life outside of a privileged situation. It doesn't make me a a bad person - but it DOES make me ignorant. It's a type of ignorance that I'll never really graduate from, but this book is one of the few resources I've encountered that left me just a little more enlightened about what it means to live with or without privilege. 
 I promise you - this book offers a fresh and honest perspective that our empty public media discussions of race and stereotypes deprive us of. It will both reinforce and challenge your world view....and yes, it will make you laugh. Trevor is heartfelt and honest - and I am genuinely inspired to turn back to the Daily Show and support him. I know now that Jon Stewart picked Trevor Noah because he was a man with a gift for bringing people together. I can't wait to see Trevor grow into his role and let down the barrier of humor like he does in this book. When he does, he will inspire people. (P.S. Listen to the audiobook narrated by Trevor Noah - his emotion and fluency in multiple languages will keep you connected to his story).

This is by far one of the best books I've read this year. Trevor Noah has always been one of my favorite comedians, and his touching, hilarious stories of his childhood reinforced my fangirl love for him. Thank you, Trevor, for sharing your wonderful stories. I can't wait for more!

An amazing book. I've learned so much about South African culture, as well as history, from Trevor Noah's eloquent words. This is more of an emotional reaction to a book for me, rather than an intellectual one. But it's difficult not to feel emotional about Born A Crime, especially while reading, "My Mother's Life." More later.

This book is as good as Trevor's show and stand up comedy. After reading this book you will understand how tough everyone's life is but we can all make it through. Thanks for all these well written stories. I dont know we will get more books from him in the future but this is one of the best book i read in a while.

First line: "The genius of apartheid was convincing people who were the overwhelming majority to turn on each other." 
 This book is brilliant. I couldn't tell you the last time I read a non-fiction book. In fact, you could say I'm extremely wary of them because they might be too wordy, or too boring, or too confusing, or any other number of excuses. This book was anything but that. Trevor Noah is a mastermind at retelling his life story while interweaving bits of history and humour into an otherwise bleak childhood. He writes as if he were sitting down and having a conversation with you, and I never felt overwhelmed, despite his story having absurd amounts of racism, abuse, poverty, and violence. I'm thankful he is so adept at balancing the darkness with funny anecdotes and witty remarks. 
 Despite knowing barely anything about Trevor Noah, other than he's a comedian and now hosts The Daily Show, I now have a tremendous amount of respect for the man. I'm grateful for his story and new knowledge I have about South Africa that I sadly might not have had I not read this book. His story is going to stick with me for a long time and I feel sorry for any memoirs I read after this, because this was amazing.

A thoroughly enjoyable and often funny account of life during and just after the apartheid regime in South Africa by a comedian that has taken America by storm over the last few years, especially after filling the seat on The Daily Show. How much is embellished is hard to say, but I had a sense that he was telling mostly the truth, with a comical bend. Still, we are talking about a horrific system and also life in poverty and discrimination. No doubt some readers will know next to nothing about this side of South Africa, which only strengthens the need for works that recall and explain the system to future generations, even if done with humor.
I could hear Trevor Noah's as I read this book. It was funny and thought-provoking. I also learned quite a bit about apartheid.
An eye-opening look at what childhood was like in apartheid and post-apartheid South Africa. Highly recommend.

Disclaimer: I have listened to the audiobook. It seems to me that an audiobook couldn't get better than this, and this surely relies heavily on Noah's excellent narrative power. 
 I found the book excellent for 4 main reasons. 
 The first one is that Mr. Noah keeps you longing for more, because he always gives enough away in advance for us to know that something dramatic might happen soon, without us knowing what exactly. This is a writer's classic weapon. I won't dwell on it. 
 Secondly, and more importantly, Mr. Noah has a unique way of narrating life lessons, failures and resulting wisdom. 
 Obviously, I was not the only child born to black and white parents during Apartheid. (...) Once Mandela was elected, we could finally live freely. Exiles started to return. I met my first one when I was around seventeen. He told me his story, and I was like, "Wait, what? You mean we could have left? That was an option?" Imagine being thrown out of an airplane. You hit the guornd and break all your bones, you go to the hospital and you heal and you move on and finally put the whole thing behind you - and then one day somebeody tells you about parachutes. 
 (...)Language, even more than colour, defines who you are to people. 
 Being chosen is the greatest gift you can give to another human being. 
 I don't regret anything I have ever done in life, any choice that I've made. But I am consumed with regret for the things I didn't do, the choices I didn't make, the things I didn't say. 
 People love to say "Give a man a fish, and he'll eat for a day. Teach a man to fish, 
 and he'll eat for a lifetime." What they don't say is "... and it would be nice if you gave him a fishing rod." 
 Thirdly, I found the book to be a historic treasure, because it helped me like nothing else to understand the different layers of society, religion and race that the Apartheid consisted of. 
 Soweto was designed to be bombed--that's how forward-thinking the architects of apartheid were. The township was a city unto itself, with a population of nearly one million. There were only two roads in and out. That was so the military could lock us in, quell any rebellion. 
 The whole issue of Santa Claus is a rather contentious one when it comes to African Christmas. A matter of pride. When an African dad buys his kid a present, the last thing he is gonna do is give some fat white man credit for it. 
 This people had been so fucked by their own construct of race, that they could not see 
 that the white person that they were looking for, was sitting right in front of them. 
 Finally, there is a treasure of amusing expressions and sentences in this book. 
 It was like Game of Thrones with poor people. 
 The Bible was not written in English, but the Bible came to South Africa in English, so to us, it's in English. Which made my prayers the best prayers. Because English prayers get answered first. How do we know this? Look at white people." 
 In the car, he insisted on driving me as if he was my chauffeur. "Master must always sit in the back seats." I never challenged him on it. What was I going to say? "I believe your perception of race is flawed grandfather."? No. I was five. I sat in the back. 
 We didn't eat chickens, we obliterated them. Our family was an archeologist's nightmare. 
 Is that the girl? -Yes. -You can take the BMW. 
 When you make the effort to speak someone else's language, even if it's just basic phrases here and there, you are saying to them, 'I understand that you have a culture and identity that exists beyond me. I see you as a human being 
 I am not American, I haven't seen much of the Daily Show, my mothertongue isn't English. Trevor Noah is not so much of a TV personality to me, which probably enabled me to read his book as if I was reading a professional writer. 
 And I absolutely devoured it.
Easily the best memoir I've read in recent memory. Politically grounded yet entirely personal, Noah writes for posterity lest we forget the individual impact of societal injustice.
A-maz-ing. A truly fantastic read. Noah has a gift for building a story and he makes so many important connections to current events. Thoroughly enjoyed this one!

Born a Crime is a poignant memoir of growing up in apartheid South Africa with a powerful and eccentric mother and abusive stepfather. Trevor Noah is a fantastic storyteller. He also holds a magnifying glass up to the injustice of apartheid and how being born to a black mother and white father created a unique set of problems.

I really enjoyed this book, it was really eye opening to the race relations in South Africa during and after apartheid. Trevor and his mother's outlook on life is inspiring. I would definitely recommend this to other readers.

Noah's distinct voice shines through this sincere yet often humorous, rather gripping account of his time growing up in South Africa under and after apartheid. The chapter at the end about his mom's attack and recovery floored me. What a fascinating read.

This is an exceptional book of stories from the life of Trevor Noah, a mixed race child growing up in South Africa in the final years of Apartheid when it was a crime to have mixed race relations and the early post-apartheid years where Trevor continually struggled to work out which race he identified with, black or white. His mother as was an inspiration and Trevor is now a well known comedian and his comedic skills and attitude are evident in the way he tells his stories. Excellent read.

"People love to say, "Give a man a fish, and he'll eat for a day. Teach a man to fish, and he'll eat for a lifetime." What they don't say is, "And it would be nice if you gave him a fishing rod." That's the part of the analogy that's missing. Working with Andrew was the first time in my life I realized you need someone from the privileged world to come to you and say, "Okay, here's what you need, and here's how it works." Talent alone would have gotten me nowhere without Andrew giving me the CD writer. People say, "Oh, that's a handout." No, I still have to work to profit by it. But I don't stand a chance without it.

This book is beautifully written and well paced. It has a few stories that will certainly be repeated in conversation, in fact, I've already read one over the phone to a friend who lives interstate. The ups and downs of this narrative are so compelling that it feels as if I really KNOW Trevor. It isn't the "report card" that some autobiographical works can be, rather, this is an open, informative experience. I laughed, held my breath and, of course, sang "Go Hit-ler! Go Hit-ler! Go Hit-ler! Go Hit-ler!" My neighbours probably think I'm a Nazi now. (Come to think of it, the Muslim lady DID move out all of a sudden yesterday... hmmm... uh, whoops?) A mixture of fun and fable. This is definitely a solid 5 outta 5!!

Born a Crime is a relatable book, both by the lower and middle class people. As Trevor narrates about apartheid in South Africa, you see a dystopian society only found in George Orwell's 1984 (that's how I was able to understand how bad apartheid was). The lessons in Born a Crime are invaluable for the ghetto dweller to the snobbish ones, life on the streets and in the country, rich and poor ... it is the first autobiography I have finished reading. I loved Trevor's mother, and I wonder where she is now, and if poetic justice caught up with Abel. It is a great book with strong message, except for a few typos and poor form.

I was impressed with Trevor Noah the first time I saw him on The Daily Show. He had tough shoes to fill with Jon Stewart leaving, and he filled them well. After listening to his book, I'm even more impressed. He can now add accomplished writer to his resume. 
 The book chronicles Noah's often difficult childhood in South Africa. It's both shocking and entertaining. If you're able, I'd suggest listening to the audiobook. Noah is a gifted storyteller and narrator and can pull off nearly any accent. 
 I never wanted the book to end--had me hanging on every word. I hope Noah does a follow-up that talks about how he ended up on The Daily Show. 
 Highly recommended.

I wish I could give this audiobook more than 5 stars. What a life Noah has lived, and there is so much of his story still to be written because he is so young. Despite his brilliant, fresh talent as a comedian and writer, this memoir makes me feel hopeful that his is a long-burning, slow-growing flame of a life rather than a meteoric, short burst. He seems so grounded, tough, and loving, just like his mother who plays such a big part in this book and his life. The persona conveyed in this account of his life so far makes me feel he will be gracing us with his bright gifts and large heart for many years. Can't wait.
4.5 stars

i truly loved this book. Trevor Noah is relatively unknown here in the U.S. prior to his Daywalker documentary and his new role as host to The Daily Show that he took over for John Stewart, but he has quickly become a voice from South Africa that i truly admire. 
 His book is a collection of interesting stories that almost work as parables to lessons he learned in his life. He was born in South Africa to a Black woman and White man during the Apartheid when it was illegal for the races to mix, hence he was proof of their 'indiscretion'. Which gives him the title for his book "Born a Crime" his very existence was a crime. 
 His book contains stories of naughty child who had a strong wise mother and family who often did not know how to contain this child they often had to hide from the public in fear that he might be taken away or his mother prosecuted for her "crime". 
 there are stories full of laughter as well as some that are truly heartbreaking and give a darker glimpse into daily life struggling with poverty, finding an identity and abuse. 
 You will walk away having cried, laughed and hopefully a bit wiser. You start the book thinking that Trevor will be the hero of his own story, but by the end you realize that Trevor's Mother is the strong heroine of his life, she instills wisdom, patience and tough love that makes you wish for such a parent. 
 Trevor himself has called this a Love letter to his mother, and i couldn't agree more. They were a team and Trevor is a product of that love they shared. 
 A great book, a quick read, and a I will gladly recommend to others.
Wow what an ending
I am still taking it all in...
Incredible book written by my 4ever crush. Really allows you to get a little glimpse of what it's like growing up as a colored person in South Africa with all it's complexities.

3.5 stars. A year or so ago when Jon Stewart named Trevor Noah as his successor on The Daily Show, I said "who????" But whoa, what a life he's already lead! Mostly stories from his childhood in South Africa during apartheid. Many funny, and some heartbreaking, stories. I listened to the audiobook read by Trevor. I'd recommend to do that if you can.

On the page, Trevor Noah's words have a staccato quality, but I heard his voice as I read and was captivated by his storytelling. His wandering among the three worlds of South Africa's apartheid--White, Black, Coloured--was an eye opener. His gutsy, determined mother was the right role model for a child born of the "crime" between a black woman and the white man she chose to bear her son. Noah would not have been an easy child for his mother to rear, but his cockiness and mischief built the ladder he climbed to a life no one could have predicted when he was young. 
 While I thoroughly enjoyed reading the book, I would like to go back and listen to the audio version. Noah has an impeccable sense of timing and nuance. Both would likely come through even better in the version he recorded. 
 An important book to fill in gaps of outsiders' knowledge of life under apartheid.
Trevor Noah has an amazing life story. Highly recommend this to one an all.
Trevor Noah is really funny and an excellent storyteller. What an interesting childhood. He does a great job explaining apartheid and race relations.

Absolutely engrossing, riveting and compelling. Trevor Noah has nothing but my respect for having told his story and making the readers/listeners understand the world he grew up in. I highly suggest this on audio as Trevor is so engaging as the narrator.
Trevor has had a really interesting childhood! South Africa is a complex country and being of mixed race made it all the more interesting for him.

In what is essentially an early years autobiography, Trevor Noah examines life in South Africa and how things changed (and stayed the same) after the release of Nelson Mandela and the end of apartheid. 
 Noah's style of writing is really friendly. He tackles all sorts of issues whilst telling the story of how he grew up and he does it in a relatable, funny way. 
 There are a couple of places where he jumps around his timeline and it takes a minute to realise you've gone backwards and a couple where he relates something that has already been mentioned, but that didn't detract from my enjoyment. 
 I devoured this book and would definitely recommend it.
This was a great surprise - what a wonderful combination of humor and the stark realities of life under apartheid and its aftermath. Absolutely listen to it on audio - Noah's delivery is perfection.
Strong mothers, devoted son. loved!

I love him on The Daily Show. I love his very clever stand-up. I love this book! It felt like an education in apartheid and growing up during that time in South Africa. So many things were facepalming, especially the part about him actually being born A Crime, how they separated black from white from colored (that is what he is considered) and the things they just accepted because that's all they knew. Even if you don't know Trevor Noah, this is an excellent book.
Read this book! Actually you should listen to it because he narrates it himself And does a fantastic job. You won't be sorry you read it!

Hysterically funny. Incredibly wise. I used to think Jon Stewart would be my next husband, but now I am torn.... I learned a lot about apartheid in South Africa. He made me think about language and culture and fitting in. He shared observations about crime and human nature, about imperfect people living in an imperfect world. He made my jaw drop. He made me almost pee my pants. Trevor Noah managed to educate me, make me think AND make me laugh (so hard I cried). Doesn't get much better than that.

Trevor Noah faced an almost impossible task - take over the host position on the Daily Show from Jon Stewart. He's actually done an incredible job, if you ask me. He has a dry humor but a knowledge of American culture and politics that, while not as extensive as Stewart, is deep indeed. 
 This is Noah's story about his life in South Africa. Some parts are extremely funny while many are just plain sad. It's amazing that he made it out of there as is a normal human being - albeit funny as all get out. 
 For that he owes his mother. She was an independent black who bucked the system just enough to succeed. She decided she wanted a child by the Swiss man she had been seeing but wouldn't marry. He eventually agreed and was part of Noah's life until his mother's marriage to a jealous man kept them from visiting his father. But his father never really lost touch. When Noah looks him up as a grownup, he discovers his father has kept a scrapbook of any public mention of Noah. 
 Because his mother wanted him to be a success and have a chance to get out of the stilted system in South Africa, she made Noah learn English as his first language. He also picked up hers, his step-father's and several other of the more common South African languages, including Afrikaans, the language of the Dutch exploiters who created the apartheid system. 
 Noah grew up partly under apartheid. He knew the strict color code and was an outcast according to it. There were categories for white, black, colored and Indian, but none for mixed. (Colored meant that somewhere along the line blacks and whites had mixed but the offspring had married other mixed so the lineage was not strictly white-and-black.) Because of that he learned to blend in wherever he could. He was light enough to almost pass as white, and in situations where identifying with the whites was the best choice, he chose them. He wasn't entirely white, so when the situation was right, he identified with the blacks. Identifying with the coloreds was hard because they were very violent and Noah was not, so keeping up the pretense of being colored was hard. 
 He was also a nerdy kid, very smart and a bit chunky with extreme acne as a teenager, so he again didn't really fit in anywhere. At one of his schools he became a "runner" - he was so quick that he was always the first in line at the small shop that sold the students their lunches. So he took orders from five people each day, for a cut of course. He also developed a sense of humor to deflect any difficulties he ran into. 
 In fact, he was so fast that he could beat any other runner in his schools. Again, his mother was responsible for this. When he did something wrong, if he could, Noah would take off running and Mom would come chasing after. Not like most Moms, where they give up after a little while. SHE was very fast too. In fact, Noah and his mother won all the running contests at school functions. 
 Perhaps the most stunning example of the split between the whites and everyone else came in an episode where Noah and his friends were asked to perform their song and dance at an all-cultures event at a Jewish school. Noah had built up an incredible collection of music from illegal downloads which he then burned onto CDs and sold. Because that collection was on his computer, he could serve as a hip-hop DJ without having to have vinyl. 
 The group had one dancer that was the favorite everywhere they played. They had become accustomed to yelling out his name and saying "Go, go" and encouraging him while he danced solo. Unfortunately his name was......wait for it........Hitler. Really. Truly. 
 In South Africa at the time, blacks and colored were turning away from traditional names and looking for English names. Because they were never taught history in school - if they went to school - they had to get their world news from what went around. During WWII, they only knew that Hitler and Mussolini were men who fought against the English, who, of course, were part of the oppressors of the natives. They had no idea of these men's politics or beliefs. 
 So here is Noah and his group shouting, "Go, Hitler! Yay, Hitler!" in a Jewish school. Neither side understood why the other was upset. 
 This is more a memoir book than an autobiography. It doesn't give Noah's life in start to finish order. It's more a collection of events and people who made him who he is now. Noah is a great comic and it turns out, he's a great writer too.
So glad I jumped on the hype train. This book was so wonderful!

I love Trevor Noah,case in point i have watched every stand up show at least thrice.He is the epitome of cool,class,eloquence. 
 Born a crime is brilliant on so many levels,it teaches,it entertains,it makes you think, it enrages & makes you reflect. 
 I highly recommend

This book started out great, sustained a high level of compelling thought and humor, and somehow ended even stronger than it had begun. Bravo -- I recommend this book highly! It's mostly a series of short stories so it's a book that can be picked up and put down at any time; it's very compatible with any reader's reading style. I'm really glad Noah was the audiobook reader too. Not only did his conviction lend deep credibility to the nonsense that surrounded his youth, but he could slip back-n-forth from accents and personas with ease and authenticity. I don't think any reader but the author himself could've come close to how genuine his performance was in reading these stories back to us. Fantastic work!

I never heard of Trevor Noah before this and have not seen his tv show or watched his comedy act. But I will be checking them out! I learned a lot about apartheid in South Africa from reading this book, as I was not really very well educated about it. Trevor's father was a white Swiss and his mother was African, and fraternization between the races was prohibited at the time of his birth. Therefore, he was "born a crime." His mother was a strong woman and raised him basically alone. This memoir was funny, interesting, educational, and well-written, in my opinion. It reads like a novel and I found it quite engaging and a pretty quick read. Highly recommend. It was a good book club pick!

3.5 
 This biographical account of Trevor Noah's childhood was both lighthearted and amusing and informative and critical. Detailing his life growing up in South Africa with a single mother, this book is full of fun stories and fond memories but also deals with the racism and discrimination he faced and details how he and his mother had to break many laws that told them what they could and couldn't do in their attempts to live good lives. Born a racially mixed baby, his very existence was illegal. Keeping his identity secret was of the utmost importance to his family. He certainly made it difficult though, as he couldn't seem to stop causing trouble. 
 I thoroughly enjoyed this read. Trevor's personality really shines through and his trademark cynicism and sarcasm is hilariously present despite the eloquence of the writing. The last book on my BHM reading list for this year, I feel I really made a good choice. The writing wasn't overly formal, but it was informative about the politics of South Africa and the laws of segregation. A quick and fun but conversely heavy read.

oh this book... This book is so important. 
 This was such a powerful read! I think it was my favorite read of the year. Trevor is great at storytelling and also talking about heavy subjects, while not being depressing. This book is a must read! It deals with race issues and culture differences in such a upfront, yet enlightened way. I recommend this book to everyone. 
 Side note: my husband got me started at watching Trevor Noah's stand up comedy and I remember saying "this guys needs to write a book!" I appreciate Trevor as a comedian and public figure, but I always thought the stories, from his childhood, he told in his comedy routines were too heavy to be laughable. I felt guilty when I laughed, the things he makes jokes about shouldn't be funny. 
 In this book, Trevor tells stories of his childhood in a lighthearted, but not hilarious, way. Which I find is much more fitting.
WOWOWOWOWOWOWOWOWOWOWOW.

This was a great book and everyone should read it. While it deals with horrible themes and events (racism, both personal and institutionalized, and oppression, as well as domestic violence and living during and after the fall of Apartide), Trevor Noah writes with such humanity and humor that you are educated and entertained.

As much as I enjoyed reading Trevor's childhood stories, and learned about a country's struggle with racial relations, I had to fight to the finish. Noah's book is not in chronological order, and it's hard to remember where he is in life at the time of each story. (Does he have both brothers? Which school is he at? Has he started his CD business?) I couldn't give you an actual timeline of events, and I *just* finished. 
 The writing is definitely of someone who does not write for a living, which makes it raw... in the bad sense. This book felt more like a series of unedited journal entries reflecting on Noah's childhood than an autobiography. There were too many flaws for me to focus on the important themes of living in post-apartheid South Africa. 
 All that being said, the most compelling aspect is his mother's unrelenting faith. Her life, as put by her doctor, is a miracle.

A son's ode to his mother. Born A Crime has the right dose of sarcasm, satire, humour, tragedy and drama for the reader and what is better than reading this book? Having it read to you by the author himself! The book is entertaining as hell. I listened to the audible version of the book and I'm thankful that I did. If you can't find it watch a couple of his videos get his voice pinned down and read it using his voice. Trust me, it's going to do a world of difference. I've never been a fan of autobiographies but this book doesn't feel like an autobiography at all but a beautifully written novel.
Cracking read. A great insight into South African society and culture (which I knew virtually nothing about) and plenty of laughs.

Spectacular read. Despite telling some very hard stories of growing up during apartheid, Noah remains fair, honest, and endearing throughout. He handles each story with grace and humor, and provides connections to current politics and events in North America. I highly recommend this. Though it is a memoir, there is also lots of history and critical analysis.

I am not sure what I expected, but considering Trevor Noah is a comedian, I guess I expected it to have quite a few humorous moments in it. I was wrong. That being said, it does have some wry humour, but this is a very gritty, very honest account of his early years and it was an eye opener for this middle-aged white woman. 
 I loved the relationship that Trevor and his mother have, it shines through on every page, even if he doesn't always agree or approve of some decisions she has made along the way. She sounds like an amazing lady who has overcome incredible odds to give her son the best possible life. I can't even fathom a world where having a relationship with someone of another race could cause you to be jailed for years, that is just baffling to me. His mother's issues with her ex caused me to shed some tears (some problems are the same the world over and I could really relate) and I marvelled all over again what a strong and also lucky woman she was. You will have to read the book to know what I mean by that! 
 There were a couple of places in this book that were very uncomfortable reading for me, one in particular because I am an animal lover. So I would like to warn anyone who is as soft as I am, there is a graphic description of animal cruelty contained in this book (not perpetrated by Trevor Noah, I hasten to add). 
 Anyway, this was a pretty awesome book and I learned so much more about apartheid than I had any idea about, and what it is like to be born into a society where you just don't quite fit. 
 Trevor has a great admiration for his mother, but I think he is pretty incredible himself, considering where he started from. 
 Highly recommended read from me.

This might have been the longest I have taken to read a book. Because I kept rereading. Having watched Trevor Noah's stand up shows, it gets easier to connect some of the stories and even hear him talking in your head. Like the time his mom got shot and Andrew called. That was scary but funny was hell. Before I continue, for those of you who prefer audio books, there is one and Trevor does it. Around these parts, everyone loves Trevor Noah, the problem is some do not get why people like him and it almost made me stop reading the book, except I could not. 
 The history and the talk of apartheid makes it seem even more real than it normally seems. Trevor writes about his life how it all started and all that, what is missing is how he came too be where he is. Jumbled thoughts, I guess. Or maybe there is another book on the way. There are so many instances in the book that kind of reminded me of growing up myself. It sort of seems like there is a particular way in which Africans are brought up. Not just those in South Africa but around the continent. How you relate to people, how you behave, how you parents behave. And yes being beaten up is very normal with your mother telling you "I am not beating you, I am beating the mistake". 
 First non-fiction of the year in my reading list and already it is my favorite this year

Let me start by saying Trevor's mom is a phenomenal woman! 
 Born a crime tells the story of Trevor Noah's childhood born and raised during the apartheid era in South Africa. This book is a whirlwind of emotions. It will make you laugh, possibly shed a few tears and enlighten you on the horror of apartheid. It explores topics such as racism, religion, poverty and domestic violence (the last chapter will give you the chills). Thoroughly enjoyed reading Trevor's story.
The life behind the fun and sometimes serious host of the Daily Show. It was worth it just to get to know his background.

I think Trevor Noah is proof that you can't look at someone and know their life story. I know Noah from The Daily Show and that industry seems worlds away from his childhood life in South Africa. The book is the perfect mix of history lesson on the South African apartheid, social commentary on community, and hilarious anecdotes from his childhood. He has lived an incredibly interesting life, and I loved getting to hear him tell his stories through audiobook. I can't wait to read (or listen) to more from Trevor.

This failed to be in my list of memoirs (i literally refused to put it in that folder). Reason being he is too funny and unlike other serious biographies that has got a certain order of events this was one hilarious childhood book read. No wonder he is a comedian. So why born a crime? In a nation where apartheid ruled and two different colors of people could not mingle, his coming to being was illegal/ crime that saw him get bullied, hide while other children played and even get smuggled to see his father who was from Switzerland. Thank his mother's christian ways that made them attend 3 different churches every Sunday where he got to mingle with various races that challenged his thinking. 
 Growing up he had it pretty rough but he managed to maneuver by learning all languages in SA that made conversations much easier while reducing racism at the same time. Trevor's mum was a hyper woman who breached laws where possible to achieve her goals that saw her even work as a secretary in various government offices. Through it, she was able to provide a good upbringing to Noah until Abel became his stepfather and hell broke loose. (Drunk, violent, non-provider, shot Noah's mum but she survived). 
 Noah takes a reader through his childhood in an exciting way but he does not dwell onto his success as a comedian or how he even got there. All we know is that he was a good DJ who used to burn CDs and sell out to buses that saw him go out to DJ at parties, and open shop at the hood where he made it big then a radio station took him in and before we know it he was conquering all. His jokes were his way to get along with ladies as he believed he was ugly and not good enough to date but boy, did he screw up so much!
Smart , hilarious and deeply moving.

Fascinating read. Very interesting to hear about the culture, time and place he grew up. Also very interesting to hear about domestic abuse from the perspective of the child and not the wife. Valuable lesson to learn that we really can't understand the mind of an abuse victim.
So fucking amazing. Hilarious, intelligent, informative and thought-provoking, just like the man himself. Read it.
This extremely well written tale was a good read. I received an ARCf from Net Galley.
Trevor Noah is so brilliant!! I'm definitely a fan. Here's to hoping he writes another book about how he became a comedian.!

I saw this title on Netgalley and the description really drew me in. I had heard Noah reference apartheid (of which we spent less than a week on in middle school and never again) and how his family had to walk on separate sides of the street when they went out together and I was curious to learn more. I requested the book and received a copy for free in exchange for my honest review. 
 I loved this book; it's the best I've read all year. I had high expectations and it exceeded them. I want you to read this book. I want to write a review that makes you want to read this book. 
 I didn't really know much about Trevor Noah. I was disappointed that he was selected to take John Stewart's place on the Daily Show because I thought the shoes were too big to fill. However, there are moments of profundity with Noah that are awe-inspiring. He is a few months older than me and, despite our incredibly different upbringings, I really identified with him. I was always in trouble as a child and I never understood the leaps in logic my mother and grandmother took with their religion. I got into the same arguments with them as Noah did with his mom about the will of Jesus. The dialogue in this book left me giggling to myself a lot. 
 When reading this book, it feels like a lot of different stories about Noah's upbringing. However, once you finish it, you realize that it was one big meandering story. It was really hard to keep this story to myself when I was reading it (I've already purchased the book for two people) and so I would read parts I thought were particularly entertaining to my husband. I would try to pick a starting point to read but realized that I needed to start a few pages back so he would get one of the jokes but then that few pages back would need explaining from a few pages further back and so I ended up reading most of this book to him Much to his enjoyment, I must say . 
 I say this book was entertaining but please don't confuse it with a funny humor book. It was terribly funny but in a horribly depressing sort of way. The normalcy of living in a shanty town, sharing a single outhouse with multiple families, sleeping on the floor, of the systemic racism, and all the shit his mother endured is absolutely sickening. It's gross and frustrating and heart-wrenching that anyone lives this way when so many others live well to the point of wasteful. I appreciate the different perspectives and insights Noah brought to the table, particularly the one about his friend, Hitler, and how someone would even name their child Hitler. There are so many good quotes and life lessons tucked into this book. So many. 
 The ending really slaps you in the face. I was stunned. 
 The only thing I'll say against it is that there's no link between Noah's childhood and early adulthood and where he is now. He went from eking out a living hustling to being a comedian. How did that happen? I guess we'll find out in his next book. Which I will buy. For my whole family. And friends. 
 Read this book.

I expected Trevor Noah to make me laugh. I didn't expect him to teach me so much about poverty, racism, apartheid, and South Africa. This memoir was poignant, heartbreaking, and, yes, hilarious. Read it.

Trevor tells a great story. There were so many vignettes that had me laughing out loud. I love the way he shared about his mom and their relationship. The book is as much about his mom as it is about him. If you have a chance listen to it on audible. Enjoyed hearing the different voices Trevor used during the reading.

When I was at high school I loved history, and I remember sitting in history lessons listening to Sister Mary Leonard telling us about apartheid as we studied South Africa for our school certificate. I'm not sure why there wasn't any New Zealand history taught to us because there was plenty of injustice in our history, but we studied South Africa. I found it fascinating and awful. Those lessons were probably partly to blame for my political views and outrage at social injustices all my life. 
 It was only recently that I heard about this book and I decided I needed to read it immediately. I'm really glad I did. Trevor Noah had a very interesting childhood and this is a collection of his recollections of growing up in South Africa as a coloured child under and then after apartheid. It is called Born a Crime because his mother, a black woman was forbidden under apartheid to have a child with a white man, it was also illegal for his father to have a child with a black woman - basically any fraternisation between whites and blacks was forbidden, having a child who was a mix was proof that this had happened and therefore Trevor Noah was proof of a crime being committed. This book which is chock full of great yarns about what it was like to grow up coloured, unaccepted by both black and white communities and not fitting in with the world in which he was being raised. 
 I read this as an audiobook, narrated by the author and that was a great choice, his voice is great, he reads it brilliantly. Inserting accents and different voices for the various people in the stories, this could have been horrible, but it worked well. The stories in the book are at times funny, frequently shocking and downright horrifying. His was an upbringing which was full of adventure and terror. You need to read the book to find out the details. I loved the short pieces at the beginning of the chapters which gave stats and statistics and anecdotes, l thought those were completely fascinating as they told of life in South Africa. 
 This is nowhere near the usual celebrity autobiography, this is much more gripping, more serious and informative. I'm grateful to our history teacher for suggesting it.
Trevor Noah's memoir about his childhood growing up in South Africa.
It's very funny in places, very serious in others, but he's an excellent storyteller.

4.5 stars 
 I don't even know where to start!!! 
 I went into this book thinking I'd relate to so much, as I'm also coloured, but I only related to the book's setting because I know some of the suburbs mentioned. 
 There is so much to say but I want to have a virtual book club about this and don't want to spoil it all. 
 Why did the book lose the .5 star? Too much of the f word :) 
 Do I recommend it? HIGHLY! Get it - you'll enjoy it and you'll learn a lot. I'm South African and I learnt so much. But do get the audible version - it will enrich the experience 100-fold.
Great book. I love the voice and the format. The mix of historical/cultural facts with personal narrative was fantastic.

Candid, funny, horrifying, and brutally honest. 100% recommended. It's difficult to imagine how the charismatic Trevor Noah managed to overcome the unbelievable circumstances of being raised as a mixed child in post-apartheid South Africa. Stories of his hustle and ingenuity in selling pirated CDs as a child are mixed with tales of the hardship of living with an abusive stepfather, and narratives of the pure grit of the only constant in his life - his mother. Trevor's use of humor to lighten an otherwise heavy book is very well done. One of my favorite books I've read this year. 
 5/5

I like Trevor Noah on the Daily Show and so I was interested in this book, but it was so much better than I had anticipated. Trevor writes about his life growing up under the consequences of apartheid in South Africa where he faced poverty, violence, and racism. 
 He also acknowledges the privilege and advantage he had along the way such as his amazing mother, who went above and beyond to do everything she could for him, and the advantages he sometimes had thanks to being classified as coloured rather than black. 
 Trevor manages to discuss some really heavy subject matter with wisdom and humor. Just like on the Daily Show, he is great at highlighting the absurdity of a situation, making you laugh, and then following up with an insightful observation. 
 I learned an awful lot about the realities of apartheid in South Africa from reading this book and I also learned a lot about Trevor's character in how he responded and reacted to what was, at times, a very challenging childhood. Highly recommended.

I was introduced to Trevor Noah by my son - not surprising given that they are close in age and Trevor is the kind of comedian that appeals to millennials of a certain age and education. Noah is bright, with amazing insights, he is worldly (having hailed from South Africa and performed in Europe before finding his way to the US and eventually hosting the Daily Show). 
 I have long thought that Noah's stand up is hilarious. And I have watched as he grew into his role on the Daily Show. And I know that he was born in South Africa to a Black mother and white father when the very act of consensual sexual intercourse between those two people was punishable by time in prison. I knew all of that, but none of that prior knowledge prepared me for his story as brilliantly told in "Born A Crime". 
 His story is as layered and multidimensional as any story could be that is born out of the absurdity of Apartheid (apart hate as he describes it). Noah is not a child of privilege. He is not the child of parents from the intellectual classes making a political statement through their relationship. No, he is the child of an amazing woman - Patricia Nombuyiselo Noah - who refused to be defined by or held down by her circumstances. And he is the son of Robert, a white man of Swiss origin who refuses to adhere to laws that make no sense to him. But they are not rebels, so for much of Noah's early life he has to be hidden from the authorities (his very being is an affront to South African rules). 
 Trevor Noah is a master story teller. With every word I was transported to his world - to the angst and anxiety of the teenage boy trying to figure out girls and social pecking order. To the discomfort of "not fitting in" because of his parentage and skin color - not white, not black, not "colored", not Indian (basically not easily categorized no matter how much South African authorities insist that everyone should be categorized). To the child of a mother who so enthusiastically committed to her belief in Jesus that they go to three (yes three) Church services every Sunday. I loved the imagery - black church, white church, mixed church. As an African-American woman in the US I knew exactly what he meant. 
 And that was the other brilliance of this memoir - although I and my family are eight generations removed from Africa (and from West Africa at that), there was a theme that flows through the book that I could relate to . The superstitious Grandmother - yes I had one of those. The suspicion of cats - yes that was my family. The insistence that only "white" folk let dogs live in the house - yes that was my family too. The crazy way that black mothers have to raise their children, especially their sons - Patricia tells Trevor "if i don't punish you the world will punish you even worse. When I beat you, I'm trying to save you. When they beat you, they're trying to kill you." Every black mother in America could relate to those words. For us, those words transcend culture and oceans and miles. We know how it feels to raise a son in a world where he is despised. 
 Trevor Noah manages to weave a funny, heart felt story that explains South Africa and explains the peoples of Southern Africa - even throwing in lots of history - while focusing on his own individual story. Brilliantly told! He is only thirty-two and yet his life story is inspiring and entertaining to any reader of any age. 
 Ultimately this is a story about love and faith. Patricia's love for her son and her AMAZING faith. When folks talk about "faith like a mustard seed that can move mountains" they should read this book. In fact I highly recommend that all "so called born again Christians" ought to pick up this book to really understand what it means to believe. To believe so strongly that you literally are able to save your son from his own worst impulses and the world that works so hard to destroy him. 
 I am a fan! I love that Trevor Noah wrote this book and shared this part of his life with us. And I can't wait for his next edition - there is still so much to share.

Highly recommend! This memoir is a collection of humorous, poignant, and thought provoking stories from Noah's childhood in South Africa. It is also a love letter to his mother, a truly amazing character. 
 His observations and experiences of life in post apartheid South Africa are very relevant to our American experience. This would also be an informative and relatable read for high schoolers. 
 If you can, listen to the audio read by Noah. It's excellent and you get to hear all the different languages that make up parts of the stories.

I really can't recommend this book enough. 
 I only bought it because I love Trevor Noah on The Daily Show. I expected it to be similar to every other memoir I've read this year. But instead it surpassed all other non-fiction I've read and now ranks among my all time favorites. 
 Like all memoirs, I got this on audible, because I love hearing the author read their own lives in their own words at their own pace. And I heavily emphasize here, please if you are going to read this, read it through audio. His different accents, translations, and tone while reading, really should not be missed. 
 That aside, the story is amazing because of the glimpse he gives us into South Africa during and after apartheid as an outsider- never fully accepted by either the white, mixed, or black groups. The stories, the things he and his mother went through, are tragic, shocking, and yet full of humor and love. 
 I finished this book so thoroughly impressed with all Noah has accomplished and with his very intelligent well articulated observations on aspects of humanity like language and race. I laughed (very hard at some points), I cried, I jaw dropped, I yelled "what?!!!" aloud to myself randomly like a crazy person... I felt a whole spectrum of emotions, and am very thankful he decided to share his journey with all of us.
I really enjoyed this book. Noah's take on outsiderness and racism is different, clear, and felt right. And he's plenty funny.

Being South African, this was an incredible read for me. Even though we grew up in the same cities, our experiences were so different. Thank you Trevor for sharing your life story with everyone, I am a big fan!

An excellent, important, amusing book from a celebrity! It was a pleasure to read. I laughed, I cried, I learned. One of the things I learned is that Trevor Noah is exceedingly intelligent. Multi-lingual, smart about people, good business acumen, and good looking to boot. If he hadn't actually come from a background where his very existence was against the law I might be so jealous I'd hate him! Instead I love him. How could I not? Trevor Noah is the kind of celebrity who actually brings people together in a positive way. He often chooses making an important point over being funny, even in his stand up . Awesome.

I went into this thinking it would be a cute, funny memoir like many of the books out there written by comedians (Amy Schumer, Mindy Kaling, etc.). It was much more thoughtful and intelligent than that. Not only does Trevor Noah have a compelling story to tell, but he's great at telling it. (I assume he wrote this book without the help of a ghostwriter, because it's definitely in his voice.) It's not just a story about him. It's a story about an entire culture. And it's incredibly fascinating. I not only found myself doing a lot more research about Apartheid and race relations in South Africa, but I also wanted to watch him more on the Daily Show, so this book definitely did its job and then some.

A great reminder that where you're born doesn't determine your life. Trevor's life was full of obstacles along the way and he managed to do some fantastic things.This book also deepen my understanding of the end of apartheid and modern South Africa.

A must-read (or listen as I did)! Apartheid in South Africa, domestic violence, jail time, poverty, plus sweet stories of crushes and dances. I am amazed at what still goes in our world. Noah has an amazing story and he tells it well.

> audiobook. 
 as a rule of thumb, i don't rate biographies, but that's not going to stop me from recommending this to everyone.

What a fun read! His bubbly, energetic personality really comes through. I knew he was from South Africa, but I didn't realize he'd grown up in such poverty or under such an oppressive system - had thought apartheid was more or less over before he was born. Also didn't know he was into computers at all, or DJing, or that he could fix cars - or that he was such a pain in the rear growing up or was in trouble with the law in any way. Would not have guessed that he - who seems so well put-together on TV - was a typically awkward teen with bad acne and a lack of social skills around girls. Do wonder if he's for real or being overly modest on that aspect. Some crazy stories in there, especially about the mess in the dustbin and the women's reactions and about the dance party at the Jewish school.
