Sorry to hear about the alcoholic stepdad - not an unusual story, but rarely a happy one. Definitely recommend this.

This isn't a breezy celebrity memoir cashing in the resultant media exposure after taking on the Daily Show from John Stewart. This is more a loving tribute to Trevor Noah's dauntless mother who raised a coloured child in apartheid Africa. Noah is the product of his Xhosa mother and Swiss-German father - literally born a crime during a time where inter-racial relations could by punishable by 5 years in jail. 
 With a comedian's sense of timing and a gift for storytelling Noah tells us about never being able to walk with his father in public, to never hold his mother's hand outside. Of hiding indoors with his imagination. But he peppers the stories with an examination of the inevitability of crime in this environment, institutional racism and the unstoppable determination of his mother in the face of all this. 
 It ends up being a jaw-dropper of a story that stops well before Noah enters our collective consciousness as a comedian and host. Surprisingly moving and wildly compelling.

This was a very powerful book that touched base with so many important and challenging issues of our time: such as colonialism, racism, domestic violence, hate and hypocrisy... 
 The book tells us about the life in South Africa under apartheid and after.. Life Trevor Noah had as a child; not fitting in any community. Even basic human necessities like food, running water and electricity were denied of him most of the time. He didn't grow up in a loving and nurturing home with dependable parents. Danger, violence and fear were a part of his daily life. 
 Yet he tells his story with such humor and through such humanistic/existentialist perspective that one is left with awe and inspiration and deep respect for him. He is a fighter and a survivor. He is also a wonderful writer/story-teller.

Some of us are victims. Some of us are survivors. Patricia Noah made sure her son was a survivor. Trevor Noah is a child of apartheid but his mother made sure he used everything God gave him to rise above the vicious cycle in South Africa that could keep you in its grips for a lifetime. An amazing story of someone who seems to have their head on straight in spite of being raised in abject poverty, brutal racism and now in show biz.
Finished just in time to see him on stage tonight!
Best story I've read in a long, long while. Cried and laughed all the way through, often at the same time, and now I'm completely in love with Trevor's mom.

Born a Crime is a thoroughly entertaining and informative book. I've studied about apartheid before, but I still learned so much from Noah's stories about what it was like to live under apartheid. You can know the facts without really understanding how it impacts daily life, and Noah does a really nice job of conveying that. He's also a very good storyteller, and his stories are quite something.

Trevor Noah was named Jon Stewart's successor on The Daily Show. I'm fairly confident there aren't many people who don't know who Trever Noah is at this point. But I may have been the only person who didn't know what to expect when I picked up this book. What I found between its covers was raw and emotional. It was a story of a mother and son. Of abuse but never neglect. It was a story of a life removed from my own but so human I could relate. Noah grew up in South Africa in the last days of and the furor following apartheid. 
 "On February 20, 1984, my mother checked into Hillbrow Hospital for a scheduled C-section delivery. Estranged from her family, pregnant by a man she could not be seen with in public, she was alone. The doctors took her up to the delivery room, cut open her belly, and reached in and pulled out a half-white, half-black child who violated any number of laws, statutes, and regulations--I was born a crime." 
 Noah was born to a black Xhosa mother and a white Swiss father. The laws made it so Noah spent his formidable days hiding indoors. His parents, who weren't allowed to marry, couldn't even be seen together. Noah's mother looked so different than himself, as a result, she couldn't walk through the streets with him. If she did, someone might accuse her of kidnapping another person's child or having committed a crime with a white man by having mixed race child. Their lives dealt with crippling poverty, racism from all sides, and violence. But Noah's deeply religious mother never let anything bother her, or prevent her from raising a son she chose to have to be a man who could do anything he wanted. 
 "She taught me to challenge authority and question the system. The only way it backfired on her was that I constantly challenged and questioned her." 
 Trevor's stories ranged far and wide painting a picture of the path to the man we all know and respect today. One story is about going to jail for stealing, or rather not stealing, a car instead of facing the wrath of his mother and step-father. It was a story every inner child can relate to. Another about peddling CDs in which led to gigs as a DJ. One of those parties was at a Jewish school where the crowd morphed from jumping up and down to dead silence when his crew started chanting the name, Hitler. This was two worlds colliding, black and white, neither understanding why the other is offended. Noah tells the story of sitting at the police station, watching a video of himself and his best friend shoplifting, and the police want to know who the white boy is. The exposure on the black and white film left everyone blind by their own prejudice, to the fact that the boy was Noah. 
 I've learned, laughed, and cried through his book. It's an emotional journey and deals heavily with fear, love, and what both will do to push you as a human. I would have liked to read more about how he traveled from South Africa to the United States and made a name for himself becoming the man we know today on The Daily Show. I listened to the audiobook, as I do with most autobiographies because it brings something to extra to that can't be read on the page. It was brilliant.

This is Trevor Noah's story of growing up in South Africa, the son of a black woman and white European man. HIs mother Patricia is a very strong character in his life and I admired her courage.Trevor recounts his street hustling and charming ways while at the same time he was getting an education. It seems that he never felt like he belonged in any racial group in his younger years. 
 There are some very frightening incidents mentioned that happened to him and he is fortunate to be alive! I would have liked to have had at least one chapter on how he became a comedian and came to America. 
 Although his forte is really not writing, this is an entertaining and lively account of what it was like for him.

Trevor Noah writes about his experiences as a mix-raced child under Apartheid in South Africa. The stories he tells about his childhood feature his thoughts on race, being a son to a strong and independent mother and the hijinks he got into. 
 Read my Review - https://bythecoverreview.com/2017/03/...
This is a terrific memoir, covering Noah's childhood in South Africa. I also highly recommend the audiobook, which Noah narrates himself.

Did the audiobook for this one, and it was great to hear Noah's stories in his own words. I highly respect and thank him for his incite into a thousand different topics: from racism, feminism, and masculinity to nationalism, interpersonal relationships, language, and cultural value. 
 Highly recommend.

A singularly excellent journey through Trevor Noah's early life, this book is packed with dark humor, thoughtful reflection on adolescence, and a sincere family story that brings the entire narrative experience together. A great, witty read with fantastic writing. Recommended.

This is probably the best memoir I've ever read, or at least certainly in years and years. There is only one way to experience it: on audio narrated by Noah himself. I loved the moral ferocity of this book, the way it stretched and challenged and, yes, taught me almost subliminally beneath all the laughter and the deeply moving bits. But most of all, I [?] Trevor Noah's mother.

*listened to the audiobook* 
 What an honest book. I don't think I've ever read something as truthful and raw. Trevor Noah is such an incredible person and truly inspires me. This book is one of those everyone needs to read asap! Although I lived my childhood in a privileged part of the world, I connected with his story deeply. What a moving book.
Listened to the audio book, which is a must!

This was sooo good. It will make you laugh. Think. Choke up. I learned so much about things I knew so little about, important things -- South Africa, apartheid, inequality, the cycle of poverty, committing a crime versus being a criminal, the importance of language, empathy and understanding people who are different from you, patriarchy... I could go on and on. And it was so. Damn. Funny. Definitely listen to this on audio -- it was one long educational, stand up comedy. Trevor Noah is as good an ambassador to his country as Nelson Mandela is.
Loved every single moment! Listening to it now...

I received this book through the Goodreads program for free! This book was a page turner from beginning to end! His story reminded me of the saying "When life gives you lemons...you make lemonade" The author overcame so many obstacles throughout his life! Brought up with the love and guidance and faith of his mother, Trevor grew up t0 become a wonderful person even when all odds were against him!
I'm still wrapping my head around the whole thing. It's crazy, we think it's one thing when it's more complicated than that.
Everyone should read this book.

I just finished this book and was surprised by how much I loved it. Don't be deterred by Noah's lightweight Daily Show performance. This memoir made up of short essays is laced with dark humor but the content is actually quite serious. He has a lot of smart and insightful things to say about growing up during and after apartheid, and he dissects institutional racism in a way that rings all too true for our current moment in America. It's short, very well written, and if you listen to the audiobook like I did, his delivery is perfect (one of those books where the author's narration greatly enhances the content). I'll keep hoping that he brings more of his authentic worldview to his late night persona. Recommend!
I'm feeling a lot of feelings right now but I'll try and write something coherent about my thoughts on this in the morning.

Had no idea about his background and childhood before he came to be on the Daily Show. Appreciated his perspectives on a lot and felt like I could draw some parallels to the US regarding race and inequality. Listened to the audiobook which was read by him - definitely recommend.

I know apartheid existed, but had never read anything about it. I am 3 years older than Noah, so his experiences under apartheid seemed absolutely crazy. How did this system go on for so long?! There were funny parts to the book, but it was also a serious memoir with insight about a social system in which race was everything. I highly recommend this book.

As is my style, I know of Trevor Noah but I don't know anything about him. The only thing I've ever seen of is, is the time he interviewed Tomi Lahern (and killed her, rest in peace). My mom got me this book for Christmas, and I figured I'd give it a read. 
 I enjoyed the essays on South Africa, its history and culture, much more than the memoir essays. Normally, I like reading about people I don't know, but I found both young and old Trevor Noah to be annoying and unlikeable. I didn't really like Noah until the very very end of the memoir. Perhaps for his fans, he will come across funny or relatable, but I just genuinely didn't like him in his book. The prose was okay, but nothing fancy or exciting. Overall, this was just okay. 
 My biggest issue was a publishing one. The font was way too stiff for a memoir. It's a silly thing, but it severely impacted my reading experience. The font was remisiecnt of that in Another Day in the Death of America: A Chronicle of Ten Short Lives, which was perfect for a jarring, general non-fiction, but it felt too distant for a memoir. 
 Maybe pick this up if your a mega fan of Trevor Noah, but there's probably some better books on South African apartheid.
Loved this book. Trevor Noah is a great storyteller.

This was a fantastic read! I knew very little about Trevor Noah picking this title up and the book shed so much light on his upbringing and how he became the man he is today. He doesn't shy away from openly discussing major issues and weaves humour into his stories, almost like he's telling you about all the hijinx he got into as a kid with you in the room. 
 Solid 5/5

"In any society built on institutionalized racism, race-mixing doesn't merely challenge the system as unjust it reveals the system as unsustainable and incoherent. Race-mixing proves that races can mix - and in a lot of cases, want to mix. Because a mixed person embodies that rebuke to the logic of the system, race-mixing becomes a crime worse than treason." 
 There is so much to love about this collection of essays by Trevor Noah about his life growing up in South Africa. He was born during the era of apartheid with a black mother and a Swiss-German father at a time when it was illegal for blacks and whites to mix. He had tremendous strength of character in a world in which he did not have a place. He did not feel like he truly belonged with the whites, the coloreds, or the blacks. Most other children born to parents of mixed races fled the country, so the parents did not have to hide their "crime." 
 Trevor's essays shed insight and understanding to South Africa's diverse African cultural population (a country with 12 official languages), life under apartheid, and the aftermath of conditions once apartheid ended. They are full of humor, grit, love and incredible good fortune or luck. 
 Trevor was raised by his mother who was a very resourceful, independent, strong woman who devoted her life to religion and instilling strong morals into her son. She would whip him for misbehaving. They would have long dialogues over what was right and wrong, and when she felt that he could think up arguments faster than she, she agreed only to argue in writing. Letters back and forth would ensue, sometimes friendly and other times more aggressive. She very much shaped who he was, what he became, made him a strong thinker, a fast runner, and who he is today. Interestingly, he also helped to shape his mother. She parented his younger brother differently from how she parented Trevor, because of what he had taught her. 
 This book is so small, yet so expansive. It is full of wisdom, insight, depth, humility and love. To cover topics including apartheid, poverty, religion, domestic abuse, relationships, police corruption and do it all so well is an incredible feat. I highly recommend this book to everyone! 
 For discussion questions, please see: http://www.book-chatter.com/?p=920

4.5. The stories are poignant and definitely made me think. He touched on so many relevant themes of race, gender equality, economic disparity, discrimination, and coming of age (among others). 
 I actually listened to this one on audiobook, which is narrated by Trevor, which I feel enhanced the experience as it was his voice telling his own story. The inflection, the accents, the voices, and the correct pronunciation of the different languages drew me in as if I were listening to a friend tell me a story over drinks. 
 Not being familiar with Trevor and his work before, I am definitely a fan now.
Trevor Noah does a great job of revealing the complicated issues of race, poverty, and violence while telling a beautiful story of a strong mother and son relationship.

I don't tend to write reviews but for Born a Crime I feel compelled to do so. 
 I watch the Daily Show regularly and although Jon Stewart's departure was a painful one, Trevor has proved himself to be a more than worthy replacement who seems to improve within his own style of comedy, very day. Needless to say, I'm a fan. 
 That being said, being a fan of someone's comedy doesn't automatically translate as being a fan of their memoir [past experience has taught me that]. I'm pleased to say that this is an exception. I started reading this book for it's title and the premise behind it; someone can be born a crime and how I, as a mixed-raced person myself have never thought of how being born as such could be so dangerous. 
 This book is much more than that. The subject of race, racial discrimination, tensions and belonging is found all throughout but it's the various anecdotal episodes of Noah's life that reel you in. He effortlessly transitions between tragedy and humor with an extreme easy that in no way cheapens either. As much as I'd love to discuss them all here, I'll leave it to you to read and laugh and gasp at the various chapters. 
 I would, however, like to comment on one thing: Patricia Nombuyiselo Noah. This woman, Trevor's mother, is an amazing person. A powerhouse, an independent, forward thinking woman in a culture and time in which that was not encouraged let alone done. She was an extremely devout woman who did not that take any shit and was full of amazing, insight. Many on my favorite passages in the book are from her, excerpts of her advice, her wisdom which she was always ready to offer to everyone who was in need. She is the type of woman, the type of mother I can only hope to become. 
 This is not just a funny book written by a funny man; Trevor Noah captivates you with every single aspect of this book, telling sad, tragic and heart-warming stories with amazing genuineness, humor and awareness.
What a fantastic, moving read. Everyone should read this memoir.

I really enjoyed this novel as it was eye opening and informative. I enjoyed really getting a sense of the different perspectives that make up so many world views in society, in different cultures, and indifferent time periods. Plus, he's one of my favourite comedians and it was enjoyable to "get to know him" on a more personal manner. I'm hoping he'll write another one to continue his story.
Such an enjoyable and eye-opening read. Made me fall in love with Trevor Noah even more
So fantastic!! Highly recommend audiobook - he does an amazing performance. Laughed and cried.
Trevor Noah is both insightful and amusing in this memoir about his South African childhood. 4.5 stars. Excellently read by Trevor Noah himself.

Born a Crime by Trevor Noah is a collection of essays. In each essay, Trevor narrates stories about his life and focuses on a particular memory or event against a backdrop of South Africa's history. The main theme of this book is apartheid and life as a biracial child during this dark period. As Trevor explains, interracial relationships were punishable by law although the whites were freed with a warning while the blacks got imprisoned. He talks about spending his childhood behind closed doors because his family was afraid that the government would take him away and arrest his mother. He also talks of how apartheid separated him from his father. These narrations are emotional and I found myself angered by the injustices that the black people in South Africa went through for so many years. Racism is illogical and ugly and I never knew just how bad it was in SA before reading this book. It is crazy to think that I was born in the same year as Trevor, grew up in Africa like he did but under totally different circumstances. Growing up, I didn't know much about apartheid apart from little bits of information through history lessons and movies like Sarafina. I was 10 years old when apartheid ended. 
 Trevor narrates his story the same way that he presents his standup comedies; mixing reality with humor. I found myself laughing through the chapters and sometimes wondering if I really should be laughing. I mean they are serious issues but Trevor just has his own way of narrating things so that they are serious and funny at the same time. 
 The story takes us through his experiences during apartheid. He also shares his experience with domestic violence. At the same time, this is a story of a man determined to get through a tough life and succeed in a world in which he was never supposed to exist. The stories about his childhood escapades were hilarious. As a self-confessed naughty kid with a funny mom, he had so many hilarious adventures. I also like how Trevor mixed historical background and personal stories to create better understanding of events which is great especially for those living outside South Africa. 
 The final chapter in Born a Crime by Trevor Noah was tough to read. I have heard him speak about his mother getting shot before. If you have watched his standup comedies in SA, then you may have seen that bit about his brother calling him to tell him that their mum had been shot. However, I never knew the circumstances that led to that call. It was heartbreaking to see what his mother went through. It is even worse to think that the same thing still happens especially here. Women get battered while everyone looks away. Sometimes from the outside, it feels hopeless because what can you really do? You can't stop the fights and you can't also call the cops because they will do nothing about it. It was a sad reality. That is the thing about this memoir; his story is my story and everyone else's story. It may not be exactly the same but it is something that everyone knows about and may have experienced at some point in life. 
 Born a Crime by Trevor Noah is a book that I highly recommend to everyone. I am not just saying this because I like the guy and think that he is brilliant and funny (just mentioning it in case it is not yet obvious). However, this is a book about family, a mother-son relationship, friendship, racism and a person's ability to overcome all hurdles in life. It is also a coming of age story. I am so proud of Trevor for all that he has achieved in life. He is an inspiration to all the people who have ever faced any adversity and felt like they don't belong. I think this is an inspiring story for our continent too. I mean watching Trevor touring the world and now hosting the Daily show, overcoming so much to get there....wow! This is an inspiring memoir that will make you laugh and cry through the chapters (sometimes at the same time). If you are looking for a diverse read then you should definitely pick this one. If you want to understand more about South Africa and Apartheid (from an insider's view point), this is the book for you. Seriously though, just get the memoir. It is a wonderful!
Amazing read. Informative, funny and well-written.

Harrowing, but also humorous stories of life growing up in South Africa at the time of apartheid and just after Nelson Mandela's release from imprisonment. Trevor Noah was born a crime as his mother was black and father white and struggled to find his place in either community. 
 One review said the writing was sharp-edged and it is, nothing is sacred, life is shared in the good moments and the bad. 
 This meets two criteria on the Pop Sugar Challenge 2017 
 1. A book by a person of color. 
 2. A book recommended by a Librarian

I love you a million times more now, Trevor Noah. Through his captivating recount of growing up in South Africa, we gain insight not only into Trevor's story, but the social structures and issues that impact life in a post-Apartheid society. I recommend the audio, read by Trevor himself.

** spoiler alert ** 
 This is the first book that touched me so much that I felt the need to leave a comment. This book is funny. It is insightful. It gives you a look into both a culture and a history that many around the world will never know or understand. 
 It also gives you a view into the author's personal life. His struggles with identity but also his conflicted feelings about the abuse he dealt with. 
 I too was abused as a child by my stepfather, and while my mom is thankfully still alive, I struggled a lot with the same feelings that Noah so artfully puts into words. I was not expecting this book to hit so close to home for me, but it really moved me. It made me feel such a range of different emotions throughout. I am just so thankful i decided to pick it up. 
 I love that Noah blends in the african languages so seamlessly. It really adds to the experience and you start to really feel like you understand after a while. It opened my curiosity into the languages of South Africa and now I want to learn more! 
 I hope that you will give this book a chance, I think it is one that everyone should read! Its just all around great!
I have so much more respect for Trevor Noah right now. what a hopeful story that I needed right now.
Really interesting insight into Trevor's life and life in South Africa in general.

** spoiler alert ** 
 I initially began this book reading it myself but then the Audible format was reasonable and features Trevor Noah reading it himself. This made the book all that much better. While he does a bit of rambling historically in time, he weaves a story of his upbringing that is a fascinating view of Apartheid, poverty, race in general and the importance of education to pull yourself out of an oppressive environment when the opportunity is available. 
 He also shares a moving part of his life when telling about the domestic violence that his mother suffered at the hands of his step-father and how that affected he and his siblings. 
 This was a truly moving and insightful look at where someone can start in life and know where they are now. Terrific book.

I didn't know much about Trevor Noah, but I thoroughly enjoyed reading this book about his life in South Africa. Trevor was a boy who didn't seem to fit in anywhere. As he grows up, he strives to figure out where he fits in and how to live a life he is happy with. It's wonderful when I can recommend a book to students and staff that can truly be inspiring; that is what this book could definitely be. Highly recommended!

I would really give this about 3 1/2 stars, but I'm rounding up. Overall, I loved this series of short snippets from Noah's life in South Africa; it was interesting, and brought more insight into who he is, and how societies run. It gave more of an idea as to how our past shapes who we've become in sometimes hidden, unexpected ways. Noah's humor also shines throughout this book, adding some levity to some rather brutal scenes. But, non-fiction is just not really "my thing"; I would've preferred if he wrote this more as a memoir that had a plot with a prose-like story, but that's just my taste.

Whoa. Need some time to process. 
 Not tearing up on the bus, though. Nope.
Both his story and his inferences about life are remarkable. I literally laughed and cried.

VERDICT: If you know nothing about South Africa, I highly recommend this book. An easy read, with lots of humor, but that goes right to the heart of things, with amazing concrete examples of a feisty mother and how she raised her children. 
 see here my lasthttps://wordsandpeace.com/2017/02/28/... post with Q & A and links to comments on earlier parts of the book:

Loved this book although it ended on a tragic note. Please read or listen. I am glad I had the book on tape. I listened to the story in his own voice and that of all the characters. Trevor is a fantastic accent mimic.

A few tales stitching the South African comedians life together. He took what was actually a sad heartbreaking childhood marred by abuse, racism and many other hurdles but as a great story telling her gives enough comic relief that makes it an hilarious and inspirational tale . Please note the profanity can be off-putting though but otherwise its a five star highly recommended , totally must read for all. I felt sad at times but most often , the book was insightful and had me in stitches .
Great read. Shows the appalling cruelty of living under the restrictive apartheid regime. Amazing life story so far.

It isn't often I can find a really well-written celebrity memoir. This one is exceptional. Noah has intriguing stories about growing up as a child of a white father and black mother (a crime) in South Africa under apartheid. A government system designed to put white people in control and divide people of color and with different languages into various opposing groups giving them different levels of privileges in order to control them, Noah shares plenty of interesting stores and he keeps his focus on the slice of life under apartheid. He never really knew his real father, his mother was fiercely independent and as a kid, Trevor was always on the move, always into something, often something daring or illegal. I loved the story of his dog Fufi, the stories about HItlar dancing, his pirated CD business, and even getting arrested. The funny stories make this book a real standout.
5/5 book. By far one of the best memoirs I've read.

Noah relates the story of his upbringing in South Africa under Apartheid without self-pity or bitterness. His mother and father are clearly very dear to him and he tells a little of their stories as well as his own. Highly recommend the audio version which he narrates.
This started off a little boring but then I couldn't get enough. Very funny but also very eye opening. He's had a fascinating childhood and he introduces us to his mother who is just fantastic.

I thoroughly enjoyed Trevor Noah's, Born a Crime. It tells his fascinating story of growing up as "colored" (legal term used in S. Africa for a bi-racial person) in the final stages of Apartheid in South Africa. His stories are tragic, funny, interesting, and enlightening. I finished the book with much more respect for him and the strength that he had/has to arrive to where he is now. One critique is that he represent a sometimes very skewed version of Christianity and what the Bible teaches and passes it off as if that is Christianity. Another is a strange habit where he would finish up a story in one chapter then start another tiny story as almost an appendix to finish the chapter. This second story didn't relate to the first. It was just a little strange. I would recommend this book with the caution that it contains a fair amount of language and adult content.

I listened to the audio book. As expected, Trevor Noah's narration is awesome !!! The first half of the book is OK. It covers his childhood. The book really comes into its own in the second half once Noah starts talking about his teenage years, his friends and his relationship with his step father. Overall a good listen. I strongly recommend going with the audio book.

A fantastic window into race and culture in South Africa (pre- and post-apartheid) by a funny, insightful storyteller. Trevor Noah manages to convey even some of the harrowing experiences in his childhood with a saving grace of humor. It's a great choice for high school-age teenagers, too. Telling his own stories of growing up, Noah makes history and politics in South Africa human and accessible. His stories of his mother alone will have teens ROFL. This is not a book of cheap laughs, though. It's a serious book that often uses humor to tell its story. Get the audiobook, read by Noah, to get the full impact.
Great read. Compelling and insightful. Enlightened me about the nuances of apartheid and its long-lasting repercussions.

Listened to this on Audiobook. 
 Loved it. Loved learning about his childhood, his family, his mom, and just the general aspect of growing up in South Africa. 
 I loved listening to him narrate it. The voices he used for his mom and friends, just cracked me up! 
 Trevor really seems to have processed and analyzed his life, especially for someone young. It was powerful to listen to his insight.
Aghhhh I love this man! His writing is amazing and his story is amazing. I feel like I've learned so much. HIGHLY RECOMMEND!

Not only was this story incredibly educational and memorable, but also highly entertaining and heartfelt. For the audiobook--As a stand-up comedian and host of the Daily Show, his comedic timing is flawless and I think that really contributed to my enjoyment.
What a story.

I would have liked to have known how Noah finally got into comedy and away from the life he had been living; however, I felt he was being honest about his childhood and young adulthood. This book gave me a much deeper insight into South African apartheid than I had had previously. While I knew apartheid was cruel and ugly, Noah provides examples of the lingering effects after apartheid officially ended. Until I read Noah's book , I didn't understand the definition of the "Colored" group within South African society. I had thought biracial individuals were classified as Colored, but I learned that was not the case.

When Jon Stewart left The Daily Show I was bereft. I did so love his witty, honest commentary and I had never heard of this 'Trevor Noah' guy who would replace him. But I needn't have worried. Noah quickly became one of my favourite 'tell-it-like-it-is' comedic commentators on current events and I wanted to know more about him. 
 In his book, through a series of vignettes, Noah shows his readers what life was like for him as a bi-racial child, who never felt like he really fit in, during post-Apartheid South Africa. He shares funny, loving, awkward and negative aspects of his childhood and many of his descriptions of the harsh realities of living in South Africa at that time will hit you like a punch in the gut. He was a self-proclaimed sh*t disturber as a child and teenager and some of his antics made me want to yell "What the heck were you thinking?!?" He definitely liked to stir things up. 
 "The names of the kids with detention were announced at every assembly, and I was always one of them. Always. Every single day. It was a running joke. The prefect would say, 'Detentions for today...' and I would stand up automatically. It was like the Oscars and I was Meryl Streep." 
 I respect his brutal honesty and I love, love, LOVED the special, yet often complicated, bond he had with his mother -- the ultra-religious, determined, fierce, rebellious woman who wanted so much more for her son. Though a few of her parenting methods may surprise some, her deep love for her son is indisputable. 
 She'd say things to me like, "It's you and me against the world." I understood even from an early age that we weren't just mother and son. We were a team." 
 Growing up I learned about Apartheid in school but I know I only got the bare gist of it. In stark contrast, Noah brings a human side to the economic and social aspects of segregation, hatred and the blatant violation of human rights and basic decency that one group withheld from so many others. 
 "Language brings with it an identity and a culture, or at least the perception of it. A shared language says 'We're the same.' A language barrier says 'We're different.' The architects of 
 apartheid understood this. Part of the effort to divide black people was to make sure we were separated not just physically but by language as well...The great thing about language is that you can just as easily use it to do the opposite: convince people that they are the same. Racism teaches us that we are different because of the color of our skin. But because racism is stupid, it's easily tricked." 
 "People love to say, "Give a man a fish, and he'll eat for a day. Teach a man to fish, and he'll eat for a lifetime." What they don't say is, "And it would be nice if you gave him a fishing rod." That's the part of the analogy that's missing." 
 This book is filled with wonderfully quotable tidbits (far too many to list here). The only thing I regret about this book is that I couldn't get my hands on a copy of the audiobook. Having Noah read the book to me would have been the icing on the proverbial cake. 
 Before reading this book, I was already a fan of Trevor Noah. I enjoyed his honest yet humourous approach to current events (and his dimples didn't hurt either). He's obviously a well-informed and funny guy but, after reading this book, I have a better understanding of where he comes from. Trevor Noah will make you laugh, cry and give you much to think about. The hype surrounding this book is duly given. I highly recommend this book.

I'm sure I would have loved the story itself if I had read it, but I listened to the audiobook with the author reading it himself, and that made this book amazing! His stories are hilarious, but hearing it from his own voice made it feel like he was just chatting about his childhood while we were sitting with some beers.

"Being chosen is the greatest gift you can give another human being." [Trevor Noah BORN A CRIME] 
 Wow. What amazing stories, and a life you've had so far. 
 And your mother - what an incredible woman. 
 Strong women could change the world if we empowered them. 
 Thanks for the laughs, the cries, and sharing your story. 
 Really enjoyed this all the way through Mr. Noah :) Thank you! 
 Would recommend to anyone.

This book was so good. Noah is such a charismatic, funny, heartfelt storyteller. I loved so much about this book, but especially the relationship between him and his mother. It was so real and full of love, which meant that there was also plenty of conflict along the way. 
 I knew very little about South Africa and the apartheid before reading this book, and learned so much from reading it. Noah painted such a picture, one that was hard for me to wrap my head around, of the world he lived and grew up in. 
 I think one of the most interesting things about life in South Africa was the way he talked about race, which was obviously a very significant issue. It was interesting to me to hear him discuss the difference between "colored" and "mixed" people, and how they were VERY different things in South Africa. To be mixed was somehow acceptable, while being colored was proof of a crime, and had to be hidden. His discussions of having to choose between black and white were also interesting, and how even though he felt one way, the color of his skin had people assuming he belonged to another group. Those discussions of identity and inclusion were really interesting. 
 One of the other pieces of the book that really stood out to me was a section where he talks about language being more important than color. He talked about how, if someone can communicate with you, you feel like they understand you, even if your skin color isn't the same. This really got me thinking, and I totally understand that. In another part of the book he mentioned that even trying to communicate with someone in their own language sends a strong message that you WANT to understand or help them, because you're making an effort to reach them in their own language, even if you don't speak it well. There was a lot of discussion about the different languages spoken in South Africa, and the kinds of messages it sent to be able to speak various ones. 
 Another section of the book that really struck me was in a chapter where he talks about his friend Hitler, and discusses the difference between Western culture and the rest of the world, the way Western culture doesn't really often acknowledge the atrocities that didn't concern them. And yet, in South Africa, the atrocities of WWII were significant, but not covered in schools the way they are in Western schools, because that part of the world is so far removed from them. He talks about some of the horrific massacres of black people that have occurred, that so few people know about because no one bothered to track how many black lives were lost. He said at one point "Holocaust victims count because Hitler counted them." No one bothered to count the blacks massacred because it didn't matter to them. That really struck me, and made me so sad. 
 I absolutely adored Noah's mother. She is a hurricane of a woman, and it was amazing to me how she persevered through so much adversity to live the life she wanted to live, and give her children good lives. 
 I really loved everything about this book. It expanded my worldview, and though there were plenty of times it shocked me or made me sad, it also highlighted the power of compassion, perseverance, and love.
This was a great book. He certainly had a rough childhood but had a great mom. I laughed out loud several times. Great writing style that keep me entertained yet I learned a lot.

An amazing story. Go and read it-or listen to hear it in Trevor's own words. 
 Funny and heartfelt and honest and frightening--everything a memoir, or any good writing, should be.

Informative, reflective and snort-into-your-tea funny. If I'd had the opportunity to teach Trevor at school he would have been my favourite student. I also fell a little bit in love with his mother, Patricia, who is the most bad-ass and wise mother ever to have lived. Definitely give this a read!

This was a really interesting read - I haven't really followed Trevor Noah in anything apart from TDS, so I was pretty much going in blind. What I loved about this was that it was written in his voice - as I was reading it, I could imagine Noah's voice narrating. He's funny, articulate - and most of all, real.

An eye-opening look into post-Apartheid South Africa, told with humor and heart. Technically this is a celebrity memoir since Trevor Noah is a celebrity on the Daily Show, but it's well-written and interesting and looks exclusively at Noah's childhood and teenagerhood, before he was really a celebrity. Born during Apartheid, Trevor was literally "born a crime" since it was a crime for a black person and a white person to be together and have a child. He speaks about race, poverty, and family troubles without ever veering into depressing (maybe because you know he eventually made it out). 
 Noah himself narrates the audio recording and he does a nice job of it. It's always nice to hear a memoirist read his own words; it feels like he's sitting down and telling the story of his life. I would recommend this for fans of memoirs or anyone curious about life in South Africa from the perspective of a "colored" (the word he uses in the book) person. I knew very little about life in South Africa and this book was definitely a window for me.

I won this book on a Goodreads Giveaway (thank you) 
 I loved this book, it was interesting because in Canadian curriculum we really didn't learn anything about apartheid. So I learned a lot of new things today! 
 It was hilarious! Which was surprising because he covered a lot of really horrible things. But OMG the shitting on the floor thing had me rolling. 
 It was also so sad. Although there is a lot of humour written into it, Trevor is making light of a really hard existence. Minimal childhood friendships and having to be the "secret child", witnessing domestic abuse and living in serious poverty. To go through this all and come out on the other side a comedian and writer... I can't imagine. You must be some kind of resilient. 
 This is an amazing read and a look into a world many people are not privy to. 
 Thank you for a fantastic read!

Trevor Noah leapt to prominence in the U.S. when he succeeded Jon Stewart as host of The Daily Show. Now, at age 32, he's published his memoir. If that seems premature, it's only because you haven't read it yet. The title of Noah's book, Born a Crime, is an indictment of the apartheid system into which the South African comedian was born. 
 More than an autobiography, Born a Crime is a child's eyewitness account of life under apartheid and the upheaval that followed when that regime ended. The book's also a tribute to Noah's feisty, outspoken mother, Patricia. A member of the Xhosa tribe, Patricia defied the law by having a relationship with white businessman Robert Noah. Once Trevor was born, the couple couldn't be seen in public as his parents. They enlisted a mixed race neighbor to pose with Robert and Trevor for "family" photos. The Black woman standing in the background of those photos, pretending to be the nanny, was Trevor's real mother. 
 Noah finds humor and pathos in this bizarre upbringing. On a more serious note, he also speaks out strongly against domestic violence. Many years after her relationship with Noah's father, Patricia married Ngisaveni Shingange. Noah recounts in chilling detail the gradual escalation of violence in the household and his mother's struggle to leave Shingange. The decision almost led to her death. His stepfather's threats against Trevor's own life were one of the reasons the comedian turned his sights to a career in America. 
 Clearly, Noah has packed a lot of living into his short life -- and this book only covers the first 25 years. Fans of books by The Daily Show alumni Stephen Colbert and Jon Stewart will enjoy reading Noah's autobiography, but it will also be of interest to anyone curious about life under apartheid. 
 Reviewed published at "Between the Covers," the Baltimore County Public Library's book review blog [http://www.bcpl.info/between-the-cove...] on December 20, 2016.
Amazing Story!!

"Born a Crime" is an enormously engaging memoir about the early years of Trevor Noah's life. Noah is the successful host of The Daily Show, the satirical American news show on Comedy Central. He was born in 1984 during apartheid in South Africa to a black Xhosa mother and a white Swiss father. His parents could have been jailed for five years for having a mixed race child, and Noah could have been sent to a state orphanage. He spent much of his childhood indoors at his grandmother's home with his cousins for playmates since it was dangerous for him to be seen outdoors. 
 Post-apartheid, Noah went to school but he felt like he did not fit in because of his mixed heritage. Noah had picked up multiple languages from his mother and other people so he used language to be accepted in school and on the street. "I became a chameleon. My color didn't change, but I could change your perception of my color. If you spoke to me in Zulu, I replied to you in Zulu. If you spoke to me in Tswana, I replied to you in Tswana. Maybe I didn't look like you, but if I spoke like you, I was you." (56) South Africa has 11 official languages so Noah's facility with languages was important. 
 Noah's mother was a secretary who tried to expose Noah to the world. She was also very religious, and Sundays were spent going to multiple churches. Money was tight, but she made sure her son went to good schools and had books to read. Even when things were hard, their senses of humor always came through. When she married Noah's stepfather, Abel, their world changed. Although Abel was a good mechanic, he was a violent person when he was drinking. Noah left their home when he finished school, and continued his business of copying and selling pirated CDs for a few years. He also worked as a DJ at dances. Eventually he went on to become an internationally known comic. 
 This book is dedicated to his mother: "For my mother. My first fan. Thank you for making me a man." Noah's stories are sad and humorous at the same time. There's a wealth of knowledge about South African people in this book. Every time I put the book down, I wanted to get back to it to read more. Highly recommended!
This book provides insight into Trevor Noah's life story and life lessons. It was well written and I enjoyed it immensely.

This was an absolutely touching but hilarious memoir. I've never really had a strong opinion of Trevor Noah, but this book has made me fall head over heals in love. How he describes the details of apartheid in South Africa are chilling and surreal. This book mainly focuses on his childhood and his special relationship with his mother. I am so grateful that I listened** to this, because his beautiful voice could serenade me forever and I would never get bored.

I have no idea how I managed to forget to rate this book. It is such an amazing and impactful read that I highly recommend to anyone. Even if you don't normally enjoy nonfiction (like myself) I would still encourage you to pick this up because through most of it I felt like I was reading a fascinating story rather than an autobiography.

Really interesting and entertaining account if Trevor Noah's early life in post-Apartheid South Africa. I learned a lot about the country and the culture that I'd never known before. Highly recommended on audio.

5 stars. I loved this so much. I frankly think that it should be required reading, because while we learn about apartheid in history classes, nothing in a textbook can compare to an actual account from someone who lived through it. But at the same time, this book felt like a love letter from Trevor to his mother and I loved that. She was an absolutely amazing woman.
I recommend the audiobook version! Trevor Noah reads it himself and you get so much more from listening to him tell his story.

I took a couple of months break from this book for no good reason and finally finished it today. I can hardly relate to Trevor's story about growing up in some pretty extreme situations, and hearing his story really took me aback. The style of writing was clear, descriptive, and light-hearted. I imagined him reading it. Excellent memoir- highly recommend.

This is a story that needed to be told and Noah told it with mastery. I also listened to this as an audio book so I got to hear his voice, which made it doubly entertaining. 
 I recommend this book to anyone who wants to understand what happened in South Africa, and how this affected its people. There is something very sad about a government that uses prejudice and hate as a tool to keep their people oppressed but its not uncommon and its a great way to keep people preoccupied while you take advantage of them to have more power. 
 But I digress. This is really an autobiography about someone who led a very interesting life. It's told through the eyes of his innocence. He knew no other life. He had to pretend that his father didn't exist because it was a crime to be half black and half white. They couldn't walk together as a family. 
 But that's not all. The twists and turns of Noah's life was directly related to the complex prejudices of his culture. Still, he was just a kid, trying to make his way in a harsh world. On top of this, Noah is funny. He can laugh at the irony of it all which makes it much easier to read. That doesn't change the fact that some of the things that happened in his life were very dark and could make us angry. He just made it easier to swallow. 
 This is a MUST read for anyone. I highly recommend it.
Recommend listening to the audio version of this book, since its narrated by Tevor Noah and the narration definitely adds to the story.
This is my favorite book of 2016.

Wow. This book was amazing. 
 I don't really watch Trevor Noah on the Daily Show, but this book was making its way around my friends, so I downloaded it on Audible. 
 I'm glad I did and it totally was nothing like I expected. I am woefully unfamiliar with Apartheid and the culture in South Africa and I feel like I just got a master class from Trevor Noah. It was funny, heartbreaking, and widely informational. I loved hearing the story about his mother, albeit painful at times. 
 I highly recommend this book. It was wonderful.
Excellent read, the right mix of humor, synicism and tidbits of South African culture to make it a page turner that was hard to put down. Highly recommended.

I wanted to be able to give it more stars, but the narrative jumped back and forth through time a bit too much for me. Because of this, there was some repetition that disrupted my focus and took away from the narrative. I love Trevor Noah and enjoyed hearing his stories from his childhood. I just wish the book had been better organized.
Touching, funny, heartbreaking. The story of Trevor growing up, and his remarkable mother along with the history of apartheid South Africa makes for a fascinating read.
Fantastic read/listen. I enjoyed how Trevor Noah incorporated South African history and culture with his personal stories. It was engaging and at time very funny.
I had no idea how much I would love this! Alive.

A funny, insightful, and sometimes heartbreaking account of what it was like to grow up in post-Apartheid South Africa, by one of my favorite comedians and late night hosts. I first heard Trevor Noah speak about his upbringing on NPR's Fresh Air, and the interview left left me wanting to know more. This book expanded upon the most interesting stories from that interview, and then some. I recommend listening to the audiobook to hear the emotion (and accents!) in Trevor's voice.

I read This book in one day. Trevor Noah is so much more than just a comedian. His story of his account of being a mixed race young man in South Africa and really being seen as a crime since the day he was born. His stories are wild, intriguing and I couldn't put this down!

I loved this biography of the South African comedian and host of The Daily Show, for its humor, its heart, and the many fascinating (and heartbreaking) details about what life was like in South Africa during apartheid and right after the official dissolution of that horrible system. Trevor writes with a personable style, but each story is prefaced by background information on a particular aspect of South African life that he then addresses in his personal anecdote. We learn about his Xhosa African mother and his Swiss/German father--that having "relations" with someone of another race was strictly forbidden in South Africa, hence his birth as a biracial child was literally a crime. And yet, even what race one was classified as could change on the whim of a government official! Trevor really had a difficult time as a 'colored' boy in South Africa, where he was too white to fit in with black children and too black to fit in with whites. One thing that often helped him was that he knew several languages--his mother's Xhosa, English, but also Afrikaans, and Zulu and other tribal languages--this let him fit in with any group he came in contact with and avoid getting beat up. He learned to be a bit of a chameleon in that way. His mother is an amazing woman, who raised him as a single parent for much of his childhood, in really tough circumstances--she overcame so many obstacles in her stubborn clever way. After reading this book, I would love to meet Trevor's mother, because she sounds like such a brilliant strong woman. He describes his other family members with funny and touching stories about them. His stepfather, however, is not such a good man--alcoholic, abusive, with an unpredictable temper, he makes Trevor's life much more difficult. In the book Trevor writes about his childhood--he was kind of a wild child, and became adept at outrunning his mom!-- and young adulthood, when he made a living in "the hood" bootlegging CDs and Djing parties, and hanging out with petty thieves and criminals but not really one of them. It's quite a story and very engagingly told.
Trevor Noah is a gifted storyteller.

This book is incredible. Not your typical memoir. Trevor Noah actually has something to say. His perspectives on race and class from growing up colored in South Africa turn an important mirror on the state of the US as well. Told with humor and a remarkable lack of bitterness or self pity. I highly recommend to anyone.
Best "read" by audiobook.
Wow. What a life.

Craftlingual book club pick 
 Opt for the audiobook if you want to immerse yourself in Trevor Noah's story. 
 I wouldn't have picked a memoir as a bookclub selection due to the fact that not everyone knows the author, so getting people to read the book would be a bit harder. 
 But I needn't have worried, Trevor Noah delivered a funny honest tale, that discussed everything from family relationships, race and white privilege, to police brutality. Trevor transitions from humorous to seriousness so flawlessly. 
 There were a few inconsistencies here and there, and I did not follow the school's or the neighborhood's names out of laziness, must be more interesting to people more familiar with those places 
 My mother used to tell me, "I chose to have you because I wanted something to love and something that would love me unconditionally in return--and then I gave birth to the most selfish piece of shit on earth and all it ever did was cry and eat and shit and say, 'Me, me, me, me me.' " 
 You gotta lough at that.

Trevor Noah's beautifully evocative, massively heartfelt and perpetually funny memoir puts other celebrity autobiographies to shame. To shame, I say! Filled with careful insight, tremendous love, and formidable recollections, it's the kind of book where every page astonishes. Never delving into melancholy or self-pity, Noah's pen is confident and direct, never shying from the truth or his own humility, while also paying the utmost respect and dedication to his mother, who gets as much attention throughout the book as the author does. I should have a full review soon, but this one is pretty special. I look forward to more books from Noah. It might be The Daily Show host's true calling.

The rating is actually 10 stars out of five. Whatever your interest, just go for this. 
 Absolutely mind blowing. And watch some of his stand up shows. 
 Try to go for the audiobook read by Noah himself. His voice acting is fantastic.

Intelligent, smart and just bloody excellent! 
 The ability to rise above the injustice and find humor in the face of oppression is impressive. This book made me laugh out loud in instances, transporting me back to the best aspects of my childhood. Loved it!
Trevor Noah, You just Nailed it. Amazing.

I loved Trevor Noah without knowing anything about him the first time I saw him on The Daily Show. I loved the calm, no nonsense way that he spoke truth, humbly and with so much intelligent perspective. 
 I honestly did not know he was a comedian until I looked him up but this book is so well written, just like a good comedy show is. It is full of raw storytelling but held together by clever segues and punchlines that make it obvious that he knows exactly what he's doing. 
 I was ASTOUNDED at his story. It is really amazing to me how a child with such a hard upbringing can not only rise up from his circumstance but admit his mistakes and ignorances, broaden his perceptions and manage to become someone so informed and smart all while still remaining so unpretentious. 
 I also fell in love with his mother and the way that he cherishes her and his view of women because of her.

Reading this book was truly a ride! It packs the whole spectrum of emotions within its pages. I'd laugh out loud at some pages and have my jaw dropped wide open at others. It provides such a unique perspective on racism and apartheid, and is a definitely a mind opening read!

Funny, witty, piercingly critical and tragic, this is the kind of book that can both make you laugh out loud and cry your heart out in equal measures. I loved every chapter of it. It gave me a great insight from an inner perspective of what was actually taking place in apartheid South Africa, with Noah's voice into my head as though he were making a monologue for some show.. That was a great experience!

The audiobook version of this is narrated by Trevor himself which elevated this from a 4 stars to a 5 stars. He brings a lot to the telling of the book with different accents and sometimes different languages. 
 I realized how little I know of South African culture and apartheid overall when listening to this. It was extremely funny, interesting and sad at the same time. Definitely recommend!

This book is an eye-opener and for the most part, it was pretty good. It was interesting to read about growing up in South Africa during aparthied and immediately after. 
 What I didn't like about it is the manner in which the stories are told. It's literally a group of stories. Some lacked cohesiveness and others lacked a point altogether. The book gets dull towards the end. I wasn't really that motivated to finish. 
 While I can appreciate this not being another celebrity fluff memoir, It could have been written better. I can't see myself re-reading this.

What an incredible book. It reads like fiction because of Noah's amazing life. It is an account of Noah's life before he came to America. The book is entertaining and thought-provoking. I highly recommend it to anyone: Republican or Democrat, young or old. It seems to me that this would be a great required-reading selection for middle-school students. It would provoke many interesting discussions!

Wow, what an incredible story; I had no idea Trevor Noah had such a tumultuous upbringing. I have even more respect for him now knowing how far he's come! 
 This book was well written, honest, and at times humorous. I learned so much about apartheid in South Africa and what life was like there. Trevor Noah's reflections on race and how he continuously had to choose which group to identify with were insightful. And, oh my, his mother's story was just amazing!

Trevor Noah is a magnificent storyteller. I could not put it down. He has led such a fascinating, albeit difficult, life. Even with the cursing, this story is eloquent and extremely poignant. This memoir gives a very vivid inside look into life during and after apartheid for families living in South Africa. In telling his very different story, he somehow finds a way to remain relatable. I cannot recommend this book enough. I loved it.
I laughed, I cried, I learned a ton. Read this book immediately.
It's crazy to think some of these things were happening across the world to someone my age. Well-written and very enjoyable.

Honestly, probably one of the best, most well rounded biographies that I've ever read. This book touches on so many issues from poverty and institutional racism, to domestic violence and religion, and manages to do it all in a way that will make you laugh throughout the book. This was good enough that I can see it being worked into classrooms in high school. I think younger than that and some of the material might be inappropriate but this book is truly a masterpiece of contemporary biographies and something worth reading. I'm disappointed that I haven't supported the Daily Show more in the last several years now after reading this book.

Delightful and inspiring. Trevor is a very smart individual with a talent for understanding the world he occupies, even as a young child. His mother's influence, and words of wisdom, clearly shaped him in to the empathetic thoughtful person he is today. Most people, faced with his early life, would have given up. He is an entrepreneur, a hip hop dj with a talent for charming those he meets. The chapter entitled Go Hitler had me crying with laughter. Really helps you see how western-centric most history books are.
It's an emotionally overwhelming book. His mother is an amazing person.

It's weird to think that, at one point in our history, it was illegal for a person of one race to marry a person of another race. Thankfully, our Supreme Court decided that antimiscegenation laws were stupid and racist. This was good, because if that decision hadn't been made, I may not have been born. See, I am the product of a bi-racial marriage, a marriage that might never have happened if my parents lived in one of the states in which bi-racial marriages were illegal. 
 It's weird to think that antimiscegenation laws even existed in the first place, but it's even weirder to think that law enforcement in those states actually tried to enforce them. Logistically, it makes me wonder how they could enforce them. It's thoughts like this that make me realize that the conservative argument against overreaching federal laws that restrict state's rights, in some cases, completely falls apart. 
 It's been said that morality can't be legislated, but laws that prevent racists from doing stupid, racist things like attempt to enforce antimiscegenation laws can be legislated, and they should. It may not change how a racist thinks---and, most likely, won't---but it changes how a person behaves by punishing racist behavior. 
 Of course, if you thought the U.S. had it bad, you should look at South Africa's history. 
 Stand-up comedian and host of The Daily Show, Trevor Noah, was born and raised in Johannesburg, South Africa. The country of South Africa was, inarguably, one of the countries with the most blatantly racist governments in the world. 
 Apartheid was an institutionalized attempt to segregate, dehumanize, and eradicate black people. It was nearly successful, through a propaganda campaign that pitted blacks against blacks along often arbitrary lines. Sometimes it was based on a person's tribal affiliations. Sometimes it was nothing more than one's skin color: light-skinned vs. dark-skinned blacks. 
 As Noah writes in the opening of his book "Born a Crime", "The genius of apartheid was convincing people who were the overwhelming majority to turn on each other. Apart hate, is what it was. You separate people into groups and make them hate one another so you can run them all. (p. 3)" 
 Under apartheid, it was not only illegal for blacks and whites to marry, it was a punishable offense for blacks and whites to even be seen together in public. Bi-racial public displays of affection of any kind could get one arrested. Jail time or heavy fines were doled out for simply holding hands. 
 Noah's parents bucked the system. Noah's father was a white German expatriate living in South Africa. His mother was a young black woman who belonged to the Xhosa tribe. Their brief sexual encounter resulted in Trevor, who was, quite literally, born a crime. 
 Thankfully, apartheid ended during Trevor's childhood, when Nelson Mandela came to power. Unfortunately, the country quickly became a chaotic mess after vast swaths of black people who were, essentially, being paid slave wages in enforced jobs found themselves "free", which also meant "unemployed". 
 Noah's book is a memoir, of sorts, written in a series of vignettes and essays. Some of them, like his stand-up comedy, are hilarious. That he was able to find humor at all in some of the bleakest and most depressing of situations is impressive, to say the least. 
 Some of the stories, however, paint a sad and disturbing look at the horrendous aftermath of apartheid. The effects of apartheid's destructive stronghold on the black people of South Africa are still being felt today. 
 The prevailing motif throughout the entire book is Noah's love and admiration for his mother, Patricia Nombuyiselo Noah, who single-handedly raised Noah through much of his childhood. Not an easy job, according to Noah, who admits to being extremely unruly and awful as a child. If any of his stories that he recounts about his childhood are true, then he truly was a little monster. 
 Still, despite being a single mother, she managed to keep food on the table and provide Noah and his younger siblings an education, a home, and love. 
 "Born a Crime" is an extraordinary story that is alternately funny and moving. There are parts that one can't help but laugh hysterically, and other parts where it would behoove one to have a box of tissues handy. 
 While not the best of writers---Noah writes the way he speaks, which isn't necessarily a bad thing, because he speaks like a stand-up comedian, so he has a great sense of timing and detail and knows how to build up a story toward a punchline---Noah nevertheless possesses a passion and enthusiasm for the subject matter that makes it a great read.

This book was nothing as I expected & somehow that turned out to be a very good thing. Although this is a memoir written by a comedian, it is not a comedy book. It is a deeply personal story of a mixed race boy growing up in South Africa under the rule & then dismemberment of Apartheid. It is the story of a boy witnessing domestic violence in the home & systemic violence in society. It is the story of a boy trying to find his independence & strength, sometimes with great success and sometimes with damning failure. Trevor Noah writes with underlying wit & wisdom, and his story gave me more than I would've expected.
Very knowledgeable with loads of fun writings.

3.5 stars if I could do a half a star, rounded up for benefit. 
 I don't know much about Trevor Noah besides his work as a replacement for Jon Stewart. I've never watched his show and I've never heard his comedy. 
 The book is highly recommended and I picked it up for my book club, excited for something a little different. 
 Trevor Noah narrates his own audio book and I picked that because of it's easy access. I think the audio book is the only way to listen/read this book. His voice, accents, language tells his story in a way that would be lost in written form. 
 In Born a Crime, he talks about growing up in South Africa-where being a mixed race was literally illegal. His life and misadventures fall a little flat to me-to be honest. There aren't a lot stories that stick out from the book. 
 The thing, or rather, the person that sticks out in the book is the power of his mother. The book should be called, My Mom-the Saint. His mother made him who he was and shaped him in ways that I can't understand. She inspired him with food and books-the two essentials they lived off in his early years. 
 As a mom, I take a lot of validation from his story. I worry so much about providing for my children and their happiness. I worry that I'm hard on them and push them too hard/fast. He has this wonderful quote near the end of the book that says something like, "Relationships are sustained by love. If you love someone, you want to create a better world for them." At the end of the day, isn't that what we should strive for, not just our children and families, but what about strangers? 
 Born a Crime is full of little gems, thoughtful inspirations for life. Beyond the gems, I know more about Trevor Noah and life in South Africa. 
 Definitely worth the read, at least once.
A great biography with an interesting mix of the history of Apartheid and its socioeconomic effect on a hilarious & insightful biracial comedian.

Beautiful work 
 I enjoy reading books at about cultures I'll never experienced. I'm amazed how different but similar our lives are.
thoroughly enjoyed reading this amazing story.

I greatly enjoyed reading this book. Trevor gracefully moves from difficult topics and racial tensions with humor and ease never overlooking the emotional impact of each topic. Trevor looks at each experience not just through his over experience but also family and outsiders as well.
Wonderfully performed by the author. His unique voice and sense of humor carries through some extreme circumstances under apartheid. Its a personal perspective on historic events.
A great look peak into life growing up half a world away. Trevor is an awesome storyteller and manages to break down his experiences for everyone to understand. You will definitely laugh and cry.

4.5 stars. This memoir was amazing. Trevor Noah has a fascinating story and is such a natural storyteller. He chooses wisely to concentrate his efforts on his childhood and teenage years, and he gracefully tells not only his personal story but also brings his eloquence to the larger socio-political climate of the Apartheid-era South Africa of his childhood. Listen to this one on audio if you can.

This is probably one of the best books I have read. EVER. 
 Trevor's simple but perfect way of writing transports you into not only his life but into South Africa pre- and post- Apartheid. 
 From his childhood and early adulthood, Trevor teaches us about racism, apartheid and the multitude of problems of his country. In his narrative he is honest, genuine and heart-breaking. 
 When approaching this, you can't think of him as the new host of "The Daily Show" or a celebrity, but just as a man from South Africa telling you this unbelievable story. 
 Trevor talks about apartheid, he explains to us reader (that like me aren't partiularly familiar with South Africa's history) what it was actually like growing up in that time: the corruption of the police, poverty, church, faith, racism, feminism, equality and more. 
 At that time in South Africa he was actually born a crime: his mom is a black woman and his father is white, something that was illegal . He describes how difficult it was for him to identify in a specific group: is he black? is he white? Is he black enough? Is he white enough? 
 I can't stress this enough: this book will be one of the best things you will read. 
 One of the best things about "Born a Crime" is Trevor's mom Patricia. What an incredible woman. 
 Her life lessons included in the book are some of the best pieces of advice I have ever heard. 
 I can't even process what I have just read... I'm feeling lots and lots of emotions right now and I can't think straigtht. 
 I'll just say this. READ IT. Study it. Encourage everyone you know to read it. It's a masterpiece. 
 For now that's it... I'll definitely review this in depth on my blog. I'll update this review as soon as I have calmed down.
A lot of language, which was a bit of a turn-off, but it was still amazing to hear what the Noah family has been through. My problems pale in comparison.
I like Trevor Noah as a person and this book is well told as well as important, but I don't think I'll ever like The Daily Show. I can appreciate him, but I don't enjoy watching him.

Although I don't watch The Daily Show (I know, I know), I have seen online clips of Trevor Noah in action and have found him to be funny and charming. When Audible offered a free download of his self-narrated memoir, I knew I wanted to listen to it. I'm so glad I did. Trevor is a beautiful and hilarious narrator of his heartbreaking and heartwarming story of growing up in poverty and extreme prejudice in post-Apartheid South Africa. As I've mentioned in probably every non-fiction book review I've ever written, I love reading about something which I know little. I learned so much about South Africa in the 1990's and was able to make many distressing connections to the poverty and prejudice described by J.D. Vance in his memoir of growing up in Appalachia, Hillbilly Elegy. Parts of Trevor's memoir made me LOL and other parts had me wiping tears off of my face. The end of the book had me doing both (his Mom!!!!!!!). I highly recommend this audiobook and hope that Trevor Noah will narrate more books in the future.

Heard this on audible and HIGHLY recommend listening to it! Noah's telling of his childhood is mesmerizing. He brings humor into a life that many of us would consider tragic and learning about Apartheid from his perspective is fascinating. Highly recommend!

Everyone has heard about the South African apartheid, but how is to grow up under its influence? This is what Trevor Noah tells us in his memoir. Born a Crime is an apt title for this book, since it refers to the fact that Noah's very birth was a crime. He was of mixed race parentage with a black South African mother and a white Swiss father. As a coloured person, who was brought up in a black culture, Noah did not feel at home with any group. It made for interesting reading since Trevor brought up all the different facets of his life seen from his unique perspective. 
 The stories are presented in snippets, so it is not a linear description of Noah's life. But most of the chapters were interesting and you begin to get a sense of what a background of racism and poverty can do to someone even if they have the opportunities to get ahead. Noah escaped the vicious cycle because he managed to find a job he loved. But before that, he wasted time hustling even when there was no need for it. All this because he wanted to fit in, and the only people he felt comfortable with were poor people with nowhere to go. 
 This biography is intensely honest, which I appreciated. The murkier aspects of Noah's own behaviour and that of those he loved was not glossed over. For example, Noah's mother was annoying. She didn't spoil the book for me, because the human interest element was pretty high. But I began to find Nombuyiselo quite unsympathetic at some point. Her crazy religiousness was putting her life and that of her son's in danger and she would not admit it at all. It was not impressive, it was darn foolish! 
 But this is what oppression is all about - there is no scope for critical thinking. The scourge of apartheid remains in South Africa, decades after its official ending. Gender imbalance is rampant, and so is violence, poverty, and crime. Criminals are at the helm, and poor people live like they always have. 
 One thing that annoyed me about this book was the Americanisation. Everything was described and explained from an American angle, instead of just describing it as it is. For example, a store was described as the American version of Target. Why would I care? This was done consistently and I began to lose any feel of reading about South Africa, which was a great pity. 
 Born a Crime is not a comprehensive look at apartheid, but it is a great snippet to get you started. Noah's humour shines through in places, and after reading this book, I am convinced that he is a good comedian.
Listened to this on audiobook--read by Trevor Noah--brilliant. He has so many important things to say about race, and color and culture--and he is a wonderful, hilarious storyteller.
Interesting perspective on post-apartheid South Africa and what people had to do in order to survive on a day to day basis underneath the headlines of the Nelson Mandela story.

I couldn't recommend this book highly enough. It's not just that it's funny or interesting or gut-wrenching, although it's all of those things, but it gives such different perspectives on life. What an amazing young man.

This book on audiobook was one of the best audiobooks I have ever listened to. Trevor Noah did such an amazing job retelling his childhood and the history of South Africa, while infusing his story with humor even in dark times. I absolutely loved it!

I borrowed this book because of the story. I didn't know much about Noah beyond a couple of YouTube videos that commented on political issues and an interview with President Obama. 
 This is a powerful book. Of course there is humor in the book, but this is a serious book. I can identify with Noah in a number of ways while finding new insight into a life I can't imagine. 
 Noah paints pictures with his words, illustrating the meaning of privilege in a world of inequality. He shows how poverty can trap generations of people who work hard to escape without the tools and education to do it. The struggle of domestic violence and loving someone who hurts. 
 I did not expect to be confronted with the weight of the serious topics. Nor did I expect the time of honesty and disclosure that surfaces in the book. 
 For me, this book have me a glimpse of the pain that bias puts people through. Not just racial bias. Noah shows that answers are easy to give while solutions are difficult. I see the reality of a sin sick world that can only be cured by God. I do not know where Noah stands in relation to God (he does not shy away from profanity), but he gives the testimony of his mother a spotlight for the world to see the power of her faith. 
 I would recommend this book to those who are interested in better understanding prejudice and poverty and the subtle ways society contributed to these forces.
