Noah uses profanity liberally, so that is something a reader will have to consider in approaching this book. For myself, what I gained from the reading well outweighed the profanity.

Trevor Noah is the new host of The Daily Show on Comedy Central. When Jon Stewart announced that he was leaving the show last year, like most fans I was basically crushed. How could he leave?! And who was this Trevor kid? No, seriously, he looks like a baby. How can this child replace JON flippin' STEWART? But as I watched the new host settle into his role, I actually began to like him. No, he wasn't Jon Stewart--but he also wasn't trying to be. He brought a completely different flavor to the show. He was still funny--but his background and perspective were different, intriguing. So when I first saw he had a memoir coming out, I knew I wanted to read it. 
 I have a track record of being disappointed by books written by newly-famous celebrities. (Somehow they tend to come across like they were written just to keep the gravy train rolling...) But this book. THIS BOOK. Holy smokes, it is so good. Never mind that it's written well and that Noah has a great sense of humor and self-awareness about all the Ish he's had to endure in his life. What I love most is that the book absolutely surprised me. I wasn't prepared for where it went--or, rather, I wasn't expecting this to be what Noah's childhood was like. I guess I thought if he was able to get his own already-popular show, he must have had more than a few connections and handouts. And who knows, maybe he did eventually meet the person who knew The Person. But he certainly went through his fair share of Terrible Horrible before he got where he is now. 
 For example, Noah grew up in apartheid South Africa and was raised mostly by his mother (since his white father couldn't be seen with him in public). His stepdad was a colossal dick and did some truly, truly horrible things to the family (especially his mother, yeesh). He was incredibly resourceful. He was chunky. He had bad skin and was very unpopular in school. He was also a troublemaker. He could run really fast and managed to evade cops more than once. 
 The point is, this is one of those books that doesn't go anywhere you expect it to. I can't begin to say how much I love it when someone's personality or life story surprises me--and I especially appreciate it when a person turns out to be a scrappy-as-hell survivor. 
 My only very minor complaint is that the book ended too abruptly. I needed a few more pages telling me where Noah went from that last horrific act he describes in the book. Is that what propels him to go to America? I just needed more closure. But other than that, I absolutely loved Born a Crime. It's one of the best memoirs I've read all year. (Along with 32 Yolks, if you're looking for another good one...) :D 
 See more of my reviews at www.BugBugBooks.com.
Fantastic. I recommend getting it as an audiobook. Trevor Noah is a great storyteller and hearing the different languages he speaks helps to understand what a chameleon he had to be.
100% the best autobiography i've ever read!
This was a good listen on audio. Many difficult situations sprinkled with humor.

This was a great book. I read the whole thing in one 4 hour plane ride, so it's pretty quick. But man. Talk about a different childhood! Noah writes with a sort of dry, ironic humor throughout, so it's not too heavy. There are parts I laughed out loud, and that rarely happens to me in books. And his mom. Wow. He's so lucky he was born to such a dedicated and independent woman. 
 Just go read it.

Trevor Noah's memoir of his youth in Apartheid South Africa is a beautiful and harrowing commentary on his young life as a "colored" (mixed-race) youth among violence, poverty, crime, and both the legal and social stigmas associated with being who he is. Noah discusses his earliest days of joy, where he would run around completely isolated from the realities of his world. He grows, causes more trouble, and tries to forge relationships with friends and his elusive father. The story continues through his mother's various tribulations with men, the staggering effects of poverty that creep into every decision they make, and the building of his career...as a young petty criminal. The book ends just at the early moments he starts making a dent in the career we are familiar with today. 
 Now, the best part of the book has little to do with what one might have expected. Sure, there are some extremely funny moments (my favorite was an ill-fated DJ set with one of Noah's peers), but what this book provides is an uncompromising study of the effects of, causes of, and results of poverty on young minority men (and I am using that term loosely as Noah's race has a big role in the book, constantly shifting social alliances with good illustrative and literal reasons) in Johannesburg, but honestly all over the world. His approach to these important issues is fun to read, making all the difference in a book that needed to be written now more than ever. He covers crime, unemployment, healthcare, family, alcoholism, and every major issue affecting the low-income families of the inner city. Noah has an incredible ability to formulate an extremely important and misunderstood argument against what much of the American rhetoric says about poverty and crime, and he uses the form of his memoir to illustrate - to show and then explain - how this all works in the context of a dangerous urban environment. He is accurate, engaging, entertaining, and the lessons his memoir provides are extremely important to society today. 
 This was an enjoyable read - and I will likely adopt this in my classroom in reading both memoir and discussing social justice. While this was definitively a memoir, the message it carries is unflinchingly, bravely, beautifully bold.
If you can, "read" this as an audiobook; Noah's voice adds to the experience.

Even though this book was about Trevor Noah's life, I truly believe these stories were written out of love for his mother. She is an amazing woman who has endured many injustices. This was an opportunity for a son to use his fame as a platform to tell the world her story.

I have been a bit obsessed with Trevor Noah since he began hosting The Daily Show, so I was very eager to get my hands on this book. Growing up poor in South Africa on the tail-end of apartheid, Noah's childhood was tragic, complicated but also filled with the typical pre-teen moments of self doubt, broken hearts and the longing to fit in. What makes those typical moments atypical is coming of age under government-mandated racial separation, where not only were South African's citizens divided between black and white, but black and white and Indian and Chinese and "colored". Being born to a black Xhosa mother and a white Swiss father, Trevor fell into the category of "colored" yet struggled to fit in with any particular group, whether they be black, white or "colored". Trevor recounts fond memories of his strong-willed and determined mother who loved him unconditionally, despite her family's reluctance to accept him as one of their own. He explains what it was like being a child under apartheid, and how the government not only wanted to separate white from black, but aimed to fracture the divide even more by isolating the Xhosa, Zulu, Pedi, Tsonga, etc., who would maintain their own language, and therefor be unable to communicate with each other. Because he is a comedian, there are of course very humorous moments and observations, but the overall tone is quite serious. Obviously life for Trevor Noah now is much different from his upbringing, but his journey of how he got there is inspiring.

"You can only dream of what you can imagine". 
 It's a collection of stories from Trevor Noah's life that are filled with hilarious stories that had me laughing out loud until I realized the biting and insightful social commentaries. Heartfelt memories of his mother.
*Really* liked this one...listened to on Audible (love me some accents). Didn't know much or anything about Trevor Noah but am a fan for sure now.

"Language, even more than color, defines who you are to people." 
 WARNING! You're not educated well enough. To change that, please proceed the following way: 
 1. Buy this book. 
 2. Read it. 
 3. Fall in love with it. 
 4. Be angry at the colonizers. 
 5. Mourn for justice. 
 6. Finish reading the book. 
 7. Spread word about the book. 
 8. Discuss the wrongness of domestic abuse, apartheid & racism, corruption... 
 9. Read the book again. 
 10. Never stop getting educated. 
 If you STILL need reasons to read the book, here you go: 
 1. For the sake of education 
 2. Beautiful languages 
 3. Amazing, independent mother 
 4. Funny stories 
 5. Important topics 
 6. The Shitting Scene. 
 7. So, SO much more, but... spoilers. 
 8. Just read it goddammit. 
 British racism said "If the monkey can walk and talk like a man, then perhaps he is a man." Afrikaner racism said "Why give a book to a monkey?"

Very good read. I didn't know much about him, but enjoyed the stories no matter what he's become. He tells very interesting insights into growing up in apartheid South Africa. I wouldn't say it was a super hilarious book, but there are the ridiculous stories that are funny. My favourite was Go Hitler.
Honestly one of the first times I've both teared up and laughed out loud while reading a book. Amazingly well written and gives great insight into South African culture
As if I needed another reason to love Trevor Noah....

I've always loved Trevor Noah's show. He has a wonderful sense of humor and intelligence. I now know that he has incredible background which helps understand his perceptions better. He had quite the traumatic youth, and I would whole-heartedly recommend this book to people who want to learn more about life...not as YOU know it. I read "Hillbilly Elegy" right before this and thought they were similar in different countries and of a different race. You will see the parallels.
Fabulous!!! And eye opening biography about his life in South Africa, from Apartheid to stardom!
I was surprised at just how lively and readable this book was. The first-hand perspective of apartheid in South Africa and the layers of racial issues was an eye-opener, as was the honesty and humor.
Probably one of the best celebrity memoirs I have read.

I was frightened by Trevor Noah's descriptions of apartheid South Africa be cause of their parallels to the situation in the U.S. with the new president. Born to a black mother and white father, Noah was hidden from the South African officials because multi-race relationships were illegal. A reallly interesting book that opened my eyes to apartheid.
Read this read this read this. So important and wise.

I guess by now everyone knows Trevor Noah as a comedian and from the Daily Show. The truth be told I bought this one because it was super cheap on Kindle and didn't expect too much (no I did not read any reviews before). Well, I was dead wrong. It is by far the best book I read this year and I can't praise it enough. He describes growing up in South Africa as a biracial child during and after Apartheid, how everyday racism, poverty, domestic abuse and crime are still present in black South Africa. It gives a necessary insight into the "rainbow nation" showing that post-Apartheid South Africa is still far away from an equal and just society. As a foreigner in South Africa, it made me think, it explained to me and showed me the inconvinent truth of the life of non-white people in this country. But what I loved the most was that this was a love letter to all the strong women in his life. I guess his mother is a true role model. His writing style is engaging and makes it easy to read. There were so many passages I wanted to highlight. The book is full of laughter but never covers the actual truth in beautiful lies. If their is one book you want to read about the life of black South Africans it should be this one.

Let me start off by saying Trevor Noah's mother is one of the most inspiring and badass people I have ever read about. 2 chapters in I fell in love with her and by the end of the book she had solidified that spot. Starting his book I expected it to be much more jam packed with jokes and funny stories, but these were truly stories of his childhood and upbringing that transformed him into the person he is today. Trevor keeps it funny but also teaches us a ton about apartheid and South Africa that I can assume the average reader never knew. Overall I laughed, I cried, and I loved every story in this entire book. Very well done, Trevor!!!
Really incredible story. Makes me like him even more!

Listen to this on Audible in public and lose control of yourself to the point where you are peeing your pants, crying, and bending over holding your sides laughing so hard. It will just prove how good it is that you could not control the public loss of control! :)

This book is truly amazing. I would recommend listening to the audiobook to hear Trevor Noah read his own words. 
 I laughed and I cried hard. There's so much heart and fire. 
 Seriously, read it. You won't be sorry.

Deeply poignant and quite funny. Trevor Noah is a great story teller. What's really amazing is how he can tell stories about his childhood in Africa that are at the same time completely foreign and then immediately relatable. I hope he writes more. I would be interested if he tried fiction.

If you take anything from this book, you need to note that Trevor Noah's mom is a bad-ass. Holy crap. I am just saying. She is an amazing person and even though I don't agree with a lot of her methods, I think it is fantastic that her son told this story. 
 Read more here: 
 http://www.platypire.com/j-hooligan/b...
Wow wow wow! I liked Trevor Noah solely on the strength of his hosting the Daily show; but to hear him narrate this and see all that he's been through gives me so much respect for him!

I don't know that I would have given this book 5 stars if I had read it traditionally from a book instead of listening to Trevor Noah read it as an audio book. I liked this book because it touches on several social and moral issues that I have been mulling over and discussing for years. I loved this book because Trevor Noah tells his own story in his own voice so wonderfully. His narrative, use of several different African languages and accents, surprising past in a politically turbulent country, and the baring of his soul make this a read/listen I couldn't walk away from for too long. If I had had the time, I would have listened to the whole thing in one fell swoop.

Trevor Noah is an engaging storyteller. His memoir is by turns both hilarious and heartbreaking. 
 His mom, Patricia, is the star of this book. She is a strong, rational, no-nonsense woman who does what she wants without caring what other people think. 
 I recommend the audiobook; he reads it himself and he does the voices.

I read this on two back to back flights and LOVED IT. I was surprised how much his commentary on race taught me about South African politics, and similarly, how much I enjoyed learning the history of the person and the country.

I am not an autobiography reader, I'll be honest. I've been disappointed at some of the material from comedians like Amy Schumer and Caitlin Moran because I'd expected their sense of humour to translate perfectly to the written word, and for me, it did not. But Trevor Noah has a true story to tell. It is by no means a literal transposition of his stand up sketches, but you recognise the same brand of humour and his authorial voice is strong: you can hear his voice jump off the pages. The human truths he talks about are universal, and yet he gently adds to our layers of understanding about the issues of post apartheid South Africa and how everything is not as simple as it is can appear from the outside. It is not a triumph of one side over the other, there is no right vs wrong but many many shades of grey, and for many South Africans, freedom created as many problems as oppression ("The world has been taught to be scared of him but in reality he's scared of the world"). You can see, smell and hear the environment he conjures so vividly ("There is something magical about Soweto. Yes it was a prison designed by oppressors, but it also gave us a sense of self determination and control... in America the dream is to make it out the ghetto. In Soweto, because there was no leaving the ghetto, the dream was to transform the ghetto"). Highly recommended.
I read it in his voice and accent. this is important . thats how tragedy and struggle becomes comedy in the hands of a young, intelligent and sensitive human being.

A fascinating story, which covers Noah's youth and doesn't touch upon his later fame. It's a fascinating insight into South African society as well as a revealing portrait of of a childhood where Noah didn't fit in anywhere, and had what sounds like a very difficult home life. 
 I've gained even more respect for Noah after having read this, and I also learned a lot about Apartheid and post-Apartheid South Africa. 
 Well worth reading.

If you are a fan of Trevor Noah's iteration of the Daily Show, with his stream of consciousness, witty, oft scathing comedic style, you will find this book entertaining. Me, not so much. 
 Born a Crime is raw, almost disturbingly so, yet exploration of his South African upbringing. Noah's casual, rather matter-of-fact way of dealing with the tragic and horrific details of his childhood are hard to read, but necessary. 
 Trevor loves his mom and the relationship between these two is heartwarming and wrenching. She's fiercely independent, yet also comedic in her child-rearing approach, so you see where Trevor got his wit. 
 But, when he uses this literary style to convey everything from South Africa's draconian miscegenation laws to the systemic poverty and institutional education policies that crippled many Africans during Apartheid, slightly diminishes the gravity of the issues at hand. He's strives for laughter, however for me, the tone was disquieting. 
 I won't give away the end, it involves his mother and if you've heard any of his interviews for the book, he tears up when he talks about it. Let's suffice it to say that like so much of the book, he takes a topic like domestic violence and treats it with such a subtle and matter of fact tone, that you "almost" forget that what he's conveying is yet another tragic aspect his life. 
 It's clearly a survival mechanism, I just wished that in some cases, he'd have been a little bit more serious, but then, he wouldn't be a comedian. 
 TD recommends
Wow.
Review: https://angryangelbooks.com/2017/08/2...
I really enjoyed this book; I wish he had given us a bit more information about how he got in to comedy

This is my 132nd book read in 2016. It's also my very favorite book this year. 
 I know that publishing a book can take years and years but I believe the timing of this release- after a divisive election and moving into a time where many feel human rights will go backward in this country- is meant to be. There is so much to learn from this book about Mr. Noah's upbringing in South Africa, most notably what can happen when a government divides it's people so that they are easier to control. 
 A beautifully written book that is honest, moving and heart-wrenching. I highly recommend it.

Trevor Noah has been my favorite comedian for a long time. Between his stand ups and the Daily Show he has always been a favorite. 
 But man that book. It was powerful,inspirational, witty, and everything in between. 
 I liked his writing style. It was casual yet entertaining. It was serious at times and made you laugh others. 
 The story itself was heartbreaking. Everything he and his family went through was terrible. But they persevered and his mother is one of the strongest people I've ever read about. 
 Oh and I don't want to spoil anything so I'm just going to say this. I hate you Abel (read and find out). 
 This book will stay with me for a long time. 
 "Nine moths after that yes, on February 20,1984, my mom checked into Hillbrow Hospital for a scheduled C-section delivery. Estranged from her family, pregnant by a man she could not be seen with in public, she was alone. The doctors took her up to the delivery room, cut open her belly, and reached in and pulled out a half-white,half-black child who violated any number of laws,statues, and regulations- I was born a crime."

** spoiler alert ** 
 Great book and so thankful I was able to get it for free through audible. 
 It's so interesting because Trevor Noah has had so much happen in his life that this book essentially only covers his birth through early adulthood. None of his experiences in the media are discussed here. 
 But there is SO MUCH that has happened and is discussed that it makes his rise to fame, that much more astounding and amazing. 
 A great writer, the only reason I gave it 4 stars instead of 5, is because there seemed to be a lull in the later quarter of the book (SPOILER: After his friend is arrested for stealing and before his mother splits up from his step-dad). 
 But otherwise it was a great read and a fine book.

I expected to enjoy this book, but I was blown away by how much I liked it. Trevor Noah has given us a completely human look with all of the sadness, terror, hilarity, and love that it entails into his childhood. At its root, this a story of his mother's love through apartheid, domestic abuse,poverty and youthful indiscretions. Many celebrity memoirs feel a bit removed, this one does not feel that way at all. 
 The audio is highly recommended.

Trevor Noah is the current head of The Daily Show after replacing Jon Stewart and whilst he may not be universally liked on that show he's really grown as a host in recent months and it was interesting to read his memoir to learn more about his past in South Africa, which is something that he doesn't shy away on through his show. Noah himself explains how from a young age he was born a criminal, to a Swiss father and a Xhosa mother, during a time when such a union meant a lengthy prison sentence, and he explores his early life very well indeed with some great writing, and some added elements of humour that really work and helps his story feel authentic. 
 If you aren't familiar with Trevor Noah as a comedian but this memoir sounds interesting enough for you to read then you might want to consider watching a few episodes of his show or a few clips on Youtube first to get an idea of what he's like. The Memoir may not go into great detail about The Daily Show - in fact, it barely mentions it, because most of the focus here is on Noah's journey throughout his childhood. He explores several incidents such as one time where he was caught on camera shoplifting with his friend and whilst his friend got caught he wasn't recognised, whilst at the same time explores his relationship with his family, namely his mother, very well indeed. 
 The book is fast paced for a memoir and moves through events quickly, and it's a fairly short read so you'll be able to speed through this in a couple of sittings. I'm not overly familiar with South Africa and the apartheid but Noah manages to tell a insightful and story with a lot of heart. I know I mentioned that it might be a good idea to watch some of Noah's standup comedy or his work on The Daily Show to get a good idea but that is only optional as you could probably dive straight in without any further information needed. Even though there is humour that is not the main focus of the book, as it explores Noah's background incredibly well making it a must read. It might not quite be the best memoir that I've read this year but it's certainly up there.

This is one of the best audiobooks I've ever read. Just enough of a history lesson of South Africa that it didn't turn this history rebel away. His voice is amazing and his story even better. I've been giving the discs to Mike as I finish and he loves it, too!

Trevor Noah made me cry and laugh out loud. His stories about growing up in South Africa highlight the many dimensions of race, class, and gender and the importance of language. I recommend listening to him read it.

An ode really to Trevor Noah's mother and a wonderful book on what it means to have their love and have them in your corner. 
 The host of "The Daily Show" Trevor Noah recounts his life growing up in South Africa and being born from two different cultures and takes on issues of race, religion, and class. 
 It's not so much funny "ha ha" as a funny tour through Noah's early life and full of anecdotes of his upbringing that just make you respect mothers all the more. 
 A quick unexpectedly heartwarming read.

Remarkable story of a hugely challenging and inspiring 
 life written by a genius. Highly recommended.

I don't normally go in for celebrity memoirs, but I'm glad I went in for this one. 
 As I started to read, I remembered, "oh yeah, he's a comedian". The book delivers the same style of one-liners as Noah does on The Daily Show. Then as I read further, I remembered, "oh yeah, he's a political commentator" and all the incisive observations that come with that jumped out of the book too. 
 So, it's basically like watching the Daily Show, if Noah was presenting his life instead of the news. You can hear his voice as you read his writing, and you have an idea of how he wants it delivered. 
 But on top of that, you've got his actual story. He lays out his upbringing in South Africa and gives the right amount of context to help us understand the implications of a biracial kid's existence during and immediately after apartheid. I come out of the book respecting Noah even more for his willingness to divulge his personal history, which sounds like it would be extremely painful to dredge up, let alone share with the world.

** spoiler alert ** 
 I listened to this on audible. It was a great sorry of family, faith, and childhood. I about died at the poop story with Trevor Noah deciding to poop in the house on newspaper, and his blind great grandmother being in the same room. I will always remember this book for that moment.

I simply loved this book. From the beginning to the end. I picked it up at a friend's house, with no context or background, and it immediately pulled me in. I knew Trevor from the daily show and as a comedian, so I was surprised and intrigued when his book was not comedy writing, but instead stories from his childhood growing up in South Africa. There's a comedic flair thrown in (he has a strong voice that stays consistent throughout), but it's not a humor book. 
 I loved how Trevor [sidenote: after reading this I feel like I can call him by his first name, like he's the kind of person I could meet in a bar and with we could share a great conversation] weaves his social commentary and observation in with his stories. I never comes across as preachy or didactic. Though his stories center around very intense things that have happened to him, he has no tones of self-pity or self-grandiose. Reading this book left me with a craving to learn more, to DO more. 
 I was at a 4/4.5 leading into the end...and then the last story blew me away. It literally gave me goosebumps, which hasn't happened to me since I read "one hundred years of solitude" as a teenager. That pushed me to a 5 star rating. READ THIS BOOK!

The ending of this book surprised me with all the feelings I didn't realize I was going to feel. I will admit I didn't watch a lot of his show before reading or know much about him. While I assume this is a good read for fans, I thoroughly enjoyed this book about his life, a little of South Africa's history, and how everything connects.
I highly recommend the audiobook!
https://poseidons99.wordpress.com/201...
Amazing.

I give this book 5 stars not for its literary genius, but for Noah's incredible talent of taking horrifically difficult topics and adding just the right amount of humour. Apartheid, domestic violence, racism are all tackled without the usual self-depreciating drivel of modern literature. He is honestly funny, but he's has something very important to say between the laughter. I was laughing (and at times crying) through the entire book. This is an incredible story and despite the fact it's not a 'high-brow' memoir it's still well written, easy to read and hard to put down! 
 In short - I loved it!
My review is here.

One of the joys of reading Noah's biography is the fact that, as a comedian, his retelling of one of the most truly despicable institutionalized race segregationist policies never becomes dramatic, hyperbolic, or soul-crushingly depressing. Instead of levelling on and on about the atrocities of apartheid, Noah tries constantly to present the small absurdities in his life while observing how they would relate to the wider national community. And in this right, I would argue, Noah succeeds far better in demonstrating the ineffectiveness of apartheid, because while concerted political efforts were what ultimately brought down such an odious system, it's the power of subverting the institution through laughter that a real victory is achieved. 
 If you can laugh at something, it's difficult to take it too seriously. 
 If the reader would like to read my full review on my site White Tower Musings they can by following the link below: 
 https://jsjammersmith.wordpress.com/2...
A thoroughly enjoyable read. This young man is simply amazing. Do yourself a favor and read his story. You will laugh, cry and care deeply.

"The world saw me as colored, but I didn't spend my life looking at myself." 
 Be still my multiracial heart. I never wanted this to end. I wish there was literature like this when I was growing up. I wish I had someone that could explain the complexity of being biracial to me. I've longed for it for so long, and now, when I finally got it, I was a teenager again, and I cried through the whole thing. 
 "I wasn't popular, but I wasn't an outcast. I was everywhere with everybody, and at the same time I was all by myself." 
 It is very very rare for me to find a book that I hold so close to my heart. Books that make me stop, think, read passages over and over and spend breathing days in between reading something meaningful to me, so that I not devour it all in one gulp. I stopped reading for days cause I didn't want it to end. I read books in between because I didn't want to finish it. 
 "Ever the outsider, I created my own strange little world. I did it out of necessity. I needed a way to fit in." 
 I doubt this is the general consensus, but for some it might me. Voices of generations of kids growing up in a world that has no place for them is so important. We all long to find a safe space to call our own, a place where we can be understood. I found that space in between the pages of Trevor Noah's book. 
 So many times tears fell and loudly had to exclaim YES! That's exactly how I feel! I read passages to friends and they all nodded in agreement that the text was practically describing me. And I am not even black or african or swiss. I'm Norwegian, Spanish, Filipino, Indian, Chinese. And yet, the words call out to me. How powerful is the new emerging tribe of half-breeds that their experiences can rise above race all together and be the same story far across the other side of the world. 
 Nelson Mandela once said, "If you talk to a man in a language he understands, that goes to his head. If you talk to hi in his language, that goes to his heart." 
 So this was mostly my reaction to the book, and I may be biased. But the book, I though was also written very well, Mr.Noah is fantastic storyteller and he kept my attention and interest sharp throughout. I also learned a lot about apartheid and places in the world I have never been, reading about his childhood in South Africa. I think this book is an interesting read regardless if you know of him or not (which I barely did) and regardless what race you are, it's an interesting story. Sometimes funny, sometimes sad, sometimes inconsistent, sometimes exciting. It shows a life. And a story of a life is always worth telling, and always worth reading. 
 I would definitely recommend this book to anyone biracial with interest in introspection. There is comfort in finding situations and people living a life similar to your own. I would also recommend this book to everyone else. The naivete of a child is something everyone should be able to relate to, and if you've ever crossed a few lines, I'm sure there's comfort for you in there too. If there's one thing Mr.Noah successfully showed me it's that it's ok to have a past, but we don't have to live there, we can move on to the future.

What a fantastic read. What an incredibly amazing childhood - amazing in a way that it was so different from mine and therefore so incredibly interesting to read. And of course, there is an underlying humour to the stories. You can hear Mr. Noah's voice in your head as you read the passages. The humour helps to soften the negative experiences, yet you are still left with an understanding of this part of the world. Definitely a recommended read.

I don't usually read memoirs/bios, but let me say that I really enjoyed this one! I listened to the audio book (which is another thing I don't usually do) and boy was it entertaining. Trevor reads it himself and really adds a whole new level to the experience. To give an example here he will speak many of the languages that I would have had a hard time imagining in my head. He also does impressions and just has a generally pleasing voice. This book can be very sad and very funny- often at the same time thanks to how it's written. He's had quite an interesting life, to say the least. Much respect to him and his mother for being so strong through so much.

I listened to this on Audible and I'm so glad that I did. Trevor Noah narrates his own book and it adds so much to the experience. His story is worth listening to (or reading) because, for me, it is out of my realm of existence and it enriches my understanding of the other, the not me, the rest of mankind.
Great book, really opens the eyes about how people can change, and are affected by those around them.

More reviews available at my blog, Beauty and the Bookworm. 
 A few weeks ago, my boyfriend was going out for drinks with a friend at a local bookstore and cafe. I was invited, but am a total homebody and told him have fun, but bring me a book. He brought back Born a Crime and Neil Gaiman's new nonficton, The View from the Cheap Seats. Born a Crime was shorter, so I started that first. 
 Born a Crime is exclusively about Noah's life before he left South Africa, and it's largely about his life before he got into comedy--comedy is only mentioned a handful of times, at best. The majority of the book takes place during his childhood and teens, when he lived with his mother and, later, his stepfather and younger brother. During his early childhood, apartheid was still in effect in South Africa, and later on its effects were still being felt even after it was officially abolished. As a mixed-race child (black South African mother, white Swedish/German father) Noah was literally born a crime, and his anecdotes are about race, discrimination, and the fluidity of identity during apartheid and after. As a mostly basic white girl, these things were fascinating to read about, because it's a culture I will never be a part of, but something I dearly want to understand in order to be a more educated, worldly, and tolerant individual. 
 Floating around in the background of many of the anecdotes is Noah's home life, which practically vanishes from the page after his mother marries his stepfather. This lends a very strange dynamic to the book, because you can tell there's something to do with that, and abuse, floating around in the background, but it seems like Noah's avoiding it. Which is totally his right, if wants to, but it's a strange feel. Well, he's not avoiding it. He comes out with it all in the last chapter of the book, and I can see why. While much of the book has touching moments, that final chapter is definitely the one with the strongest emotional impact. It adds so much context that was missing in the rest of the book and makes a lot of things much clearer in hindsight. 
 Noah has an extremely readable style. While he's a comedian, this book is frequently poignant rather than laugh-out-loud funny, though a few of his signature jokes are in there--like how, during apartheid, he couldn't walk with his mother when police were around because mixed-race relationships were illegal, and when cops would appear she would drop him like a bag of weed so that they wouldn't be harassed. Each chapter is prefaced by a shorter section that says something about apartheid and how it affected and still affects the people in South Africa. He shows both how far South Africa has come, and how far it still has to go, in a variety of ways--from racial equality (not that the United States is exactly a beacon of excellence in this area) to things such as basic sanitation. But at the same time, he includes touching stories of his relationship with his mother (this book was infinitely better than Maya Angelou's Mom & Me & Mom in that regard) and of finding himself. It's a great book, an easy read but one that packs a punch at the same time in a lot of areas, and I highly recommend it. 
 5 stars out of 5.

'Born A Crime' is an autobiography. For me, the goal of reading an autobiography is to learn about a person, to learn about their view on the world and preferably to learn from their experiences. It gives me the chance to (as cheesy as it sounds) widen my horizon and understand and tackle an important topic from a perspective I might not have known, or might not have the chance to gain all by myself. For example, Apartheid and with that racism as a whole is a topic that I know about and understand what it means. But, as a white caucasian woman, I'm fortunate enough never to have experienced racism on my own skin. So, by reading an autobiography by someone who actually experienced racism I can at least come close to grasp the full extent to which racism affects its victims. 
 The reason why 'Born A Crime' gets 5 stars, is simply because it's all I wish for in an autobiography. Before I read this book, I liked Trevor Noah. After I finished it, I had new respect for him. He doesn't only tell the story of his childhood, but he also gives a unique perspective on the world and especially on Apartheid/racism. I laughed with him, I cried with him, I felt with him, and all of that even though I absolutely cannot relate to (almost) all of the hardship he had to go through. And funnily enough, the secret hero of the book isn't Trevor Noah himself, but his mother. So, apart from every other reason why you should read this book, to everyone who loves to read about a strong, incredible woman, I recommend Trevor Noah's 'Born A Crime'.

I originally heard about Trevor Noah from his appearance on QI, and looked up some of his stand up on YouTube, which focused a lot on South African culture and growing up there. This memoir has a lot of different stories, not linear, but grouped vignettes, about his childhood in South Africa and the many hardships he and his family faced. But also what an unstoppable force his mother is. With a mother like her, it's no wonder he survived his childhood and can laugh about it now. Considering he's about my age, I was certainly aghast at the vast differences between our childhoods. This book really opened my eyes to the plight that so many still live with. However, Trevor has the delightful ability to make even the saddest stories make you laugh. I was entertained the whole way through.

3 stars = good. I thought this was a good telling of a fascinating story. I appreciated the insight into South African cultures and his revealing personal accounts of recent history. I'm very glad to have read it and found the mother/child aspect of the book both frustrating and inspiring. I actually listened to the audio version, with the author himself providing the narration, and while I'm sure he was able to give an emotional performance unlike anyone else would've been able to, I found the language a bit harsh for my taste. When I read I can skim over those words but when listening to it I wasn't able to and now have those verbal memories associated with the book which is a negative for me.

I think this might be the best book I've ever read. This was interesting, funny, and amazing. I knew pretty much noting about South Africa besides Mandela to be honest and this was a real eye opener. He has lived a very interesting life and it really made him into one celeb that people SHOULD look up to as a role model.

I was a huge fan of The Daily Show with Jon Stewart, but I've only watched sporadically since Trevor Noah took his place. 
 So I wasn't sure what I was getting into with his memoirs. I knew he was South African and that was about it. I was blown away! I know bits and pieces of South African history (usually involving Nelson Mandela.) But this was from a different perspective. A half white, half black boy growing up in Apartheid and what happened after Apartheid was over. This story had me laughing, shocked and tears in my eyes during parts. His mother is such an admirable woman, taking whatever life threw at her and her family and making sure her son learned and grew from it. I hope to be at least half as great a mother as she is. 
 This was a free audiobook provided by Goodreads, and I think hearing the author tell you his story made it so much more. I'm sure this help with the various languages he speaks throughout the story. It felt like he was sitting across from me, having a drink and telling me about his life. Being that he's a comedian, he found ways to make light of hard situations. I listened to this while at work and it made my days fly by!

Listened to this as an audiobook, so we're doubly blessed with Trevor reading his own horrifying, heartbreaking, and hilarious story of his young life in South Africa. I had never heard of him before he took over the Daily Show, and that has been a success also. Enjoyed it for the humor, sadness, and descriptions of what poverty and/or being black was like during and after Apartheid. Bigger topics included how women and their families deal with abuse, and how few choices they have. Highly recommended, especially in audiobook format.
Loved! His writing style is witty and accessible, and I enjoyed his narratives about South Africa, a topic in which I am not knowledgeable. Would definitely recommend!

I found Born a Crime to be an interesting and informative read. Trevor Noah is a good storyteller. This book gave a deeper understanding of the complexities or race and class, by looking through the perspective of a boy trying to figure out his own identity.

Fast read that is eye-opening yet full of humor. I learned a ton about South Africa -- most of it abhorrent -- and about Trevor Noah. I know I had previously pigeonholed him as "the successor to Jon Stewart who isn't as good" but there's clearly a lot more going on with his story and it makes me want to learn more about his style and humor.

Thank you to The Rick O'Shea Book Club for recommending this one. I'd come across Trevor Noah briefly but doubt I would have put this wonderful story of a young man and his relationship with his mother as he grew up in South Africa to the top of my list but for the recommendation. 
 Noah is a great storyteller and you quickly become engaged in his life story. The book is sprinkled with enough detail on how apartheid operated to give the reader context without being highly political. Pick it up you won't regret it dY$?--

Por onde comecar? E imperdivel. Para quem conhece e acompanha o Trevor Noah e tambem para quem nao faz a minima ideia de quem ele e. Imperdivel. Quando pensamos em Africa do Sul, pensamos em apartheid, depois em Nelson Mandela e pronto. Mas o que era realmente o apartheid, como se manifestava a toda a hora, nao fazemos ideia. Este livro faz-nos ter uma ideia de como era, de como foi a 'transicao', mas nunca numa perspetiva amarga. E nem sequer de uma perspetiva propriamente comica, como se poderia pensar. Antes de um ponto de vista muito pragmatico e terra a terra. E das melhores coisas que li nos ultimos tempos. Daqueles que queremos que toda a gente leia, para comentarmos, para pormos a nossa vida em perspetiva, para imaginarmos as nossas reacoes. Demasiado bom.

"Catholic school is similar to apartheid in that it's ruthlessly authoritarian, and its authority rests on a bunch of rules that don't make any sense." 
 Trevor just summed up the years I've spent at catholic school.
LOVED it. Very honest, open. Talks about some tough things with very interesting history of south africa thrown in. Very engaging!

I really enjoyed this book. Trevor Noah manages to write about apartheid and how it affected his early life without being either flippant and dismissive or overly grave. He treats the subject with some humor while also managing to highlight the damage the policy did to the lives of his fellow South Africans. The book is laugh-out-loud funny at times. At others, the story is harrowing and terribly sad. I recommend the audiobook - not only is Noah's accented voice beautiful to listen to, you also get to hear him speak some of the other six (!) languages he is fluent in.
3.75, listened on audiobook
Trevor Noah is always funny, but this book also offers insights into life in apartheid and post-apartheid South Africa.

I became a chameleon. My color didn't change, but I could change your perception of my color. 
 I really wasn't sure what to expect with this book, but I thoroughly enjoyed it. Imagine being born from a black mother and a white father in a country where interracial relationships were against the law. This would mean that because you are colored you could not be seen with both of your parents (or they with each other) or stay in the same area as them. I think I learned more about apartheid, as well as the effects thereof on people's everyday lives and thoughts, than in any other book I've read before. Although Trevor's story is sometimes upsetting and depressing (it's hard to imagine the things humans do to each other), it is always genuine and balanced and often laugh out loud funny. He does not write from a place of hate or self-pity. There is a lot of wisdom and insight in these short vignettes. As he is now the host of The Daily show, there is a lot of American comparisons, which I found very interesting, and which will help non South African readers have a better understanding of what he is describing. The only reason this loses a star is because I would really have liked to see some photo's, but I read an ARC copy so maybe the finished title will include these. I recommend this book to absolutely everyone, I got sooo much more than I expected from it. It will transport you to a different place and time, teach you a lot about SA and it's people and problems, but all in a fun way.
You will discover a whole new world, yet at the same time you will find your reflection in it. Far too many things that we take for granted are actually to be appreciated and loved.

Excellent! Wonderful writing, terrific narration by TN and written with a great sense of humor (of course). Fascinating tales of life in such a different world, funny and scary boyish escapades and becoming a successful man despite very difficult odds (but with the support of a powerful mother who led the way).

I've enjoyed Trevor Noah's stand-up for years and actually do like him as the host of The Daily Show. Born a Crime was a great extension of some stories that I have heard him talk about in the past and new ones I knew nothing about. Even though we are close in age, his life growing up in South Africa was so completely different than mine. Born a Crime really makes you think and give you an interesting look into another countries culture. 
 Also, I listened to the Audio version of this. I highly recommend it. He really brings the stories to life.

I really enjoyed this on audio. First off, Trevor's accent never hurts! But also, he is a great storyteller and I learned so much about the history of South Africa and about apartheid in general. I will definitely miss having this to listen to in the car! The only qualm I had with the writing was that it was sometimes hard to discern when in his life an event took place

Trevor Noah, for us Americans, is probably best known for his surprise replacement of Jon Stewart on The Daily Show. Here was this comedian not many were familiar with, taking over one of the landmark shows on television. Threw many for a loop, that's for sure! In "Born A Crime", Noah takes the reader on a ride through his childhood in South Africa - from literally being a crime to be born, to being thrown out of a vehicle BY HIS MOTHER, to his life of petty crime. 
 This is not a book written by a comedian. Rather, it is a book written by a person who happens to be a comedian. Which is to say - it's not constant jokes and laugh-out-loud funny. There is humor here, some of the "make a joke" variety, and some simply in the circumstances in which he was raised. There is a lot of tragedy as well - and some pointed commentary about how and why "the system" doesn't work for far too many people. 
 I wasn't sure what to expect, really. Noah is a fairly unknown element, this is his first book, and he's a comedian writing a reasonably serious book. Basically, it could have gone very wrong - but it didn't. The stories are interesting and tend to tie together very well, the history of South Africa that is part of the book is eye-opening, and he writes as I would imagine he is in every day life...still joking, but able to be serious. Sort of like the cute guy next door who always has a smart-assed comment, but surprises you with his intelligence as well. The only thing I wasn't fond of was the ending - it did seem a bit abrupt. But - that's a minor nit-pick.

What an amazing story. Incredibly well written (and performed). Wasn't expecting such a powerful testimony about the amazing life of Trevor's mother, but wow. Definitely worth a read, or better yet, a listen, as the audio book was top notch.
I highly recommend the audiobook!

Wow. This book was so inspiring. If I had one word to describe it, I'd call it inspiring. We follow Trevor's life as a kid growing up in South Africa during the apartheid, which was essentially the law that forbade blacks from being a part of the white population. He also follows up after the policy was dissolved when Mandela was freed, how he transitioned and what came after. Trevor is an amazing story teller. 
 Read my full non-spoiler review up on my blog: https://bookishendeavors.wordpress.co...

Super interesting for the first hand account of living in South Africa as Apartheid ended and moved into democracy from the point of view of a man who as a child had to be hidden because he had a black mother and a white father. Much more fascinating than funny, I would say, despite being written by a comedian, though having read the autobiographies of many comedians I would certainly say that is par for the course.

This was such an interesting snapshot of a life that I couldn't even dream/imagine. 
 The strength of Trevor and his mother, and their relationship radiates through the pages. 
 I highly recommend this book.

In the back of the book, his bio states simply: Trevor Noah is a comedian from South Africa. 
 Enigmatic is a word I would add. This is not the story of Trevor Noah's rise to fame. Indeed, there's no clear connection from the stories he shares to where he is now. 
 I'm sure a great deal of the book was intended to be humorous and purposefully irreverent, but I read undercurrents of resentment and extreme selfishness. At some points there was incredible incongruity in the retelling. He writes that he felt (and still feels) no guilt for the enormous repercussions others faced for his actions (i.e. unemployment, homelessness and jail time).... when those others were Black South African domestic workers and their children. However, he then writes how guilt ridden he was when one of his buddies brought him a stolen digital camera to resell (as part of his regular hustle) with images of a white family vacationing. He actually went into detail about how that one thing, so insignificant compared to other stories he shared, had the power to make him evaluate the direction his life was going in. He was devastated by the thought of a well-off white family being robbed of their vacation photos... even as he sat on a corner in the Alexandra slums taking advantage of his fellow oppressed Black South African neighbors. That was difficult to read and hard to swallow. 
 Instances like this and others made it feel as if he were playing to an audience. Throughout the book, he played to several different audiences: Americans, Black Americans, the World, South Africa, white people. All large scale and somewhat large in scope with little to no intimacy. 
 That being said, Born a Crime is a good read. The pacing is consistent throughout. Noah's commentary on various cultural and societal norms as well as the history of South Africa is insightful and at some times, eye-opening. There's no real chronology to the stories, he actually jumps around quite a bit with no solid grasp of time period or age, but the stories flow well together. 
 Early on the book comes across as a loving tribute to his mother. He shared some beautiful moments and teachings from his mom. Towards the middle the underlying resentment becomes quite prominent. I got the sense that there's quite a bit he has yet to come to terms with, to accept or to forgive. He explains situations and rationalizes experiences but he doesn't really express any real understanding or empathy for the people he's writing about. Which is surprising, considering how he prefers to talk about his mother's courage and devotion to providing for and protecting her children. There are also stunning moments when he belittles his mother on the sly... while propping himself up. His intelligence. His speed. His independence. His logic and realism. Eventually, at a very young age, he became better than his mother. He doesn't explicitly say this, but it is implied throughout. Ironically, one of his biggest tributes to his mother is her insistence that he learn to think for himself, that he question authority and systems. It becomes evident that his critical thinking and questioning led to an internal rejection of his mother, her faith and cultural beliefs. Due to the way life flows, there is also hope that his thinking will bring him full circle to a wholesome appreciation for everything his mother is and represents. 
 Common Themes: 
 Church and faith: Christianity as a white man's religion. Trevor Noah appears to have equal low regard for the practice of Christianity and tribal mysticism. He writes a great deal about his mother's faith but nothing of his own. In this way he provides the scope of a panoramic image (mother, tribe, cultural history) without the intimacy of his details (is he a Christ believer, follower, practitioner?). 
 Critical thinking and breaking cycles of bondage: Patricia Nombuyiselo Noah is a rebel with a cause. She didn't so much spend time questioning the systems and norms as much as figuring out how she could get around them to live her life on her terms. From an early age, she made decisions for her life and grew from the consequences and results of her decision. She was determined not to live in her mother's home on tribal homelands in obscure servitude as the second girl child in the family. She was even more determined not to raise children who were beholden to the past and the tribe. Her intelligence, her perseverance, her dexterity, her independence allowed her to venture where most Black people did not dare in apartheid South Africa. Bit by bit, Patricia Nombuyiselo Noah carved out a space for herself in a world that was completely against her. Then she made room for her son, Trevor. Eventually, she enlarged that space to include her growing family. When I first read the below passage, I thought, "Even if showing Trevor that the ghetto was not the world was all she had done, she would have indeed accomplished a great deal." 
 People thought my mom was crazy. Ice rinks and drive-ins and suburbs, these things were izinto zabelungu - the things of white people. So many black people internalized the logic of apartheid and made it their own. Why teach a black child white things? Neighbors and relatives used to pester my mom. "Why do all this? Why show him the world when he's never going to leave the ghetto?" 
 "Because," she would say, "even if he never leaves the ghetto, he will know that the ghetto is not the world. If that is all I accomplish, I've done enough." 
 Ms. Noah, you've done a superb job! 
 Independence and outsider: Trevor Noah writes about being an outsider everywhere he went at each stage of life he shares about. Perhaps more from that feeling than his mom's teachings, he grew to be fiercely independent. It also seems clear that his fondest days were when it was just him and his mom. Before the family expanded and he became an outsider in his own home. In some instances it seems the idea of independence and being an outsider morphed to mean the same thing and become somewhat interchangeable in the retelling of his stories. 
 Power and impact of choice: At one point he writes: "Nobody wants to be rich. People want to have choices. Money gives you choices." Perhaps overall, he dissected his movement through the world as varying levels of opportunity and choice. On some level, he may truly believe that money equals choice and translates to power. Perhaps he thought as he took advantage of his opportunities he could create the power to choose his life as well. Ultimately, he has. However, the glaring power moves he made in Born a Crime were when he accepted the benefits of being mixed/colored/lighter skinned in black and white communities when doing so put other black people at a severe disadvantage and occasionally harm's way. 
 My mother used to tell me, "I chose to have you because I wanted something to love and something that would love me unconditionally in return." I was a product of her search for belonging. She never felt like she belonged anywhere. 
 Love, discipline and rebellion: Noah thinks his mother was too hard on him, but it seems like she let him get away with a lot just from exhaustion. In many ways he parallels his life with his mothers' life. Her quest for love and belonging became his. Her need to discipline him birthed his need to out-maneuver her and perhaps show her how little he needed her in general. On the flip side, he also viewed her rebellion as his natural inheritance. 
 Freedom: There is a strong cord of freedom flowing throughout the stories Trevor Noah shares. As a concept, reality, illusion, wish, hope... as something somehow always out of reach. A couple of times, regarding his own troubles and the poor Black South African community in general, Noah writes, "They're free, they've been taught how to fish, but no one will give them a fishing rod." At one point, he thanks someone from a privileged class for giving him a rod. The analogy has a false ring to it. Or perhaps it's simply incomplete. The poor, oppressed and disadvantaged people of the world are not incapable of enjoying their freedom because the lack the tools to nourish it. The poor, oppressed and disadvantaged people of the world are prevented from accessing resources (farmable lands, drinking water, washing water, bodies of water with fish, etc.). He actually writes about how the South African government purposefully removed groups of people from their tribal lands and forced them onto near barren lands and locked them in with walls and guns. When apartheid fell, the people pretty much stayed where they had been put for the last century, i.e. Soweto and Alexandra. The irony of looking to your oppressor for a handout is painful. The way around that is to exercise your freedom. Make your way to the resource you need and figure out how to nourish yourself with the tools on hand. Usually the only tools we have are our own two hands. However, necessity is the mother of invention. The poor, oppressed and disadvantage people of the world have been made to think that their better life is on the other side of a wall. In other words, that they need their oppressors. They don't. They only need access to resources that cannot be owned, but that men the world over continue to capitalize on and create barriers around. 
 Language and Communication: One of the most beautiful illustrations in Born a Crime, is Trevor Noah's use of language. He speaks several languages and learned at an early age that language, not skin color is the true indicator of belonging and community. When you speak a person's language you are able to speak to their heart (paraphrased). Even as he shared how he was able to switch from being an outsider to an insider by speaking the language of the group he was attempting to appear like or to infiltrate, he also showed how speaking the same language with no common understanding is as disastrous as speaking different languages while working towards the same goal. In some ways, Born a Crime is a micro study of how communication between and within groups can go awry and also how it can tie us all together.
Love love love this audiobook!!

Trevor Noah is - in my mind - one of the funniest people on this planet. And this book just proves what an amazing storyteller he is! When I finished this book on Saturday I had the urge t hug someone...seriously. I grew up in such a different place and to read about what he had to deal with and how he had to grow up, it's amazing how he kept his humour this whole time. His mother sounds like the most incredible person who you immediately like and respect. I can't even press enough how much I wish everyone would read this book, it's inspiring!

This book was... amazing. I've watched Trevor Noah sporadically on The Daily Show, not enough to consider myself a "fan." But this book. This. Book. I will say that I experienced it by audio book, read by the author, and I specifically recommend that. His experiences are enhanced by his use of accents and language. I just can't recommend it enough.
This book was well-written, insightful, eye-opening, hilarious, and one of my favorite reads this year. I highly recommend.
No words yet.

Whoa. This hit me hard. Before this novel, all I knew of Trevor Noah was that he was the new host of The Daily Show and that he was from South Africa. Now, consider me a true Trevor Noah fan for life. This book has nothing to do with Trevor's life in America, or his experiences as a Hollywood celebrity, or how he feels about American politics. Instead, it is a gripping memoir that nearly had me in tears several times, had me laughing out loud at other points, and had me knowing that I will remember this book for the rest of my life. I learned so much about South Africa, about institutional racism, and about human experiences that I will never have to face. If you decide to pick this book up, I highly recommend the audiobook. Trevor as a narrator is nearly as remarkable as his skill in writing the memoir itself. I cannot recommend this book enough, even to those who do not typically enjoy nonfiction or memoirs or autobiographies. It exceeded all expectations I had. 5 stars. Near perfection.

I've read a lot of celebrity members, but this was probably my favorite. Noah managed to add humor to truly dark times in his life and in the world. I think his journey is amazing, and I can't wait to see what else he accomplishes.

Trevor Noah is an excellent storyteller; balancing the horrors of apartheid with the comedy of everyday life. His recollections are heartbreaking, charming, funny and endearing all at once. Both the audiobook and hardcover are thoroughly enjoyable.
Thoroughly impactful and enjoyable.

Lighthearted 
 Sincere 
 Down to earth 
 Inspiring

I really thought this book was going to be a downer, and I braced myself for a sad story. I'd never heard of Noah Trevor, so I took the content at face value. This is heartbreaking material. I couldn't have been more surprised at how funny his story turned out to be, and how well I related to it. Mothers are nothing if not universal.

This book is the kind of book that leaves you enraptured. I had the pleasure of simultaneously reading and listening to the audiobook and myself enraptured by the tales of the authors resiliency from boyhood to manhood . 
 It is a book imbued with wisdom, and through the author's minds eye one gets to see the african fabric is so clearly elucidated one feels deeply involved in the world. I will end my review by saying ; if you, the reader wants a reason to read this book; I would say read it for the love between a mother and her son . This is so as this book tells one of the greatest love story between a mother and her son. (#PatriciaNoahisMomGoals ) 
 10 stars. 
 Favourite Quote: 
 My mother took me places black people never went. She refused to be bound by ridiculous ideas of what black people couldn't or shouldn't do. .... My mom raised me as if there were no limitations on where I could go or what I could do. When I look back I realize she raised me like a white kid--not white culturally, but in the sense of believing that the world was my oyster, that I should speak up for myself, that my ideas and thoughts and decisions mattered. 
 We tell people to follow their dreams, but you can only dream of what you can imagine, and, depending on where you come from, your imagination can be quite limited. 
 Growing up in Soweto, our dream was to put another room on our house. Maybe have a driveway. Maybe, someday, a cast-iron gate at the end of the driveway. Because that is all we knew. But the highest rung of what's possible is far beyond the world you can see. My mother showed me what was possible. The thing that always amazed me about her life was that no one showed her. No one chose her. She did it on her own. She found her way through sheer force of will. 
 Perhaps even more amazing is the fact that my mother started her little project, me, at a time when she could not have known that apartheid would end. There was no reason to think it would end; it had seen generations come and go. I was nearly six when Mandela was released, ten before democracy finally came, yet she was preparing me to live a life of freedom long before we knew freedom would exist. A hard life in the township or a trip to the colored orphanage were the far more likely options on the table. But we never lived that way. We only moved forward and we always moved fast, and by the time the law and everyone else came around we were already miles down the road, flying across the freeway in a bright-orange, piece-of-shit Volkswagen with the windows down and Jimmy Swaggart praising Jesus at the top of his lungs. 
 People thought my mom was crazy. Ice rinks and drive-ins and suburbs, these things were izinto zabelungu--the things of white people. 
 So many black people had internalized the logic of apartheid and made it their own. Why teach a black child white things? Neighbors and relatives used to pester my mom. "Why do all this? Why show him the world when he's never going to leave the ghetto?" Because," she would say, "even if he never leaves the ghetto, he will know that the ghetto is not the world. If that is all I accomplish, I've done enough

Wow, what a book. This has got to be my favorite celebrity memoir. Trevor Noah writes about growing up in post-apartheid South Africa in almost perfectly told short stories. Some stories are sad, some hilarious, but all are utterly compelling. The chapter about how petty crime in "the hood" operates is one of the best and most sympathetic pieces about crime and poverty that I've read.

I cried. I laughed. I prayed. So many feels. I feel like I've been through several history lessons they don't teach you here in the U.S. 
 I remember talking about the idea of being multi-racial at a summer internship. One of the leaders told me she always felt like people make up multi-racial individuals to be the bridge to racial reconciliation when she really just feels like a wall of fucking hostility. Trevor Noah. Damn... 
 The thing is, it's not all just about race. Social constructs, patriarchy, a justice system that doesn't give people the tools to get out... 
 My words are not eloquent. Read his instead. Even if you don't know who he is, I still feel like this is an important read.

This was very enjoyable in audio, and I'm not sure what my experience would have been in print. Trevor Noah writes about his childhood growing up "colored" in South Africa, which you will learn, as a reader to this book, how that is different from white or black or Indian. Despite studying apartheid in school (or so I thought) I had no clear concept of the complexity of the system, intentionally designed to put people at odds with one another. 
 Trevor Noah was quite a character, running from his mother and selling bootleg music. He has some deeper experiences such as an abusive stepfather, but most of the book is just about everyday life with the backdrop of the politics as they touched his life. 
 Of interest to me, while a minor element of the book, is some comparison between South Africa and other countries in the way they approached native populations, how they educate their current students on their past, and what lingers today.
What a wonderful, touching, funny and eye-opening book. The Audible version features Trevor Noah himself ... great narrator of his own story.
Amazing story. Amazingly well written.

Wow. Riveting, funny, moving. I couldn't stop listening to the audiobook, and I'm dying to talk about it with other people. I wish I could listen to more stories by Trevor. Hi memoir is beautifully told and full of wisdom. LOVED IT AND HIGHLY RECOMMEND IT!!!
so. so. good. Get the audio book - you want to be able to listen to Noah speaking Xhosa and Zulu.

This is a brilliant, brutally honest, humorous account of Trevor Noah's life growing up in pre and post apartheid South Africa. 
 Throughout the book Mr. Noah's charisma and humour shines through his writing. He is frank about his many wrong doings as a youngster but relates the stories in such a way the reader is often laughing out loud at his pranks. 
 Trevor talks of his family openly, his obvious high regard for his mother even when she is chastising him shines through and gives a unique insight into the character of the woman who survived many harsh events while teaching her oldest son real life values that he needs to live by to be an upright citizen and human being. He talks about the abuses imposed on himself and his mother by a step father/husband and corrupt system, all of which taught him the kind of person he should never be. 
 I heartily recommend this book to anyone familiar with Trevor Noah as the very funny comedian that he is and also to anyone interested in how life was for the various factions of non whites during the unsettled times surrounding pre and post apartheid in South Africa. 
 I bought a hardback copy of this book on amazon.com and chose to review it
This book is a treasure. I don't often read biographies, but Trevor Noah's was fantastic.

I am a fan of the Daily Show. When Jon Stewart retired from the show, I quit watching it regularly; although I have caught a few episodes during this election season and have been impressed with the new young host. So, I thought I'd give his new book a read. 
 I was surprised - it has absolutely nothing to do with his 'day' job as a comedian. The book does a great job of painting a chilling picture of life in South Africa both during and after apartheid. 
 "In America you had the force removal of the native onto reservations coupled with slavery followed by segregation. Imagine all three of those things happenign to the same group of people at the same time. That was apartheid. " 
 "What I do remember, and will never forget, is the violence that followed. The triumph of democracy over apartheid is sometimes called the Bloodless Revolution. It is called that because very little white blood was spilled. Black blood ran in the streets". 
 Noah was/is smart... and spent time as a street hustler.. he observes "As soon as things start going well for you in the hood, it's time to go. Because the hood will drag you back in. It will find a way." 
 However, not all the villains in this book are white. His mother is the victim of horrific domestic abuse; and despite her attempts to file charges, the police do nothing. Even after shooting her in the head ... he spends no time in jail. It's appalling. 
 Yet, Noah resists the temptation to respond to violence with violence... this book doesn't get into his career, and how we went from the hood in Johannesburg to The Daily Show - hopefully we can read about that in his next book!

I loved this book and since absolutly love Trevor Noah. 
 The book is so funny but also very insightful. 
 Listen to the audio book read by Trevor himself and you are in for a treat!
Wonderful audiobook. Learned about SA and his life.
A must read! Trevor Noah is funny and witty as he tells sad, tragic, and inspiring stories of his life in South Africa.

Read Larry's review. 
 Rather eye-opening stories.

What a crazy life he has led and how different it is now! Interesting glimpse into a country and culture I know nothing about. It skips around a bit time wise which is a tad confusing, and it's not a very humorous story (only occasionally), but fascinating. I need a part 2 to learn how he left South Africa!
Just really good - Listen to Trevor read his own book, its totally worth it!

This was a very entertaining, funny (sometimes REALLY sad) story of Trevor growing up in South Africa with a religious mother and an abusive stepfather. 
 I really enjoyed the audible version of this book with Trevor Noah reading. Dude highlights some funny and sad times in his life. I love the way he was able to weave his humor into telling the story of his life.

Everyone should listen to this book. It's way better on audio to hear Trevor speak the African languages and share his own words of his incredible life. I had no idea he had come through so much. I have an even greater respect for him after hearing this book.

5 Stars - Superb book!! 
 Words cannot describe how much I love this book and yet here I am writing a review. You may know Trevor Noah as (to my knowledge) the most well-recognized African (South African to be exact) comedian or as the newish host of the satirical news program The Daily Show. Full disclosure, I love Noah's comedy style and his stand-up shows (at least the ones on Youtube and Netflix) as well as The Daily Show. However, even if his comedic style isn't your type this book is worth reading. 
 In Born a Crime, Noah weaves the story of his childhood and young adulthood with history and implications of Apartheid, and his mother's life. This book seems part autobiography and part history book. In other cases that combination may not work but for Noah and his story the reader must understand, at least on a basic level, Apartheid and how it shaped Noah's life. 
 I'm ashamed to say that before reading this book I didn't know much about apartheid. Yes, I knew what it was and that Nelson Mandela was instrumental in bringing it down but I had no idea how it worked. Noah explains that as a form of control over the black South Africans, white people divided, categorized and pitted the black South Africans against one another. The two main groups were: Zulu and Xhosa. Noah describes Apartheid as perfect racism. It was well studied and carefully implemented. Noah says it best: 
 "In America you had the forced removal of the native onto reservations coupled with slavery followed by segregation. Imagine all three of those things happening to the same group of people at the same time. That was apartheid." p. 20 
 This book gives a nice introduction to apartheid while simultaneously learning about the author's life. 
 Now, let me address the title. He was born to a black mother and white father: a crime. I had to take time and think about what that title meant. Noah describes some of the things he had to endure because he was not supposed to be born by apartheid standards, at least with the parents he had. I'm still struggling to wrap my mind around the concept. It's something that I, a white woman, cannot relate to in the least bit but it's important to learn and understand. 
 While I can't relate to the discrimination and ostracization Noah, and black South Africans more generally, faced I can relate to certain elements of his upbringing. The big one is the Christianity. Noah's mom was a devout Christian. Three different church services, at three different churches every Sunday, that's what Sunday held for the author. God and Jesus were the center of all decisions. This is something I can relate to. My parents were devote Christians and so were their children - in name at least. I won't say much more because his church experiences were so similar to mine and I don't want to give it away. Just read the book. (Sidenote: thankfully my parents aren't that.... let's say devoted anymore and haven't been for awhile). 
 The last thing I'd like to touch on is his mom. As much as this book is about Trevor Noah, it's just as much about his mom. At times, this book reads like a beautiful, heartbreaking ode to his mother. She worked her ass off and defied the odds. She went against the grain of what was expected of a woman but of a black South African woman. That translated into the way she raised her son. It's fascinating to read about their relationship because in the context of South Africa during and even after apartheid what she did was so unusual. She faced riots, sexism, domestic violence, and being shot in the face . There is no other word for her other than incredible, a powerful force. 
 So, with all of that being said, or written, please do yourself a favor and go read this book. You won't can't be disappointed.

Wow! As I listened to this remarkable book, read by the author, I was struck again and again by how little I know about South Africa. With humor as a back drop, Trevor Noah weaves the stories of how he and his mother navigated life in the racially driven world that was South Africa in the 1980s and 1990s. I often had to remind myself that Noah was born in 1984 and these were current events he was speaking of in his book. It was truly an eye-opener and I loved it!

This is a funny and gritty autobiography that everyone should read. I have a new appreciation for Trevor Noah. I would have loved to have seen a picture of his mom in the book after he described how beautiful and strong she is.
Loved it! So so funny and so so touching and insightful.
4 stars, lots of laughs, a few tears and a genuine miracle. A glimpse of life as a colored person who identifies as black during and after apartheid.
