As a POC I could well empathize well with many things in Born a crime. The more so, when I myself was born in an ex-colonized country. There's a spirit in ex-colonized countries, as the author puts it, an 'aspiring to whiteness'. I love this paragraph, and how the perspective flips: 
 Colored people had it rough. Imagine: You've been brainwashed into believing that your blood is tainted. You've spent all your time assimilating and aspiring to whiteness. Then, just as you think you're closing in on the finish line, some fucking guy named Nelson Mandela comes along and flips the country on its head. Now the finish line is back where the starting line was, and the benchmark is black. Black is in charge. Black is beautiful. Black is powerful. For centuries colored people were told: Blacks are monkeys. Don't swing from the trees like them. Learn to walk upright like the white man. Then all of a sudden it's Planet of the Apes, and the monkeys have taken over. 
 The book is also about the author's relationship with his mother. In the very first chapter, he drops a bomb 'shot at the back of her head'. And we find out in the end what really happens. Faith plays a large part. Miracle too. It plays on our emotion (heartbreaking) as mother and son become distant and we see the whole futility of arguments. Every chapter has a twist, some kind of irony, sweet romance or luck (as his friend Andrew bequeathed him a CD writer and 'changed his life'). 
 There are so many quotable sentences and words of wisdom in this book that it is hard for me to choose. Born a crime makes me laugh, makes me think and reminds me of my own childhood living in poverty. 
 In Germany, no child finishes high school without learning about the Holocaust. Not just the facts of it but the how and the why and the gravity of it--what it means. As a result, Germans grow up appropriately aware and apologetic. British schools treat colonialism the same way, to an extent. Their children are taught the history of the Empire with a kind of disclaimer hanging over the whole thing. "Well, that was shameful, now wasn't it?" 
 In South Africa, the atrocities of apartheid have never been taught that way. We weren't taught judgment or shame. We were taught history the way it's taught in America. In America, the history of racism is taught like this: "There was slavery and then there was Jim Crow and then there was Martin Luther King Jr. and now it's done." It was the same for us. "Apartheid was bad. Nelson Mandela was freed. Let's move on." Facts, but not many, and never the emotional or moral dimension. It was as if the teachers, many of whom were white, had been given a mandate. "Whatever you do, don't make the kids angry." 
 The unemployment rate, technically speaking, was "lower" in South Africa during apartheid, which makes sense. There was slavery--that's how everyone was employed. When democracy came, everyone had to be paid a minimum wage. The cost of labor went up, and suddenly millions of people were out of work. 
 And I'll finish with the last quote, my favorite: 
 I don't regret anything I've ever done in life, any choice that I've made. But I'm consumed with regret for the things I didn't do, the choices I didn't make, the things I didn't say. We spend so much time being afraid of failure, afraid of rejection. But regret is the thing we should fear most. Failure is an answer. Rejection is an answer. Regret is an eternal question you will never have the answer to. "What if..." "If only..." "I wonder what would have..." You will never, never know, and it will haunt you for the rest of your days. 
 I haven't picked a memoir for a long time, and can't regret picking this one. 
 Beautiful, entertaining, thought-provoking, emotional read.

After listening to this book (narrated by Trevor Noah himself), I'm quite amazed at the man Trevor Noah has become despite his upbringing. In a series of essays, Trevor Noah details growing up in South Africa, from stories of rampant racism (Apartheid was still in place when he was born), to dating, to domestic abuse. Everything was told with an honest and frank assessment that made the story that much more touching and realistic. 
 Trevor Noah was born to a black mother and a white father during Apartheid, which was illegal. Despite knowing about Apartheid and its general horrors, I've never truly read about it, so listening to Trevor's story was both eye-opening and horrifying, such as when he and his mom couldn't be seen together in public because he was colored and she was black. Throughout the story, his mother was truly the amazing one. This woman didn't let other people's views and beliefs rule her life, although it saddens me to say that later in life she could not get out of the cycle of domestic abuse that women sometimes find themselves in. What amazed me even more was the police's treatment toward the husband, which was disgusting. 
 Trevor's memoir is one worth listening to. Not only is it a daily look into Apartheid and its impact on the people, but it's also an unique perspective in that he was colored and found himself torn between both part of him. It is also a story about the resilience of humans in the face of hardship and hopelessness. As the audiobook is narrated by Trevor Noah himself, I would highly recommend listening to the audiobook.

Really enjoyed Trevor Noah reading this book. I'm not sure who else could have spoken all of the different South African languages. While some of the parts of the book were pretty amusing, mostly I was just amazed at the different ways he came up with to survive.
So. Good. I had heard of Trevor Noah before reading this book, but I didn't know the first thing about him. His story, and his writing voice, are fantastic and engaging. Highly recommended!
4.5 I was genuinely surprised by how funny and good this book was! I strongly advise listening to this in audiobook format. Trevor Noah's voices are great!

Fantastic. Truly fantastic. Also this begs you to listen to it to an audiobook since it is read in Trevor Noah's wonderful voice and since there are a variety of phrases in different South African languages that benefit from being pronounced.

"Born a Crime" is a compelling, page-turning memoir, but how Noah turned to comedy as a career is never explored. His mother, though, has an in-depth portrayal. Her philosophy of life and her depth of faith is amazing. Noah also shares insights into his younger self, his family, and his culture. Since events are not told chronologically, the reader may sometimes get confused with what is happening when. Some chapters are abrupt but others are longer and more developed. Overall, though, his writing is humorous and sensitive subjects are handled skillfully.

I bought the book because I watch the Daily Show and think Trevor Noah is funny. Wow did I get much more than that. I heard the audible version, which I recommend 100% as you hear his impressions and when he speaks the different African languages. This book is honestly an ode to his mother, Patricia Noah, and their journey together. It's about a child born at the end of apartheid, about racism, about machismo, about social constructs, about adversity, about family, about never losing the sense of humor, it's about the importance of understanding one another, and so much more. Newly found respect on the author, great storyteller.

If you've never used Audible, it's worth using the free credit they give you for this book as performed by the author. Reading it will only give you half of what this story is. Hearing him speak Zulu, Afrikaans, Xhosa, and other languages as he tells the stories of his childhood was incredible. Great book.

Both a memoir of Trevor Noah's life and a brief history of apartheid in South Africa. Each chapter begins with information about life in South Africa -- the many languages spoken, the mix of tribes and settlers, societal norms in South Africa -- and Noah then connects his story to that history/information. The book does not discuss his current life or rise to fame, it is very much about his roots, his childhood, and, most importantly, his mother.
Couldn't put this one down. wow.
Highly recommend the audiobook version read and performed by Trevor. Worth it just to hear his pronunciation of Volkswagon.

I now have a better understanding of Nkechi Amare Diallo (aka Rachel Dolezal - remember?), though that was hardly the intent. I have a better understanding of a lot of things: Apartheid, culture, linguistics, tribalism, poverty, identity, identity politics... 
 Mainly Apartheid. 
 For many Americans, their understanding of Apartheid is this: there was a racist government in South Africa. It was set up by the British, or the Dutch - one of those racist imperial colonizing powers... They imprisoned Nelson Mandela for 27 years. They released him after international pressure and much singing. He became president, unified the country, and South Africa has lived happily every after ever since. 
 I wouldn't be surprised if for many Americans it's actually much less than that. 
 When Noah talks about Apartheid being intentionally set up as a racist government, it's jarring. The architects of Apartheid looked around at all racist governments throughout history and used what they could to gain and maintain power. A little from the Third Reich, a little from the British, American Slavery... It's weird to think of people being so callous to humanity. 
 But then I think of all those others... They didn't just... happen. The Holocaust had architects. Slavery had architects. Jim Crow. And though "architect" or "designed" may be too strong of a word for many of the famines that ravaged India while they were under British rule, they were certainly man-made. 
 Even today in America, we're living in cities designed by redlining, and the consequences of slavery are being passed down - even to the seventh generation. 
 Noah explains that the unsavory history of South Africa is taught in South Africa much in the same way that the unsavory bits of American history is taught in America - it happened, it's over, let's move on with things. 
 Contrast that to how Germany teaches about the Holocaust, or Japan teaches about the invasion of Manchuria. 
 Noah lays out what it was like to be born into a system where his very existence was a crime. Interracial relationships were illegal. (But of course they happened.) 
 And he got a glimpse into a variety of lives. The white life, the black life, the "colored" life. Race relations are complicated in America. But damn. To many people, he looked white, but he identified as black - and hung out with mainly the South African Black population. (Hence the deeper understanding of Dolezal...) But more than that, he was legally recognized as neither, but rather "coloured" by the South African government. 
 Humanity's key task is understanding how we relate to others. It's understanding them, or trying, and developing a better understanding of ourselves in the process. 
 With empathy and love, Noah exposes the most vile scoundrels of his life, and sometimes he's the one being exposed. We join him in the understanding he's developed, and appreciate how much he's learned about himself in the process.

This book was chosen by my book club. Initially I didn't know all that much about Trevor Noah so I was unsure if his book would be interesting. I had seen a few clips before and thought he was funny, smart, and cute so I went for it. I was not disappointed at all. This book was facinating, funny, heartwarming, intense, and just generally fun. I also learned a ton! I didn't know very much about Apartheid since I was born in 1986 and was still little when it ended. Apartheid wasn't something I was ever really taught about, they would mention it briefly, but never really in depth. Great read. It really put things in perspective and made me feel very lucky!

If you like Trevor Noah, read this. Or if you've ever wanted to learn more about South Africa, but hate nonfiction, then read this. Or if you like autobiographies set against a historical background (the fall of Apartheid happened during his childhood) then read this. No history book or documentary can top firsthand experience. 
 If you want to find out more about his career, this is not the book for that information. At some point in the story, he is a rising comedy star, but he says it as a fact, not part of the story. This isn't a story about his career. This is a story about his childhood, his family (mainly his relationship with his mom), the complications of his race (half white, half black) and a story about South Africa. 
 This is now my 2nd favorite nonfiction I've ever read. It's more than just an autobiography of his childhood. There's a great deal of educational information here, things I wouldn't have bothered to learn in a dry old history book, but told in Noah's voice, it drew me in. Before each chapter is sort of a prologue to that chapter, over half of those contain historical fact and tidbits about the country, the other half contain facts and tidbits about Trevor, then he launches into the relevancy during the chapter. 
 But don't misunderstand me, this book is HILARIOUS as well as deep. He is a comedian after all. I laughed so hard several times, especially during "Go Hitler." There were times I started crying because I'm a big sap and some of the things he went through were horrible, and sound that much more horrible because of how he tells it. In a weird mix of intense and lighthearted. Inserting humor into situations that most would be hard pressed to find humor in.

Absolutely outstanding. Recc the audio version--hear it in Noah's voice. I really loved this book. It's not a comedy-- there are some funny parts, but it is enlightening, masterfully told and was informational on the culture in South Africa that I didn't know about. Read it. (listen to it).

If you're going to read one book in 2017, make it this one. Better yet, listen to it on audio - Trevor narrates the story perfectly, switching between his own voice and perfectly executed secondary voices for the others in his life. An incredible telling of an incredible upbringing.

"The compelling, inspiring, and comically sublime story of one man's coming-of-age, set during the twilight of apartheid and the tumultuous days of freedom that followed. Trevor Noah's unlikely path from apartheid South Africa to the desk of The Daily Show began with a criminal act: his birth. Trevor was born to a white Swiss father and a black Xhosa mother at a time when such a union was punishable by five years in prison. Living proof of his parents indiscretion, Trevor was kept mostly indoors for the earliest years of his life, bound by the extreme and often absurd measures his mother took to hide him from a government that could, at any moment, steal him away. Finally liberated by the end of South Africa's tyrannical white rule, Trevor and his mother set forth on a grand adventure, living openly and freely and embracing the opportunities won by a centuries-long struggle." 
 This book is amazing. That is all. Go preorder it. 
 I was reading this on my Kindle app and was highlighting like crazy. Trevor Noah has been an outsider all his life. In South Africa under apartheid there were four racial categories - white, black, colored, and Indian. Colored people were the descendants of interracial relationships in the past. There was no category for 50/50 black/white children because it couldn't legally happen. He chose to identify as black because that's what his mother was but he wasn't accepted there either. 
 Growing up both defined by and outside of such a strict racial hierarchy sharpened his insights. 
 "That is the curse of being black and poor, and it is a curse that follows you from generation to generation. My mother calls it "the black tax." Because the generations who came before you have been pillaged, rather than being free to use your skills and education to move forward, you lose everything just trying to bring everyone behind you back up to zero." 
 "British racism said, "If the monkey can walk like a man and talk like a man, then perhaps he is a man." Afrikaner racism said, "Why give a book to a monkey?" 
 He talks about history when describing why having a friend named Hitler wasn't considered strange. 
 "Every country thinks their history is the most important, and that's especially true in the West. But if black South Africans could go back in time and kill one person, Cecil Rhodes would come up before Hitler. If people in the Congo could go back in time and kill one person, Belgium's King Leopold would come way before Hitler. If Native Americans could go back in time and kill one person, it would probably be Christopher Columbus or Andrew Jackson." 
 "Holocaust victims count because Hitler counted them. Six million people killed. We can all look at that number and rightly be horrified. But when you read through the history of atrocities against Africans, there are no numbers, only guesses. It's harder to be horrified by a guess." 
 This is the story of growing up illegally because his mother fought to make a place for him even before the fall of apartheid. She was a visionary. However, even after apartheid there wasn't a place for him to make a legal living as easily as it was to make an illegal one in the townships. He talks about the saying about teaching a man to fish vs giving him a fish. He points out that it doesn't work if you don't also help him get a fishing pole. 
 This isn't the story of how he became a comedian or how he ended up taking over for Jon Stewart as the host of The Daily Show. That all comes later. This is the story of the world that shaped him into the person he is today. It is funny. It is horrifying. It is necessary reading. 
 I received this book from NetGalley. 
 This review was originally posted on Based On A True Story
Listened to the audio and very much enjoyed Trevor Noah's storytelling as well as his insights into race relations. He made me think and he made me laugh. Good stuff.
Read this book. Read it right now.

I really enjoyed the honesty of this book. Trevor doesn't placate readers with a rose-colored picture of who he is. He shows us his true self -- vulnerable, scarred, selfish, and human. His upbringing in apartheid South Africa as a child of mixed racial heritage underscored the vast racial divide and how it impacted black and coloured during apartheid. He offered a unique perspective -that he never felt like he belonged anywhere. I was forced to reflect on the circumstances of mixed race individuals in Canadian culture. While not subjected to the systemic racism that existed in South Africa, the struggle in belonging is complex.

5 stars 
 Very heartfelt, thoughtful, funny, and educational. I recommend the audio book as there is a lot of humor in the way Trevor voices the people in his life.

4,5-4,75* I enjoyed this book so much. An eye opening and honest story. My only complaint is that the time line was sort of messy and it bothered me when I was trying to keep track of everything. A part from that I just have to say, I want more!
Funny, poignant, and insightful.
Made me laugh until I cried and then it just made me cry. A must read.

Fuck, that last chapter was intense. This book gives a powerful insight into what it's like to grow up in South Africa during and soon after Apartheid. Through a number of essays, Trevor Noah tells his story. It's very interesting and, though a bit disjointed at times, very well written. Trevor being the great comedian he is, the book also manages to be very funny, at exactly the right moments.

I love Trevor Noah on The Daily Show, but was late to the party and really didn't know much about him. This book, brilliant vignettes and snapshots of his life growing up in South Africa, is at once moving, funny, poignant, sad, and incredibly insightful. I like him even more now (but am sure glad I wasn't his mom, given what a stinker he was. Plus I could never live up to the mom he describes). Highly recommended - personal, absorbing, intimate discussions of the realities of race and apartheid, then and now.

Read this in a day. So easy to imagine all these words in Trevor's voice, and who doesn't want to listen to Trevor's voice. Fascinating perspective. Enjoyable and provacative. I learned a great deal about South Africa I hadn't known, and I would have considered myself reasonably knowledgeable on the topic. Still astonishing how recent all this is.

I really enjoyed the exceptional story Trevor Noah tells. I was not expecting such a beautifully crafted narrative. The author talks about numerous episodes of his life, from when he was a little kid to his adulthood. In the book he explores his relationship with his family - his mother in particular -, his friends, his neighborhood, and what it meant to grow up during the apartheid. I especially enjoyed the chapter dedicated to his mother's life. In the same chapter, as a reader, you find yourself amused, surprised, and moved at the same time. The style is captivating and the story compelling. I strongly recommend it!

Listened to as audiobook narrated by Trevor Noah himself. 
 After having read several reviews of Noah's book and being a fan of his Daily Show I decided to give this a shot. Due to his talent to mimic voices and accents very well I chose the audiobook, which is definitely the best way to get hold of this story, because he does a fabulous job with the narration. All the different languages spoken in South Africa, the people's accent and the intonation in their voices are best listeend to. It is likely that most of the story's charme is lost if one reads it. 
 The narration was definitely the best part of the story. The plot doesn't follow a chronological order which sometimes can be confusing when the jumps backwards and foreward don't seem to follow a specific pattern. The story itself is interesting and surprising at many moments, most of all for someone like me that didn't know too much about South African culture and the people living there. 
 It was a lovely insight told with the example of one boy's life and I would recommend it to pretty much everyone that has a little time on their hand to listen to the audiobook.

I first saw Trevor Noah when he took over for Jon Stewart Daily Show. OK, so Noah was from South Africa. But I had no idea what that meant. Noah's book is shocking, funny, sad, amazing, and incredible, by turn. 
 Noah tells his story by jumping back and forth over his life, instead of telling it in narrative order. He seems to tell the framework of the story first--how his black mother met his white father, how having a mixed-race baby was punishable by imprisonment, and how the toddler Trevor had to meet his father in a public park in which all races could meet. 
 Noah doesn't make himself a saint in this book. He talks freely about his stealing, selling hijacked music, fights, and a week he spent in jail for driving a car with the wrong plates. 
 As the story develops, we are introduced to Noah's stepfather, Able, and his unpredictable, violent temper. His siblings are born much later in the story, and the casual mention (in the opening of his book) to his mother's being shot, is finally completed at the end of the book. 
 The book is spellbinding, a big story, well told. You will have a completely different view of Trevor Noah and his determination at the end of the book.
Very good book

An incredible memoir that was such a joy to read. Noah cleverly sneaks in inspiring jokes, lessons, and tragedy into anecdotes that tell a story of a heartbreaking, yet courageous, life. We can all learn a little something from each other, and Trevor Noah is no exception. The obstacles and hurdles he had to overcome to get where he is today explains so much when it comes to his core political and fundamental beliefs. I whole-heartedly recommend this book; you will not regret it.

Well played Trevor. I assumed the we would hear all about the life of a boy from Africa in New York. You, however, left that open for the next book. Nevertheless entertaining, having grown up on SA I have to say it is all about perspective isn't it?

Trevor Noah does an excellent job of explaining not only his own life, but the wider life of Apartheid in South Africa. He's the son of a black South African woman and a Swiss man at a time when having a child together was indeed a crime. His thoughts on the topic were incisive and fascinating.
Excellent read

I really loved learning about Trevor Noah's background and I am even more impressed by him. There were many funny stories but also a number of incredibly tragic stories and situations that he experienced. A great book to learn about recent South African life.

I loved it ( even overlooked the lack of suspense Trevor is known for, the poor switching of timelines and some of the poor analogies used), however my biggest issue and the reason for this rating is the continuous comparison of South Africa to America. He constantly makes references and seems to appeal to an American audience which leads me to believe that perhaps this books audience was the Americans. This definitely narrows the audience for the book and leads me feeling detached from his story.

I really liked this book, and I am usually not a fan of memoirs by comedians. However, this one is so rich and emotional. It entertains on many levels and is so much more than just a funny book. I listened to the audio book, read by Trevor Noah himself, and highly recommend it. His tales of growing up in South Africa during and after apartheid are humorous, insightful, educational, and depressing.

Noah's reading to the book only immersed your further in his childhood stories and gave you a true sense of his life in South Africa. One of my favorite autobiographical pieces. 
 I listened to it via Audible and I highly recommend it!
I really enjoyed this book -- well-told stories, interesting people, and excellent perspective.

The Amazing life of Trevor Noah 
 Five Amazing Stars* 
 I'm was just so excited to read and learn more about the amazing life of comedian and tv celebrity, Trevor Noah. I have been so fascinated about his birth in South Africa and how he made his working life to now end up on such a popular tv series in New York today. Such a wonderful story I thoroughly enjoyed this story so much. 
 We learn of the incredible troubles of living in South Africa. A county dealing with apartheid. How it affected each and every region, how they fought and how basically they ended up divided. Then fighting began cause lung the slaughtering to kill so many. 
 They had to them fight so hard. It latest for so many years. Even when apartheid ended the fighting still never stopped. It was time now to move on. 
 Such an amazing book. So full of hope and love for his family and the people home in South Africa too. Such an emotional read and a wonderful book. I couldn't put it down. A complete Winner!! 
 * I recommend this book to everyone!!
Insightful account of what it was like to live in apartheid. Trevor thoughtfully describes the absurdity of racism. It is worth the read.

This review originally appeared on the book review blog: Just One More Pa(i)ge. 
 I love Trevor Noah on The Daily Show - I think his social and political commentary is some of the best (hilarious, but one of the most cutting). I didn't really know much about his past, but I have always appreciated the perspective he brought to the table and his occasional references to sayings or events from his country of origin (South Africa). Pretty much in the world of late night comedy hosts, hilarious though they all are, any minority POV is something different/special. But I never really thought about it (Noah's history) beyond that. Well, this book gives so much information, much of which is hard (but necessary), to swallow. And it's an absolutely fascinating and entertaining read. 
 There are two main threads in this memoir. Partly, this is a collection of Noah's personal memories - events and moments that stuck out to him from childhood. Partly, this is a commentary on apartheid and racism, looking at it both specific to South Africa and commenting in a more general sense. The personal stories and real, touching, and (when appropriate) hilariously rendered. In a departure from the normal celebrity memoir topics, Noah does not talk at all about his rise as a comedian, how he actually got to where he is now, or his experiences as a mainstream and very popular figure. Instead, this book is exactly what the title claims "Stories from a South African Childhood" - which is refreshing. Noah shares scary stories (like jumping from a moving vehicle as a 9-year-old), hilarious stories (like shitting on the kitchen floor or the always amusing tales of dating blunders), personal and heartbreaking stories (like what his mother did with her life to give him opportunity or his stepfather's abuse and the threat to his mother's life as a culmination of that), insane stories (he burned down a house?! or their neighbor that tried to steal their dog), unbelievable stories (it was literally illegal for his parents to have him, since they were different races, and he could have been taken away from them at any time, if found out, because he was now a different race from both of them), and illustrative stories (like how he became a local pirated music "kingpin" and DJ). All of which are written with his characteristic style of straightforward, harsh truths with a soft-ish comedic edge. His life kept me on the edge of my seat and, more than once, made me yell "what?!" out loud - a number of his stories border on the ridiculous and for one person to have experienced it all...it's clear why he (or an agent) wanted his to turn it into a memoir. 
 Regarding the commentary on racism, it's handled flawlessly for a book like this. Between each of the chapters there is a little section with a comment on apartheid or other aspects of South African life that, concisely and clearly, demonstrated the insanities of apartheid (and racism in general) or illuminated key (sometimes funny) cultural differences. These were short and pointed, making you think and question, but not to the point where the enjoyability of the rest of the book is overshadowed. Essentially, these are the written versions of his late-night monologues, all focused on one topic. So good. Also, periodically throughout the book, there would be times in the middle of a story that Noah would stop and make a quick observation/explanation on how absurd some of the social constructs that made the experience what it was actually are. These were on anything from the universal way middle/high school friends communicate and set each other up with "dates" to the way the South African government took advantage of black South Africans' cultural differences in order to manipulate them into, essentially, keeping themselves down. There are also many other types of lessons, those that Noah pulls together himself and those that have come from his mother. He talks about the things like the oversight in the common adage "give a man a fish and you'll feed him for a day, teach a man to fish and you'll feed him for life" - sure then he'll know how to fish, but if no one is willing to give him a rod, what good does that do? He talks about the necessity of perspective when speaking of human rights atrocities - the prevailing Western point of view that that the worst offender is obviously Hitler versus the completely overlooked experiences of people across the African continent throughout history. He talks about his mother's lessons that in order to be whatever you dream to be, you need to have enough experiences that you are not limited by the fact that you don't know how to dream any bigger. He talks about, as a colored (mixed) kid who didn't ever fully fit anywhere, sometimes it's easier to be an insider as an outsider than an outsider as an insider (your own "people" are harder on you, if you don't conform, that those you might consider "other" to yourself). 
 Although apartheid has officially ended, every reader should be able to see the parallels between the remaining prejudices and inequalities, born of years of law-enforced racism, in South Africa and in the United States. This parallel, the enduring need for so much effort in both places before the effects can truly be overcome, might be (as an American reader) the most important take-away. Between the humorous childhood misadventures and the poignant mother to son lessons and bond, there is a distinct, if subtle, call to action. The drama in this book is what makes it hard to put down, but the historical and moral education (I learned a lot) is what will hit home. You won't be able to come away from reading this without taking both with you. Sometimes laugh out loud funny and sometimes so brutally serious that it's hard to listen to, this memoir has a little bit of everything and I definitely recommend it. 
 **I listened to the audiobook version and, after looking at the print version, I highly recommend the audio. Noah's accents and pronunciations are (obviously) perfect. And I know I would have come nowhere close to them if I had been guessing at it in my head while reading. It's a much more immersive and authentic feel and, more so than any audiobook I've listened to in the past, I think that makes a significant different here. The only thing is that the book is so good - so funny and so dramatic - that there were times that I did not want to stop listening and get out of the car when I reached my destination...
Mind blowing-read this book to just understand the cultural context of South Africa. His personal story is fascinating.
Always liked Trevor Noah and knew he had more to his story than he had already let on. The book was great. A bigger insight to his life and life as a South African.

One of the best audio books I've ever listened to. Trevor Noah has a gift for storytelling and is even more articulate and intelligent than we can tell from his TV appearances. I only wish the audio was longer!

I have read this really slowly, savouring each narration of events, which would have made anyone else in Trevor's shoes weak and scared to fight back, but clearly not him. The title reads Born a Crime, while I take it to be Born a Fighter. His mothers fortitude and never say die attitude is actually the cherry pick of this story, peppered with Trevor's unique sense of humour. I used to recommend to my friends the Daily Show ever since he took the reins, now I don't miss a chance to recommend this book. It's a must read for any and all readers and non-readers alike.
Great book! Love his sense of humor and totally respect his love for his mother

This is an amazing autobiography describing growing up in apartheid South Africa. Trevor Noah explains racism, poverty, single parenthood, religion, and being an mixed race child in a country where it is illegal for a white man and a black woman to have a child together. He had to call his father by his first name because otherwise people would discover the crime. 
 I expected this to be funny or a social indictment due to Noah's comedian profession, but instead it was very insightful and felt genuine. One of my favorite messages from the book is that "teaching a man to fish" only feeds him for a lifetime if you give him a fishing pole. He was given some computer equipment at 18 that allowed him opportunities that he would have never had despite his education and intelligence. Another message is that it is never too late to turn your life around and make better choices. He certainly had some wild years in his youth. 
 I can't wait until he comes out with his next book.

I LOVED this book! I really enjoy memoirs and especially celebrity comedian memoirs (Tina Fey, Mindy Kaling, etc) but this was so much more. Trevor Noah's voice speaks in every line - I could "hear" h tell these amazing stories as I read. I learned so much about South Africa and apartheid, but I was also wholly engaged by his funny, heartbreaking, totally entertaining stories. I *highly* recommend.
This is not well written. But, if you keeps logging through, you can learn a great deal about immediately post-Apartheid South Africa. I would say it's worth it. Approach it in small chunks!

** spoiler alert ** 
 The format of the story telling was hard to follow at first, but all the personal stories helped elevate the narrative about his mom and WHO DOESN'T LOVE A GOOD STORY ABOUT HOW MUCH A KID LOVES HIS MOM?? Hilarious, as always, and pushes the reader to consider how many untold stories there are through history of people inflicting harm on another people based on personal / group-based prejudices.

Loved this book. Listened to it as an audiobook with Trevor Noah narrating it himself. You don't have to be a fan of his or a fan of The Daily Show to be mesmerized by his fascinating childhood growing up in South Africa. To me, this book often felt like a love letter to his mother, an amazing woman who must be very proud of the son she raised. If you're expecting him to talk about how he became host of The Daily Show, you'll be disappointed. This is really about the events of his childhood and young adulthood, some scary and some funny, that shaped who he is today. My husband and I listened to it together and we both loved it.

This is a pleasant surprise. I simply wanted to listen to a comedy audiobook, and checked out Trevor Noah's latest, and it turned out to be one of the absolute best books I've ever 'read'/listened to on the subject of Africa and black issues. 
 There are plenty of funny stories about Trevor's childhood, and it's no Daily Show, but above all Born a Crime is an excellent introduction to all things South Africa. Even after visiting recently, I could never get a handle on how to explain the complexity of the country. Everyone in their own bubbles is a big problem. But Trevor Noah expertly maneuvers through different scenes--much of it due to his mixed background--and explains so much history with apartheid and the different tribes and the colored thing and life in the townships and life in the homeland and so on... Some through little lessons scattered about but mostly through his own personal tales which gives this sort of thing a lot of emotional weight as well as knowledge. 
 Another major theme of the book is that his mother is the main character, besides himself. What a woman. It is very sad what happens in the end, but even through the tragedy Trevor's positive perspective makes it somehow. He has a lot of heart. South Africa does of course have it's problems, yet after this book one has to be at least more empathetic. And maybe even optimistic in some way. In any case I am left with much newfound respect for Trevor Noah, after learning what he's been through. 
 Recommended most of all for visitors to the great state of South Africa~

This memoir was powerful and haunting. I had no idea of the complexities of South African racial categories, languages, and traditions beyond the laws and aftermath of apartheid. Trevor Noah reveals a difficult but full childhood and an amazing spirit.

A great memoir which I enjoyed reading and couldn't put down. It deals with some heavy subject matters including apartheid and domestic violence but is interspersed with Trevor's humour and wit and the stories are truly told so naturally, I often heard Trevor's voice in my head as narrator. I do need to add that Trevor's mother sounds like an amazing human being who for the most part, managed to keep true to herself, her faith, her values and her loved ones despite all the challenges she faced. I found that very inspiring.
Funny, fascinating, moving, and sobering. You'll never watch the Daily Show the same way again. Highly recommend listening to the audiobook to hear it in Trevor Noah's voice!

Trevor Noah is a South African comic. I have seen his funny segment comparing Trump to an African dictator, but haven't seen much else of his (maybe nothing). As a result, I probably came to his memoir of his childhood growing up in South Africa, Born a Crime, from a different vantage than most readers (having only heard him interviewed on NPR). His memoir is sometimes funny, but if that's what you're looking for - I wasn't - you probably want to look elsewhere. 
 Noah's memoir is an often-insightful exploration of the relationship between a mother and son, love, domestic violence and physical abuse, racism and color in South Africa, the effects of poverty on the impoverished, and more. I have friends who are "colored" in South Africa who have in the past attempted to explain the color system and their place in it - and I didn't get it. It makes sense now - as much as their system makes sense. (When my friends visited last summer, they asked for Trump stickers so as to put their own government's problems in context.) Noah's descriptions of the decisions one might make when poor - from my perspective, desperately poor - explains why he and others flagrantly skirted the law (e.g., often because that was the only available option). 
 Noah named people, some of whom probably would have preferred to not be named. For example, his stepfather attempted to kill his mother, saying, "You've stolen my life... You've taken everything away from me. Now I'm going to kill all of you (Loc. 4015). His mother was at risk before, but probably even more so now. Noah was as brutally honest about himself, describing a range of embarrassing behaviors and illegal acts, as well as smart and savvy ones. 
 Noah offered nuanced views of his world: You want to live in a world where someone is good or bad, where you either hate them or love them, but that's not how people are (Loc. 3868). He described the good in his abusive stepfather. He saw his mother's "hidings" as coming from a place of love (Loc. 3808). He allows his world to be as complicated as it is. 
 This is a man to watch.
Moving, funny, and I learned some things about South Africa under and after apartheid.

5 star read. Anything I want to say feels inadequate. Yes, he is a comedian and the book is funny and the stories are presented in an entertaining way but I hope the format doesn't minimize what readers could learn from his experiences and insight. I really hope he writes another book with the rest of his story once he found success and I would also love to know more about his mother, who sounds unimaginably strong. 
 The very first paragraph reads, "The genius of apartheid was convincing people who were the overwhelming majority to turn on each other. Apart hate, is what it was. You separate people into groups and make them hate one another so you can run them all." I know we don't label it as such here but it sounded so familiar, like he could be talking about our country today. 
 I also had an "Amen" moment when he was talking about the missing link to the ever popular phrase "give a man to fish and he'll eat for a day, teach a man to fish and he'll eat for a lifetime". Mr. Noah makes the excellent point that it's not enough to teach someone to fish, you also have to provide them with the rod. People need resources to succeed (and it's not a handout to get the resources because they still have to make good use of them). It sounded so simple when he said it and that's an outlook I will definitely hang on to. 
 I laughed at his anecdote about getting detention every day for being late. "The names of the kids with detention were announced at every assembly, and I was always one of them. Always. Every single day. It was a running joke. The prefect would say, "Detentions for today..." and I would stand up automatically. It was like the Oscars and I was Meryl Streep." 
 A Few Quotes from the Book 
 "[His mother was] estranged from her family, pregnant by a man she could not be seen with in public, she was alone. The doctors took her up to the delivery room, cut open her belly, and reached in and pulled out a half-white, half-black child who violated any number of laws, statutes, and regulations - I was born a crime." 
 "We tell people to follow their dreams, but you can only dream of what you can imagine, and, depending on where you come from, your imagination can be quite limited." 
 "Human beings like to laugh, and lucky for me pretty girls are human beings." 
 Find all my reviews at: http://readingatrandom.blogspot.com

READ THIS BOOK! How in the world Trevor ever made it to where he is, is a miracle. This book gave me a whole new view on him. I highly recommend listing to the audiobook because Trevor does such a great job putting emotion into everything he reads.

Wow - this book is fantastic! I haven't seen any of Trevor Noah's comedy, but I will definitely be checking him out after reading his memoir! Trevor is a great storyteller and he truly does have a great story to tell. Sometimes I don't find comedians funny in print, but Trevor's humour really came through in this memoir and made what could have been a heavy topic incredibly interesting and enjoyable. 
 I really liked the formatting of the book and how each chapter was prefaced with a bit of historical and cultural context . It was really interesting to learn about his experience growing up in post-apartheid South Africa and the identity struggles he faced growing up in a black family but being considered 'coloured' by the rest of society. 
 The most beautiful part of this book for me though was Trevor's relationship with his mom. His mother is an incredible woman and I really admired her spirit, tenacity, and unflinching faith. She went after the life she wanted and was an independent woman in a place where it wasn't easy to be one. The system worked against her, but nevertheless she persisted!

I did not "read" this book. I listened to it on Audible. Absolutely brilliant. I loved every bloody minute and think that Trevor Noah is a goddamn genius. Clearly he is so, so smart. The way he tells the story, with all the different accents and the acting out of parts, I would recommend listening to this one, rather than reading it quietly. 
 Trevor Noah paints the picture of growing up in Apartheid South Africa in a way that is at once so sad and heartbreaking, yet at the same time funny and rich and full of wisdom. 
 The story of his "matrix" dance date will make your heart fall out of your chest cavity. 
 You can only get this kind of three-dimensional, global, compassionate, earthy wisdom from real people with real life experience. I cannot say enough how good this book is. Kudos to you, Trevor Noah, and thank you for sharing yourself in this way with all of us!

This is WONDERFUL on audio. Noah's voice is fantastic, and the intensity and humor of his stories is all the better with his own voice. 
 I also clearly need to do some nonfiction reading about apartheid. I knew it was awful, but I had no idea about many of the particulars Noah mentions.

An example of why memoirs read by the author are some of my absolute favorite audiobooks. Noah jumping back and forth between languages, accents, himself at different ages - it adds so much. 
 Even if you're not up for the audio, you should know that a book by a comedian, talking about apartheid and its aftermath, is both as funny and as horrifying as you might expect.
Loved this book! Personal vignettes interspersed with historical info and commentary make it almost like a collection of short stories.
Great on audio.
Fascinating account of the early life of Trevor Noah and the events that shaped him - particularly the multi-lingual multi-cultural upbringing

Born a Crime, like its subtitle, is about Trevor Noah's childhood at the very end of apartheid in South Africa. And like the title, the fact that Noah was born to a black mother and a white father was punishable by five years in prison under the existing system. Even when apartheid ended and Nelson Mandela took over as president, many of the old structures remained, and it was difficult to live and survive in that system. 
 South African culture divided--and continues to divide--its races into four distinct groups: whites, blacks, Indians and coloreds. Under apartheid it was law that you were required to socialize only within your group, and whole communities--neighborhoods and even cities--were built to handle a particular group. Coloreds were traditionally people of mixed descent, and could be those with blended parents, or those whose ancestry was colored. What makes it even more complicated is that judges can rule a child colored, black, or even white, regardless of what their parents look like. Then his or her parents have to decide whether they both have to move to a different community, or separate so one will go with the child. 
 It's a totally different way of looking at race, and the apartheid rulers looked at how race was handled in many places--the United States, England, and other countries--before they came up with their structure. And it's an interesting part of the book. But it's not all of the book. Much of the story has to do with Noah's childhood being raised by a very strong, church-going mother. It's filled with humorous and interesting anecdotes, such as the time he and his dance troupe took their lead dancer named Hitler to a Jewish party, the time he spent a week in jail and what he learned, and his senior prom with the most gorgeous girl he had ever met that didn't speak a word of English. 
 It's a well-written book (at first I was sure it was ghost written and kept checking, but Noah apparently wrote it) and truly entertaining. I encourage you to get a copy.

Trevor Noah's upbringing would surprise most people. Born from an illegal mixed-race conception during apartheid in South Africa, he's a polyglot (including some of the cool native African languages with click consonants), went to church all day every Sunday as a kid, and experienced life as a mixed-race individual in a world where races weren't supposed to be mixed at all. 
 This memoir is excellent. At times heart-warming, at times educational, at times hilarious.

I don't think there are words to describe the richness of this book. If it was a movie it would be a block buster poetry. Shocking reality and wisdom given with honesty and humor. So many images and so much food for thought that, I think, will be with me for the rest of my life!

I've never seen The Daily Show, never knew Trevor Noah, but heard good things about this book so thought I'd give it a try. What a tragic childhood this young man had growing up bi-racial in South Africa during apartheid. The whole definition of what was "non-white" is atrocious, and the discrimination of same is astounding. Trevor even as a youth used humour to make sense of the crazy world he was growing up in. He gives us first person accounts through stories, that sometimes made me laugh, but often broke my heart, and sometimes made me cry. You will be shocked and saddened at the atrocities, but warmed by his incredible perseverance. 
 I only give it four stars due to the terrible editing! This should have flowed better. The are sometimes out of chronological order, and more than a few times the stories were stories within stories that I had read already. A bit confusing.

A lovely read. A beautiful story of a colored guy and his mom in Africa during and after apartheid. The book is written with light humor that turn tragic events into not-so-happy ones. No wonder it's written by a comedian and his mom is a ROCKSTAR!

'Born a Crime' is an interesting set of stories which tells of life in both apartheid and post-apartheid South Africa. The tales are sometimes funny, sometimes sad but always enlightening, it shines a light on this world many people didn't know about (I certainly didn't). It's well written and interesting from start to finish.

Loved it! Loved all the stories. Loved the style of writing. The book, and especially the conversations, is written in a stand up comedy style; which means as you read, you get to pretend to be a stand up comedian (which was personally great because I can't tell jokes to save my life). Trevor Noah highlights the childhood experiences that have influenced his life and who he is today. In addition to his stories, we get the South Africa story the events that made it what it is today. I especially loved this part, because first I know next to nothing about that part of the world, and second, it put Trevor's childhood's stories in a context and become vivid in the process. I didn't need pictures to visualize his neighborhoods. Trevor made them accessible through the descriptions and details. Finally, I loved getting to know his mother. What a strong woman, and I learned a thing or two about how I would like to raise my children (that is when I get them). I highly recommend this book!
wow!

Awesome audiobook (though I will be going back to the print copy too just to get a better sense of all the languages he was speaking throughout the course of his storytelling and reminiscing). It's great to hear his voice narrating his words and creating voices for the people in his life. What an incredible life's story he shares in this eloquent, poignant, funny, heartbreaking and ultimately uplifting audiobook.

This book was excellent. I wasn't sure what to expect, but the tone is the right balance of funny, informative, and emotional. Incredibly interesting - I thought I knew a bit about apartheid and its effect on people but this book gives a perspective that you won't get from "in 1987 there was X resolution and it created Y living areas..." -- it's really personal and hits home. And it's quite well written - he writes simply and clearly.
Loved the audio version, read by Trevor Noah

Wonderful story telling. This is probably my favorite read of the year. I loved listening to Trevor Noah narrate the audio book. The book discusses heavy topics as poverty, crime, racial tension, and revolutionary violence but maintains a level of comedic awareness that makes it hard to put down.

This may be the best book of the year. Trevor Noah's ability to weave together moments so funny I sat back and laughed, moments incredibly emotional and raw, and history of South Africa makes this hard to stop reading. I recommend listening to it. Noah talks a lot about language, and many of his stories involve speaking different languages. Hearing those languages made it much more powerful, and his narrating is fantastic.

I have enjoyed Trevor Noah's outsider take on our political landscape ever since he took over for Jon Stewart on The Daily Show. So I was very interested in reading more about him and his experience growing up bi-racial in Apartheid South Africa, where mixing of the races was strictly forbidden. 
 The book is a series of recollections, stories from Noah's childhood and stormy adolescence, as well as information on the history of Apartheid, how it was enforced and how Noah's family and friends managed to get on with their lives under its control. 
 Some of the stories work better than others. 
 After reading this book, I have to say that I came away from it with a great deal of respect for his mother Patricia. She refused to follow her assigned lot in life, which was to live in the black ghetto and clean houses for rich white people. Instead, she got a job in an office in Capetown where she met a Swiss businessman who became her friend, and later the father of her first son. 
 She was a very strong woman who found her own way in life, despite the rules and expectations of those around her, both black and white. 
 If you're a fan of The Daily Show and if you've always wondered how South African enforced its brutal segregation policies, I'd recommend this book.
An interesting account of the life of person born of mixed race in South Africa during the Apartheid era.

I have been watching Daily Show regularly. I also enjoyed his stand up comedy shows even though I got bored with most of stand ups. I was really excited to read his book and it lived up to my expectations. This book has got me laughing for five minutes straight and also very emotional and touched. 
 Trevor Noah's life was hard and tragic mostly. Not only he could not be seen with his parents in public (without devising special ways to make them look like they have a different relationship), he also grown up very poor. He was always the "outsider", not belonging to the white, the black, the Indians or the colored. But instead of feeling left out, he became a chameleon, with the ability to speak multiple languages and to make people laugh. He was mostly liked. In one of the stories, he get to know the "black Hulk" and he escaped being robbed because he's a polyglot. It was very amazing how he managed to use his skills for comedy to make light of his situation and being able to move on from the pain and trauma. 
 This book's main character at times seemed to be his mother. The rebellious, independent feminist was inspirational. It seemed like Noah's comedy out of tragic seemed to come from his mom, who joked that now Noah is the best looking person in the family because she got shot in the face! Noah's comedy and jokes sometimes make the reader forget what kind of tragedy he was actually in.

From beginning to end, I loved this book. It was very interesting to learn about his life through his words. I was both amazed and captivated by his stories. 
 The only thing I didn't like about this book is that it never specified his age and each chapter jumped around to different ages so you were kind of left guessing how old he was by the things he mentions.

Netgalley provided me with free digital access to this title in exchange for my honest opinion. 
 I've been a fan of Trevor Noah's comedy for a couple years now, so I was excited to get my hands on this from Netgalley. I've read South African authors before, but I feel like I learned a lot more about the multiculturalism than I did before.

Trevor's story will give the reader insights into Apartheid and the life growing up as a person born of a black mother and white father in a world where that was unacceptable and unlawful. Very funny, at times.

I would be totally happy reading books like this one for the rest of my life. Love the stories and seeing/experiencing the world through another person's eyes. 
 **metriculate is a weird word and the Google definition does not seem to match with the usage in this book....further investigation required**
Love Trevor Noah and I love him more after reading his story.
I wish they would've explained how he got to the US but I guess the point was to explain his life and culture in South Africa. It had kind of a violent then awkward ending.
I want to read this all over again.
Trever's mom is such a badass. I loved reading about their relationship and Trevor's childhood. So interesting to read from a perspective so different from my own.

An extraordinary, raw and often poignant book, I cannot recommend this enough. Even if you don't know about Trevor Noah and his work, read his book. It's nothing short of an experience - one that will stay with you for a very long time.

I listened to this as an audiobook and I implore you to do the same - it is wasted read, as Noah narrates the book himself and does such a stellar, special, intimate, incredible job. It is a memoir full of love, energy, humour and mischief, but it is equally a compelling and informative commentary on the end of apartheid in South Africa, with the most brilliant, strong, wonderful woman at the heart of it all (Trevor's Mum). It truly is a gem of a memoir, written an narrated by a such a clever, funny, excellent man. Highly, highly recommend.

"We tell people to follow their dreams, but you can only dream of who you can imagine, and, depending on where you come from, your imagination can be quite limited." 
 I picked up this book thinking it would be an interesting and entertaining story of how Trevor Noah traveled from South Africa to the world of stand-up comedy and political commentary. It was that, but also more. In these days in which racism seems to be accepted in this country by some, we need this reminder of how wrong that attitude is. The undercurrent through these stories of navigating first crushes and poverty and parental discipline and cultural issues is racism's insidious evil.

Someday (maybe it's today, I don't know) there will be an entire generation who has only known The Daily Show as hosted by Trevor Noah. I am not of that generation. I am of the generation who still remembers The Daily Show with Craig Kilborn. I am of the generation who was skeptical of Jon Stewart taking over (who could replace Kilborn?). I am of the generation who then watched the entirety of the Jon Stewart years and loved and respected him and came to believe that no one ever could replace him (who could possibly replace Jon Stewart). I say this because the truth is I've never really given Trevor Noah much of a chance. He seemed young and less political, more jovial, and, dare I admit it, a little too cool for me. He seemed to lack the experience and gravitas I'd come to expect from The Daily Show. And for no good reason, based on nothing but these assumptions (and also because I go to bed really early) I stopped watching The Daily Show. 
 I read his memoir because it was given to me, not because I sought it out, and in retrospect I both feel really bad about that and am really grateful it did find its way to me. Noah has a witty sense of humor, a solid comedic timing and an inherent likeability to him. But it's the wealth of experience and insight that makes this such a compelling read. Noah's stories focus on his childhood. They are at times humorous (the Go Hitler bit will kill you), at times painful, and in general paint a clear picture of life in South Africa during and following the end of apartheid. It is a memoir of poverty of an awkward teenager, of family dynamics, and race relations in South Africa. And it is, overall, something of a long love letter to his mother - an incredibly strong, independent woman who defied much of the rules and restrictions placed on her, and whom Noah clearly holds in the highest esteem. 
 It is certainly one of the most enjoyable memoirs I have read up late, and I humbly apologize for my earlier doubts of him. I have a new found respect for Trevor Noah. So much so I would gladly start watching The Daily Show again. Except, sadly, I still go to bed really early.

I was prepared for the laughter. I was not prepared for the crying. It's hard to describe just how much this book put my own childhood into perspective. I had a lot to say on the subject, but in the end it came off to me as too vulnerable and I decided no one really needed to hear it; what you need is to read (or listen to - Trevor does a brilliant job reading this for Audible!) this story for yourself. 
 I was a casual Trevor Noah fan before reading this book. I absolutely admire and respect him.
I listened to the audiobook, read by the author. I highly recommend listening to him read his story!

*4.5 stars* 
 First, go watch Trevor Noah. Then, read this in his voice. Such dark, anglo-humour that's sure to elicit laughs, gasps, and maybe even a few tears from around the Commonwealth. 
 Because the Americans just won't get it. It hits a little too close to home for them. 
 Also, as usual, the real hero of his life is his mother.
Quite simply an amazing book.

(Audiobook version). Excellent memoir about growing up under Apartheid in South Africa with a rule-breaking, progressive mother. Trevor Noah provides a clear voice for understanding the motivations and effects of white rule in SA, but also the economic and societal disenfranchisement of his family and friends. These observations on race, class, and poverty are even more poignant when paired with his particular humor and wit. One of the stories (the dance off) had me laughing so loudly in public, I turned more than a few heads. I would HIGHLY recommend the audiobook version as it is performed by Mr. Noah. As a native English speaker, the nuances of the diverse tribal languages are accessible in the audio format. Moreover, hearing these humorous, wrenching, and contemplative stories in his voice made them that much more personal. 
 Hands down my second favorite biographical novel of 2016 (second to When Breath Becomes Air). 
 *4.5 stars!*

One of my favorite autobiographies I've read (in this case, listened to) and I've never seen him on TV. Fascinating history. Really enjoyed the relationship between mother and son. Loved the Hitler story (will be thinking about that one for some time....a great tale that perspective is truly everything.)

I had never heard of Trevor Noah before I read this book. I had no idea who is was...and only read the book as it is my bookclub choice for June. This book made me realize, again, how lucky I am to be born in America. Our racial issues do not hold a candle compared to what the people in South Africa have been through. Great book, will make you think!
This was fantastic. Such a neat view into the life of a child in another country we know next to nothing about.

Absolultely loved it- he weaves the politics and the political ramifications of the time into his own childhood. He holds nothing back and it makes the reader connect current and past world events to real situations. Well written and engrossing. Highly recommend!
Phenomenal story- entertaining, touching and insightful. Loved every minute of it. His story should be made into a movie. Now I want to learn more about the apartheid in South Africa.
Pretty good. Written as a string of vignettes, and in a very casual style. Could have been about 25% shorter.

So many evening giggles and a few late night tears due to this fantastic piece of work. 
 I'm in love with Trevor's ability to tell a story and I was inspired by each and every chapter to really dig deep into the history behind each story told. 
 As a Christian, I valued more than anything the raw, comical approach to his mother's faith that intertwined in understanding his relationship with her throughout all of the trials and blessings. 
 Hoping for more from Trevor! He's a gem.

What a life! What a story! I really knew a whole lot of nothing about apartheid and learned a lot from this book, especially about reconciling the fallout after it was abolished. I liked how Trevor Noah included humor, but not in an overdone way, like some books I've read by comedians. I felt like there wee a lot of inconsistencies in the story that distracted me but still worth reading.
I listened to the audiobook and really enjoyed it. Noah is, as expected, an excellent storyteller. I also learned a lot about apartheid and post apartheid South Africa.

Read. This. Book. Better yet, listen to Trevor Noah read it to you. What an amazing surprise. Not a typical celebrity autobiography, but a beautifully written, heartbreaking yet joyous, compelling story of growing up "coloured" (!Xhosa mother and Swiss father) in apartheid South Africa, and growing up with an abusive step father. His reflections on these issues are insightful, powerful and brilliant. 
 "In any society built on institutionalized racism, race mixing doesn't merely challenge the system as unjust, it reveals the system as unsustainable and incoherent. Race mixing proves that taxes can mix, and in a lot of cases want to mix. Because a mixed person embodies that rebuke to the logic of the system, race mixing becomes a crime worse than treason." 
 His mother is a powerful woman, and the book reads much like an homage to her. Not a perfect woman, but a strong, Jesus loving, hardworking woman who understands the world. "The world doesn't love you. If the police get you, the police don't love you. When I beat you, I'm trying to save you. When they beat you, they're trying to kill you." Later Trevor talks about the police responding to his mother's repeated calls for help after being beaten by her husband (who would later shoot her in the head)- and their complete lack of concern or help. "That's when I realized the police were not who I thought they were. They were men first. Police second." 
 I could quote the entire book - he touches on so many important subjects - racism, brutality, poverty, love, abuse... "people love to say, 'give a man a fish, and he'll eat for a day. Teach a man to fish and he'll eat for a lifetime.' What they don't say is "and it would be nice if you gave him a fishing rod." He comes back to this analogy again- the importance of having the fishing rod is too often ignored. 
 "You want to live in a world where someone is good or bad. Where you either hate them or love them. But that's not how people are." 
 The book overall has a light, comedic feeling even though he is dealing with painful subjects. His wit shines through. He talks about his grandmother being afraid to hit him - when you hit black children they stay black- when you hit white children, they turn red and blue and green. 
 You should really listen to the book. You not only get Noah's comedic timing - you get to hear the multiple languages spoken by Noah. Absolutely beautiful. "When you make the effort to speak someone's language, even if it's just basic phrases here and there, you are saying to them, "I understand that you have a culture and identity that exists behind me. I see you as a human being."

An intimate, well-written, moving and shocking memoir - Trever Noah has more stories in his short life than many people have in twice the time. His experiences in apartheid, his abusive and attempted-murdering stepfather, his limbo status, and all of his life problems - so many trials. A great read, and even better listen, narrated by Trevor himself.

If you have not read born a crime by Trevor Noah, you're missing out! I listened to it on audio and he is amazing. The way he explains the complex and ridiculous system of apartheid and its effect on his own life is both humorous and enlightening. If you watch his stand up documentary on Netflix you get an idea of just how many challenges he has to overcome to be where he is today.

This book could be my favorite this year... It's hard for me to comprehend that, as I've read quite a few really, really good books this year, but this one in particular was so informative and interesting and heartfelt and charming. I'm sure the audio version is amazing. I'll have to give it a listen sometime, maybe beg my local library to add it to their digital collection. 
 I'm a fan of Trevor Noah. I think he's charming and intelligent, and I think he's done a good job on The Daily Show. I enjoy watching him. Honestly, even if I set all that aside, I still want to recommend this book to everyone I know. It's just that well-written and provides such an insight. It's his personal experience, his memoir, but because he is both an intelligent man and a comedian, he makes his story entertaining, endearing, and emotional. 
 This must be said too: Trevor's mother is one of the most amazing women I have ever had the pleasure of reading about. She is such an admirable human being, a force to be reckoned with, an almost mythical figure. I love her. 
 UPDATE 3/2/2017: This is not related to the book, but I'm going to see Trevor do stand-up in Ithaca in April, AND I'M SO EXCITED ABOUT IT, EVERYONE!!!
Because I listened to the audiobook I now "hear" Trevor's imitation of his Mom occasionally admonishing as a part of my internal dialogue.

I admit I don't know much about South Africa, pre or post-apartheid. Noah's autobiography was truly eye-opening for me. Two passages of the book really resonated, especially now after Charlottesville as we debate healthcare. The first, it's not just enough to teach a man to fish, but how about giving him a rod while you're at it. Second, the difference between how South Africa and the US teach their racist history compared to the rest of the world. 
 And I want to hug him. As a single mom of a very, um, independent son, his loving-but-strained relationship really connected with me.
I want a billion more books from Trevor Noah. This audiobook was EXCELLENT.
I am in awe of the grace and humor with which this man approaches everything from racism (have you see his interview with Tomi Lahren??) to the threat of nuclear winter. Talk about resilience.

I rank this as amazing not because it's great literature but because I can't stop thinking about it weeks and weeks later. I've brought up stories from it in half a dozen conversations. I want my kids to read it. Turns out I had only the fuzziest of concepts about South African apartheid and Noah's stories bring it into sharp, personal relief. Oh and yes it's insanely entertaining (caveat: I am a die hard Trevor Noah fan from the Daily Show) while being deeply thought provoking. I also take my hat off to Trevor for the way he structured this memoir. The ending was just perfect. I dare say I may have wiped away a tear.

Holy moley this book. I want to start off by saying that I'm actually not a huge fan of Trevor Noah's comedy, its just not my favorite. Through the encouragement of other audiobook lovers, I checked this book out and was instantly drawn in. 
 This is a story of struggle and a tough childhood but it is full of humor and love. The central thread is the relationship between Trevor and his mother, which is incredibly moving and beautiful. The entire story is told during the time Trevor grew up in South Africa and the years right after apartheid ended. These portions of the story were particularly illuminating for me as I don't actually know that much about apartheid. I'm definitely going to look into other books about this topic so I can continue learning and understanding the apartheid in South Africa and how it has made it into the country it is today.

I highly recommend the audio version of this book. There is nothing like hearing these stories from Trevor Noah himself. Compelling stories of family, struggle and strength. He survived quite a childhood and am glad he shared it with us.
A funny and honest telling of the experiences that shaped Trevor Noah.

Trevor Noah is an outsider, fitting into none of the established South African categories - and the established categories are insane. As he points out, the Chinese in South Africa were categorized as black simply because there were too few of them to create their own category like the Indians. The Japanese, in contrast, were categorized as white because South Africans wanted to establish good relations to sell them luxury goods in their homeland. Noah imagines the struggle of the South African apartheid-era cop spotting an Asian: "Hey, get off of that bench, you Chinaman!" "Excuse me, I'm Japanese." "Oh, I apologize, sir. I didn't mean to be racist. Have a lovely afternoon." 
 As with all racist systems, the distinctions are arbitrary nonsense meant to strengthen divisions. Noah is considered colored in South Africa but has no connection with them since his parents aren't colored. Even after the end of apartheid, he struggles to find his group. Each time he changes schools, he has to negotiate where he will be accepted and fit in. At one school, they fast track him academically with the whites but he feels isolated. When he asks to transfer to classes with black students, where he feels a kinship, he's told he's ruining his future by aligning with the "wrong" group. He writes of colored people being officially promoted to white because of lighter skin tone and of whites being demoted to colored because their skin tans too easily. Never is your place in the racial hierarchy secure. 
 Noah does not detail his path to comedy success yet you get the sense that his outsider status gave him more acute observational skills fueling his comedic sense of absurdity. The "Go Hitler! Go Hitler!" diversity dance at the Jewish school is a brilliant and hilarious clash of oppression one-upmanship. His irate Pedi-speaking stunner of a prom date showed him where he was oblivious. He's also the ultimate survivor from being thrown from a moving car to supporting the miraculous survival of his mother, shot in the head by her abusive ex-husband. You get the sense that he's seen it all before, making him the perfect host to observe and comment on our current political insanity.
One of the best memoirs I've read. Also a great account of how apartheid works. This gets my highest recommendation.
A riveting look at growing up in South Africa and despite the many horrors and atrocities Trevor lived through, he still managed to make me laugh. Sensational!
This book is important. It is engaging. Read it now, please.

Hilarious. I really recommend the audiobook. And, there really is a good poop story. If you're at all curious about what it's like to be a colored minority in a majority black country where the majority were systematically marginalized, this is your book. However, most should be able to identify with the stories of growing up, gaining independence, family, friends. I hope he writes more. It would be interesting to hear about how he got from his wayward adolescence to the host of the Daily Show. 
 You do not have to be a Trevor Noah of the Daily Show fan (I am not) to enjoy this book.

I loved this book. Trevor Noah paints the story of growing up in pre and post Apartheid South Africa in a way that is Frank, funny, and touching without seeming like he feels sorry for himself. I fell in love with his mother, she was by no means a perfect mother, but she challenged him to think in many ways, and she always suspected he was involved when there was trouble!

Born a Crime is the compelling, and often funny coming of age story of a mixed race boy growing up under Apartheid in South Africa. Trevor was born to a white Swiss father and a black Xhosa mother at a time when such a union was punishable by five years in prison. Living proof of his parents' indiscretion, Trevor was kept mostly indoors for the earliest years of his life, bound by the extreme and often absurd measures his mother took to hide him from a government that could, at any moment, steal him away. What I liked about this book is the humor that is woven throughout the stories. I also learned the author has a late night talk show and does stand up as well (super funny-youtube it).

Trigger warning: domestic violence and abuse, race-related fuckery (obviously) attempted murder in a domestic abuse context . 
 I listened to the audiobook version of this, narrated by Trevor himself. I think it's totally worth it, if you like audiobooks at all, to go for the audio over the printed copy. (I think it's almost always worth it to go for the audio of a biography if it's read by the author, so long as the author has stage/audio/acting credibility to their name.) 
 Listening to it from Trevor's voice made it *amazing*. We already know him, we recognise his voice, his intonation, how he'll be setting something up for a joke, and therefore we get all the anticipation to go along with it. It sounded conversational and intimate at times, like he was telling you a story at the same time as he was figuring out his own mind on the issue. Mostly, it was worth it because he wasn't ashamed to not show emotion in his voice. There was at least one time when I could tell he was near tears with what he was reading - the book tells you cried while writing it, but it's extremely moving to hear someone's vulnerability like that. 
 The story itself is worth it. It's a broad view of South Africa over the last 30 years, as seen by someone who was pulled from one view to another as they grew up.
