He's also got an outside perspective (he's used to explaining things to foreigners), so he doesn't drop us into things without context and explanation, which I think it really helpful. 
 But mostly it's personal, and intimate, and ridiculously interesting. OMG, his life, man, his life.

Fans of The Daily Show have grown to love new host Trevor Noah. Acerbic and witty, he gives us the intelligence to look at world news with a skeptical eye with the added bonus of being able to find the humor in it. 
 In Trevor Noah's first memoir book, Born a Crime, we get to see what it was like to grow up in South Africa during and just after Apartheid. Born to a white Swiss man and a Xlosa Black woman, Noah's birth was considered illegal in 1984, as a child of mixed race was a crime. He uses the book to point out the irony of the laws in place at the time of his birth, as well as what it was like to not quite fit into any one group. He had to end up becoming a sort of chameleon of sorts, sliding between groups speaking one language or another, but never really fitting into any sort of niche. 
 We learn of his childhood, where his mother tried to expose him to every opportunity she couldn't have, how deeply religious she was and how he saw things a little differently than she did how it didn't matter. We learn of how he overcame poverty and abuse, and his position as a person of mixed race to learn and grow. We also get insight into his ability to get himself into trouble, and how he eventually learned how to avoid it. 
 The book reads very similar to how he speaks; as I understand it, he also did the audio version of this himself, which makes me wonder how much of it was written before the audio version was done, or if he did the audio version first and then had it transcribed into the written form. Either way, the formula worked for his tale, and leaves the reader in anticipation for more. We only get up to as far as when his early comedy career took off, so there is room for more story later on. We get doses of the history of South Africa at the beginning of chapters, from the early laws from Apartheid to post-Apartheid South Africa; this is an area where I had little knowledge but the book is enlightening and engaging. 
 My rating? four out of five stars. Trevor Noah's attempts to give us a glimpse into how he evolved into the man he is now are awkwardly laid out in the book, but the story flows. The current host of The Daily Show's voice can be heard mentally as you read through this memoir of his early years, as it is written like he speaks: eloquently and intelligently. The stories of pure horror are intermixed with some light-hearted moments, giving us all a sense of how this man can find humor in even the most disturbing of scenarios.

5 stars! 
 "But the real world doesn't go away. Racism exists. People are getting hurt, and just because it's not happening to you doesn't mean it's not happening." 
 Oh this book. This is my first ever autobiography and I could not have chosen a better book to read. First of all let me tell you that I just love Trevor Noah, I think he's doing a fantastic job as The Daily Show host and he's simply hilarious. If you've seen any of his stand up acts then you know how often he mentions apartheid and his parents, so going in, I had a pretty good idea of how deep this book would go. And then I was proven wrong. If possible, Noah went even deeper than I ever thought possible. He made me feel like I was just another part of his family, watching his life unfold before my eyes. The apartheid, the racism, his relationship with his mother - I just want to hug her, I can't - his relationship with his father and later in life his relationship with his friends, and school, and everything, really. 
 Reading Born a Crime was like having him next to me, speaking, like we were having a chat like friends. I actually felt like I was his friend and he was telling me his life's story. Noah being the amazing comedian that he is made me laugh so much with this, it balanced out the darker parts and those moments that made me go ohh hell dude. I don't really know how to rate a memoir, this is not fiction, this is the raw, hard truth, from someone that lived through these situations and he's sharing them with us. This book - apart from the engaging writing - delivers some pretty on point messages, countless in fact, that made me pause and nod along in agreement, I just loved how powerful it was and how unapologetic.

More like 3.5 stars. 
 Pretty interesting read, more sad than funny, but definitely a fascinating glimpse into what it was (is) like to grow up mixed in South Africa.
A powerful, timely, well-crafted memoir. Well, well worth a listen--the audiobook, read by the author, is perfection.
Because my awesomest friend knows just what to send for my birthday.

I listened to this book and it was fantastic! Trevor Noah narrates it himself and it was gripping. His life has been incredible. There were funny parts, sad parts, scary parts, etc. I loved it. There is definitely a lot of language -- so there's my warning.

LISTEN TO THE AUDIOBOOK if you can. Oh my goodness. Noah has had such a stunning breadth of experience in just three decades. This is so different from other memoirs. I kept wondering when it would get to the part when his comedy career took off--then I realized that whatever story that is, it would be far less interesting than everything recounted here. Part history lesson, part breathless accounting of his remarkable childhood, part autobiography of his astonishing mom. She's the true hero of this story, not Trevor. What an amazing woman; what an amazing story.
Fascinating and funny. Trevor Noah is an incredible writer. Audiobook perfection!

Good heavens was this good. SO good. Maybe the best audio book I've ever listened to. Trevor Noah proves himself as not only a capable comedian, but one hell of a storyteller. I was transfixed by his narration (ooohhhh that voice of his!) of his story of growing up in South Africa. I felt like I learned so much about the effects of apartheid, and felt ashamed on more than one occasion as I was struck by the realization that Trevor and I are near the same age. And that, while I was reading Babysitter Club Books and going to piano lessons at 11, Trevor was sleeping in a car in a garage, living off caterpillars. 
 Loved how he ended the book, tying it back to his infuriating love for his mother. 
 Would recommend this to anyone, and then encourage them to follow it up with Trevor's Netflix special. Hope this isn't the last of his writing. He's too good at this to stop at one best-seller!

This is a book that needs to be read by anyone who is clueless about apartheid. Trevor Noah's stories from his childhood are both unbelievable and full of hope all at once. There were several examples he drew between South Africa's treatment of native people and how Native Americans were treated by the "settlers". This is a really good book to read in light of the current atmosphere in America where immigrants are no longer welcome which is asinine because every single American came from immigrants.
A very touching memoir of growing up in South Africa and getting a child's eye view of apartheid.

See my blog for a longer review. I thoroughly enjoyed this book. It gave a more human face to the effects of apartheid than the bare facts give, and illustrated that nobody could escape the discriminatory cycle, and everyone could have their race classification questioned or changed at any time, through the eyes of somebody whose existence was proof of a crime, who wasn't white enough for the white classification, but not black enough for the black classification - a mixed race child who learnt to become a chameleon and use this to his advantage, told with humour and affection.

This is an amazing book. As a stand up comedian, Trevor Noah knows how to tell a tale and it's evident in his memoir. It's not just a story of rags to riches or the American dream, it's also a story of South Africa and apartheid. It brings to mind another great memoir, Angela's Ashes.

I had never heard of Trevor Noah when he took over the beloved Daily Show and it took some time to get used to his humor. But reading this book gives you an immense sense of his life from growing up under apartheid to living the violent streets of freedom. Few folks can tell a story of escaping rape and murder by being thrown out of a moving car and make you giggle doing so.

Halfway through this book, I thought this book would be well consumed in the form of an audio-book with Trevor Noah narrating it, especially because of my familiarity with his narration style. That being said, this book is amazing, it provides this insight into his life, into a life after apartheid and the color divide and class structures from his point of view, but just that is insightful in itself. I was laughing through quite a few moments so just for that, I think I would say it's a must read. Maybe the structure could have been better because there were specific things that were repeated across the stories. I understand that the story needed context so it needed to be done but it is different from an autobiography because it is not in a chronological order, and each story adheres to a theme rather than a specific timeline. If you enjoy his show, if you enjoy reading about people's experiences, I would recommend this.
Honest, irreverent, funny. All the qualities that Trevor Noah brings to his comedy routines are in this book.
I listened to this and am glad Trevor Noah narrated it. Helped me learn a lot about South Africa and apatheid, but mostly was an entertaining love letter to his mother.

This book was amazing! So much more than I expected it to be. Not only was it witty, heart warming, exciting, and really relatable, but it was also EXTREMELY informative! I feel like I learned so much more about what it actually was like living in South Africa During the times of apartheid. I really truly did enjoy this book and I can definitely see myself revisiting it in the future.

It's not as funny as I would have hoped, but the history and context of South Africa under apartheid more than makes up for it. It's definitely a more interesting celebrity memoir than the standard fare.

Trevor Noah is a resilient, bright young man and I like him even more now that I've read his book. Deeply affecting, you cannot imagine what he's lived through to get to where he is today. He's not your typical TV personality. Even if you think you know something about apartheid you'll be sure to learn something new about just how cruel the system was especially for those, like him, that did not neatly fit into a group.
Interesting in the beginning.

This is the fastest book I've read this year, not only because it was kinda short, but because it was really engaging, moreso for an avid young African reader such as myself. 
 As a young man growing up in Kenya, I could definitely relate to most of the experiences Trevor is talking about: the hiding(i.e being whooped senseless by your parents), the religious fanaticism that is rampant in the poorer areas of our live, the issue of race, domestic violence, all of it. Trevor is definitely not the best writer when it comes to prose and character development(his characters are not well rounded so to say), but heck, can he be real. I particularly enjoyed how he addressed the issue about race- something that not many people do not [unfortunately] talk about at this day and age. Why has being black lost its value? Why is white considered some god-sent bs? Yes, he sort of talks about this via his experiences growing up. This realness(though maybe a bit biased) is what made me enjoy this book.

I loved this book. I knew very little about what life was like in South Africa after apartheid; only what I saw on the news. I would never know what it would be like to be of mixed race in all that change and animosity and distrust between the cultures. But this is one of the reasons I read - to learn and empathize with other's lives. Trevor does a great job of expressing the pain and humor of his childhood in the midst of terrible circumstances. He's a good writer and analyst of the times into which he was born. Thank God for his humor and mother's love.

If you read this one, I recommend the audio version. Trevor Noah really does a fine job in telling his own story. The story skips around to different time periods of his life, which may require you to stay on your toes.
Listened to this one and it was amazing! I'll never forget this book. I don't think reading it would have been nearly as affecting or memorable.

Not being fully aware of the history in South Africa, I had a very general knowledge going into this book. Learning about Noah's life and hearing the stories from his experiences, I have a newfound appreciation for what struggles exist. Intertwined with humor, this book is beautifully written in a way that you can imagine his experiences and ponder how you might personally react. The influences of religion and diversity are strong his life in a way that seems to have shaped him into the person we know and adore today. I listened via Audible with Noah narrating. What a pleasure!

Admittedly, embarrassingly, before he took over for Jon Stewart at The Daily Show, I had never heard of Trevor Noah. I wasn't initially sure what to expect from Stewart's replacement, but to be fair I wasn't really a die-hard follower of the show in the first place. Sure, I enjoy Stewart and his humor, but I wouldn't be completely lost if I didn't watch every episode or even every day; I typically only even watched occasional clips online. Needless to say, when Noah took over I started watching more; more often and more regularly. His humor, his perspective, and his voice are precisely what we need today. Thus, when I learned that he was releasing a book, especially a memoir, I just knew that I needed to read it. I was not, by any means, disappointed. 
 Before Noah's voice even appears on the pages, there are three highly notable things worth mentioning about this book: 1. There is a picture of young Trevor with his mother right on the title page, 2. His dedication: "For my mother. My first fan. Thank you for making me a man," and 3. The Immorality Act of 1927. The weight of these three elements sets the tone for the book and, in retrospect, appropriately balances his attention to subject matter. His life with his mother, and even his mother alone, are by far incredibly prominent focal points for Noah's essays. The very nature of his existence, as technically a crime under the Immorality Act, is also a major factor as it dictated how he and his parents could interact in a society rife with such prejudices and, let's be honest, flat-out racism, as was the case in apartheid era South Africa. Each move he and his family made had to be precisely calculated. In many ways, there are incredible, and incredibly heartbreaking in every sense of the word and its meaning, parallels to the black experience here in America, especially in poor, underprivileged areas. Noah's reflections on his own poverty (at one time being so poor that he and his family slept in cars at his stepfather's workshop and ate worms) really provide a much needed perspective that everyone can and should appreciate. 
 Trevor Noah is also known for his comedy, so while there are definitely very serious and even scary (especially regarding his stepfather, Abel) stories between these pages, there are also some really hilarious aspects, too. Trevor generally seems like a guy who had a happy childhood (thank you, Patricia Noah) and was, quite frankly, a bit of a clown. I enjoyed the back and forth between him and his mother, especially when he tries to reason with her for getting out of going to church (a whole day ordeal, schlepping between three different churches: black church, white church, and mixed church; I can't say I blame the kid). I actually found that while I enjoyed this book in its entirety, I particularly and especially enjoyed any and every story involving his mother, Patricia. I became so invested in this strong, beautiful woman, that I almost skipped ahead to the last chapter (essentially an ode to her) to read over and over again. I remained patient, however I still have the urge to reread this chapter. Trevor's love and appreciation for, and dedication to, his mother is clear throughout this book, even in his reflections of tense, painful situations (e.g. cutting her out of his life when she becomes pregnant with Abel's second son). Her resilience and strength give me hope and strength by extension. 
 'You're lucky to be alive,' I told her. 'I still can't believe you didn't have any health insurance.' 
 'Oh, but I do have insurance,' she said. 
 'You do?' 
 'Yes. Jesus.' 
 'Jesus is your health insurance?' 
 'If God is with me, who can be against me?' 
 'Okay, Mom.' 
 'Trevor, I prayed. I told you I prayed. I don't pray for nothing.' 
 'You know,' I said, 'for once I cannot argue with you. The gun, the bullets--I can't explain any of it. So I'll give you that much.' Then I couldn't resist teasing her with one last little jab. 'But where was your Jesus to pay your hospital bill, hmm? I know for a fact that He didn't pay that.' 
 She smiled and said, 'You're right. He didn't. But He blessed me with the son who did.' 
 Though we grew up in vastly different worlds and with vastly different experiences, I found so many common traits with Trevor: 
 I didn't have any friends. I didn't know any kids besides my cousins. I wasn't a lonely kid--I was good at being alone. I'd read books, play with the toy that I had, make up imaginary worlds. I lived inside my head. I still live inside my head. To this day you can leave me alone for hours and I'm perfectly happy entertaining myself. I have to remember to be with people. 
 Okay, so the above relates in large part to the fact that he often couldn't go out, especially in certain neighborhoods, because of the color of his skin: he was always considered either too white or not black, never just Trevor. I understand the lone nature, though; as an introvert, this has always been my general state of being. Being alone is not being lonely and it's perfectly cool to be content with entertaining yourself, especially when books are involved... 
 My books were my prized possessions. I had a bookshelf where I put them, and I was so proud of it. I loved my books and kept them in pristine condition. I read them over and over, but I did not bend the pages or the spines. I treasured every single one. As I grew older I started buying my own books. I loved fantasy, loved to get lost in worlds that didn't exist. I remember there was some book about white boys who solved mysteries or some shit. I had no time for that. Give me Roald Dahl. James and the Giant Peach, The BFG, Charlie and the Chocolate Factory, The Wonderful Story of Henry Sugar. That was my fix. 
 As a librarian and general bibliophile, I fell in love with the above quote. As an anthropology minor (undergrad) and ever hopeful (future) linguistic anthropologist, I found Noah's comments on the power of language to be really inspiring and meaningful. 
 Language brings with it an identity and a culture, or at least the perception of it. A shared language says 'We're the same.' A language barrier says 'We're different.' The architects of apartheid understood this. Part of the effort to divide black people was to make sure we were separated not just physically but by language as well...The great thing about language is that you can just as easily use it to do the opposite: convince people that they are the same. Racism teaches us that we are different because of the color of our skin. But because racism is stupid, it's easily tricked. 
 Nelson Mandela once said, 'If you talk to a man in a language he understands, that goes to his head. If you talk to him in his language, that goes to his heart.' He was so right. When you make the effort to speak someone else's language, even if it's just basic phrases here and there, you are saying to them, 'I understand that you have a culture and identity that exists beyond me. I see you as a human being.' 
 Trevor Noah is a polyglot, a necessary trait he developed while growing up in South Africa, where people were separated for so many stupid reasons (because, yes, racism is stupid) including language (aka tribe). By learning so many different languages, Noah was able to fluidly navigate difficult social situations as well as establish friendships, avoid being mugged (or worse), and understand others' cultural identity. We could all learn at least a little bit, if not more, from Noah's examples, especially here. 
 I highly recommend this book to everyone, regardless of your familiarity with Trevor Noah. I also recommend reading this book simultaneously with (or before/after reading) the YA book The Hate U Give for some beautiful/heartbreaking parallels (both with some much needed humor!) as well as important perspective into the black experience in America, especially today.

It's a powerful experience, shitting. There's something magical about it, profound even. I think God made humans shit in the way we do because it brings us back down to earth and gives us humility. I don't care who you are, we all shit the same. Beyonce shits. The pope shits. The Queen of England shits. When we shit we forget how famous or rich we are. All of that goes away. 
 Trevor Noah has the perfect blend of politics, insight, and funny. That quote up there is a perfect view of that. It's funny--he's discussing the act of pooping. By default, it is toilet humor. But then he brings you around to this magical idea about how poop is the ultimate level playing field. You make six figures a year? You still shit, and you still have to wipe your ass. 
 He brought this kind of funny thinking process to every essay in this book. His mother pushing him out of a car. Being a criminal (insofar as creating pirated discs). Being adrift in a sea of black and white, and not quite belonging to each. Plus, it's totally worth reading just so you have Trevor Noah's voice in your head. His voice is so smooth, and when you tack on the South African accent it's just magical.

Brilliant! Perhaps the only time I'll take Trevor Noah to bed but he made me laugh, made me feel and educated me on what apartheid was really like. Definitely the best non-fiction/memoir I've read in the past year.

If you have a chance to read this book, I would highly recommend the audio book. Trevor Noah does an amazing job of telling his life story and the impact of apartheid on him, through his own voice and through the voices of the people in his life. He's a talented orator, and it comes through in his audio book.

Definitely the best celebrity memoir I've read and a contender for the best memoir I've read. Even if you have no affinity for Trevor Noah or The Daily Show, the stories about his mom and their relationship alone make this book a must read. I do, however, kind of wish I'd listened to the audiobook. Next time . . . Five stars, no question.

I am one of the few individuals who first read the book, got to know Trevor Noah, was inspired by him and became a huge fan of him. I saw one of his shows when I was flipping through the TV channels and didn't really think much of it. 
 Recently, I got this book and right from the start I was intrigued. I couldn't stop, I kept turning on page after page completely immersed in the story and wanting to know more. 
 Through the different chapters we get to know Trevor as a child, his life during and after the apartheid, his early youth days and his triumphs and his transformation to a celebrity and successful comedian. 
 Highly entertaining and spectacular.

I listened to the audio book and loved it. Hearing Trevor Noah narrate his life story in many different langauges and with a South African accent really made the book come to life. What an incredible story and an incredible storyteller.
Recommended!!

A charming audio book. Noah is at his best recounting stories from childhood, where his vocal interpretations make the banter between school kids especially enjoyable. He has brilliant moments - describing defiling his grandmother's house, cheering his friend 'Hitler' obliviously - and poignant ones - taking a girl to prom who was so beautiful that he hadn't bothered to talk to her. Noah communicates the complex web of cultures, languages, and race that Apartheid South Africa stewed up, which I appreciated as someone with limited understanding of that time and place. 
 While I can imagine the book being good, this is one where the voice of the author adds a dimension to the story. I can imagine coming back to this again.
Loved this book. I listened to this book on Audible. Great narrator (author), exceptional insights into the human condition, entertaining and surprising. Very worthwhile way to spend your time.

good storyteller 
 dry humour throughout 
 talks of South Africa, its story and living in and after apartheid. regals childhood stories with his strong and rebellious mother. lots of culture stories... super funny story about Koko his great grandmother, him and the poo in the house. other stories are scary, some sad. 
 insights and lessons learned, like with his insight on connecting via language, the hardships of coloured folks (part ii) and lessons his dog fufi gave him. 
 I love his mom!
A must-read. This book is told with humor and you get to walk with Trevor and his Family in their journey in South Africa.

Wonderfully succinct and thoughtful memoire on the entanglement of a national identity with individual spirit. Noah's love for his mother and his insight into his own past motivations leave the reader feeling hopeful about humanity and curious to know more.

Wow- this gave such a detailed look at not some distant South Africa of the pst but one from our lifetime. His humor does add some lightness and his life definitely had entertaining moments but what shined through the most is the strong relationship between the independent mother and her high-energy spunky son! I would recommend reading this!

Excellent book filled with short stories about his childhood in South Africa. Good balance between humor and seriousness. A lot to be learned in here through the eyes of a man who grew up as a young 'mixed' boy in the terrible era of apartheid. A pleasure to listen to on audiobook, almost a necessary part of the experience I think, to be able to hear his rendering of the traditional African languages. 
 4 stars instead of 5 as I noticed some overlap and repetition. Perhaps could have been edited together more cohesively. Still, it paints a great picture and well worth the time to read - or better yet - listen.

I enjoyed Trevor Noah's "Born a Crime: Stories from a South African Childhood" enormously. First of all, if you have watched "The Daily Show" which he took over from Jon Stewart a while ago, you'll hear his voice in every sentence. His writing has that kind of authenticity. It bubbles over with excitement and good humor, and at the same time it's penetrating in the accuracy of its psychological and social observation. 
 To have been "Born a Crime" was of course a literal truth for a bi-racial child in his native apartheid South Africa. Deprived of more than fleeting contact with a Swiss father, Noah was brought up by a fiercely loving and tenacious mother, who spared him neither the beating when she thought he deserved it, nor the often biting wisdom of her tongue. From his early years, he made fun of the Christianity to which she was devoted, but learned from her the ethical compass that saw him through even a mischievously rebellious--and at times moderately criminal youth. 
 Noah earned his smarts the hard way: on the back streets of Johannesburg's black townships, where survival was a matter of learning to negotiate the constantly shifting shoals of social, racial and political turmoil. Coming of age at the moment when apartheid was finally crushed by a mix of internal and international pressures, and always an outsider--not white, not "colored," not Indian, and never accepted as completely black--he slipped cheekily between racial barriers by guile, deception and duplicity, making sure that he always, improbably, came out ahead of the game. Well, usually. There are times he described being slapped down brutally. But he has the native ability to bounce back up every time he gets knocked down. 
 If Noah takes us on an often riotous journey, it's one that is also often profoundly moving. Little short of a miracle that he survived a brutally abusive stepfather, a peripatetic education that combined the disciplined experience of Catholic school with the chaos of the streets, and his own unruly spirit that rejected every social norm, to become the sharp-witted, unsparing social critic that he is today. If you want to understand where his peculiar brand of satire comes from, this is a good place to start.
Absolutely fascinating look into Trevor Noah's life. I liked how it was written and the audio book quality was fantastic.
Amazing book. Amazing story of how one can rise from years of difficulty and a broken system.
Incredible story and refreshing characters. Beautifully told by the author in audiobook form.

This book is about a child's perspective and his childhood life during apartheid poverty in South Africa. Many thinks the book is funny, but not to me. For me, the book is more on Trevor's memory and tribute for his mum. Trevor has told his story of his life with his mum at South Africa. His mum brought up a today's Trevor Noah. Although his mum didn't change the South Africa, she changed her son into a better person, a person that able to get out from apartheid environment cycle. 
 Recommend to those that what to know about apartheid in South Africa.

Very rarely does it happen that books categorized under "Comedy" are actually funny. This book most certainly is a great laugh. The author's past is traumatic but the narration makes it hilarious. I can only imagine what it must have felt like to be raised in apartheid. Respect.

Given the current state of race relations in the world, the timing for the release of Born A Crime is impeccable. 
 Noah paints a vivid picture of what it was like to be born as a a mixed child during apartheid. He discusses the implications that his mixed status imposed upon his own identity but also how it resulted in others groups not being able to fully accept him. He wasn't black enough for the blacks, or white enough for the whites, and he definitely did not identify as coloured. Subsequently, he experienced substantial amounts of isolation throughout his life. 
 Although the story of his early childhood is fascinating, the book is made that much more interesting through the parallels that Noah draws between the US and South Africa. He details how the South African government studied the racist policies and discriminatory initiatives of the British, German, and Americans and then developed the most perfect system of racism. Moreover, he warns the world of the age old truism: a people divided are easy to conquer.

1) PATRICIA NOAH IS BADASS <3 
 2) Trevor Noah is genuine, funny, insightful, and such a cutie
Wise and witty. Hilarious and heartfelt. My favorite book of 2016.

Couldn't put this book down!! Trevor Noah writes with a special kind of honesty and wit, about an extraordinarily difficult upbringing in South Africa, and an ending that brings out the tears. Highly recommended.
A beautiful story! I recommend the audible version. Trevor Noah's storytelling skills are amazing. Do it. You'll be happy you did.
MUy bueno, me gusta la sencillez y humildad con la que describe su vida, los ultimos capitulos me parecieron desgarradores.

** spoiler alert ** 
 Excellent writing. And I had the pleasure of listening to the audio book. Even better. In fact I would recommend to anyone who can to get the audio, takes the experience to new heights.
I am a huge Trevor Noah fan, so I simply loved this book and was drawn in by his narration.
A fascinating read. My only regret is that I did not buy the audio book version as well.

I really like Trevor Noah's comedy and I enjoyed reading his book, although parts of it felt like fiction at times. But, as with any autobiography, it's impossible to remember events and conversations exactly as they happened, so there's always an element of fiction involved, I just felt it was more obvious in places. I also wasn't a huge fan of the way the narrative jumped around, at one point he's 20 and you think you're about to read how he started his career but suddenly he's 10 years old again and then 25. But, in terms of the subject matter, it makes sense why he split the narrative in that way. All in all, in was an interesting and entertaining read, especially if you are familiar with Noah's comedic style - I think an audiobook read by Noah himself would be great. The book offers a unique perspective of his childhood during apartheid, a picture that you wouldn't get from official accounts or factual sources which was really interesting. Would recommend, especially if you like Noah.
Good read and a interesting insight into life in South Africa when Trevor Noah was growing up - makes you think about the 'problems' we worry about in everyday life

'Born a Crime' is an story of an boy Trevor Noah who's mother was an black women and his father was an white man.Apartheid was an role to segregate black people from white in south Africa. At this period trevor birth was an crime and it could have put his mother in jail for years. Trevor noah narrates his story in a beautiful way. He narrates his tragedy story in funny way.In many instances he imitates the character in this book. Trevor Noah's mother Patricia was an brave women. She raises noah as a great man. She teaches him about Jesus Christ , good habits,respecting women. 
 As a single women she upbringing Trevor Noah in the world of terror.Trevor Noah narrates how naught he used to be in his childhood and those chapter were very funny. In one chapter Patricia teaches noah about discipline by giving the following versus from bible. "Folly is bound up in the heart of a child, but the rod of discipline will drive it far away." Proverbs 22:15. 
 I liked Patricia's faith God and her unconditional love on her child. Patricia shapes her son's future by teaching discipline,respecting and helping others, and keeping other happily. At end of this book Noah explains about his step father and how he ruins her mothers and his life. Totally this book was a Inspirational book. I recommend this book to everyone.

I definitely recommend the audiobook. It will definitely take longer to complete, but he has superb storytelling skills and it will give you a superior experience over reading the book! Highly enjoyable book with many hilarious stories about his childhood as a mixed-race kid.

Hilarious, harrowing, heartfelt and heroic, Trevor Noah's memoir paints a vivid picture of a childhood and coming of age pre- and post-apartheid, a picture of a brilliant, trouble-making young man emerging from a chaotic life, and a stunning portrait of his fiercely loving and powerful mother. Deeply insightful into life, love, the political and the personal, from every angle, and beautifully written, this book will grab you with both fists and drag you (willingly) for the full duration of its wild ride.

** spoiler alert ** 
 I'll preface this by saying that reading books has been by hobby, pastime, passion- you get the point. So naturally, I have read innumerable books. Many have moved me, mostly with laughter and happiness. About 3 have ever made me tear up, and 2 of those are Harry Potter books. 
 This book was beautifully crafted, compelling you with Trevor's life, the history of South African apartheid, his incredibly humorous narration, and his strange ability to neither dismiss the hardships he talked of, nor elaborate on them long enough for them to hurt deeply: but always just enough to pierce your heart before a light quip made you chuckle. 
 Yet, I surprised by self by bursting into tears- actually more like sobs- where Patricia, kind, beautiful, fierce, unstoppable Patricia, Trevor's mother, was shot. To me, it was a bioaccumulation of all the seeds of injustice sewn throughout the novel. Moments later, following Trevor's own emotional trajectory, I was half laughing through the tears, in awe at his mothers ability to crack jokes at a time such as that, in a world such as this. 
 This book teaches you that perspective and earnestness are everything. You can make the most of any time, place, and financial status so long as you are the special kinds of people who, like Trevor and his mother, never seem to lose the practical idealism of the good that life will give, if you knock hard enough and believe sincerely enough.
This book started off a little slow. A bit too chatty and windy for me, but once I got into it, it was amazing. I totally loved it.

I thoroughly enjoyed this book. I have always been a fan of Trevor Noah, since he replaced John Stewart on "The Daily Show that is. However, I didn't know anything about his life. I only knew that he was funny and had the same political views as me. This book was one of the most enlightening things I have ever read. I learned so much from it. Especially when it came to the intense and unjust details of Apartheid in South Africa, as well as the affects it had on black people, Indian people, Colored people, even Asians (which I never even knew existed in South Africa at the time of Apartheid.) This book also gave me insight on why people from "the hood," usually never make it out of the hood. As well as the reason poor people, can't simply "pick themselves up from their boot straps" and make a better life for themselves, simply because they lack the knowledge and resources to do so. I am very privileged, I've never been in a situation where I was afraid someone would come and take my Mother, or was afraid my step father would hit/shoot my mother. These fears I could never imagine coming true, were regulated and part of the norm in most towns of South Africa. I feel much more knowledgable and educated now that I have finished this book. Not to mention grateful of my situation and status. Especially considering I am no different than a "colored girl" from Africa that grew up during that time. The only difference between us would be the circumstances we were born into. She was born a crime, I wasn't. I don't know if that makes me feel blessed, or terribly sad. Maybe both.
Great book. Love this cat.. he's had a hell of a life!

This is a really beautiful read! I haven't read a book this funny. 
 A really sad story written in a very comical way. Just when you are about to shed a tear, Trevor throws in a joke that leaves you admiring his courage and resilience. Despite his struggles, there is no time for pity party. For him, every challenge is an opportunity to help him fit in. 
 His mother, Mbuyi, is a relentless, typical African woman. Amidst all the apartheid, poverty, hatred and family struggles, Patricia Nombuyiselo Noah takes life head on. To her no problem is too big to handle and that is what she has instilled in her son,Trevor. 
 Trevor, you were born an entrepreneur. From being a tuck shop guy, to selling CD's to DJ'ing. You definitely were destined for success.
Overall, I felt like it was a great read and kept me engaged the entire time. The only thing that could have made it better is if the author had stuck to a time line instead of skipping around.

I expected to laugh reading this book - and I did. But I am not sure I expected to learn and to think - and I did. Trevor Noah paints a vivid picture of life in South Africa both during and after apartheid. He does it with his expected humor and also with depth and poetry of language. His life is both unimaginable to a white American and completely relatable. His insights into race are downright profound. In the author description at the end of the book, he says "Trevor Noah is a comedian from South Africa". He's going to need to amend that to add "philosopher" and "writer".

An enjoyable as well as educational read. Trevor Noah does an awesome job telling "his" story of being born a crime. 
 Through this book I have learned more about Apartheid than I ever truly ever understood, while at the same enjoyed a story of family, love, disappointments, victories, losses, fear, and growth. 
 After reading the book I wish I could meet his mom...a strong and determined spirit. I am also very proud of Trevor as if I know him!

"Current Daily Show host gives his reader an introduction to his life growing up of mixed-race during Apartheid and post-Apartheid South Africa. It is a powerful look at his story and that country during its recent history. Very little attention is given to his rise in celebrity, which is okay with me. It was funny and deeply meaningful, and an easy summer read. This is a great book to check out!" - Summer Reader, Ben
Loved it ! Fascinating, humorous and heart warming story of Trevor Noah growing up in South Africa, this book keeps you binding till the end.

This was one of the best books I've every read- thought I did the audio. It's a story told book read by Noah himself and personally I wouldn't want to enjoy this material any other way. I'm not usually one for autobiographies but this one is so engaging I literally stopped listening to it for a few days because I was devastated that it was almost over. An excellent book narrated wonderfully.

I came across this book right after my trip to South Africa. I was already interested in the country's history of apartheid and culture. I don't know much of Trevor Noah's comedy so that wasn't my major motivation for reading. This book had me laughing out loud and tearing up the whole time. It's also a great look inside South Africa's recent history. I highly recommend this book whether you're a fan of the author or not!

I absolutely adore this book. I love Trevor Noah's funny, yet dark perspective and the pithy insights he includes in many of his childhood stories: "hustling," his brief stint in jail, his childhood crushes. But Trevor's mom is definitely the character who stole the show. <3 This book was largely an ode to his amazing mother, whom he is so lucky to have in his life. Another great aspect of the memoir is that readers get to learn what it's like to grow up during the fall of the South African apartheid -- unimaginable! 
 I recommend reading it as an audio book (as I did), because Trevor is a polyglot and speaks in many languages throughout the book. It was cool to hear all the different languages pronounced with the proper accents. If you do read this book in print, just keep in mind that the word "Xhosa" has a click in it. :) 
 This memoir took me on a wild ride, and I loved every moment of it.
super great!
Laugh out loud funny at times, perspective-shifting at other times. A fast and wonderful read.

Listened to this book on road trip. Fascinating story. Trevor uses his own humorous way telling a heart broken story. Highly recommend to listen because Trevor actually reads it, being his own narrator. Too many good quotes from the book. Want to revisit the written version later.

It was a sad, beautiful, and amazing story. I laughed, I had tears, and fell even more in love with Trevor Noah. Wish he would have talked more about how he became famous but it was a great audiobook.

Trevor Noah is one of South Africa's most beloved exports. When this former criminal turned comedian was given the job as host of the prestigious The Daily Show in New York, South Africans were bursting with pride. 
 But Noah's rise to fame had humble beginnings. The title of his bestselling autobiography refers to his parentage: a black mother and white father. Interracial relationships were forbidden under the racist apartheid regime and so, his very existence was a crime. With wit, irony and wry humour, Noah describes how his mother had to pretend she was his nanny because he was lighter than her. As a child, Noah was not allowed to leave the house, for fear that someone who questioned why such a light-skinned child was around black people. That didn't prevent his clever escapes, however. 
 From being a rascal as a child to a criminal teenager and finally, a comedian headed for stardom, Noah's story is a tragi-comedy. The book is also about his relationship with his mother, a fearless woman who was determined that her son would succeed, even as she battled poverty and domestic abuse. 
 Trevor Noah's book made me laugh out loud in one chapter, just to reduce me to tears in the next. It is a courageous, honest and engrossing read that highlights just how bizarre, ludicrous and cruel apartheid was.

Noah's story telling is outstanding. He completely draws you into his life experiences with insightful, sometimes funny, sometimes serious, but always grounded and without pretense, narratives. Amazing stories told with clear eyes, and great affection for those he writes about. And his mom - who wouldn't want to know her? For me, the book exceeded any expectations I had, and is a real page turner. Entertaining, thoughtful, and thought-provoking. Give us more Trevah.
Witty, hilarious but also with a pint of sadness.

Known to many North Americans as the host who replaced Stephen Colbert in "The Daily Show," Trevor Noah began life literally as a "criminal." He was born to a white Swiss father and a black Xhosa mother in the 1980s, when such a relationship was punishable by five years in prison in the apartheid state of South Africa. 
 In a series of achronological essays or chapters that are intensely dramatic and yet often comical, Noah describes his coming-of-age when apartheid was finally ending, but when freedom and safety were far from guaranteed. 
 From a precocious, mischievous boy, Noah describes his growth into a restless man, desperate to earn money and to find his way in a culture where "he was not supposed to exist." 
 Undergirding Noah's dramatic coming-of-age story is his mother's devoutly Christian but "unconventional, unconditional love." He describes her as his "first fan" and the caregiver whom he says "ma[de] me a man."

This is a book you won't regret picking up. "Born a Crime" is chiefly the narrative of Noah's outstandingly unique childhood and early adulthood, but more subliminally, it is the story of his mother's life: one dictated by faith, strength and gritty determination.

A really fun, quick read. It was entertaining and educational as well. Although I have learned about the South African Apartheid before, it was really interesting to read a first-hand account from someone who grew up in that environment. He shares his history full of difficult and heart-breaking situations, yet I found myself laughing throughout.
This book is amazing, funny and touching. Trevor Noah's story of rags to riches and a trinute to him mum. I could not put this book down!

An amazing story of a young man and his mother who went around the block a few times and beat the odds. Great read, I would recommend it. It's very personal, while giving you an interesting insight into apartheid and post-apartheid South Africa. His voice is all over the essays ,I could almost hear him narrate it, humor included. It brings you closer to amazing people, the tone is optimistic (which I find amazing) and it's a fantastic look into the life that made Trevor the man we admire these days.

Thank you, Trevor, because this book was something. I listened to it on audible, so hearing him, telling his story, was even better. I got a better understanding of growing up during apartheid, being colored.. 
 I smiled, and cried a little bit, throughout the book. 
 I was immersed into his world, his childhood, at a difficult time in South Africa. He beautifully narrated it, and I liked every little things about it, I had a good time!
an Honest and moving memoir.
Vivid depiction of a apartheid in every single way possible. Possibly one of my books and fastest I have drown myself into. An inspiring story indeed.

After having caught one of Trever Noah's stand up specials on Netflix, and becoming more familiar with his life through internet searching, I've been intrigued from the start. I could not put this book down! An easy read of a collection of tales from his upbringing that, needless to say, formed his ability to shield peril, and use his differences as fuel from which he benefits. It reminded me many times that just when I think I have it bad, others have it worse. He is admirable, intelligent, and cultured.

I would actually give this book a 4.5. I really enjoyed it. Noah did an excellent job. There are so many important themes in this book: Love, race, language, family, privilege, abuse, crime, friendship and a few gems pertaining to life lessons. This isn't a book I would normally read. It's autobiographical short stories. However, I'm so glad I did!
What a crazy childhood/life?! Great read.

These stories are beautifully written and give insight into a country and time period often talked about in broad, sweeping terms. I don't often read books by celebrities, but I love Trevor Noah and am glad I picked this one up. It's not all in chronological order, which is a little confusing, but the stories are told wonderfully and it's a hard book to put down.
Absolutely LOVED this book. Trevor Noah has lived such an incredible life. His book is both engaging and hilarious, a must read.

Best book I've ever read, no doubt. His true life story telling abilities are remarkable. I was hanging on every single freaking word. I honestly have so much more respect for him than I already had. What he's been through and who he's become today - it was meant to become a book for everyone to read. Who knew! Trevor Noah, you are remarkable and strong. Thank you for taking time from your busy life and hosting the Daily show to write this. I and many I'm sure, hope to see more books; if not, I am still forever satisfied with this one.
touching ending.
Totally recommended! Superb read.

Amazing! I am always a trifle suspicious of autobiographies, because who can really say what is true and what isn't? But this had, for the most part, the ring of truth in it. It was candid, funny, and most importantly riveting. Have had a wee bit of a crush on him for a while; and this book certainly didn't help matters. :)

A deeply honest and full account of growing up in post-Apartheid South Africa. 
 Heart-breaking, hilarious, moving. 
 This story shows Noah's remarkable ability of overcoming hardship with humor and offering a unique multilingual mirror on South Africa, a mirror that cuts deeper than many.

Amazingly powerful, I have enjoyed reading this book immensely. It's been a long time, since I've read a book which touched me so deeply. Now time to convince my mother, who doesn't like reading, to read this book. 
 Tears. lots of tears toward the end. Very awkward while in the break room at work. 
 I will be reading this many times over.
Great story!

Inspiring compelling read about my favorite comedian Trevor Noah. I couldn't stop reading the book. I am so amazed and flabbergasted by his biography -- Trevor growing up not only during apartheid SA, but also being raised clearly by a codependant mother and an abusive father. Yet, despite it all, his broken past doesn't define him nor does he look at it with menace -- he simply uses humor telling his disturbing past life that one ends up laughing instead of being horrified by it. Loved it!
Wonderful story made even better by Noah's beautiful narration.

I was ignorant to the circumstances in South Africa during and after apartheid. I think this book brought a lot of insight into daily life and Trevor Noah's upbringing. The dash of humor cuts the serious notes of racism and discrimination.

I really do adore Trevor and his cunning wit is on full display here. I thought I knew practically all there was to know about apartheid, but the layers he reveals in this candid memoir proved me very wrong. 
 The writing is much better than I expected and this is a very easy read. However, I feel like the book ends too abruptly and not satisfactorily. A major trauma happens to his family and it is resolved with a basic summary? 
 I understand that he is still a young man and will probably have 2 or 3 more books to come, but the reader is definitely left hanging here. 
 Not funny Trevor.

I have never in my life related to book like this one. Being biracial is such a weird world to navigate. The way Trevor wove the facts and history of South Africa with personal stories to speak of his life during the apartheid is truly remarkable. I also find the life of Trevor's mother both beautiful and remarkable. I loved this book from start to finish.
Incredible. I learned, laughed and cried. I can't recommend this book more.

Trevor Noah's stories are delightfully funny while at the same time teaching you about his country of origin South Africa. He uses humour to help you understand his nation, its struggles and its people. He has a way of making you see how desperate the situation in south Africa is without making you gloomy and sad. His stories are stories of hope fun and love.

I wish I had more starts to give. this book had me laughing, mad, and sad. I have loved Trevor since he was first introduced to us. reading his book, has taught me so much more than I was looking for. He is clever and super funny. His mom is my new hero and I will try my hardest to be more like her.
Funny, insightful, poignant. Taught me how much I never knew about Apartheid South Africa, and how much I still have to learn. Mr. Noah is a born storyteller.
South African comedian Trevor Noah talks about his childhood and race relations in this wonderful book that tackles complex race issues with humor and his personal touch.
Amazing. I have no other words. I enjoyed every second of this incredible book. Definitely recommend!!!

Wow. This book is emotionally and mentally engaging. It is both funny and sad. Some of the issues raised are potentially troubling yet need to be addressed. Prior to reading it, I assumed that it would probably be a story centered around racism and how it affected him as a child. It was, but it was also so much more than that. Loved how the book revolves around the relationship between a single mother and her child (definitely hit a soft spot in my heart), sexism and domestic abuse. 
 In the book, Trevor Noah also did a great job of depicting the crisis of identity conflict among mixed race children, and I thought it was brilliant of him mentioning how language plays a bigger role in the perception of identity than skin color. Learned a lot about another culture in another side of the world, that I would probably never venture into had it not be for this book. It is interesting how we people of different backgrounds think we are different from each other, yet we share so much in common in daily life struggles.
Trevor Noah's life is amazing.

This book is very powerful and talks about Noah's life in South Africa. I suddenly realized Noah's backstory. This book is divided into little stories that are not too long, but not too short. This gives a new perspective into the life of people in the apartheid era of South Africa. 5 stars - Highly Recommended

I never before read a book and put it down feeling as though I had actually lived someone else's life. This could possibly be because I don't read much nonfiction. In fact, for the life of me I can't remember the name of another memoir that I've perused. Having given you that little disclaimer, I can go on to say that this is worth the read.

My decision to read this book had everything to do with star power or fandom. I have to admit I have watched Trevor Noah on the Daily Show from day one. His childhood in Apartheid South Africa as told by Trevor gleefully finds comedy in tragedy and allows the reader to experience something rather therapeutic through the protective lens of laughter.

The gritty story of Trevor Noah's rise as person of mixed race from apartheid South Africa to late night talk show host. How his African mother manipulated her life so that her son had as well-rounded and rich upbringing as possible. Trevor is candid and unflinchingly honest in telling about his life from youth to young adult, a keen insight into a brilliant mind. Today he's cultured, well-spoken, articulate and informed . . . how he got that way is the kernel of this autobiography.

I like Trevor Noah. I think he is intelligent, funny, and very articulate. I really enjoyed reading this book about his life, which involved more challenges than I could have imagined. There are a lot of lessons in this book, but one that I think is relevant right now is the lesson about the leadership of South Africa, and the beginnings of apartheid. How they sought to divide the country to make them easier to control. I'm sure I am not alone in recognizing the parallels with today's America. This year there have been so many stories splitting America into groups; by race, by religion, by political parties, by location, etc. I think we would do well to listen to history, and remember that we are all alike, and not hate based on our differences but try to work past them. Thank you Trevor for sharing this story, and for being a rational voice in the world.

Love this book! I don't usually read biographies or memoirs but I love Trevor Noah and wanted to see what he had to say because I love how he expresses himself as a comedian as well as hosting the The Daily Show on Comedy Central. 
 I can honestly say, I was not disappointed. I breezed through the book because it was such an easy read. It read like one of his comedy show. It had me laughing for the most part while other parts had me looking at the world from a different yet still relevant perspective. Each chapters of his books gives a little introduction with a little bit of nugget of truth and knowledge that is worth sharing as well helping us open our own eyes to what is happening in today's society. 
 This is a personal story about Noah's life and what he went through growing up in the tail end and post apartheid South Africa. 
 He's well spoken and humorous which made reading his book enjoyable. I will gladly recommend this book to anyone to read because it's great story telling with a purpose and as well as just a great way to past the time.

Read this & then tell me Trevor is just another opinionated know nothing comedian. His comedy is so good because he has lived through horrible human truths. This was a can't put down kinda read with great insights to our own country.
Such a genuine insight into the life of a mixed race child during the apartheid era. It reads how he writes, definitely enjoyable and evocative.
I love Trevor, his comedy talk show is very smart & funny, his background is very interesting, he has quite a world view from his experiences

Trevor Noah, do we need anymore reason to read the book. From the very start of this book, he gets your attention, the words starts talking to you. When you read the book you actually hear him in your head narrating his life story thats how good a storyteller he is.The story of a coloured kid being raised by a black woman in Africa during turbulent times. It's an adventurous, fun filled at the same time challenging life story of a mischievous(this would be an understatement) kid and his rebellious mother during apartheid.It is dramatic, inspiring ,emotional, thought provoking and hilarious all at the same time.Definitely worth a read.

My favorite memoir by far and I've read a few of them now. It's touching, entertaining, informative and educational, and most importantly it really feels like Trevor's true voice. And hey, Trevor is a gifted storyteller. 
 Exceeded my expectations. Really. I learned so much about South Africa, apartheid, and race relations. Thank you!
